HEADLINE: NYC;
The Seventies Give Nostalgia A Bad Name

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
OF all the decades to get nostalgic about, why the 1970's? You could pick a better era out of a hat.
How can anyone get misty over a decade that gave us Watergate, Kent State, gas lines, economic recession, double-digit inflation, soaring crime rates, Pol Pot, Son of Sam and American hostages in Iran -- not to mention leisure suits, men's ties wider than the Lincoln Tunnel, some of the worst hairstyles since scissors were invented and -- hold your angry letters -- disco? 
 Yet the 70's have slammed into our millennial consciousness with all the subtlety of Charles Bronson blasting his way through "Death Wish," that 1974 Hollywood vision of urban hell.
A stage version of "Saturday Night Fever" is playing on Broadway. Studio 54 is back from the dead. So are lava lamps and bell-bottoms. (Can fondue sets as wedding gifts be far behind?)
Recent movies have explored the 70's in ways satiric and straight. We have had "The Ice Storm," "Boogie Nights," "Summer of Sam," "Man on the Moon" and, for those who wish they still had Nixon to kick around, "Dick." Television has chimed in with "That 70's Show," a Fox sitcom.
Bill Bradley's presidential campaign trades on his fame from his championship seasons with the New York Knicks in the 70's. Even 70's crime is back, now that Michael C. Skakel has been charged in Connecticut with bludgeoning Martha Moxley to death 25 years ago.
Topping all that off -- the glitter ball above the dance floor, so to speak -- the New-York Historical Society opens an exhibition today on one of the lowest points in New York history: the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's, which almost tipped the city government into bankruptcy.
The three-month show at the society, on West 77th Street, includes photographs, posters and artifacts from those dark days. Not the least of them is a blowup of the front page of The Daily News from Oct. 30, 1975. Its headline remains one of the greats:
Ford to City:
Drop Dead
In fact, President Gerald R. Ford never quite said that. What he said was that he was prepared to veto any bill that included a federal bailout to keep New York from default. Pretty dry stuff. The News got to the point with more pop than a wad of bubble gum, so much so that millions thought the president had actually uttered those nasty words. Some believe the headline contributed to his political demise a year later, when the voters told him to drop dead.
All right, what gives? Why all this looking back?
"There's a spotlight always focused on the period that is 25 or 30 years before the present," said David Frum, who examines the 70's in a new book, "How We Got Here" (Basic Books). Many find it especially painless to return to the 70's, he suggested, because they now enjoy good times. "We went through a process and came out the other end, and it turned out O.K.," he said.
MR. FRUM, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, the conservative research center, is himself no 70's fan. To him, they were worse than the 60's in transforming America into a less responsible, more hedonistic, less law-abiding and more illiterate society. But he understands why young people may be fascinated with that era.
"If you're 20 now, you must feel like you live in a police state," he said. "The drinking age has been raised. It's harder to buy cigarettes. Drugs are treated savagely, and you're told sex will kill you. Abstinence is in. Schools have metal detectors. So they look back on that time as the golden age of teenage liberty."
For Betsy Gotbaum, president of the historical society, one reason for the fiscal-crisis show is the ticking clock. Those who helped rescue the city then are not exactly kids, including her husband, Victor Gotbaum, the labor leader. The former mayor, Edward I. Koch, she said, had proposed that "we do this while we're all still alive."
That sounds reasonable. Still, it means returning, if briefly, to a time when New York hit bottom -- to the brutal blackout of 1977, garbage strikes, exposes of systemic police corruption and the nightmarish Times Square of "Taxi Driver." Let's not even discuss the Bee Gees.
Those days were not all bad, said Kathleen Hulser, the exhibition's curator. Artists flourished in a city that was far more affordable, she pointed out. Also, Ms. Hulser said, "the 70's were when the idea of public and private partnerships took off."
Quite right. All in all, though, you get the feeling that nostalgia is not what it used to be.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: By Terence Neilan

 BODY:

THE AMERICAS
 
CANADA: RIGHTIST'S UNITY PLAN -- Canada's leading conservative politician, Preston Manning, embarks this week on a nationwide tour to unite the political right, bolstered by a 75 percent endorsement at the Reform Party convention for his plan to create a new national party, the Canadian Alliance. The Liberal Party has governed Canada on the federal level since 1993, largely because conservatives have been split along regional lines. James Brooke (NYT)
 
CANADA: ONTARIO GETS TOUGH -- Starting Monday, the police in Ontario, Canada's most populous province, can arrest people for aggressive begging and offering to clean windshields at traffic lights. In December, Ontario's Conservative-controlled legislature banned intimidating panhandling after complaints from the mayor of Toronto. It is now illegal to beg anywhere there is a "captive" audience -- at bank machines, bus stops, or in a line of vehicles stopped at a red light. James Brooke (NYT) 

MEXICO: SCHOOL STRIKE PROTESTED -- Several hundred law students opposed to a nine-month strike at the National Autonomous University of Mexico tried to get into the law school by tearing down barricades at the entrance, but were repelled by strikers with rocks and blows. Othon Perez Fernndez, a law professor who encouraged his students to charge the barricades, was knocked out by a rock and briefly hospitalized. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
ECUADOR: TEXACO RULING -- A Manhattan federal judge says he is leaning toward ruling that an environmental lawsuit against Texaco by Ecuadorean Indians should be tried in Ecuador, as Texaco prefers, rather than in the United States. But Judge Jed S. Rakoff, citing Ecuador's recent coup, asked the parties and the Ecuador government for more comment about whether Ecuador's courts "might reasonably be expected to exercise a modicum of independence and impartiality" if the suit was sent back there. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
CHINA: VATICAN TELLS OF INTIMIDATION -- Beijing has stepped up its intimidation campaign against Catholic clergy loyal to the Pope, the news agency of the Vatican's missionary wing reported. The agency, Fides, said church buildings had been destroyed and priests and bishops abducted in the last three years, including an 80-year-old bishop, James David Lin Xili, who has been missing from Shanghai since September. Beijing recognizes only the official, state-backed church. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)
 
CHINA: 2ND GROUP REPORTED CLOSED -- China has closed down 100 offices of a group with similarities to the banned Falung Gong spiritual movement after declaring it a cult, a rights group based in Hong Kong said. The Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said the police began the crackdown last November after President Jiang Zemin attacked the Zhong Gong group, which has more than 10 million practitioners. (Reuters)
 
PAKISTAN: CHALLENGE ADJOURNED -- A constitutional challenge to the army coup in October was adjourned until March 1 by the nation's new chief justice of the Supreme Court, Irshad Hassan Khan. The court's new leader was given the job after his predecessor, like several other judges, refused to take an oath of allegiance to the new military government. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
INDONESIA: SWISS AID SOUGHT ON SUHARTO -- Indonesia is preparing to ask Switzerland for new help in tracking down huge sums of money said to have been deposited in Swiss banks by former President Suharto, said the current president, Abdurrahim Wahid. Jarkarta said it is seeking the return of $9 billion thought to have been diverted to the accounts of Mr. Suharto, who has denied any wrongdoing. Mr. Suharto's successor, B. J. Habibie, made an initial request for legal help last June. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
EUROPE
 
FRANCE: TRUCKERS START PROTEST -- Three weeks after their bosses set up blockades to protest the government-imposed shorter workweek, truck drivers retaliated with blockages of their own. The drivers said concessions made by the government had robbed them of some of the main benefits that employees in other sectors would enjoy in the transition from a 39-hour to a 35-hour workweek. The protests, focused on blocking truckers from entering France, are expected to go on for two days. Suzanne Daley (NYT)
 
NETHERLANDS: BELGRADE LAWYER FINED -- Raising suspicions of Yugoslav meddling in its proceedings, a United Nations war crimes tribunal found a Belgrade lawyer in contempt of court for manipulating witnesses with bribes or other forms of persuasion in the murder trial of Dusan Tadic, a Bosnian Serb sentenced to 20 years in prison. Milan Vujin was fined about $7,000 and barred from appearing before the panel. The ruling lent credibility to allegations that Yugoslavia and Bosnian Serbs had tried to prevent the fingering of higher-ups. (AP)
 
BRITAIN: DOCTOR KILLED 15 WOMEN -- A general practitioner from near Manchester, Dr. Harold Shipman, was given 15 life sentences after he was found guilty of murdering 15 female patients, most of them elderly, with heroin injections. Prosecutors are considering bringing murder charges involving as many as 23 other patients who died in his care. Sarah Lyall (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
SOUTH AFRICA: UNIONS BEGIN PROTEST -- The Congress of South African Trade Unions began a three-month campaign of lunch and teatime demonstrations and worker forums to highlight the government's failure to create jobs. The campaign, which will not disrupt business for the time being, was kicked off by the South African Textile and Clothing Workers' Union and the National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa. Some estimates put unemployment as high as 40 percent. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)
 
ZAMBIA: DOCTORS END STRIKE -- Striking public hospital doctors returned to work after a court refused to grant an injunction ordering the government not to fire them. Calling their work stoppage a leave of absence, the senior doctors walked off the job in support of hundreds of striking junior doctors who were fired for protesting hospitals' poor working conditions and lack of drugs. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: TRIAL OF JEWS NEARS -- The trial of 13 Jews accused of espionage will begin in a few weeks, an Iranian radio report said. The decision to start the trial soon was made at a meeting of senior judicial officials led by the judiciary chief, Ayatollah Mahmoud Hashemi Shahroudi, Tehran's Radio Payam quoted a spokesman as saying. If convicted, the suspects could face the death penalty. (AP)
 
CYPRUS: TALKS WITH ANNAN BEGIN -- Leaders of the divided island began negotiating separately with Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations in an attempt to break a long-running impasse between Greece and Turkey. The two sides never met. First, the Greek Cypriot delegation trooped into the United Nations European headquarters in Geneva to meet with Mr. Annan. Then the Turkish Cypriot delegates arrived, led by Rauf Denktash, above. Mr. Annan said he thought a deal could be reached within the year. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

HEADLINE: Consumers Kept Spending In December

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Consumer spending rose in December at the fastest rate in four months, a sign that the economy may be picking up speed as it nears a record for the longest expansion in the nation's history.
Spending grew 0.8 percent in December after rising 0.7 percent in November, the Commerce Department said. That helped lift the increase for 1999 to a 10-year high of 6.9 percent, after a 5.9 percent gain during 1998. 
 "Spending growth has been strong and it looks to be strong unless the stock market comes unglued" or Federal Reserve policy makers continue to raise interest rates in multiple steps, said Greg Jones, chief economist at Briefing.com in Jackson, Wyo.
Incomes rose 0.3 percent in December after climbing 0.4 percent in November. For all of 1999, incomes rose 5.9 percent, the same as a year earlier.
A separate report by Chicago-area purchasing executives suggested that the regional manufacturing economy grew for the 12th consecutive month. While the January index issued by the Chicago affiliate of the National Association of Purchasing Management showed it slipped to 55.6 from 56 the month before, readings higher than 50 indicate businesses are expanding.
The reports give the last snapshots of the economy before Fed policy makers begin two days of meetings on Tuesday to determine how much to raise interest rates in an effort to cool the economy and keep inflation in check.
January is the 106th month of economic expansion, matching the record.
The report showed that last year's spending gains were led by a 7.7 percent increase in demand for nondurable goods like clothing or food. It was the largest yearly increase for that category since 1981.
In December, spending on non-durable goods rose 1.3 percent, the largest monthly gain since February 1994. Spending on durable goods like cars, computers and washing machines rose 0.8 percent in December after increasing 2.2 percent in November. For the year, spending on durable goods rose 8.6 percent, the same as in 1998.
The Commerce Department report also showed that the nation's savings rate fell to record lows for the month and for the year. The December savings rate of 1.5 percent was down from 2 percent in November. The annual savings rate declined to 2.4 percent, from 3.7 percent in 1998.
Signs point to continued increases in spending. Two consumer sentiment indexes rose to record highs this month, and jobs remained easy to find, recent reports showed.
Average hourly earnings rose 0.4 percent in December, more than the 0.1 percent increase in November. Average weekly earnings rose to $464.37 in December from $462.30 a month earlier.

HEADLINE: A Citizenship Incubator for Immigrant Latinos

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON PARK, Calif., Jan. 28

 BODY:
At one time, Pacific Boulevard was where the residents of this hip-pocket city in southeast of downtown Los Angeles came to realize their fondest middle-class desires. The boulevard was the apotheosis of the postwar California dream, an all-white working-class Beverly Hills with swank department stores, auto dealerships and first-run cinemas.
Jack Zagha recently sat in the home-furnishings store his family has run on Pacific Boulevard for nearly 50 years and recalled those days as so distant as to be almost an illusion, all but blotted out by memories of how white flight and indoor shopping malls later turned the once-vital street into a cliche of urban despair. Then he interrupted his reverie to exchange a few words in Spanish with a busy sales clerk and marvel at the new California dream taking shape around the racks of towels, curtains and bedspreads. 
 Today, thick crowds again stroll past his store, the Home Shop, but they rarely get past the maze of $2 and $5 tables clustered near the doors. The steady flow of sales is transacted almost entirely in cash. Conversations are in Spanish, still carrying the accents of the regions in Mexico from which most of Huntington Park's new residents emigrated.
"We're still in business, but just about everything else has changed," Mr. Zagha said. "Times aren't bad."
If there is a vantage from which to observe the concluding chapters of Los Angeles's transformation into the country's largest Hispanic-dominated metropolis, Huntington Park may be it. It provides a glimpse into the region's rapid ethnic makeover not because it is a reflection of the city as it will be, but because it is the gateway to that future.
Indeed, Huntington Park is not a perfect mirror of the Los Angeles region; incomes are generally lower and it is far more homogeneous -- it is close to 100 percent Hispanic -- than the diverse, increasingly affluent neighborhoods in the surrounding areas. But it plays a central role in the region because it is one of several neighborhoods where Mexican immigrants often come first, one of the places where they begin their pursuit of the dream that brought many here, a middle-class way of life. Huntington Park has become a sort of citizenship incubator.
And the impact is being felt. As of 1998, Los Angeles County had 9.6 million residents, of which 44 percent were Hispanic and 33.5 percent non-Hispanic white. Government experts predict that in 2010 the Hispanic population will make up slightly more than half of the expected population of 10.6 million.
"What you learn from looking at a place like Huntington Park, and I'm not sure people appreciate this, is how upwardly mobile most Latinos are," said Jack Kyser, the chief economist at the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit organization. "This city is where the newcomers learn how to do that. It is a stepping stone into the future of Los Angeles, and that's not something you would have expected if you looked at the city a couple of decades ago."
Jose Legaspi, a major real estate broker and developer in this part of Los Angeles, added: "This is a point of entry for the Latino population in Los Angeles, not a destination. This is where the education begins for a lot of people. Huntington Park has been where people aspiring to the middle class get a leg up."
Decades ago, Huntington Park thrived because it was the terminus of an electric streetcar line -- since shut down -- and had a wide downtown boulevard that attracted shoppers from all over the region. It was where people, many of them white immigrants from the Midwest, spent weekend afternoons.
It was, however, a residential oasis amid one of the most heavily industrialized areas of Los Angeles County. Just to the west was the Watts section of Los Angeles, which was traditionally a large, and largely poor black community resting, literally, on the other side of a double set of railroad tracks that for years defined the borders of ethnic peace.
Then 30 to 40 years ago Huntington Park went into a steep decline, a victim of industrial cutbacks, white families' nervously fleeing the proximity to a suddenly restive black community and the devastation on the boulevard caused by the emergence of indoor shopping malls. When the car dealerships left, the city's tax base went into a tailspin.
Tom Jackson, a resident for more than 40 years and a City Council member for 31 years, said that many white families left reluctantly but that when they did were often more inclined to find Hispanic home buyers, rather than black ones. "You're talking about 30,000 people who just pulled up and left," Mr. Jackson said. "It was a racism thing."
Huntington Park's subsequent phoenix-like rise has taken off with the soaring numbers of immigrants from Mexico. The city, which covers a little more than three square miles, saw its population swell to more than 70,000 people today from about 30,000 people two decades ago. It is perhaps 98 percent Latino. (Even nearby Watts is now dominated by Latinos, not blacks.)
The median age, which had risen to more than 60 in the 1970's, is now about 24, the city estimates. Reflecting its working-class status, the city's median household income is about $28,000 a year, below the county's average of $40,300. Its main elementary school and middle school each has more than 4,000 students. Pacific Boulevard It has become a cut-rate retail bazaar of shoe stores, dress shops, travel agencies, taquerias and dental clinics.
"The boulevard is back again, even better than it used to be," said Frank MacLean, the president of the local merchants association.
Elena Martin, who said she had been a resident for six years, was strolling with her three young children on Pacific Boulevard recently, looking at the ostrich-skin cowboy boots she said her husband coveted, but probably would not buy. She said she had little interest in malls, in part because she has to rely on public transit and in part because she did not feel at home at them.
Jacob Givertz, who has owned a clothing store, Buy Rite, on the boulevard since 1974, agreed that the immigrants had provided a solid new retail base. "I don't think the malls are competition for me," he said. "This boulevard reminds them of the way things were in the old country."
Rosario Marin, the city's mayor, said: "The people who move here are often new arrivals, but they really want to make it. Truthfully, they don't want to stay here. It's their first stop."
Still, Mayor Marin conceded, the city's transformation has also created enormous challenges.
Ms. Marin estimated that perhaps 40 percent of the population consisted of people who had lived in the country less than 10 years and that perhaps 20 percent were here illegally. That means that few vote, and many shield themselves from the authorities.
The number of new immigrants has also created enormous challenges for the city's schools. Ms. Marin said roughly 60 percent of the parents of the children in the city's schools read English at a level of third grade or lower.
"We've become a safe harbor for new immigrants, a place where they can come and feel at home right away," she said. "When it's time to move on, they move on, but I hope they remember Huntington Park and what they got from this place."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
1 Davos, 3 Seattles

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: DAVOS , Switzerland

 BODY:
Every year at the World Economic Forum there is a star or theme that stands out. The star of Davos 2000 was, without question, Seattle. Seattle was talked about everywhere. The only problem was that the business and government leaders here were actually talking about three different Seattles -- the Seattle that is afraid of the future, the Seattle that is demanding a slice of the future and the Seattle that is building the future.
All three were at play here, and it is important not to forget that, because there are some activists and politicians who want you to believe that there is only one Seattle that counts -- the Seattle of protesters against trade and globalization and the World Trade Organization, who trashed Seattle last November. Nonsense. 
 Yes, the Seattle of the backlash against globalization is real. This backlash was spearheaded, and financed, by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the steelworkers and dockworkers, who oppose more free trade because it means a churning of jobs. Alongside these unions in the streets of Seattle were many serious environmentalists, who are legitimately concerned about what more trade means for turtles and trees. But the environmentalists and the unions -- and the stone-throwing anarchists who joined them -- are not organic allies, with a shared agenda. (God save any turtle that gets in the way of the dockworkers unloading a boat. You wouldn't want to be that turtle.)
The unions that drove this first Seattle want you to think that they represent the world and the poor, and that they are all rising against free trade. Oh, really? Africa is begging to increase its textile exports to the U.S., and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is blocking the African trade initiative. Why? Because Africa might increase its share of total U.S. textile imports from its current level of 0.8 percent. The notion that this first Seattle represents all the downtrodden is a pure fraud.
Just ask the second Seattle. This was the Seattle of the populous developing countries -- India, Mexico, China -- who know that the reason they have all grown so fast lately is because of trade and foreign investment. They came to Seattle not to wreck the W.T.O. but to get a better deal from it, and they resent the protesters who want to keep them out by imposing impossible labor and environmental standards. Mexico's president, Ernesto Zedillo, denounced these "globophobics -- a curious alliance of forces from the extreme left, environmentalists and other self-appointed critics in a common endeavor to save the people of developing countries from development."
Egypt's economy minister, Youssef Boutros-Ghali, who was in Seattle, said: "The world was not represented on the streets of Seattle. The truth is, most of the world's population was inside the conference room in Seattle, not outside. It was developing countries, like us, who want a fairer share of the pie, not to destroy the pie. I can't grow unless I integrate with the global economy, but the trade rules by the developed countries are unfair. . . . We open to you, but you don't open to us."
The third Seattle was the Seattle of Amazon.com, Microsoft and the Internet revolution. This high-tech Seattle is creating an enormous number of jobs, and has captured the imagination of youth all over the world, but it has also terrified every C.E.O. Internet commerce has been described as "Darwinism on steroids." And John Chambers, head of Cisco Systems, unnerved a packed hall in Davos of business execs from Europe and the developing world by telling them that survival in such a world required radical restructuring and moving their companies online -- from customer service, to relations with suppliers, to in-house education. If you haven't started yet, said Mr. Chambers, it's probably too late. You're soon to be road kill. His speech was delivered at Net speed, and so convincingly that the moderator promised the wide-eyed audience to play back the tape of his lecture at half speed.
As I said, there are three Seattles -- those who want to slow down the world so they can get off, those who want to slow down the world so they can get on, and those who want to speed up the world so they can stay ahead. Can they live together? Only if there is real dialogue and hard trade-offs, and only if there is a recognition that the moral high ground isn't the monopoly of just one Seattle.

HEADLINE: Ads Lift Gannett Profit by 14%

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Gannett Company, the largest newspaper publisher in the United States, said here today that fourth-quarter profit increased 14 percent, spurred by more growth in advertising sales at USA Today.
Gannett, which also owns 21 television stations, said profit from continuing operations rose to $284 million, or $1.01 a share, from $248.9 million, or 89 cents, a year earlier. Revenue increased 13 percent, to $1.50 billion from $1.33 billion. 
 The gains stemmed mostly from USA Today, where ad revenue jumped 14 percent, driven by national ad sales. Revenue at Gannett's TV group rose 1.7 percent.
Income of $10.6 million, or 4 cents a share, from discontinued operations, resulted in net income of $294.6 million, or $1.05, in the latest quarter.
Gannett had been expected to earn $1 a share, according to the average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial.
Publishers like Gannett are profiting from a robust American economy, which is helping to finance new- media companies. These Internet companies, in turn, are promoting themselves with ads in print newspapers and other traditional media.
"As long as the stock market remains buoyant, I'd expect this kind of ad spending to flow through," said Mark Zadell, an analyst at Banc of America Securities, who recommends buying Gannett shares.
Gannett also benefited from an 8 percent decline in newsprint costs, typically a paper's second-largest expense after salaries. Newsprint prices fell an average of 12 percent in 1999. This year, Mr. Zadell said, prices are expected to rise about 6 percent, meaning that newspaper companies will face tougher financial comparisons.
Gannett shares rose 93.75 cents today, closing at $69.50. They are down 16.5 percent from a 12-month closing high of $83.25 on Dec. 28.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
2 U.S. Institutions Separated by an Uncommon Bond Policy

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
It is hard to believe that the United States Treasury would do anything to make Alan Greenspan's job of effecting monetary policy more difficult than it already is. But that is exactly what is happening today.
The Federal Reserve's policy makers are widely expected to vote to raise short- term interest rates at the end of their two-day meeting scheduled to begin in Washington today. But some of the tools that Mr. Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, has to cool the economy in coming months have been dulled considerably, thanks to the United States Treasury. As a result, the central banker may have to be even more aggressive in raising rates than planned. 
 Policy makers at the central bank are in a highly unusual situation today. The economy is strong by almost every measure and in recent weeks, some inflation indicators have begun to stir. So the Fed has tried to slow things a bit by raising short-term interest rates three times and signaling that further increases were likely.
Even as they have done so, yields on long-term bonds have fallen, the opposite of what normally happens in an escalating- rate environment. The move has created what is called an inverted yield curve, where long-term yields fall below those on short-term issues. Such an occurrence is atypical because investors who take on additional risk by investing in long-term bonds are typically paid more to do so than those who have taken on less risk by investing in shorter-term issues.
The 30-year bond yield has dropped from around 6.75 percent on Jan. 20 to 6.48 percent yesterday. At the same time, the yield on the two-year note has raced from 6.49 percent to 6.58 percent.
Behind this oddity is the Treasury's aggressive plan to reduce the nation's debt. Its two-pronged plan to cut back on issuing long-term debt and to buy back as much as $45 billion in long-term bonds has made institutions like insurance companies and pension funds stampede into the long end of the bond market buying anything they can. These companies need long-term bonds to offset their extended obligations; the perception that there is going to be a shortage of long-term United States Treasuries has brought these investors into the market with a vengeance, causing yields on long-term bonds to plunge.
What worries some bond market participants is that this plunge in yields will blunt the impact that the Fed's interest rate increases will have on the economy. By raising rates, the Fed hopes to curtail economic activity by making it more expensive to borrow. But with long-term rates so low, shrewd borrowers who might typically have tapped the short-term market for capital will simply issue long-term debt. Easy access to cheap, long-term debt will help to keep the economy hot, while the Fed wants it to cool.
"Raising the Fed funds rate has a much more powerful impact when the yield curve is steepening than when it is inverted," said Timothy Irwin, principal at Irwin Capital Management in New York. "And if it is the Treasury's actions that are causing the yield curve to invert, these actions are effectively making Greenspan's job more difficult."
Fed policy makers consider many things, of course, when they contemplate raising interest rates. They weigh economic data to analyze the strength of the nation's output and scour the numbers for evidence of inflation. But they also rely very heavily on the behavior of the bond market to assay whether credit is too easily available to companies issuing bonds or too tough to get.
The bond market's moves have become a more critical consideration for the Fed today than they had been to past central bankers. That's because while banks once extended most of the credit to issuers across the economy, now the capital markets are responsible for the bulk of it. In 1975, banks accounted for 55 percent of total credit extended across the economy while capital markets accounted for the rest. Now banks account for 30 percent, while the capital markets dominate.
So the Fed watches the bond market closely. In the late summer of 1998 as Russia defaulted on its debt, the bond market's seizures persuaded the Fed to cut rates aggressively.
Today, the inverted yield curve and the mixed signals that it is sending to the Fed are troubling. "It's a difficult situation because the Fed has relied more upon capital markets to determine how tight or tough credit terms are becoming," said David M. Jones of Aubrey Lanston & Company. "I would say anything north of 6.5 percent on Treasury yield might have a chance of slowing down the economy. Now suddenly we're back below 6.5 percent but you don't know what that means."
As long as the Treasury's buyback of debt continues to distort the bond market, the Fed will have to find other signals to monitor whether credit is too lax or too tight.
In addition to making current credit conditions more difficult for the Fed to measure, the recent behavior of long-term bond yields carries significant risk to financial institutions and consumers if it continues. Anyone with an adjustable-rate mortgage will suffer because short-term rates are high, for example. And banks, which borrow in short-term credit markets and lend for longer terms, will be badly hurt.
"The real risk in the marketplace is a massive inverted curve for a long time," said Stan Jonas of Fimat U.S.A., a brokerage firm in New York. By raising rates, he added, the Fed may invert the yield curve even further with short-term rates escalating while yields on longer-term issues continue to fall. "This would be good for pensioners, but bad for people with adjustable mortgages. And it would kill the banks."
And yet, many of the recent economic figures point to a growth rate in the United States that is much hotter than Mr. Greenspan would prefer. So short-term rates are expected to get a bump tomorrow, possible inverting the curve even more.
Nobody said being a central banker was easy.

HEADLINE: Study Documents Homelessness In American Children Each Year

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
About 1.35 million children in the United States -- nearly 2 percent of the nation's total -- are likely to become homeless at some point in the course of a year, a new analysis of national census and survey data being presented today has found.
The children are among an estimated 3.5 million people nationally who become homeless at least once in the course of a year, according to the analysis by the Urban institute, a Washington research group. The work was done by the team that prepared a recent federal report on homelessness released last month by the secretary of housing and urban development, Andrew M. Cuomo. 
 About 65 percent more Americans had an episode of homelessness annually in 1996, during a sustained economic boom, than in 1987, the institute found.
"Having been homeless as a child is a predictor of being homeless as an adult, so you're building the next generation here to an alarming extent," Martha Burt, director of social service research at the institute, said yesterday. She noted that nearly 10 percent of poor children annually experience homelessness.
In 1987, at the time of the previous national survey, Ms. Burt estimates that about 1.8 million people became homeless at some point in a year.
"The people who are doing well are pushing the price of housing up and taking over more space, and they're doing that all over the country," she said to explain the rise.
The national report found deep poverty and illness among the homeless served in shelters and soup kitchens, though almost half were in their first episode of homelessness.
The new projections are consistent with studies based on several years of complete, computerized shelter data in New York and Philadelphia, and with more recent data in eight other metropolitan areas.
Dennis P. Culhane, a professor of social welfare policy at the University of Pennsylvania, said shelter data show that 1 percent of the population in New York and Philadelphia uses a homeless shelter for some period each year, with the rate about 10 times higher among young poor children and highest among poor African American children under 5.
Most poor families, Professor Culhane added, are paying 60 percent and 70 percent of their income on rent, twice what it was 25 years ago.
Ms. Burt said the impact of homelessness may be longlasting. About 21 percent of homeless adults experienced homelessness as children.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CHALLENGER;
In the Final Round of Rallies, It's Bill Bradley, the Professor

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: HOLLIS, N.H., Jan. 31

 BODY:
Senator Paul Wellstone, a former college wrestler who knows a thing or two about cheerleading, got a crowd of nearly 1,000 Bill Bradley supporters here fired up this morning in his high-energy style, pumping his arms and screaming at the top of his lungs, "We're going to win in New Hampshire!" over and over again.
The crowd stood and cheered wildly. Then came Mr. Bradley. And for the next 25 minutes, he calmed them back down with a speech that was part lecture on the global economy and part sermon on human goodness. 
 So it went for Mr. Bradley today. On the eve of the New Hampshire primary, a time when presidential candidates typically dash from photo opportunity to photo opportunity, rallying crowds with thundering stemwinders, Mr. Bradley returned to the relaxed, soft-edged, professorial approach he perfected in front of small audiences months ago.
Yet if he was not always rousing on the day before the primary, Mr. Bradley was clearly connecting with many people in his audiences, all of which were large and enthusiastic. And it was precisely Mr. Bradley's unwillingness, or inability, to deliver a tub-thumping, end-of-the-campaign speech that made him seem appealing to many people.
"He's just straight, and that's what we like here," said Barbara Schwartz, 60, who came to hear Mr. Bradley at the high school here. "We're New Hampshirites. We don't like the rah-rah stuff."
The closest Mr. Bradley got to sounding like a conventional candidate on the brink of a critical election was during a late-afternoon speech before hundreds of charged-up campaign workers in Manchester. Yet even there, the most electrifying speeches were delivered by his surrogates, particularly Cornel West, the Harvard professor.
For much of the day, Mr. Bradley's style and speech were reminiscent of his campaign events of the fall. His voice rarely reached Wellstone-like decibels. His sentences rambled through thickets of complex clauses, only occasionally landing on punchy applause lines. He dwelt on spiritual issues as much as bread-and-butter ones. He seemed almost apologetic about asking for votes.
And after having spent nearly a week bashing his opponent, Vice President Al Gore, as dishonest, he barely mentioned Mr. Gore today.
Mr. Bradley had come under criticism recently for his new, more combative style. But his aides asserted that polls indicated that the attacks had been working and that Mr. Bradley had shifted tone today not because of concerns about alienating voters but because he wanted to finish with an uplifting message.
Indeed, there was inspirational oratory aplenty at every stop. "I want to be the president of the United States to use the power of that office to do good," he told the audience at Oracle, the software company.
After that speech, the audience gave Mr. Bradley a spirited ovation that lasted nearly a minute. But rather than basking in the applause, Mr. Bradley looked almost sheepish, stepping backward on the podium and then trying to quiet the crowd like a father with a noisy child, gently repeating, "O.K., O.K."
Yet it was Mr. Bradley's low-key approach that Roy Swonger, 35, an Oracle manager, found most attractive about the candidate. "There was no part in the speech when he was looking for applause," he said. "I'm happy to see that in a politician."
Never comfortable with the scripted gestures of campaigning, Mr. Bradley missed several photo opportunities today. In the morning, he bought a shovel in Concord and went to work clearing part of a walkway. The display seemed intended to demonstrate that Mr. Bradley, who occasionally suffers from an irregular heartbeat, is in good shape.
But few camera crews were around. Later, his bus stopped and an aide jumped off with the shovel. But Mr. Bradley never got off the bus. He was concerned, apparently, about getting to his next speech on time.

HEADLINE: Republicans Offer Tax Cut For Couples

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
House Republicans unveiled their own proposal today to give a tax cut to married couples, stepping up pressure on President Clinton and Democrats to agree to an election-year compromise on taxes.
The Republican plan, laid out by Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, was intended in part to reduce the so-called marriage penalty paid by many two-income couples and represented a counteroffer to a more narrowly drawn provision proposed last week by Mr. Clinton. 
 Mr. Archer said his plan, which would give a tax break to nearly all married couples, would be worth $182 billion over 10 years, more than four times as much as Mr. Clinton's plan.
The benefits of the Republican plan would go to couples across the income spectrum whether or not they pay a marriage penalty and would include couples where only one spouse worked.
The president's proposal, valued by the White House at $45 billion over 10 years, would limit benefits largely to two-income couples who claimed the standard deduction on their federal income taxes, nearly all of whom are in low-income and middle-income brackets and most of whom pay some marriage penalty.
Mr. Archer said his bill would be taken up by the Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday and would come to the floor for a vote by the full House in two weeks.
It is the first in a series of separate tax cuts, each with powerful constituencies, that the House leadership intends to bring up this year in a change of strategy from the last few years, when Republicans assembled catchall tax bills that the White House and Democrats cast as fiscally irresponsible.
"Fixing the marriage penalty would be the best Valentine's Day present we could give to millions of couples," Mr. Archer said today.
Democrats said Mr. Archer's approach was too expensive, and they criticized the Republicans for not seeking a bipartisan deal before moving ahead with their own bill.
Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, said the bulk of the tax relief under Mr. Archer's bill would go to the most affluent 25 percent of taxpayers. And he said the $180 billion cost of the tax cut would drain the projected federal budget surplus before Congress and the administration worked out plans to shore up Social Security and Medicare.
Republicans have long made reducing or eliminating the marriage penalty a goal of their tax-cutting efforts. The penalty mostly hits couples in which the two partners have similar incomes.
In some cases, the penalty arises when the combined income of the partners pushes them into an income tax bracket higher than they would be subject to if single and filing separately. In other cases, couples pay the penalty because the standard deduction for couples filing jointly is less than half the standard deduction for a single filer.
But not all couples pay a marriage penalty. Last year, of 51.4 million joint returns filed, 24.8 million, or 48 percent, paid a marriage penalty, according to a study by the Treasury Department. Another 21 million, or 41 percent -- mostly couples in which only one partner worked, or in which one partner made much more than the other -- actually got a marriage "bonus," meaning a lower tax bill than they would pay if single.
Mr. Archer's bill would raise the standard deduction for couples so that it is twice that for single taxpayers. Most high-income couples itemized deductions and would not benefit from that change. Mr. Clinton's proposal is built around a similar increase in the standard deduction.
But Mr. Archer also proposed to expand the 15 percent income tax bracket to higher income limits than under current law. Under his plan, the 15 percent bracket for married couples, which is adjusted for inflation each year and currently ends at $43,850 of taxable income, would rise gradually until 2008 when it would reach twice the level of single filers, currently $26,250.
Mr. Archer's plan would also increase by $2,000 the income level at which married couples lose the earned income tax credit, a cash payment made by the government to working families below and just above the poverty line.
Because of the way it is structured, Mr. Archer's plan would help all couples, not just those paying the marriage penalty, making his plan as much a broad-based tax cut for families as a marriage penalty bill.
"We're basically trying to help people also who are at home with a single earner," he said. "We certainly should be encouraging that homemaker who stays at home and takes care of the children."
The bill would provide no tax cut for single people.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Baseball Suspends Rocker Till May for Comments

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Commissioner Bud Selig, saying John Rocker had dishonored Major League Baseball by disparaging many groups of society with his harsh comments in a magazine interview, suspended the Atlanta Braves' No. 1 relief pitcher yesterday for 73 days, marking the first time a baseball player has been disciplined for speech.
The players' union said that it would file a grievance challenging the suspension and suggested that the disciplinary action was a public relations move. 
 Selig said that Rocker could not participate in spring training with the Braves, a 45-day period, and could not play during the first 28 days of the season. The commissioner also fined Rocker, a 25-year-old Georgian, $20,000 and ordered him to undergo sensitivity training.
Under baseball practice, Rocker will not lose any of his salary while he is suspended. He has yet to sign his contract for 2000.
"Major League Baseball takes seriously its role as an American institution and the important social responsibility that goes with it," Selig said in a statement. "We will not dodge our responsibility. Mr. Rocker should understand that his remarks offended practically every element of society and brought dishonor to himself, the Atlanta Braves and Major League Baseball."
Rocker, who initially gained notoriety by lashing out at Mets fans during the National League Championship Series last October, expanded his target group in a Sports Illustrated article in December. He disparaged an assortment of foreign people -- "I'm not a very big fan of foreigners," he said, adding, "How the hell did they get in this country?"-- as well as gays and others. He also called a black teammate "a fat monkey."
Talking about playing for a New York team, he said: "Imagine having to take the 7 train to the ballpark, looking like you're riding through Beirut next to some kid with purple hair next to some queer with AIDS right next to some dude who just got out of jail for the fourth time right next to some 20-year-old mom with four kids. It's depressing."
When Marge Schott was the owner of the Cincinnati Reds in the 1990's, she was suspended more than once for her public statements on blacks and Jews, but no player whom anyone could remember was ever disciplined for his public comments. Players have been suspended for drug use, and Denny McLain, a well-known pitcher for the Detroit Tigers, was suspended for the first half of the 1970 season for his relationship with gamblers.
Rocker will not be permitted to begin formal preparation for the season until April 3, when, he was informed, he can participate in extended spring training and/or minor league activities. He cannot play for the Braves until May 1.
"I do not believe it is appropriate that I should be harshly disciplined for my misguided speech unaccompanied by any conduct on my part," Rocker said in a statement released by his agents. "I have previously apologized for my unfortunate remarks and stand by my apology."
Rocker had previously been ordered to undergo psychological evaluation under baseball's employee assistance plan. The announcement yesterday said he had completed that evaluation but did not provide further information.
Rocker's remarks triggered an outcry from the Atlanta community, as well as from Braves officials and players.
As unpopular as Rocker's comments were, even with his own teammates, the magnitude of the penalty is prompting the players association to challenge it, Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said. A grievance would be heard by Shaym Das, baseball's arbitrator.
"It seems fairly obvious to me," Orza said, "that they imposed this penalty in almost defiance of but certainly with an eye toward the arbitration process. You wash your hands of it and let others worry about the propriety of what you've done. I just don't think they're going to fool anyone with what they're trying to do here."
While acknowledging that the Constitution's freedom of speech provisions do not relate to private industry as they do to governmental action, Orza said: "Speech which harms the business is subject to discipline. The question is whether the harm is real or just a function of the belief. You have to actually demonstrate the harm. Even assuming that, the magnitude of the penalty has to be taken into account."
The Braves were quick to link Rocker's remarks to potential economic harm. "It has been a very difficult time for the Braves' front office," Stan Kasten, the club's president, said at a news conference in Atlanta. Saying the Rocker issue generated the most calls and mail he could recall on a single issue, he added: "It has been difficult for us businesswise because all of these people had strong feelings. It's been difficult for the sales department, the promotions department, the community relations department."
John Schuerholz, the team's general manager, said Braves players had expressed the view that if Rocker were "suspended, punished in some way, probably fined for his comments, they would be willing to give him a second chance as a teammate. They would be willing to see him get a chance to redeem himself."
One of the first players who criticized Rocker publicly was Tom Glavine, an Atlanta pitcher, who is the union's National League player representative. He might have been one of the people Orza had in mind when he said, "Even the people who are offended by what Rocker said should see the stakes in this."
"All players," Orza added, "who work in an industry that encourages them and sometimes insists that they talk to the press have a stake at not being penalized for pure speech unaccompanied by bad conduct, particularly when the penalty for that pure speech is as enormous as this one has been."
The suspension, Orza said, is longer than that imposed on some players who were found to have been drug users.

HEADLINE: The Silicon Godfather;
The Man Behind Taiwan's Rise in the Chip Industry

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HSINCHU, Taiwan

 BODY:
The assembly lines at the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation were running full tilt after midnight last Sept. 21, when the floor began to heave. A huge earthquake had struck central Taiwan 60 miles south of here. But for the luck of geography, this futuristic technology park could have resembled a scene from the most expensive disaster movie ever made.
Although the quake cut off power and jostled the company's delicate silicon wafers -- ruining 28,000 of them -- it did little structural damage to Taiwan Semiconductor's five factories. The main problem was lack of electricity, which left Taiwan's largest chip maker becalmed when worldwide demand for its semiconductors was running at a fever pitch. 
 For Morris Chang, the founder and chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor, the solution was obvious: he placed a call to Taiwan's prime minister, Vincent Siew, requesting power be restored. Within three days the lights started coming on, and less than 10 days later, Taiwan Semiconductor's factories were humming at 95 percent capacity.
Taiwan's earthquake was a jolting reminder to the computer industry of its reliance on this island nation. Leading American manufacturers like Dell Computer, Compaq Computer and Hewlett-Packard blamed quake-related shortages for depressing third-quarter earnings.
No company better symbolizes Taiwan's role as quartermaster to the world computer industry than does Taiwan Semiconductor. And few have had more to do with putting Taiwan there than has Mr. Chang. At 68, this mainland Chinese-born, American-educated executive is one of the titans of Taiwan industry.
"People call Morris Chang the godfather of high technology in Taiwan," said Benny T. Hu, the president of the China Development Industrial Bank. "He created the semiconductor industry here."
Mr. Hu's kind words come as no surprise, given that he is also vice chairman of Worldwide Semiconductor Manufacturing, Taiwan's third-largest chip maker, which Mr. Chang agreed to buy last month in a stock deal worth at least $5 billion. That was two weeks after Taiwan Semiconductor agreed to merge with TSMC-Acer Semiconductor Manufacturing, its joint venture with Acer.
In a single month of deal making, Mr. Chang expanded Taiwan Semiconductor's production capacity to 3.2 million silicon wafers a year from 2.8 million. That is still far short of demand, which Mr. Chang estimates will be more than 4 million wafers this year and 5.5 million in 2001.
"These last six months have really been the most painful in our company's life, because there were so many customers who depended on us," said Mr. Chang, a courtly, white-haired man who was born in the eastern Chinese province of Zhejiang, spent three decades as an executive in the United States, and came to Taiwan for the first time in 1985 to start a new career.
"The central part of our corporate culture is to give customers what they want," Mr. Chang said. "And we couldn't give them enough."
It is Mr. Chang's happy problem to be caught in one of the chip industry's periodic booms. After slumping for three years in the late 1990's, demand rebounded in the second half of 1999. That was because of the end of the Asian economic crisis and the proliferation of new digital devices -- from set-top boxes to cell phones.
 Analysts estimate worldwide demand for chips will grow 30 percent this year, while Taiwan Semiconductor's sales will double. The company reported 1999 earnings last week. Even with the week of lost production in September, sales rose 45.6 percent, to $2.43 billion, while net income jumped 60 percent, to $816 million. The company's shares, which trade here and in New York, have risen 80 percent since Dec. 17, giving it a market capitalization of $51 billion.
Taiwan Semiconductor is growing even faster than the rest of the industry because Mr. Chang has discovered its sweet spot. Rather than design and produce integrated circuits as do Intel, Motorola and I.B.M., Taiwan Semiconductor acts as a contractor, making chips based on the designs of its customers.
Mr. Chang's insight was to recognize that a growing number of small chip designers could not afford to build their own semiconductor factories. Known as fabs, these space-age complexes take at least 18 months to complete and cost from $1 billion to $2.5 billion, depending on the size.
"It's hard to justify that kind of capital expenditure," said Calvin Chang, a semiconductor analyst at Jardine Fleming in Taipei. "There aren't that many companies who can afford to build new fabs."
Even for full-service producers like Motorola or NEC, the cost of manufacturing a wide variety of chips in their own factories has become prohibitive. Increasingly, the semiconductor giants are farming out part of their work to contractors like Taiwan Semiconductor. Motorola has said it plans to contract 35 percent of its chip production to these so-called foundries by 2002.
At the moment, foundries produce roughly 15 percent of the total output of the $160 billion semiconductor industry. But by 2010, analysts say, they will produce half. Taiwan Semiconductor's share of the foundry market is 35 percent. Its main competitor, United Microelectronics, has a 30 percent share. It is also based in the teeming Hsinchu technology park. Together, these companies have made Taiwan a sort of country-for-hire to the semiconductor industry.
Mr. Chang's personal odyssey is a chapter in the story of Taiwan's emergence as a technology power. The son of a prosperous Chinese banker who fled the Communists in 1949, Mr. Chang was sent to the United States to be educated, first at Harvard and later at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
After earning his Ph.D. in electrical engineering from Stanford University, Mr. Chang joined Texas Instruments and ended up running its semiconductor division. He left in 1983 after a falling-out with his bosses and joined General Instruments, where he served a brief, disillusioning spell as president.
"I had enough money not to work for the rest of my life, and I had gotten a little weary of the corporate rat race," said Mr. Chang, who is an American citizen. "At that time, Taiwan beckoned."
The Taiwan government, eager to turn this island into a technology redoubt, initially recruited Mr. Chang to head an industrial research institute. But given his pedigree and experience, it was a matter of time before the government persuaded Mr. Chang to join Taiwan's drive into the semiconductor industry.
In 1987, the government staked him $100 million and took a 49 percent share in what would become Taiwan Semiconductor. That, along with $58 million from Philips, the Dutch electronics company, allowed Mr. Chang to set up shop. The government still owns 15 percent of the company, while Philips owns 26.7 percent.
Mr. Chang has cultivated ties with senior officials and financiers like Mr. Hu, who are close to the governing Nationalist Party. But he says he has no allegiance to the party and prefers to stay out of politics.
Mr. Chang's concept of the foundry was born of an appreciation of both the virtues and limitations of Taiwan. He said he believed the country had an advantage in making wafers -- likening Taiwan to Japan, which also excels at churning out high-quality chips. Both countries, he said, had plenty of highly trained, skilled line operators, technicians and production engineers.
Unlike Japan, however, which developed a design capability, Mr. Chang said he doubted Taiwan's ability to compete in the more rarefied business of designing integrated circuits.
"I don't think we have enough creativity," he said. "Our educational system is state-run. We are very successful at turning out engineers with basic skills, in fact better than the engineering graduates from U.S. universities. However, they are not as entrepreneurial and not as creative."
Taiwan has become a pace-setter, , cutting costs to the bone and turning its factories into supple operations capable of producing a range of chips in a single factory. At one of Taiwan Semiconductor's fabs in the Hsinchu Science Park, the manager pointed out a conveyor belt that rushed silently overhead.
The belt, he explained, was used to correct imbalances in the fab's two assembly lines. Wafers were shuttled from one line to the other to ensure that both were running at capacity. Movable racks in a glassed-in storage room held boxes of wafers bound for NEC, Motorola and a dozen other companies.
Still, Taiwan remains a minor player in the world of chip design, which is dominated by the United States and Japan. Even Mr. Chang's efforts to develop memory chips, which are less complex than logic chips, have come to naught. In 1994, he started Vanguard International Semiconductor, with the goal of producing dynamic random access memory, or D-RAM, chips without relying on foreign technology.
But after losing more than $200 million in 1998 and 1999 and failing to make a dent in the memory-chip market, Mr. Chang recently decided to scale back Vanguard's ambitions. Now, like Taiwan Semiconductor, it will turn out chips on a contract basis. Taiwan Semiconductor owns 25 percent of Vanguard, and analysts expect the two will be folded together.
"Vanguard has been a thorn in the foot of Taiwan Semiconductor," said Dan Heyler, a semiconductor analyst at Merrill Lynch in Taipei. "Investors have always wondered why T.S.M.C. spent as much time with Vanguard as it did."
For Mr. Chang, however, Vanguard was not merely about money. "Vanguard was going to be the second stage of creating a really powerful industry in Taiwan," he said wistfully. "It was sad."
Despite the setback, Mr. Chang said he was confident that Taiwan would retain its edge in the chip industry over emerging Asian rivals like Singapore and Malaysia. In addition to five working factories in Hsinchu, Taiwan Semiconductor is building new plants here and in southern Taiwan, as well as joint venture plants in Singapore and Washington State. One will produce wafers with diameters of 12 inchs, which hold far more chips than the traditional 8-inch wafers.
With a stake in the company that is worth nearly $250 million, Mr. Chang can afford to take the long view. A few years ago, he stepped back from the day-to-day management of Taiwan Semiconductor, freeing up time for a role he seems to relish: the elder statesman of industry, helping to propel his adopted country to the next rung on the technology ladder.
"I have been pushing for the need for innovation, for more creativity," he declared, with the confidence of a man who gets Taiwan's top leaders on the phone with little trouble. "We need to reform the educational system. It's very slow, but it's going to happen."

HEADLINE: With Fanfare and a Delay, Amtrak Unveils a Faster Train

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Amtrak unveiled new fully electrified train service between Boston and New York yesterday, but the day was marred by technical problems that seemed symbolic of the difficulties the company has faced in a $2.6 billion high-speed rail venture.
The improved service was the first step in a project to introduce 150-mile-an-hour trains that would reduce travel time to Boston to three hours from five and cut about 15 minutes off travel time to Washington. But yesterday, as Amtrak officials boasted about the superiority of the service, called Acela (pronounced ah-SELL-ah), mechanical problems delayed the first train. 
 As a news conference concluded in Boston about 9:30 a.m., engineers rushed to fix the problems that caused a 20-minute delay. The setback, which company officials blamed on an engine problem, did not seem to faze Amtrak officials.
"This is exciting," Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin said. "It is a passion I have" to build a national high-speed railroad system, "and within that system to build regional high-speed corridors, and the first step has got to be the Northeast," he said. "What this really means," headded, "is that we will be able to become really competitive with airlines."
The train, which left Boston at 9:51 a.m. and arrived at Pennsylvania Station in New York at 3:30 p.m., was delayed as officials stopped for news conferences in Connecticut and Rhode Island.
The service introduced yesterday, Acela Regional, shortens the trip between Boston and New York to about four hours. It was made possible by extending electricity along the entire corridor between the two cities; previously, electrified service ended at New Haven, where train crews switched to slower diesel trains.
A faster service, Acela Express, which would reduce the trip to just over three hours, has been delayed by problems with the manufacture of high-speed trains. Both yesterday's train and the express train had been scheduled to begin service in September, but Amtrak officials now say it is unclear when the contractor will deliver the express train.
The contractor, Alstom SA, a French company, is redesigning the express train's suspension after problems with wear on the wheels. That train, which is being tested in Pueblo, Colo., was delayed after the wheel problems made it difficult for the trains to make curves.
The delay has caused problems for Amtrak, which hopes to generate $180 million a year in profits from the new train service. Those profits are needed to help the railroad meet a cutoff in operating subsidies at the end of the 2002 fiscal year.
Amtrak officials said that the delays would not cause budget shortfalls because of a contingency plan and fines that could be assessed against the manufacturer.
Amtrak officials hope the express service will help cut into the airline business between Washington, Boston and New York. Amtrak now carries only about 15 percent of the combined air-rail traffic between Boston and New York.
Over the last decade, Amtrak replaced nearly a dozen bridges and installed 115 miles of electrified rail between South Station in Boston and New Haven. Much of this work was paid for by Congressional appropriations. Amtrak's president, George D. Warrington, said he hoped to see rail improvements and speedier trains, similar to the Acela, the name Amtrak invented by combining "acceleration" and "excellence," traveling soon to transportation hubs like Richmond, Va., Chicago and Atlanta.
Electrification of rail lines between New Haven and Boston was proposed in 1912, but never attempted by the private railroads that ran passenger services at the time. In the late 1970's the idea was revived, but stalled during the Reagan administration, which opposed more subsidies for Amtrak, officials said.
But in the early 1990's, a bipartisan coalition of business leaders, academics and environmental advocates won reluctant approval from the Bush administration, which helped secure funds for the electrification that was completed last year.
Electric trains cannot run all the way from Maine to Washington yet, officials said, because of a small section of track missing between two Boston stations.
James P. RePass, the president and chief executive of the National Corridors Initiative, an organization that has advocated for the improvements, said his group is lobbying for direct service from New York City to New Hampshire, Maine and Massachusetts.
Mr. Warrington, the Amtrak president, said he saw economic benefits for cities along the corridor. "We have turned the Northeast corridor into a powerhouse of an engine that will help power the economy in the region," he said.

European Union Threatens Isolation for Austria
The European Union warned that its 14 other members would diplomatically isolate Austria if its anti-immigrant Freedom Party led by Jorg Haider enters a coalition government. The statement said Austrian candidates for posts in international organizations would find no support, and Austrian ambassadors would only be received at a technical level. A1

Rocker Suspended for Remarks

As a result, the central banker may have to be even more aggressive in raising rates than planned. C1

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Curcic on His Way Back to Europe

BYLINE: By ALEX YANNIS 

 BODY:

METROSTARS
 The new regime of the MetroStars is apparently determined to renovate the struggling team more drastically than expected. People in Major League Soccer with knowledge of their plans said yesterday that the MetroStars have asked the league to find a team elsewhere for Sasa Curcic, whose tattoos and behavior make him the team's version of Dennis Rodman.
 The MetroStars contend that Curcic is more of a playmaker than a goal scorer, and a goal scorer is what they need to play alongside Henry Zambrano, their main striker. It appears that Hernan Medford, a Costa Rican playing for Leon in Mexico, may be the allocated foreigner the MetroStars will get in place of Curcic. 
 Curcic was in Europe yesterday when the MetroStars left for Florida to begin training for the coming season. People familiar with the team's plans said Curcic would be removed from the team's roster for salary cap purposes.
 Last Friday the club acquired 38-year-old Thomas Dooley. Dooley played for Columbus in M.L.S. and for the United States national team beginning in 1992 after it was discovered that his father was a United States Army veteran who married a German woman.
 The MetroStars have also changed their training plans. Instead of going to Brazil after returning from Florida on Feb. 19, they will go to Portugal for a week starting on Feb. 23.
 
FIFA
 Sepp Blatter, president of the sport's worldwide governing body, speaking on French television on Sunday, called for a worldwide annual break in December. Blatter said that FIFA would present its plan next month for a new, harmonized calendar that would take effect from 2004.
 "It is vital that soccer should stop for a month," Blatter said of the plan, which has been in the works for over year. Blatter also said that all club soccer would stop between June 15 and July 15 to allow national team competitions to take place. Blatter also reported that FIFA had dropped its restriction for games played on artificial turf, saying that even the World Cup could be played on the plastic grass.
 The FIFA president also repeated his support for African bids to stage the 2006 World Cup, which is being hotly pursued by England, Germany, South Africa, Brazil and Morocco.
 
GERMANY
 The crisis at Eintracht Frankfurt deepened yesterday after the resignation of Rolf Heller, the club president. The club is currently 17th in the 18-team Bundesliga, which will resume action Friday after its winter break.
 Eintracht faces crises both on and off the field. The club has debts of about $7 million that it must pay or have its license stripped by the German Football Association, which runs the Bundesliga.
 Heller, 56, was hailed as a savior when he arrived at Eintracht three years ago after the club's previous financial crisis when it was relegated to Second Division. Eintracht fired coach Jorg Berger two months ago and appointed the former German World Cup player Felix Magath in his place.
 Bayern Munich, which will be losing Lothar MatthAus to the MetroStars next month, is expected to extend the contracts of midfielders Thorsten Fink and Michael Tarnat, both members of the national team, who joined Bayern from Karlsruhe in 1997. Bayern is currently on top of the Bundesliga and a challenger for the title in the European Champions' League.
 
ITALY
 A second-minute penalty kick by Sinisa Mihajlovic of Yugolsavia sent Lazio to a 3-1 triumph over Bari that left the Roman team only a point behind league-leading Juventus. Juventus was held to a 1-1 deadlock at home by lowly Cagliari. Like Lazio, Juventus made a perfect start with a first-minute goal by Filippo Inzaghi but failed to capitalize and conceded a 13th-minute equaliz0er to Giovanni Sulcis.
 The Ukrainian Andrei Shevchenko scored a hat trick in seven minutes, his second hat trick of the season and league-leading 14th goal, in a A.C. Milan's 3-0 triumph at Perugia. The victory pushed defending champion A.C. Milan to third, tied with neighboring Inter Milan, whose challenge for the title was revived in a 2-1 triumph over A.S. Roma thanks to a superb goal by Roberto Baggio.
 
CORNER KICKS
 The United States federation will announce an agreement on a new contract with the women's national team at a news conference today in midtown Manhattan. ... A week after signing a $40 million deal with a cable company to have its games televised, Aston Villa of the English Premier League signed a $10 million sponsorship deal yesterday with the Italian sportwear company Diadora. ... England will meet Ukraine May 31 at Wembley Stadium in London in the first match between the two countries. ALEX YANNIS

HEADLINE: Suit Accuses Sony Music of Unfair Online Acts

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Sony Music Entertainment was sued by retailers who say the company illegally steers customers to its online stores by including hyperlinks on music compact discs.
The National Association of Recording Merchandisers filed suit today in federal court in Washington. The suit accuses Sony music of copyright misuse, false advertising, unfair competition and illegal price discrimination in favor of Sony's own record club and online retailer. 
 "This gets a lot of these issues into the court," said Paula Horovitz, president of the trade association, which represents more than 1,000 music retailers, wholesalers and distributors. "We hope we can get the ground rules laid out as we get into an Internet age."
A new generation of compact discs, called enhanced CD's, includes video images and interactive features that appear when played on a personal computer. Sony and its competitors typically include a hyperlink on these video images that connects Internet users to an online store.
The retailers say they are being forced, in effect, to direct their own customers to a competitor: Sony's retail operation.
While Sony is not the only company that engages in the practice, Ms. Horovitz said, it was singled out because of its "economic power." She said legal action against other music companies had not been ruled out.
Ms. Horovitz said the questions the lawsuit raises would become more important as such new technologies as DVD's and direct online downloads of digital-quality recordings increase their shares of the home entertainment market.

An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit filed by retailers against Sony Music Entertainment misstated the given name of the president of the National Association of Recording Merchandisers. She is Pamela Horovitz, not Paula.
