HEADLINE: Signs of Iraqi Arms Buildup Bedevil U.S. Administration

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Satellite photographs and American intelligence reports have shown that Iraq has in the last year rebuilt military and industrial sites damaged by American and British air strikes in late 1998, officials say.
The recent intelligence findings have raised concerns among Defense Department and other officials in the Clinton administration that in the prolonged absence of international weapons inspectors, whose job would be to search those structures, President Saddam Hussein's government has continued its pursuit of biological and chemical weapons. 
 Despite those concerns, the administration's policy has been allowed to drift, leaving the United States unable to force Iraq to accept a resumption of inspections even after resolving an impasse at the United Nations Security Council.
Iraq's refusal has now left the administration in a quandary over how to respond at a time when international support for its policy and for sanctions against Mr. Hussein is waning.
"There is concern in intelligence circles that he has begun to rebuild buildings that could enable him" to produce chemical or biological weapons, a senior administration official said. "He has had a lot of time to operate without inspections."
Although the intelligence reports have not provided concrete evidence that Iraq is producing chemical or biological weapons, the officials said, the reports have raised the possibility of renewed military confrontation, because the administration has repeatedly warned that any effort by Iraq to produce the weapons would prompt new American air strikes.
The concern has given urgency to the new inspection program created last month by the Security Council. But for the administration, the latest Iraqi defiance has been met with frustration, uncertainty over how to proceed and even fatigue.
In his State of the Union address on Thursday, Mr. Clinton devoted exactly six words to Iraq. The American representative to the United Nations, Richard C. Holbrooke, a diplomat noted for his tenacity, barely involved himself in the Security Council's negotiations over inspections, leaving them to his deputy, James B. Cunningham, who arrived in New York just last month.
Despite a policy of "containment," punctuated by American-led strikes in 1993, 1996 and 1998, Mr. Hussein remains as much a thorn as he was when Mr. Clinton took office. And Iraq's defiance comes in a year when any action by the administration would have political ramifications in the presidential campaign.
Nearly a year and a half after Iraq blocked the last team of United Nations inspectors, administration officials said that getting inspectors back into the country remained the best way to determine if Baghdad's weapons programs were continuing.
Last week, after months of diplomatic wrangling, the Security Council agreed to nominate Hans Blix of Sweden to lead a new inspection team in Iraq, having rejected a candidate supported by the United States, Rolf Ekeus, also of Sweden.
Russia and France vetoed Mr. Ekeus's nomination after consultations with Mr. Hussein's government, diplomatic officials said.
But while Iraq has been less hostile toward Mr. Blix, Iraqi officials have said they will not accept any resumption of international weapons inspections under the terms of the latest Security Council resolution.
Even if Mr. Hussein eventually relents and allows Mr. Blix's team to enter the country, it will take at least three or four months before inspectors can resume work inside Iraq. Administration officials expressed their concerns when asked to assess the state of Washington's policy toward Iraq. Some officials defended the administration's approach, but others, including Pentagon officials, criticized the policy out of concern that it has left the United States few viable options.
Thirteen months ago, the United States and Britain launched four nights of air and missile strikes to punish Mr. Hussein after he expelled the last team of weapons inspectors. At the time, senior commanders estimated that the operation had set back Iraq's ability to produce chemical or biological weapons -- and the missiles needed to launch them -- by one to two years. "We're marching toward that point" now, a senior military officer said.
Pentagon and other officials declined to discuss the recent intelligence findings in detail, but they said Iraq had rebuilt many of the 100 installations damaged or destroyed in the American and British raids in December 1998.
Of those targets, 12 were missile factories or industrial sites that commanders said were involved in Iraq's efforts to produce weapons of mass destruction. The officials said significant reconstruction had been seen at those sites, including Al Taji missile complex north of Baghdad.
In the wake of the diplomatic wrangling, administration officials defended their policy toward Iraq. They said they remained determined to contain Mr. Hussein militarily while maintaining the economic sanctions first imposed when Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990 and while supporting Iraqi opposition groups.
Officials emphasized that a new American attack did not appear imminent. They said they wanted to see if the new inspection program would eventually get off the ground before taking any action that could further erode international support for the American stance toward Iraq.
But the officials said there remained three "red lines" that the United States would not let the Iraqis cross: a threat against a neighboring country like Kuwait or Saudi Arabia, an attack on the Kurdish minority in northern Iraq or a reconstitution of nuclear, chemical or biological weapons programs.
Critics of Washington's handling of Iraq said the administration appeared to have no clear plan on how to force an end to Iraq's defiance. "There is no adult supervision of our policy," said Anthony H. Cordesman, a military analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.
And despite American efforts to unify Iraqi opposition groups, factions remain. The administration has provided only a small part of the $97 million that Congress authorized to support those bent on overthrowing Mr. Hussein's government.
Also, international sanctions are fraying. To win Russian and French support for the new weapons inspection program, the United States and Britain agreed to offer Iraq an opportunity to end the sanctions. Under the new Security Council resolution, the United Nations will suspend sanctions if Iraq cooperates with the new inspectors.
But one reason for the continued Iraqi defiance may be that the sanctions are already leaking. Iraq is allowed to export $10 billion a year to buy food and other essential goods, and while the proceeds are closely monitored by the United Nations, the Iraqis have been able to divert some of the money, administration officials said.
Mr. Hussein's government has also been able to earn millions of dollars in smuggling. Since August, Iraq has steadily increased illicit shipments of oil from the Shatt al Arab waterway, much of it flowing through an installation near the port of Basra that American warplanes attacked and damaged in 1998, the officials said.
Last month, Iraq's illicit trade reached the highest level since the Persian Gulf war. More than 130 ships, some of them Russian, left the port and skirted the Iranian coast, staying in Iran's territorial waters to evade American ships trying to intercept them. "The Iranians are at least tacitly involved in this," a senior administration official said.
In the same month, Navy warships boarded only 36 ships and seized only 4. According to American intelligence estimates, Iraq was able to smuggle out a record amount of 317,000 metric tons of oil, or more than 2.3 million barrels, in December alone. At today's price of about $27 a barrel, the shipments were worth more than $62 million.
A recent intelligence report concluded that the smuggling was undermining the sanctions. Pentagon and other administration officials say they increasingly worry that the proceeds may be intended to finance weapons programs.
But another senior Administration official said the amounts of illicit profit were not enough to allow Mr. Hussein to produce nuclear, chemical or biological weapons. "What's inside the buildings is much more expensive to put up than any walls and roofs," the official said.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 2, 2000, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about the Clinton administration's policy on Iraq misstated the circumstances under which international weapons inspectors left that country before American and British air strikes in December 1998. While Iraq had ceased cooperating with the inspectors, it did not expel them. The United Nations withdrew them before the air strikes began.
The article also referred incorrectly to the value of the oil Iraq is allowed to sell under a program monitored by the United Nations. There is no longer a limit. Although at one point the value was set at $5.2 billion for every six months, it is not now limited to $10 billion a year.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VOTERS;
Contented Electorate Is Also Happy With Campaign

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE and ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: PEPPERMINT CORNER, N.H., Jan. 31

 BODY:
Vivian Poirier, a 44-year-old massage therapist, smiled broadly today when asked at the post office in Portsmouth, on the eastern edge of the state, to judge how this year's primary campaign for president had been conducted. "There doesn't seem to be as much -- what's the word I'm looking for? -- viciousness," she responded. "They aren't as vicious, which is nice."
In Derry, to the southwest, Grant Benson, 71, a hardware store owner, said after years of being forced to chose the lesser of two evils, he has never been as pleased with the candidates this time. "I think it may even be better today than it was 30 years ago," he said. 
 And here in this tiny enclave farther south, Joanne Tramontozzi, 52, a sales clerk, said she could not remember as detailed -- if perhaps at times dry -- an examination of the issues by the candidates. "It's been a nicer campaign," she said. "They're sticking more to issues. In the past, it was all personal."
Indeed, in a marked break from the tenor of presidential campaigns over the past two decades, New Hampshirites -- in dozens of interviews across the state on the eve of the nation's first primary -- said today they were pleased with the choice of candidates and heartened by what they described as an unexpectedly uplifting discourse by candidates of both parties, at least until this past weekend, when Al Gore and Bill Bradley, the two Democrats, began squabbling.
They also described themselves as largely pleased with the state of the nation, and, most important, the economy, in a part of the United States that has long suffered. The almost single-minded focus on economic decline that for so long dominated interviews here with voters -- and shaped the appeals of presidential candidates from both parties -- has been replaced with a broad new set of issues, including health care, education and campaign finance reform.
The voters' comments came on a day when this tiny state's fascination with politics, as well as its arguably disproportionate influence on the presidential selection process, was on display.
Caravans of candidates barreled along the state's highways, while on street corners, young volunteers, many of them bused from New York and Boston, hoisted placards bearing the names of their candidates and waving to motorists driving by, some honking in support. And more than ever, voters here, voicing a parochial pride, said they were confident that this state serves a valuable role in inspecting, even educating, the Democrats and Republicans who have put themselves forward to be president of the United States.
"What do you people in New York City think? Those country bumpkins up there, right?" said Ernest Desjardins, a clinical neuropsychiatrist from Rye. "But in some ways, we make or break a candidate."
The upbeat politicking reflected a campaign season that voter after voter today described as "nice," and the candidates as "substantive." It offered a particularly striking contrast to presidential campaigns in the past decade, when voters, here and elsewhere, always seemed unhappy with the candidates before them -- and often blamed them for their own discontent.
An important reason for the collective smiles among the electorate here may be that voters also said they were not consumed by any single looming issue and were relatively pleased with their own lives. "There aren't any that stand out," said John Prendergast, 36, a landscaper from Portsmouth. "There's nothing broken specifically."
As a result, voters said, they were not searching for candidates eager to change things in Washington. "This is the most prosperity we've ever had," Dr. Desjardins said. "I don't think anyone is anxious to have any change. It would be nice to keep this going for a while."
Andy Bouley, 51, the owner of Shute's Corner Country Store near here, said that although he was concerned about the nation's health care system, he mostly wanted things to stay the way they are. Thus, he said, he is voting for Mr. Gore. "I'd like the economy to stay the way it is," he said. "I wouldn't want to gamble with it."
The issues raised by voters today reflected, for the most part, what is being discussed by candidates from both parties. "Campaign finance is a big one for me," said Jeff Burton, a 29-year-old computer programmer from Dover, and a supporter of Mr. Bradley. "There's too much money in the system."
Megan Hall, 21, a student at University of New Hampshire, said she was concerned about the viability of Social Security, a topic that has been debated by both Democrats and Republicans. "I want it to be there when I'm ready to retire," she said.
And then there is taxes: an evergreen issue here in New Hampshire. "The government takes too much from us," Ms. Hall, and her sister, Amanda, 20, joined her in chanting the second part of a common refrain in a state that is known for anti-tax sentiment.
Yet it was the tone of the debate that drew the most remarks from voters today.
"This is the cleanest campaign I can remember -- it has been nothing like in the past," said Kelly Taaffee, 42, a legal assistant as she chatted over lunch in Keene. "The candidates have stuck to the issues for the most part. It's been a gentleman's race so far -- really." A clerk at the camera store up the street, Robert Hale, 21, said: "In general, politics are too bitter. But all the candidates have handled themselves well this year. I'm happy to see it."
Michael Donah, 55, who is retired and lives in Portsmouth, said he watched both presidential debates, and was impressed by what he described as the candidates' demeanor and depth. "We have had some intelligent debates," he said. "The consistency of the debate was pretty good. I felt they were both civil. I felt they were both civil. We did not get into a contest of stupidity."
And among voters who expressed concern with the attacks that have marked the closing days of the campaign, the blame was mostly affixed to Mr. Bradley, who stepped up his attacks on the final weekend. "It does bother me that Bradley had started to become negative in the last few days," said Mary Ann Kristiansen, 36, and a Democrat who said she had been leaning toward voting for Mr. Bradley. "It only hurts the Democratic Party. I thought he'd stay away from it."
Unlike past years, voters offered relatively little criticism of other candidates in expressing their choice. Again and again, they said they would be satisfied with a number of choices. "McCain, Bradley and Gore -- they all would make good candidates," said Al Souma, 68, a local retired manufacturing manager.
Irving Sheppard, who was having breakfast at Mary Ann's Diner, said he was voting for Senator John McCain, but added: "I feel quite good about my candidate, and not that he's the best of a bad bunch."
Finally, as politicians in other states question New Hampshire's oversized influence in the political process, most voters said they were not about to abdicate their position -- and pointed to the events taking place outside their windows in explaining why.
"In the Washington area, you never see the candidates, you just get stuck in traffic behind them," said Mike Ward, 53, an administrator at Keene State College, who moved here from Virginia last year. "The access here is phenomenal."
"Live free or die," declared Charles Butterfield, 83, a retired postmaster who lives near here as he repeated the state slogan. "In New Hampshire, you don't push us around."
Brenda Canada, a violence mediator from Portsmouth, said: "We are an eclectic people. We are highly intelligent. We are highly educated."
For all their satisfaction over how the run-up to the primary has played out, many voters here said they were ready for it all to end on Tuesday.
"I like it -- as long as it doesn't go on too much longer," said Al Dimmock, 62, a retired truck driver from Derry. "After a while it gets pretty boring."
Ms. Tramontozzi said she was eager for the politicking to end. "It seems like the only thing you see on television is campaign, campaign, campaign," she said.
Doug Crooker, 54, a machinist who is on disability and lives near Peppermint Corner, said he had been besieged for weeks by mailings and telephone calls from campaigns. As a mail carrier tried to jam more literature into his mailbox this afternoon, Mr. Crooker, who was shoveling the snow from his sidewalk, waved him off: "No political mail. Please."
The mail carrier commiserated with an understanding chuckle. "I don't blame you," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
A Day's Surge in Shares Can't Erase a Weak Month

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks ended their first losing month since September with a rally yesterday, as investors bought beaten-down telecommunications and financial shares.
Investors are betting that after the Federal Reserve raises interest rates as expected this week, "they're probably going to be on hold for a while," said Mark Tincher, chief investment officer for stocks at Mitchell Hutchins Asset Management, which manages $65 billion. "Earnings growth still looks pretty good, and the market should be O.K." 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 34.30 points, or about 2.5 percent, to 1,394.46, as telecommunications stocks gained. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 201.66, or nearly 1.9 percent, to 10,940.53, led by American Express and J. P. Morgan. The Nasdaq composite index erased a 139-point loss, closing at 3,940.35, up 53.28, or almost 1.4 percent, as the shares of Qualcomm, the most-active issue, surged more than 15 percent.
The Nasdaq began its turnaround about 2:15 p.m. with a so-called short squeeze: investors who bet on short-term declines in stocks by selling borrowed shares were forced to buy back the shares when it became clear that stocks were not going to tumble further.
"If the market is going against you, you're going to scramble to cover," said Joseph Keating who oversees $6.5 billion at the Kent Funds in Grand Rapids, Mich.
The Nasdaq had plunged early, as investors unloaded shares on concern the Fed would increase interest rates more than expected in coming months, crimping corporate profit. The Federal Open Market Committee begins a two-day meeting today.
Financial stocks, which are normally hurt by higher interest rates, gained in part because they have lagged the rest of the market for most of the last year. J. P. Morgan, down almost 7.5 percent over 12 months, climbed 4 7/8, to 122 15/16.
American Express advanced 6 1/2, to 164 3/4. It has dropped 4 percent since reaching a high on Dec. 12.
Qualcomm climbed 16 3/4, to 127, paring the Nasdaq's loss, after the developer of digital mobile phone technology said it was very close to an agreement with China United Telecommunications, which could lead to widespread use of its products in China.
That gain helped trim Qualcomm's losses so far this year to 37 percent. Qualcomm was the S.& P. 500's biggest gainer in 1999, rising 27-fold.
Earlier, the Nasdaq had fallen more than 10 percent from its record, its second correction this month. The index lost more than 10 percent in intraday trading on Jan. 4-6, closing with a loss of just under 10 percent. It then rebounded to a record 4,235.40 on Jan. 21. The index has yet to close at 10 percent below a high this year.
For the month, the Nasdaq declined 3.17 percent, the S.& P. 500 fell 5.1 percent, and the Dow dropped 4.8 percent.

Treasury Rally Stalls
 
By Reuters
Long-term Treasury securities snapped a six-day rally and traded lower yesterday.
The Federal Reserve's policy-setting body meets for two days on today and tomorrow and is widely expected to raise its short-term federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.75 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 14/32, to 95 11/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, increased to 6.48 percent from 6.45 percent on Friday.

In the seven previous years with a January decline, the index ended the year below the January close. But in 18 of the 21 years that the index rose in January, it ended the year with a gain.

HEADLINE: Commuting Long Distances and Loving It

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Like millions of other Americans, Lillian and Philip Silver drive from their house in the suburbs on Monday mornings and head for work. But the similarity ends there.
A few minutes later, Mrs. Silver is dropped off at Greater Rochester International Airport, where she boards a USAirways jet to La Guardia Airport 250 miles away and then takes a $25 taxi ride to her job in Lincoln Center as director of development for the Metropolitan Opera. Time elapsed from door to door: almost three hours. For the rest of the week, though, Mrs. Silver can walk in a few minutes from Lincoln Center to the couple's Upper West Side apartment. 
 It will probably be a long time before commuting by jet becomes commonplace. But in today's booming economy, it is no longer an oddity. Mrs. Silver is one of about a dozen people who commute weekly by airliner from metropolitan Rochester, population one million, to New York City.
In other parts of the country, the trend is more pronounced. Consider those who commute to Silicon Valley, where the median home price is more than $400,000. Planes flying into San Jose, Calif., on Monday mornings are filled with workers who have spent weekends with their families in Arizona, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon and Utah where that kind of money can buy a mini-mansion or a small horse ranch.
Likewise, Friday afternoon and evening flights leaving Dallas, Houston and Austin, Tex., are full, as people leaving jobs in one of those cities fly to their homes in the suburbs of one of the other cities, a commuting style encouraged by the low-fare Southwest Airlines, which is based at Love Field in Dallas.
"Commuting by plane is not that unusual, I discovered," Mrs. Silver said. "The finance director at the Met commutes from Minneapolis. There are other people at Lincoln Center who commute from Florida and other places. People made me feel it was quite exotic at first, but I keep meeting more people who do it."
Mrs. Silver began commuting in 1987 when she left a marketing job at a Rochester steam utility, a far cry from her dream of finding a professional home in the art world, and enrolled in Columbia University's M.B.A. program.
"My husband would say, 'We have two children, and three are away at school,' " she said. When she graduated from Columbia, the business school asked her to stay on as director of corporate relations, "and it was too appealing not to accept," she said. She had worked her way up to the post of associate dean when the Metropolitan Opera hired her in 1997 to head its fund-raising operation. Her husband practices law in Rochester.
Though living alone for four or five days a week has its down side, it also has its rewards. Commuters can earn hundreds of thousands of frequent-flier miles annually, for example, and those who stick to one airline can get upgrades to first class on nearly every flight even while traveling on the cheapest advance-purchase fares.
Moreover, a spouse who makes a good salary in a high-cost metropolis like New York or San Francisco can afford a home and way of life in a midsize city hundreds of miles away that colleagues can only dream of, even after taking into account the cost of the travel and a small apartment.
The explanations for these highflying commutes range from careers that put spouses in different cities to the pull of living in a smaller community with good schools to the expectation (often misconceived) that a job in another city will last only a couple of years and is not worth a move.
For Kirk Sapa, who commutes to Manhattan for his job as executive vice president of United Way of Tri-State, and his wife, Dr. Sharon Center, who teaches veterinary medicine at Cornell University in Ithaca, the reason was professional fulfillment.
"We don't have children," Mr. Sapa said, "which makes this far more doable. And while others have a hard time comprehending it because they don't do it, the reality in this New York market is that I probably spend less time commuting than most people in the suburbs do." Mr. Sapa drives his pickup truck to the Ithaca Airport, flies a USAirways prop jet to La Guardia, takes an airport bus to the Marine Air Terminal and hops the water taxi to the United Way office on Wall Street. He spends evenings at an apartment the couple bought in Brooklyn Heights, a short subway ride from his office.
Some people with children find long-distance commuting not only doable, but also desirable. Two years ago Jim and Laura Plant moved their children Conner, now 7, and Delaney, 4, from a tract home on a cramped lot in Silicon Valley to a 5,000-square-foot manor on three acres in Salem, Ore. Since then, Mr. Plant, 39, has been driving an hour to Portland on Mondays to take the 10 a.m. Alaska Airlines 100-minute flight to San Jose, where he climbs into his Mercedes-Benz and drives to his job as communications director of ReplayTV, a maker of technology for recording television programs on a hard disk.
"In Oregon, you can buy a really nice home," Mr. Plant said. "Sure, my kids miss their dad, but I think they enjoy the quality of their life in Oregon. And Mom isn't working, while if we lived in Silicon Valley she probably she would be if we were going to maintain any lifestyle at all.
"People have a lot of different reactions to my commute, from 'I can understand why you are doing it,' to 'Gosh, I couldn't be away from my family for five days.' "
Like many people who commute to work by air, Mr. Plant has a job that involves a lot of travel. He was interviewed by telephone while in New Orleans on a business trip.
For workaholics, commuting by jet can be a convenient way to separate work and play. Consider Craig R. Barrett, the chief executive of the Intel Corporation, who for 11 years has been boarding planes in Arizona for the 600-mile trek to his job in Silicon Valley.
"While in Santa Clara, I can work 16 hours a day and not worry about being late getting home," Mr. Barrett, who works Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays in California, said in an e-mail interview. "I usually have dinner meetings the two nights I am away from home to maximize the use of my time."
His wife, Barbara, also travels on business, he said, so "a side benefit of all this is that we can often arrange our business travel to meet in interesting spots for a weekend away."
David Cay Johnston commutes weekly by jetliner to New York City from Rochester, where his wife, Jennifer Leonard, the president of the Rochester Area Community Foundation, and their daughters live.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk

HEADLINE: In a Changing City, New York Character

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
MANHATTAN has at least 30 shops that have a superb selection of cheeses. It has only one Di Palo's.
The store opened in 1910 in Little Italy as a latteria, selling only fresh cheese, milk and butter. Ninety years later it carries products from aged pecorino to dry-cured sausages, many found nowhere else in the city. Patrons brave long waits on weekends to compare the winter Parmigiano-Reggiano with the fall version; to see what makes the store's dried figs so different; to try a slice of the sopresatta and a hunk of the mozzarella warm from its water bath. 
 Di Palo's is just one of a handful of specialty markets in Manhattan that are still doing business the way they did when schmaltz herring and fresh mozzarella were sold out of barrels. Although they may lack the fame of a Zabar's or a Balducci's, these small culinary treasures do it the old way, specialists in a generalist's world.
I spent last week at five of these gems, soaking up the atmosphere and receiving a crash course in how to survive recessions, depressions, changing neighborhoods and demographics. In addition to Di Palo's, I explored Russ & Daughters, famous for schmaltz herring on the Lower East Side; William Poll, a fancy-food store for the Upper East Side carriage trade; Poseidon Bakery, making its own phyllo dough in what was once called Hell's Kitchen; and Faicco's, a Greenwich Village market that majors in pork.
All were opened by European immigrants who arrived around the turn of the last century. Their current owners, all descendants of the founders, take a hands-on approach. They choose employees who, like them, love to schmooze. They know most of their customers by name and are never stumped by their questions. They worked in the stores as children and have learned to change with the times and persevere.
Luigi Di Palo, better known as Lou, runs one of the oldest latterias in New York with his sister and brother. Di Palo's was opened by their great-grandfather, half a block from its present location at Grand and Mott Streets. Today it is one of the few Italian shops left in what is now an extension of Chinatown, and it even attracts Chinese shoppers for its sausages and hams, Mr. Di Palo said.
The 800-square-foot store is packed with hundreds and hundreds of Italian products, including more than 85 pecorino cheeses. It's easy to see why people come from long distances to wait their turn. The sights, the sounds, the aromas are transporting. Mr. Di Palo, 48, said the family strives to run the shop the way his grandparents did. "When people shopped in their store, it was like coming into their home," he said. "It was: 'Sit down. Have a glass of wine. Try this piece of cheese.' People can still taste anything they want in the store. The counters were deliberately made only waist high for closer contact with the customers."
RUSS & DAUGHTERS, on the Lower East Side, now sells cream cheese made from tofu, under a portrait of the founder, Joel Russ, who started his business with a horse and wagon, expanded to a pushcart and opened a store on Orchard Street in 1914. "My grandfather looks down at the tofu cream cheese, and I always think the picture is going to fall down," said Mark Federman, 54, a son of one of the three daughters in the store's name.
But adding more New Age products to its stock of smoked fish and chopped liver is one way the Jewish "appetizing" store has survived the ups and downs of East Houston Street. For years, the coin of that realm was drugs, not chopped herring. "I used to wonder what would die first, me or the store," said Mr. Federman, who came to help out in 1978, when his father was ill, and never returned to the world of high-powered litigators.
To change with the times, the mix of foods has been carefully altered to keep both the old loyalists and the new customers happy. Alongside the belly lox and pot cheese and the huge barrels of pickles, there are breakfast muffins, olive oils, imported cheeses, bagel bread pudding and that tofu cream cheese. The store has been artfully redone to retain its atmosphere. The display cases have that 1940's look, and while the linoleum is gone from the floor, the tiny hexagonal black and white tiles have the look of the 1920's, when the founder moved the store to this location.
Joel Russ brought in his three daughters because he had no sons, and it became a shtick, Mr. Federman said: "Three pretty young girls picking out herrings from the barrel and slicing lox."
His mother, Anne Federman, now retired, the youngest of the three girls, picks up the story from Florida, where she lives within minutes of her sisters: "My father had no patience," she said. "If a customer said a word to him that wasn't right, he would chase her out of the store. But we girls had patience."
AN unsuspecting shopper walking into William Poll on the Upper East Side would probably not have a clue that the store is 78 years old, that the food prepared fresh in the open kitchen had supplanted the old stock of milk and soda and S. S. Pierce products, the gold standard of canned goods until the 1950's.
The sleek and elegant shop, with gleaming brass chandeliers, was redone in the 1970's and still carries a few packaged goods for the convenience of shoppers. But most of the store has been turned over to refrigerator and freezer cases, which hold dishes made from the recipes of the matriarch, Christina Poll, 81, who came to work with her husband during World War II. It originated as a corner market opened by William Poll's brother a couple of blocks up Lexington Avenue (it moved in 1952) and found its silk-stocking niche.
The William Poll brief remains the same as it was nearly eight decades ago: to offer simple, straightforward, top-quality food to people who can afford $16-a-pound chicken salad. Shepherd's pie and baked potato chips and beef Wellington are all available; the shop carries a vast assortment of hors d'oeuvres made with the special Pollonaise sauce, a cream-based garlic mayonnaise that was devised by Mrs. Poll's husband, the late William Poll, a Greek immigrant. It will take orders for any of 185 main dishes; it sells seven different quiches, five souffles, three dozen sandwiches. A four-course catered dinner featuring rack of lamb is $45 to $60 a person.
"A lot of people go out to restaurants for trendy food," said Stanley Poll, a son of the founder, who runs the store with his brother James, 48. "But at home, it's back to basics. The only thing we don't do is sushi."
Today, much of the business is done with caterers and wholesalers and over the phone, but Mr. Poll said the store will always be there. "Not having customers in the store is like throwing away a franchise," he said.
William Poll is no longer just a neighborhood shop. The family says customers call from all over the country to order prepared dishes. "If we depended on shelf items, we'd be just another me-too," said Stanley Poll.
James Poll, who was a filmmaker, came back to the business four years ago. "It's in the blood," he said. "We know everyone's name. We know what they want."
POSEIDON BAKERY has been on Ninth Avenue between 44th and 45th Streets since 1952, and certainly the interior does not seem to have changed much in the interim -- the display cases and the faded blue and white paint could stand a little sprucing up. But Poseidon has a timeless appeal: it is the only Greek pastry shop in New York where the phyllo dough is still made by hand.
At least four days a week, often more, the shop produces 50 to 60 pounds of the tissue-thin dough, the foundation of cheese and spinach pies and endless sweets. A simple mixture of flour and water, the dough is mixed and rolled and rested and stretched on huge tables over heavy muslin in the back of the shop. Then it rests again and dries and is finally cut, to be used for all the phyllo pastries and to sell in sheets.
The trick to making phyllo is to pull the dough until it is almost transparent without tearing it. Unlike machine-made dough, the handmade phyllo is "light, it has more elasticity, it's easier to handle, it stays moist longer and it has no additives," said Lili Fable, who owns the shop with her husband, Anthony, and has just turned it over to their 30-year-old son, Paul. The handmade phyllo sells for $5.50 a pound at Poseidon, compared with $3 a pound for machine-made dough.
Along with mastering phyllo, Paul Fable, who was in the restaurant business until October, will be learning the intricacies of Greek pastries: how to shape and bake the many-layered Greek sweets like baklava, and savories like cheese, spinach meat or vegetable turnovers.
Poseidon was opened by the elder Mr. Fable's mother and stepfather in 1923 on West 41st Street. Today the clientele for its phyllo has changed, the Fables say. There are fewer Greek customers, though they always show up on Greek holidays. Now, caterers and young Americans who have gone to cooking school make up the bulk of the retail business.
Since Ninth Avenue's fortunes have improved, Paul Fable plans to modernize Poseidon. At first he hopes to add a few chairs and tables and a coffee machine, but eventually he wants to branch out and sell to gourmet shops and restaurants and on the Internet. "My parents and grandparents always wanted to keep it small, but each generation is a little different," he said.
THE first thing you notice about Faicco's Pork Store on Bleecker Street is that it is spotless, not showing its 50-some years at all. Edward Faicco, representing the third generation to work in the family business, says he is almost as proud of that as he is of his vast assortment of Italian prepared foods.
The second thing you notice is the meat counter with butchers behind it waiting to cut exactly what you want. People come for a single sausage or five pounds, a single chop or enough to feed a large family. "In a supermarket, if you want to ask a question you have to walk down the aisles to find someone," Mr. Faicco said, "and then they don't answer you. I make everyone who works here prepare everything, so they know."
Faicco's was opened on Thompson Street in 1900 by Mr. Faicco's grandfather and moved to Bleecker Street in the 1940's. A Brooklyn outpost opened in the 1950's.
Until 20 years ago, Faicco's sold only pork, but little by little it filled its cases with other meats and poultry and its shelves with Italian products, from pasta to canned tomatoes. In the last 10 years it has added items like fried mozzarella sticks, fried ravioli, prosciutto balls and lasagna. But its fame still rests on pork, particularly the sausages it makes, both the dry types, prepared in the Brooklyn store, and the fresh, made right here several times a day.
At a time when specialty stores like Dean & DeLuca and Balducci's are increasingly faceless since the founders have sold out, these mom-and-pop stores still provide the authentic personality that always has appeal in an increasingly homogeneous world.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1648 words

HEADLINE: Management;
Creating Waves In Nonprofit Sea

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Several years ago, a success story at the John G. Shedd Aquarium in Chicago came perilously close to morphing into a public relations disaster.
Built in 1930, Shedd could handle up to 9,000 visitors a day. Then, in 1991, it opened an oceanarium that featured dolphin shows, drawing new visitors. But the oceanarium could accommodate only 7,500 people, and on busy days guards had to turn away hundreds of visitors, some of whom were angry after having driven for hours with their children to see the shows. 
 The overcrowding threatened to get worse if nothing was done before Shedd finished two exhibitions to reproduce the environments of the Amazon River and the Philippine coral reefs. Those additions will also have limited space.
For a solution, Shedd turned to one of the country's pre-eminent strategic consulting firms, Bain & Company, which charges corporate clients multimillion-dollar fees but like its competitors also does work free for nonprofits. Sure enough, by teasing out patterns in a sea of details the aquarium had compiled on visitors, from their ZIP codes to their ages and number of children, Bain came up with a plan to persuade local groups to visit on slow days.
Not so long ago, that achievement would have been soon forgotten, just another good deed by a consulting firm with corporate clients around the world who pay Bain an estimated $700 million annually for advice.
But now, because of a project that was nine years in the making and that was officially started four weeks ago, such sophisticated advice forms the backbone of a new initiative by Bain.
The initiative, the Bridge Group, has close ties to Bain but is a legally separate nonprofit organization. It has a staff of 12 of the best and brightest consultants from Bain's ranks who have committed themselves to stints at Bridge of six months to a year, even though they have to take pay cuts ranging from 80 percent for million-dollar-a-year Bain executives to 20 percent for junior consultants.
The Bridge Group is something entirely new in the world of big league business consulting -- a general-purpose strategic consulting firm that will help other nonprofit organizations for a fee.
Its aim is to complement the piecemeal, pro bono approach that Bain and others have long taken toward helping nonprofits solve management and logistical woes. The group will offer the consistent, sustained advice that has helped big business wring more profit out of each invested dollar. It will also enhance the quality of help now provided by a plethora of nonprofit consultants, ranging from one-person shops to niche agencies, mostly focused on fund-raising or management.
It is, Bain consultants believe, a long overdue step. After all, the United States has about 770,000 nonprofits, not counting religious organizations, which last year took in an estimated $750 billion in fees, grants, donations and investment earnings. But despite accounting for 8 percent of the economy, nonprofits get little attention in the business pages or from big consulting firms precisely because they are not in business to make investors rich.
Many nonprofit experts expect a wave of consolidation among nonprofits, just like the mergers that have swept through corporations over the last decade, as organizations seek the scale necessary for success in the 21st century. The creation of a strategic consulting firm for nonprofits is likely to encourage such a trend. For all its growth, however, the nonprofit sector is highly fragmented, with many organizations too small to accomplish much and many duplicating the works of other organizations.
"There simply is no force to push consolidations and to move organizations to an appropriate scale to fulfill their mission," said Thomas J. Tierney, Bain's worldwide managing director and father of the idea for the Bridge Group.
Moreover, about half the growth in nonprofit revenue in the last two decades came from fees charged for services that range from counseling troubled families to renting out space in churches to day-care providers. Donations accounted for only 8 percent of the growth.
Mr. Tierney's vision is not just to help individual nonprofits, but to build a storehouse of knowledge that can be applied to common problems among nonprofits in the same way that Bain can help a ketchup maker improve profits by reviewing work it did for mustard and pickle makers.
"Pro bono consulting for nonprofits often doesn't produce results because it is in and out," Mr. Tierney said. "They often have no follow-up because the ugly fact is that, ultimately, you get what you pay for."
Each project will include follow-up consultations so the insights that Bridge Group consultants develop do not gather dust on a shelf but are adopted and refined through practical experience.
The Bridge Group's consultants all have full access to the wealth of knowledge that Bain has stored in its Bain Virtual University, a database in which every corporate client's project is reduced to a case study, called a "knowledge module," so that the wheel does not get invented over and over again. This gathering and storing of information is a critical element in the efficiency and profitability of big consulting firms.
The Bridge Group, which has small offices in Boston and San Francisco, will charge fees that will generally be only about one-fifth what Bain charges for-profit corporate clients and in many cases will be paid by foundations, said Jeffrey L. Bradach, a former Harvard business professor who is the managing director of the Bridge Group.
This year, Bridge will handle perhaps 10 clients, one of them a major foundation that Mr. Bradach declined to identify. "The presenting problem was that they give away tens of millions of dollars a year but don't know what they really produce for that money," Mr. Bradach said.
The Bridge Group will analyze the donations, trying to show the foundation how to get results that further its agenda. That kind of insight into how grant-making can produce tangible results has been the Holy Grail of nonprofit evaluators. Mr. Bradach says his staff has the expertise to apply strategic consulting, over time, to improve the effect of grants.
The Bridge Group began with an idea sketched on the back of napkins at a Mexican restaurant in Silicon Valley. Mr. Tierney and Paul L. Carttar, another Bain consultant, were reviewing what they had learned from work for various charities in the San Francisco Bay Area, including the San Francisco United Way, and were bemoaning the lack of a vehicle to apply what they had learned to other nonprofits.
"Because these were pro bono projects there was no knowledge capture," Mr. Tierney said, using consultant jargon to explain that valuable insights were not reduced to case studies and stored for use by other consultants on future projects.
As the two men looked at the stack of napkins covered with notes, Mr. Tierney recalled, he told Mr. Carttar: "Gosh, there has got to be a way to do this in a sustainable manner."
Seven years later, when Mr. Tierney first sketched his idea for a reporter, it did not have a name. But soon two teams from Bain began working on the idea and, after 18 drafts of a business plan, they came up with a low-cost model built around highly motivated consultants working at low pay for fixed periods.
Bain made a $1.3 million grant for the project and then Mr. Tierney, Mr. Carttar and Mr. Bradach, the co-founders, went looking for outside financing, securing a total of $5.5 million from the Edna McConnell Clark, Rockefeller Brothers and Surdna foundations, all in New York, and the Irvine Foundation in San Francisco.
Edward Skloot, executive director of the Surdna Foundation, which has a $650 million endowment, said the Bridge Group was a critical step in improving nonprofit governance and management. "We see value in developing knowledge that can be shared" with other nonprofits, he said.
For Mr. Tierney, starting the Bridge Group is a chance to create a legacy in the world of big league consulting, an idea that could transform nonprofit management.
"If we can prove this model works, then someone else is going to do it and we want that," he said. "If one of the other big consulting firms doesn't do this in the next few years, it would be a mark against our idea."
The project has become his consuming passion. As he spoke, he took a sheet from a legal pad and, without pausing in his remarks, sketched a matrix comparing the Bridge Group model with the existing system under which firms and nonprofit consulting agencies both do cut-rate or free work for charities.
Soon, Mr. Tierney's jotting had grown into 28 boxes, an illustration of how consultants take reams of information that can easily overwhelm both corporate and nonprofit managers and reduce it to its basic components, then devise ways to deal with those components efficiently.
One question that Mr. Tierney and his co-founders say they repeatedly encountered as they sought financing was: What does Bain get out of this?
For one thing, its gets a relief valve for star consultants who might otherwise leave to become chief executives at corporations but now have the option of spending six months or more on socially redeeming work instead of helping condiment makers squeeze more profits out of their factories. Indeed, more than one-third of Bain's 2,400 full-time professionals have volunteered to work at the Bridge Group.
Only the best will get the chance, Mr. Tierney said, and they will "have to be very, very, very good."
So will the host of potential clients who have begun sending proposals to the Bridge Group, which when fully staffed will be able to handle about 40 a year. "We must be very careful about who are clients are," he said, "because as consultants you can't be any better than your client base."

HEADLINE: Talk by Putin Skips the War, But Albright Reminds Him

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 1

 BODY:
In a surprise appearance at a Middle East conference here, the acting president of Russia, Vladimir V. Putin, sat down two chairs away from the secretary of state, Madeleine K. Albright, and delivered his first foreign policy statement, which within 15 minutes delineated the differences between the two countries.
Yet in his brisk, businesslike summary of fairly standard points, Mr. Putin did not mention the war in Chechnya. Russia considers the war an internal affair, but Washington continues to press Moscow to negotiate a settlement to end it. 
 He did pointedly single out the "threat of the destruction of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty," a reference to the Clinton administration's desire to modify the major arms control treaty between the United States and Russia. And he referred to Russia's desire for an indivisible Europe, a rejoinder to Washington's expansion of NATO to include former Soviet satellite countries.
Then, Dr. Albright replied in kind.
Without using the word Chechnya, she said the progress toward a political solution in the Middle East should be used as an example for how to resolve the war in the republic.
"I believe our work here today is not only important for promoting peace in the Middle East, but should also be a model for all of us who seek to end difficult and painful conflicts," she said. "Conflicts within states, as well as those between states, threaten our common security."
She reminded Mr. Putin that the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, of which the United States and Russia are members, had recently assigned itself a role in resolving conflicts within countries.
After listening to Dr. Albright's rejoinder, Mr. Putin and the secretary of state shook hands, and Mr. Putin left the conference hall as quickly as he came.
Dr. Albright and Mr. Putin will meet on Wednesday at the Kremlin in a session that the Clinton administration hopes will give it its first close-up assessment of the man who replaced Boris N. Yeltsin.
As Dr. Albright prepared today for the Kremlin meeting, reports from Chechnya said that the rebels had left the capital, Grozny, presenting the secretary an opportunity to press her argument that the war had to be resolved through negotiation. One of Dr. Albright's senior aides said the secretary would use the "politically obvious" moment to argue again for a political resolution in Chechnya. Whether Mr. Putin, who has vowed to crush the separatist rebels, would heed the advice was another matter, the aide said.
The Clinton administration has been trying to forge a policy that expresses distaste for the methods the Russian military is using in Chechnya without so antagonizing Russia that relations are totally soured.
Dr. Albright said Moscow faced increasing isolation from other nations if it continued to shun negotiations over Chechnya. But there are also limits to the isolation that Washington wants to impose on Moscow as the administration tries to negotiate a new arms control agreement and engage Russia on other issues, including the Middle East.
The Middle East conference here, which was co-directed by Russia and the United States, was described by Dr. Albright as an example of the common ground that Washington and Moscow could forge. The gathering brought together the foreign ministers of most Middle East countries -- including Israel, although not Syria or Lebanon -- to discuss practical issues like refugees, water and economic development.
The conference was created at the Middle East peace conference in Madrid in 1991 as a permanent mechanism for dealing with matters that caused instability in the region. But the steering committee of the conference, consisting of foreign ministers, had not met since 1992, and lower-level officials had not met since 1996, when the peace effort between Israel and the Palestinians slowed down.
At the end of the gathering this afternoon, the foreign ministers announced that permanent committees had been formed on refugees, water, regional development and the environment, and that they would report back to the ministers in July.
A senior administration official said the discussion among the foreign ministers had been "practical rather than theoretical." He said many of the usual rhetorical flourishes had been dropped.
This was a sign, he said, that countries in the Middle East believed that the negotiations now under way between the Israelis and the Palestinians, and between the Israelis and the Syrians, were more likely to produce results than in the past.
At the very least, the official said, the conference and the continuation of its work "enhanced" the environment for the talks between the Israelis and the Palestinians and the Israelis and the Syrians.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Trillions and Trillions

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
An old classmate of mine, who went on to become a Latin American finance minister, once brought his technical experts to a meeting with a U.S. Treasury official. The official was furious. "Get your expletive numbers guys out of here," he yelled -- which was how the U.S.-educated technical team subsequently referred to themselves.
All of which is by way of apology for today's column, in which I am going to be, at least a bit, a numbers guy. But then my subject is a numbers issue: how big a tax cut can a presidential candidate responsibly offer? 
 Of course, it depends on what the candidate plans to do about spending. Big tax cuts won't break the budget if they go along with, say, significant reductions in Social Security and Medicare benefits. But the truth -- or at least the conventional wisdom -- is that post-Clintonian America has reached a sort of equilibrium, in which the median voter wants a government that is neither much bigger nor much smaller than it currently is. And assuming that it is a Bush-Gore election (despite last night's results), both candidates will at least pretend to respect that equilibrium. How much money does that leave on the table?
If you have been reading the headlines, you probably think that the answer is, quite a lot. After all, didn't the Congressional Budget Office just estimate that thanks to our booming economy the federal government will run a surplus over the next decade of $1.9 trillion? And doesn't this mean that the budget can easily accommodate even the $1.3 trillion in tax cuts being proposed by George W. Bush?
No. To see why, you have to look at the, um, numbers.
The key question is, What would it mean to keep the size of government about the same as it currently is? A reasonable man -- and Mr. Bush's economists are, as I said last week, reasonable men -- might guess that it means keeping "real discretionary spending per person" more or less constant. Note the modifiers. "Discretionary," meaning that nobody is proposing to scale back the big-ticket entitlement programs; "real," because if prices rise it costs more to provide the same services; "per person," because more people means more need for government services, which is why a populous state like -- to take a random example -- Texas has a bigger budget than its less populous neighbors.
Alas, that $1.9 trillion estimate was not based on anything like this reasonable notion. It was based on the assumption that total spending on discretionary programs will remain constant -- in ordinary, non-inflation-adjusted dollars -- for the next 10 years. Since the projection also assumes roughly 2 percent inflation, this means a large reduction in real spending. And since the population is going to grow over time, it means an even bigger cut in real spending per person. In other words, that big surplus number is based on the assumption of a drastic, even draconian reduction in government services.
As it happens, the C.B.O. also offered a more realistic projection based on the assumption that discretionary spending grows with inflation. That simple adjustment lops off more than a trillion dollars. But because the population is growing, that still means a substantial decline in per capita spending -- and since some programs cannot or will not be cut, it means deep cuts in what remains.
How much is really on the table? I've done my own back-of-the-spreadsheet calculation of how the C.B.O.'s surplus projection would change if real spending grew with population; the adjustment brings the total down to around $400 billion.
So how can those reasonable men advising George Bush think that he can offer $1.3 trillion in tax cuts? Assuming that they are neither planning to raid Social Security nor counting on favorable revenue surprises to save them (unfavorable surprises are, of course, out of the question), they must have in mind a sharp scaling back of government programs.
But that, of course, is not at all what the candidate's rhetoric suggests. He seems to be saying that he only wants to stop those Washington politicians from initiating grandiose new spending schemes. There is little hint that his "compassionate conservatism" can be financed only if the government sharply cuts back on what it is doing now.
If you ask me, it's time he had a little chat with his numbers guys.

LENGTH: 288 words

HEADLINE: A Wedge in the Cuban Embargo

 BODY:
Cubans have been told for many years that the decades-long American trade embargo against their country prevents them from buying even aspirin from their northern neighbor. President Fidel Castro has long used American restrictions on the sale of medicines and medical supplies to Cuba as an example of Washington's apparent inhumanity -- and a source of his own legitimacy. So last week's American health care exhibition in Havana raised eyebrows, if not actual sales. The exhibition was evidence of incremental changes in the embargo over the last few years that suggest the Clinton administration knows what ought to be done even as it avoids actually doing it.
Nearly 100 companies sent representatives to last week's exhibition, the first American trade show in Cuba since the embargo was imposed four decades ago. In turn, some 8,000 Cuban medical professionals got a look at everything from sophisticated surgical equipment to Pepto-Bismol. 
 Under the 1992 Cuban Democracy Act, medical supplies are technically eligible for sale to Cuba. But they are subject to a complex web of licensing and certification requirements that have made it all but impossible to make an actual sale. Over the last several years the Clinton administration has quietly eased some of these requirements. But significant obstacles remain -- not least the embargo's prohibition against direct banking relationships between the United States and Cuba.
The exhibition shows that American businesses are eager to open the Cuban market. The administration's policy of nibbling away at an obsolete embargo merely cedes a potentially lucrative market to foreign competitors. The time is long overdue for a bolder form of engagement.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Sprint Pays Top Dollar To Be Where It Wants

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
When new owners bought the 56,500-square-foot Gotham retail condominium at 86th Street and Third Avenue last August, they knew that the annual market rent for space on 86th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues was about $150 a square foot.
Four months later, the owners, a limited partnership led by Peter L. and Anthony E. Malkin, wound up leasing part of their condo -- a 3,173-square-foot store on that block -- to Sprint Spectrum, a division of the Sprint Corporation, at an average annual rent of $216 a square foot, more than 40 percent above market. 
 It is, real estate brokers said, a new high for retail rents on the block, at least in recent memory.
"It's a matter of supply and demand," said Fred C. Posniak, vice president of W & M Properties, the real estate management, marketing and acquisition arm of the Malkin family, which has commercial and residential operations in eight states. "Availability on that block has always been tight. You can't get space there. And Sprint very much wanted to be there. They were looking for a seven-day-a-week operation, which this is. It sits near two movie theaters, so they can have nighttime traffic if they want it."
Mr. Posniak said he had received initial offers for the space from other companies, including clothing and electronics chains, of $200 a square foot. "I showed Sprint the offers," he said, "and I told them: 'You want the space? You have to pay for it.' And there was no hesitation."
Eighty-sixth between Lexington and Third includes retailers like HMV (on the west side of Lexington), Petco, New York Sports Clubs, Steve Madden shoes, Foot Locker, Strawberry and the Children's Place. A new Wolf Camera is to open just west of Lexington. The area is considered prime, Mr. Posniak said, in part because of the heavy pedestrian traffic created by the No. 4, 5 and 6 subway stop at 86th and Lexington, the only subway lines on the Upper East Side.
Annual rents on 86th east of Third Avenue -- on blocks that include retailers like P. C. Richard, Barnes & Noble, Circuit City and Gateway Country -- drop to $100 or $110 a square foot, he said.
The Sprint space has a 60-foot storefront on 86th Street and 33-foot ceilings. The store is to sell cellular phones and equipment. Interior construction begins this month, Mr. Posniak said, with an opening scheduled for early spring.
Howard I. Gilbert of Robert K. Futterman & Associates, who represented Sprint Spectrum in the deal, said that in addition to the advantages and attributes of the block, the space itself satisfied Sprint's needs.
"Sprint had a requirement for column-free space with a lot of street frontage, at least 35 feet," Mr. Gilbert said. "I researched the Upper East Side, all the main shopping streets, and found that there were only three spaces in the district that filled both requirements. Coincidentally, all three were on the same block. And only one was available." The other two are occupied by Strawberry, just west of Sprint, and the Children's Place, to the east, he said.
So even though the rent is high, "we got very lucky," he said. "It's a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity."
The Gotham retail condominium has three retail spaces -- the Loews Orpheum multiplex and a Bombay Company branch, both on Third Avenue between 86th and 87th Streets, and the store that Sprint will be taking over, on the north side of 86th, which had been occupied by Aeropostale, a clothing retailer. It sits at the base of a development that includes 239 residential apartments.
The Malkin partnership bought the retail condominium for $17.12 million in an all-cash transaction from an investment group that included Zeckendorf Realty; Goldman, Sachs & Company and Starwood Capital. It was bought under tax-deferred exchange rules, using proceeds of recent sales, among them the sale of the 1.1-million-square-foot office building at 1185 Avenue of the Americas, at the southwest corner of 47th Street, to a group led by Goldman, Sachs for $195 million.
Section 1031 of the federal tax code allows taxes on capital gains for income-producing properties to be deferred if the gains are reinvested in similar replacement assets that are identified within 45 days and bought within 180 days of the earlier sale.
One reason for buying the retail condominium, Mr. Posniak said, was Upper East Side demographics: between the East River and Central Park, from 72nd to 96th Street, there are 48,000 households, with an average annual income of $175,000; 17 percent of the households have incomes in excess of $250,000, and half the population is between age 25 and 49, prime spending years. "Our other two tenants have long-term leases," he said, "so this new lease, with such a dramatic increase in rent, gives us an immediate upside."
Benjamin Fox of the New Spectrum Realty brokerage company said that while the $216-a-square-foot average annual rent was clearly a new high for the block, he felt it was probably an aberration.
"National chains that feel they must be between Lexington and Third clearly understand the economics," Mr. Fox said, "but they are quite mindful of their competition. And in many instances, having the right location, even at way above market rent, is preferable to having a secondary location at a lower rent, where the competitor has a primary location. In this day and age, with brand-name promotional retailing, having a secondary spot is a no-no."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Awaiting Fed Decision, Investors Lift Beaten-Down Shares

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks rose sharply yesterday as investors bought beaten-down shares of companies that had faltered during the latest debate over interest rates.
But as the Federal Reserve met in Washington, many investors remained concerned that a rate increase this week would be the first of several this year, making it difficult for companies to sustain the strong profit growth that has helped the market rebound from crushing losses last week. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 100.52 points, to 11,041.05, building on its 201-point gain on Monday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 14.82 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,409.28. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 111.63 points, or 2.8 percent, to 4,051.98.
After slumping in the morning, stocks rose on a growing sense that despite rising interest rates, which can cut into corporate profits, most companies would post strong earnings growth throughout the year.
"The earnings story continues to come in very strong across the board," said Chris Wolfe, equity market strategist at J. P. Morgan's private client group. The companies that comprise the S.& P. 500 have posted average profit growth of 20.9 percent for the fourth quarter of 1999, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Mr. Wolfe said strong earnings were helping to distract investors from concerns that interest rates were headed sharply higher in a continuing effort to slow the pace of the nation's economic growth. Yesterday, the economy set a record for the longest expansion ever -- 107 months.
The economy has defied many analysts' expectations by maintaining a torrid rate of growth without significant inflation. The Fed raised interest rates three times in 1999 to keep inflation under control, and many economists believe the central bank will continue to raise rates because of the economy's unprecedented growth.
The latest suggestion that higher rates are on the way came yesterday from the National Association of Purchasing Management, which said in its monthly survey that manufacturing activity was continuing to grow and the price of raw materials was rising.
Higher interest rates can hurt corporate profits by raising the cost of borrowing money.
"When interest rates are rising, you look to companies that are accelerating their sales growth enough to compensate," Mr. Wolfe said. "Last year, technology was the sector that was able to do that."
Technology stocks gained ground yesterday as investors bet that they could repeat their strong performance in 2000. Cisco Systems, Qualcomm and Amazon.com all rose.
Much of the buying came from bargain-hunting investors eager to buy well-known technology names after many stocks in the sector fell last week, said Richard A. Dickson, a technical analyst at Scott & Stringfellow Inc. in Richmond, Va.

Treasury Prices Increase
 By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose on expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates enough today and in coming months to cool economic growth and keep inflation in check.
"The bond market believes the Fed is going to keep raising rates," until there are signs of slowing growth, said Kent Gasaway, who helps manage $1.5 billion at Kornitzer Capital Management and Buffalo Funds in Shawnee Mission, Kan.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 23/32, to 96 2/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.42 percent from 6.48 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
CMS, a utility company formerly loved on Wall Street, cuts its dividend and faces disdain.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
HAVING almost gone broke in the 1980's back home in Michigan, CMS Energy -- the parent of Consumers' Power -- wowed Wall Street in the 1990's by going global and expanding into almost every part of the energy industry.
But that love affair appears to be over, or at least experiencing a crisis. Facing heavy debts and weaker profits from international operations than expected, CMS yesterday disclosed a financial restructuring plan. That plan will deeply cut dividend payments while raising cash by selling tracking stock tied to its old-fashioned utility business back in Michigan. 
 Investors reacted with anger, and the company's stock price fell to a four-year low as it dropped $6.50 a share, to $23.50 -- a figure that is less than half the peak reached in late 1998, when Wall Street was most impressed by the international diversification efforts.
What went wrong? Some things were beyond the company's control, most notably rising interest rates, which cut deep because much of the growth had been financed with borrowed money. But the company has also failed to produce the overseas profits it forecast, and it has zig-zagged regarding its financing strategy. Combined, the developments raise questions about management's ability to run, and to monitor, the vast operations it has acquired in recent years.
The biggest disappointment came from earnings that were far less than what the company had led Wall Street to expect. The company, which on Monday reported profits of $2.89 a share for 1999, had led analysts to expect about $3.30 in 2000. Now it is forecasting $2.50, before some special factors, a figure it forecasts will grow by 10 percent or more in 2001 and by 12 percent or more in 2002. The lower forecast reflects, among other things, reduced expectations for electricity plants in Argentina and Australia.
"We're very confident about our earnings forecasts going forward," said William T. McCormick, the company's chairman and chief executive, in a telephone interview. He voiced confidence that the stock would soon rebound.
In a conference call with analysts yesterday morning before trading began, Mr. McCormick said that he valued the local gas and electric utility in Michigan at about $25 a share, given the current share prices of other utilities.
If that analysis is correct, it would appear the rest of the company is now deemed to be worthless, with the stock priced at less than $25. Certainly the stock seems cheap, selling at less than 10 times the company's earnings forecast for this year.
In part, that appears to reflect a lack of confidence in the company's forecasts. Not only have earning forecasts come down, but just last fall the company was talking about selling enough assets to avoid having to issue more stock. Now it is planning to raise $600 million by selling tracking stock in the electric utility.
That stock would represent a 20 percent stake in the utility, and would be priced to produce a dividend yield of 6.5 percent to 7.5 percent, Mr. McCormick said. The annual dividend of regular CMS stock will be cut to 40 cents a share from $1.46. Investors interested in dividends will be given the opportunity to exchange CMS shares for the new utility tracking shares. Like other tracking shares, they would be designed to trade like common stock of the subsidiary, but would legally represent an ownership stake in the entire company.
Mr. McCormick had been hailed for rescuing CMS from the verge of bankruptcy after it built a $4 billion nuclear plant in Midland, Mich., that never opened. He managed to convert that to a gas congeneration plant and he expanded the company into fields like interstate gas pipelines and oil exploration. It now has operations in 21 countries, including India, Morocco, the United Arab Emirates and Brazil.
But along the way, the debt level -- already high as a result of the cost of building the nuclear plant -- rose as more acquisitions were made. Last year, the company delayed selling stock after spending $2.2 billion to buy gas pipelines from Duke Energy. That left it with an even heavier debt load as interest rates rose last year.
The new plan calls for the $600 million raised from selling the tracking stock to pay down debt. "That will permanently fix our balance sheet," Mr. McCormick said.
If Mr. McCormick's latest profit forecasts are accurate, then his forecast that the stock will rebound are likely to come true. But it may take some time for investors to regain their confidence in the company.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Extending A Hand, Not Cuffs

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
THE police here are facing the same happy fate befalling departments around the country -- only more so.
Reported crime dropped 23 percent last year, easily beating the national average, and since 1990 has fallen almost by half. Last year, Stamford had the lowest rate of violent crime in the region. 
 This has left Stamford with what generals call a "peace dividend." Officers have time on their hands, or more than they did in the days of crack and killing.
Many departments have adopted new police methods with crime rates plunging, but Stamford has taken big steps away from the headquarters-and-radio-car mode of policing. It has become a community policing theme park, featuring a medley of strategies, many used elsewhere, and linking with schools and agencies like probation and corrections departments to weave officers into the life of the city.
Stamford, like other cities, is redefining the job of a police officer.
The department runs a summer camp with local teenagers as paid counselors. Officers are assigned to high schools and middle schools, not for security, but to teach and listen. At night, they visit families whose children have missed school repeatedly. Another program links officers with young offenders to get them schooling and jobs before they go bad as adults. Officers working with psychologists and social workers counsel children who are the victims or witnesses of crime.
Trenda Palmer, the president of the residents' council at Southfield Village, a public housing development where relations with the police were once raw, said that she was heartened to see children in police cruisers last summer who were not being taken into custody, but to police-sponsored baseball games. "The kids are playing and the officers are coaching," Ms. Palmer said.
With the new relationships, she said, the police "don't have that animosity against us, right now."
Lt. Robert Temme, an admitted "adrenaline junkie," said officers have had to find fulfillment in doing more than chasing bad guys. With less crime, he said, "If you weren't doing this, sometimes you wouldn't be doing anything at all." He slowed his patrol car in Southfield Village, pointing to the location of a new police operation. "Down the end of the block we took over an apartment and give music lessons to kids," he said.
Dean M. Esserman, the police chief since early 1998, said all this serves the mission of keeping the peace in this economically diverse city of 111,000. There is a heavy emphasis on stopping crime at its prime source -- adolescence. "You don't say, 'I'm giving up my law enforcement role; I'm going to be a social worker,' " he said. "Why can't you do both?"
So far, vocal skeptics are rare. But Philip Russell, a lawyer for two men who are suing the department, claiming excessive force by officers, said the police had now become involved in "domestic and business squabbles." He wonders if some strategies are just designed to avoid trimming the force. "The Police Department is trying to insinuate itself into parts of life where they really have no business," he said.
Mayor Dannel P. Malloy said he hired Chief Esserman because they both saw community policing "not as a program, but as the only way to police." Chief Esserman, 42, who was never an officer, was a prosecutor in Brooklyn when he fell under the spell of William J. Bratton, the former New York City police commissioner. He became Mr. Bratton's general counsel at the New York Transit Police Department, then assistant police chief in New Haven and chief of the Metro-North police. He is following his mentor's playbook.
ARRIVING here, he signaled a change in the department's culture by halting a planned expansion of police headquarters. Instead, he divided the city into five districts, found donated space for substations, and put lieutenants in charge of each district. They are responsible for everything from fighting crime in their areas to recruiting citizen volunteers to help run the substations.
Chief Esserman is the first to admit there is still plenty to do. First, in a city where more than a third of residents are members of minority groups, only 36 of 313 officers are nonwhite.
Still, Charles G. Parks Jr., a lawyer and former president of the local N.A.A.C.P., said the biggest change was that "the police and the community they serve are not separate."
The test of that relationship will be how well Stamford, and cities making similar efforts, responds if crime rebounds. "It's the departments that capitalize on the drop," said Sgt. Ralph Romano, "that are going to benefit if things turn around."
