HEADLINE: Manufacturing Index Rises For 12th Consecutive Month

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The American industrial sector grew in January for the 12th consecutive month, though at a slightly slower pace than in December, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday in a report that raised inflation worries.
And the Commerce Department said yesterday that construction spending surged 2 percent in December, pushing the amount of money spent on building single-family homes to a monthly record. 
 The figures confirmed that the country's economic expansion, which entered its 107th month of growth yesterday to become the longest on record, was continuing.
But a worrying jump in the prices of raw materials in the purchasing managers' report, to the highest reading in nearly five years, suggested that Federal Reserve policy makers, who began a two-day meeting in Washington yesterday, had even more reason to raise interest rates to cool the economy and try to prevent a surge in inflation.
"The manufacturing sector appears to have momentum, but prices are rising to levels of concern, particularly with a new round of petroleum price increases," said Norbert J. Ore, head of the purchasing managers' business survey committee.
The data on prices and concern about the Fed meeting briefly sent stocks lower, but bargain hunters helped them bounce back. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 100.52 points, to 11,041.05. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 231/32, to 96 29/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.42 percent, from 6.48 percent on Monday.
The purchasing managers' group said its manufacturing index, based on a national survey of executives who buy raw materials and other supplies for industry, registered 56.3 percent in January, down slightly from a revised 56.8 percent in December. A reading of more than 50 percent indicates growth.
The figure for January was slightly stronger than the 56 percent reading that analysts had expected. The index is watched closely because it is the first national reading monthly on American industrial performance. The survey polls executives from more than 350 industrial companies in the United States.
The component of the index that measures the prices factories pay for raw materials soared in January to 72.6 percent from a revised 68.3 percent the month before. The reading was the highest since April 1995, when the price index hit 74.5 percent.
The group said that 17 of 20 industries indicated higher prices, a trend that has become more evident the last five months, with persistent price readings of 60 percent or more.
The Commerce Department said that construction spending rose to a record seasonally adjusted annual rate of $730.3 billion. That followed a revised 2 percent rise in November -- slightly less than the government had first estimated -- helped out by better-than-usual weather.
The December performance was much stronger than many analysts had expected. They were predicting that construction spending would fall by 0.3 percent in December. For the year, spending was up 6 percent, after rising 7.6 percent in 1998.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Job Cuts by Big French Auto Parts Maker Send Shares Lower

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Investors often reward companies that eliminate jobs and reorganize themselves to become more efficient. But shareholders in Valeo S.A. of France, one of Europe's largest automotive parts companies, sold heavily today on news that it would cut 6,000 jobs, or 12 percent of the total, in the next two years, and invest heavily in Latin America and Eastern Europe to shift its presence away from economically mature regions like North America and Western Europe.
By the end of trading here today, Valeo shares had fallen 9.9 percent, to 63.05 euros, or $61.34. The job reduction news was part of the company's announcement of 1999 annual results on Monday, after the stock market had closed. 
 Indeed at first glance, Valeo's earnings results looked strong. Profit increased 117 percent in 1999, to 563 million euros, on a 28 percent increase in revenue, to 7.7 billion euros. The company's chairman and chief executive, Noel Goutard, said Valeo would increase its dividend, which is paid in July, by 50 percent, to 1.5 euros.
But much of the profit gain was the result of a one-time increase from the sale of 50 percent of a German clutch maker, LuK G.m.b.H. Operating profit, on the other hand, rose only 14 percent to $472 million, despite the 28 percent revenue increase.
Moreover, problems nagging at Valeo's overall performance persisted in Latin America, where it generates only 3 percent of revenue; in parts of the electrical-equipment division, including the headlights unit; and in research and development, where costs rose 28 percent in 1999.
"The industry is seeing a lot of reorganization at the moment," said Jerry Raybold, an analyst with Credit Lyonnais Securities in London. Valeo, he said, "is still in the testing ground."
Yet the measures announced by Mr. Goutard, who steps down in May, are far-reaching.
In the United States, which accounts for roughly one-third of the company's revenue, job cuts involve reorganizing ITT Automotive, a maker of brake and electrical systems in Auburn Hills, Mich., which Valeo acquired in 1998 for $1.7 billion. In Germany, Valeo is investing $54 million to upgrade its electrical-equipment manufacturing. But the major task facing Mr. Goutard's successor, Andre Navarri, 47, a former executive of the Alstom electronics group, who became Valeo's chief operating officer last year, will be to push the company into regions of potential growth, like Asia and Eastern Europe, and to expand businesses that promise high returns, like electronic systems and Internet-based distribution systems.
The goal of pushing into Asia got a boost last year, after the French automaker Renault, a major Valeo customer, acquired a 37 percent stake in the Nissan Motor Company of Japan. Catching this upwind, Valeo bought a Japanese engine parts and electronic-systems specialist, the Unisia Jecs Corporation, and the Zexel Corporation, a Japanese manufacturer of fuel-injection and air-conditioning systems. Mr. Goutard has set his sights on a third Japanese acquisition, this time in the auto-electronics business.
To achieve its goals for new distribution methods, Valeo is setting up a $97 million investment fund to buy into start-up companies involved in automotive technology and Internet commerce.
Thus, some analysts think that investors punished Valeo too severely. Mr. Raybold of Credit Lyonnais says he expects the company to regain some of its value. "If you're selling now," he said, "you're selling too low."

HEADLINE: Computer Export Regulations Relaxed

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton eased some United States computer export controls today to relax what the White House called "unnecessary regulatory burdens" on the high-performance computer industry.
"This decision reflects my commitment to a control system that will enhance United States national security by implementing controls on computer exports that are effective and enforceable," Mr. Clinton said in a statement. 
 Bowing to the wishes of manufacturers, the administration relaxed a series of export limits. Unless Congress takes action to block the changes, most will take effect within about six months.
Mr. Clinton announced in an executive order that the United States would decontrol the export of all computers operating below 12,300 millions of theoretical operations per second, or M.T.O.P.S., to all countries except so-called rogue nations.
That would be a computer capable of 12.3 billion operations a second, several times as fast as ordinary desktop P.C.'s or laptops but in the range of computer servers used in offices or to host Web sites.
Companies exporting to "Tier III" countries (including China, Russia, India, Israel and Pakistan) will still have to notify the Commerce Department 10 days before the shipment of any computer performing above 12,500 M.T.O.P.S.
Exports to "Tier II" nations will also require licensing for computers operating above 30,000 M.T.O.P.S.
And exports to "Tier IV" countries (Iraq, Libya, North Korea, Cuba, Sudan and Syria) remain unchanged, meaning an embargo on those countries continues.

HEADLINE: Clinton Views Economy With Careful Pride and Calm Concern

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he was concerned about the nation's rapidly growing trade deficit and about the debt loads being carried by individuals and businesses, but he said his worry was tempered by the strength the economy derives from the federal budget surplus.
In an interview about the economy with three news organizations on the day that the current expansion became the longest on record, Mr. Clinton also gave credit to his Republican predecessors for their role in promoting growth, but said that his push to eliminate the federal budget deficit had been critical to creating today's prosperity. 
 During the half-hour interview in the Oval Office, arranged at the instigation of the White House, Mr. Clinton was expansive in discussing the roots of the long business expansion, the problems that face the economy and the sparring between the two parties over how to handle the growing federal budget surplus.
He brushed aside an aide's attempt to end the session to answer a question about Vice President Al Gore's role in setting the administration's economic policy, saying the more people know about Mr. Gore's involvement, "the more credit he'll get."
Asked whether he should get the credit for the expansion, which reached 107 months today, Mr. Clinton said it was "an American boom."
He ticked off factors including a general reorganization of the private sector starting during the 1980's, the dizzying advances in technology and the Federal Reserve's skillful conduct of monetary policy.
The Reagan and Bush administrations, he said, deserved credit for pushing a free-trade agenda. Doing so, he said, had forced American industry to become more competitive and by stimulating imports had acted as a "powerful brake on inflation."
But Mr. Clinton stressed the role played by his administration's efforts, starting in 1993, to reduce and then eventually eliminate the deficit. He said he had built on that achievement by further opening foreign markets, dealing with international financial crises and overhauling the laws governing fast-changing industries like telecommunications.
"All these things, even before they were actually felt, helped to create a mindset of confidence, which it seems to me is critical for keeping the recovery going on this long," Mr. Clinton said.
Asked what might endanger the expansion, Mr. Clinton talked about the trade deficit and what some economists say is a worrisome level of debt.
"It's highly unusual for a country to have a budget surplus as big as ours and a trade deficit this big," Mr. Clinton said. Based on figures for the first 11 months of the year, the trade deficit for 1999 is on course to reach $267 billion, about $100 billion more than 1998, which was itself a record year.
"So I worry a little bit about the impact of the trade deficit that big for a long time," Mr. Clinton said. "That's one of the reasons I hope we can get China into the W.T.O. and open that market more, because it's the biggest source of our troubles."
Mr. Clinton then talked about the risks inherent in individuals and businesses borrowing heavily in the belief that they can carry more debt in an era when the stock market is making the country feel wealthy.
"I'm concerned about that," Mr. Clinton said. "My concern is mitigated by the fact that the government is in surplus and we're paying down the debt and that lowers our risk a little bit -- quite a little bit."
Much of the money being borrowed by companies, Mr. Clinton added, "will have a growth component to it and will increase the long-term growth and stability of our economy" because it will go to investments in new equipment and technology.
But Mr. Clinton said he remained concerned about the nation's declining personal savings rate, which fell to 2.4 percent of disposable income in 1999 from 3.7 percent in 1998 and 8.7 percent in 1992.
"The one thing that no one seems to know how to fix in America is how we get the personal savings rate back up," Mr. Clinton said.
"If we can just keep moving in the right direction and realize that this is a potential danger out there," the president said, "I'm not as troubled by it as I would be if we were running a deficit or if all this money was for consumer spending or if we didn't have a better debt-to-wealth ratio than we do."
Mr. Clinton effectively confirmed that the administration is dropping any pretense of submitting a budget proposal to Congress for next year that sticks to the spending limits set out in the bipartisan 1997 balanced budget agreement.
Congress has broken the limits in all but the most technical sense for the last two years as surplus projections have increased, and the two parties seem increasingly likely to abandon the limits formally.
"I want to have fewer gimmicks in this budget than we had last year," Mr. Clinton said. "So what I tried to do is take the money they spent last time and make it the base line, and then assume a reasonable amount of inflation based on the spending patterns of the last five years or so."
The result, White House officials said, is likely to be a surplus projection by the administration that is lower than any of the three projections released last week by the Congressional Budget Office. The budget office said that under assumptions similar to those outlined today by Mr. Clinton, it expected the surplus over the next decade outside of Social Security to total $838 billion.
Asked about Republican tax-cutting plans like the one proposed by Gov. George W. Bush's presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton said they risked sending the nation back into an era of deficits or painful spending cuts. And even as he waited to hear the results of the voting in the New Hampshire primary, Mr. Clinton took the opportunity to bolster Mr. Gore's claim to having played a key role in formulating the administration's economic approach.
Mr. Gore, the president said, had been in favor of moving in the first term to reduce the budget deficit.
Mr. Clinton also said Mr. Gore had been a strong backer of stepping in to help Mexico deal with its financial crisis in 1995 even though it was politically unpopular at the time.
Asked why Mr. Gore had not received more credit for his role, Mr. Clinton replied, "I think maybe it's because people don't know, so maybe the more they know, the more credit he'll get."

HEADLINE: If Democracy Is Not Enough

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Long a trade bloc with vague pretentions to be something more, the European Union demonstrated its abrupt development into a serious political force when it demanded on Monday that Austria keep the party of Jorg Haider, a rightist politician, out of government.
"This is about Europe and its values," said Michael Steiner, the chief diplomatic adviser to the German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder. "We cannot have business as usual with an Austrian government that would allow the far right to be legitimized." 
 Although one basic value -- ending war on the Continent -- always lay behind the slow process of European integration, this blunt interference in a member country's national politics on essentially moral grounds amounted to a radical departure, suggestive of an embryonic European government.
Austria reacted with contempt to the European Union's warning on Monday that diplomatic ties with a rightist government in Vienna would be reduced to a "technical level."
Wolfgang Schussel, the leader of the conservative People's Party, who tonight formed a coalition government with Mr. Haider's Freedom Party, called the European initiative "a contradiction of the spirit of European treaties."
But in a reversal of the pattern that usually sees Europe following the United States on major diplomatic initiatives, the Clinton administration said today that it would "consider similar steps to those identified by the Europeans." This role reversal -- Europe leading Washington -- seems to sum up an important shift.
Throughout the 1990's, Europe's energy was focused on introducing a common currency, the euro. But with that project completed, and with the experience of going to war in Kosovo to combat brutality based on ethnic discrimination, Europe has awakened to its political, military and moral identity.
At the end of the bloodiest century in the Continent's history, the feeling is strong that a man like Mr. Haider, who has spoken with sympathy of Hitler and the Waffen SS -- however whimsically and with whatever subsequent regret -- should have no part in "the new Europe."
It is this newly discovered and powerful commitment to a Europe free of the ethnic hatred and prejudice that often distinguished the Continent in the past that appears to lie behind the vehement stand against Mr Haider.
At the same time, a shared currency and shared concerns about a possible rightward shift on the Continent driven by aging populations and high unemployment have clearly pushed European governments toward a more united and bolder stance than seemed possible until recently.
"From the euro, which removed the sovereignty of member states of the European Union in the financial area, we are moving swiftly to the reduction of sovereignty in the political field," said Dominique Moisi, a French foreign policy expert. "That is clear in the Haider initiative, made in Europe's name."
Of course, this emergence in outline of a supranational European state is alarming many people. Britain has resisted the euro precisely because of the implications for its sovereignty, and while supporting the European warning to Vienna, the government of Tony Blair said that "the domestic political situation is for the Austrians to resolve."
Jean-Marie Le Pen, the French far-right leader, put the problems of the European position as succinctly as anyone: "Mr. Haider democratically won almost 30 percent of the vote, and according to elementary rules of democracy, he should be able to take part in a coalition government."
Yet it is precisely in the name of "democratic values" that the European Union has intervened, with the broad support of the Continent's press and a seeming majority of its population.
"Europe has values -- democracy, the rejection of racism and totalitarianism, the respect of human rights," Massimo D'Alema, the Italian prime minister, said today. "These standards and values forge unity. If these are put in doubt, Europe has the right to state its views."
The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, expressed a similar idea, telling Parliament today, "The ideas of the Freedom Party are contradictory to the principles on which the European Union was founded."
Under its treaties, the European Union can suspend any member found to be "in serious and persistent breach" of fundamental principles. That is not the case in Austria, as the executive commission of the European Union conceded today. The warning issued on Monday was instead a coordinated measure among member governments. The decision was made because the political reality of Europe is such that the arrival of the Freedom Party in power is regarded with grave concern.
The Christian Democratic Union, the main conservative party of Europe's most powerful country, Germany, is in a state of severe disarray as a result of a fund-raising scandal, prompting fears that voters will migrate to rightist parties.
Senior officials say Germany began the push for a concerted European position on Saturday when Antonio Guterres, the Portuguese prime minister and current president of the European Union, lunched privately with Mr. Schroder in the chancellor's hometown, Hanover.
Mr. Schroder suggested to Mr. Guterres that the European Union could not be seen at this delicate moment to be opening the door to what one German official called "an extreme, right-wing, nationalist, intolerant and anti-immigrant party."
Its action contrasted with the European Union's silence when an Italian post-Fascist party, the National Alliance, entered the Italian government in 1994. Then, Europe's primary concern was still the economic integration symbolized by the euro.
A member of the National Alliance, Alessandra Mussolini, the granddaughter of the Duce, said today that the European initiative in Austria was unacceptable because it meant that "the outcome of a democratic vote is being trampled."
But Germany, with experience of the horrors that democracy can usher in, is in no mood to be swayed by such arguments. "If we make it clear that we want nothing to do with politicians like Mr. Haider, that is not interfering in another country's affairs," Mr. Schroder said today. "It is an expression that we stand for a Europe based on values and that Mr. Haider has constantly violated those values."
But the fact is that the European Union has "interfered" in Austria's affairs on the basis of the union's new political and moral pretentions rather than on any firm legal footing. That reality will not escape Austrians, who may now indignantly increase their support for Mr. Haider.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Law Firms Raise Salaries To Compete With Internet
Some of the nation's top law firms have raised salaries for associates by as much as 50 percent in the last week in a stark demonstration of both the lure and the power of Internet.
The move is the most recent part of a chain reaction that began last month in Silicon Valley, where firms have lost dozens of lawyers to dot-com start-ups, and is now spreading to the white-shoe firms of New York. At least one top New York firm has matched the California raises, and partners at other firms around the country have held impromptu meetings to discuss salaries. Page A1. 

Another Opinion on Microsoft Suit
Lawrence Lessig, a Harvard legal scholar, told the judge in the Microsoft antitrust case that the company's decision to bundle its Web browser into the Windows operating system had "obvious benefits" to computer programmers and consumers. But he then proceeded to provide a legally innovative map for determining that the bundling strategy violated the law. C8.
 
Brill Media Forms Partnerships
Brill Media Holdings, the company that publishes Brill's Content magazine, has agreed to form a partnership with CBS, NBC, Primedia, Ingram Book Group and EBSCO, a company that provides magazine subscription services and databases of already-published magazine content. C6.
 
Auto Sales Remain Strong in U.S.
Every manufacturer except DaimlerChrysler announced big gains in sales in the United States for January. C2.
 
Major Stock Gauges Rise Sharply
Stocks rose sharply as investors bought beaten-down shares of companies that had faltered. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 100.52 points, to 11,041.05. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 14.82 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,409.28. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 111.63 points, or 2.8 percent, to 4,051.98. C16.
 
A Second Act for CMS Energy
Having almost gone broke in the 1980's, CMS Energy -- the parent of Consumers' Power -- wowed Wall Street in the 1990's by going global and expanding into almost every part of the energy industry. But that love affair appears to be over, or at least experiencing a crisis. Facing heavy debts and weaker profits from international operations than expected, CMS disclosed a restructuring plan that would slash dividend payments while raising cash by selling a tracking stock tied to its utility business. Floyd Norris: Market Place. C14.
 
Reports Reinforce Inflation Fears
The industrial sector grew in January for the 12th consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in a report that raised inflation worries. Separately, the Commerce Department said construction spending surged 2 percent in December, pushing the amount of money spent on building single-family homes to a monthly record. C30.
 
Shares of France's Valeo Fall 10%
Shareholders in Valeo of France, a large automotive parts company, sold heavily on news that it would cut 6,000 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force, in the next two years. C4.
 
France Adopts Shorter Workweek
Strikes crippled subway and bus service in Paris on the day when most French companies were to begin adopting a shorter workweek, down from 39 hours to 35 hours. A10.

HEADLINE: Newest and Trendiest Autos Bring Americans to Dealers

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Americans flocked to dealerships last month to buy the most recently introduced and most fashionable cars, minivans and sport utility vehicles available, automakers said today, as every manufacturer except DaimlerChrysler A.G. announced big gains in sales.
The three increases of a quarter percentage point each in short-term interest rates last year by the Federal Reserve seemed to have had no effect on the torrid pace in the auto market last month. The Fed is widely expected to respond to inflationary pressures in the economy by raising rates further on Wednesday. But auto executives remained optimistic that the industry this year would nearly match the record-setting pace of 1999. 
 If the central bank "just keeps it small and everything else stays the same, I think the market will absorb" a rate increase, said Jamie Jameson, DaimlerChrysler's vice president for sales and marketing.
Rising gasoline prices appeared to have had only a modest effect on sales of the biggest, most profitable vehicles last month. DaimlerChrysler's sales of sport utility vehicles plunged 13 percent last month, led by a 21 percent drop in sales of the Dodge Durango. But the General Motors Corporation's redesigned Chevrolet Suburban and GMC Yukon XL posted sharp increases.
Paul Ballew, G.M.'s director of market analysis, said that the increase in gasoline prices since last winter had only added about $25 a month so far to the cost of operating the average new automobile. That is not enough to influence many buyers, he said, while declining to speculate whether any further price increases would change sales patterns significantly.
In a sign that Americans remain full of optimism and enthusiasm about the strength of the economy, the freshest, latest models sold best last month, whether they were cars or light trucks. New and fairly new models like the Lincoln LS and Jaguar S-Type sedans, the Ford Focus hatchback, the Honda Odyssey minivan and the redesigned Chevrolet Tracker sport utility vehicle all sold briskly. Sales lagged for older models like the Ford Crown Victoria and Honda Accord sedans, the Mercury Villager minivan and the Jeep Cherokee sport utility vehicle.
Among automakers with headquarters in the Detroit area, G.M., with a lot of new sport utility vehicles and pickups backed up with generous discounts, did best last month, with sales rising 11.5 percent compared with January of last year. The Ford Motor Company's sales rose 4 percent, excluding Volvo Cars, which Ford bought last March. DaimlerChrysler's sales dipped 4.8 percent, including its Mercedes division.
G.M. fared poorly in January 1999, making its performance look better this year, while Ford and DaimlerChrysler did very well a year ago, one reason their sales last month seemed less impressive. DaimlerChrysler's sales were also hurt because winter storms curbed showroom traffic in the Northeast, one of its strongest markets, Mr. Jameson said.
Ford and DaimlerChrysler appeared to have lost market share last month to the Toyota Motor Corporation, which reported an increase in sales of 35.7 percent, and to the Nissan Motor Company, whose sales leaped 26.7 percent. Nissan's strong results were the latest sign that the Japanese automaker may be halting a long erosion in its market share, as new models like the Maxima sedan and Xterra sport utility vehicle have proved popular.
Other foreign automakers also prospered in the American market, including Volkswagen A.G., up 47.7 percent; the Subaru unit of Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., up 27 percent; the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, up 9.1 percent; and the Honda Motor Company, up 3.3 percent.
A handful of small automakers did not release their results today, making it hard to calculate companies' market shares precisely. Mr. Ballew of G.M. said the industry's overall sales appeared to have run last month at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of more than 17 million automobiles. That represents a fast pace, given that sales last year totaled 16.9 million vehicles, but the industry is expected to slow somewhat later in the year because of rising interest rates and energy prices.

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 807 words

HEADLINE: LESSONS;
And So Just What Good Were the Good Old Days?

BYLINE: By Richard Rothstein 

 BODY:
It's only right for governors, presidential candidates and mayors to demand that schools improve. In a democracy, elected leaders should hold public schools accountable. But if politicians don't properly inform themselves about complex educational problems, they risk making decisions by cliche.
A case in point is the recent State of the State speech by New York's governor, George E. Pataki. Explaining his demands for reform, the governor said, "At the turn of the last century, New York's schools provided immigrant children and native New Yorkers alike with a first-rate education," whereas today "some students are forced to settle for less." 
 Those words may have struck many as harmless hyperbole. But allusions to a nonexistent golden age can be harmful, by masking the challenges schools actually face.
In the first decades of the 20th century, there was a yawning achievement gap between immigrants and the American-born. Even immigrant Jews, whom many now consider yesteryear's "model minority," did worse in school than immigrants do today. Schools took years to lift the children of immigrants up to achievement levels we now take for granted.
According to a 1911 federal report, 80 percent of native white seventh graders of that period in cities like Boston, Chicago and New York made it into eighth grade the next year. But a smaller proportion of Russian Jewish immigrant children, and many fewer Southern Italian immigrants, did so. After eighth grade, Southern Italians made it to high school at only half the rate of their native peers. (For purposes of the report, children were considered immigrants if they or their fathers were foreign-born.)
Twenty years later, things weren't much better. By the end of the 1920's, Italian immigrant high school students were still graduating at only one-quarter the rate of nonimmigrants. This was a much bigger native-immigrant gap than today's.
Immigrant Jews performed less well than native whites, but better than immigrant Italians. That was no surprise. Then as now, achievement had a lot to do with families' economic status. In 1910, 1 in 3 Southern Italian adult men in American big cities, and almost no Russian Jews, were unskilled laborers. In contrast, 1 in 3 Russian Jews, and very few Southern Italians, were merchants. As a result, Russian Jewish immigrants averaged about 20 percent more family income than Southern Italian immigrants.
Social promotion was hardly the norm back then. The term "retarded," for children deemed to have limited ability, comes from the early-20th-century practice of holding back (retarding) those who read below grade level. A 1909 study found that in New York City, Italian-born elementary students were held back twice as frequently as American-born children. Jewish and Irish students were also retained often.
Once denied promotion, many were quick to drop out. The immigrant challenge was so daunting that New York City started a special education program to address it. A 1921 survey found Italian children greatly overrepresented in these separate classes for slow learners.
Standardized exams seemed to confirm immigrants' inferiority. About this time, I.Q. tests became common. In 1919, the median I.Q. score of Italian 10-year-olds in New York City was 84; for native-born whites, it was 109. But when only those students whose fathers were unskilled or semiskilled laborers were compared, Italian and native I.Q.'s were nearly identical.
Progress was slow, and assimilation rates for subsequent generations varied by ethnicity. It seems that Jews typically adapted to schools and became fully fluent in English more quickly than other immigrant groups. Italians seemed to do so more quickly than Greeks.
But of immigrant children themselves, even Jews were mostly unsuccessful. The 1911 report found that about half of all Jewish immigrant children around the country were held back in school. (Jews from Poland did particularly poorly; two-thirds were held back.) The historian Irving Howe reviewed New York school documents from 1910 to 1914 and said he had become "impatient with later sentimentalists" who exaggerated how much Jewish immigrant children "burned with zeal" for their studies. The academically successful were a minority.
Is this relevant to today's problems? Yes, because we need reminding that the past provides models of very limited value. Americans now do a better (and more nearly equal) job of educating immigrant children than did Americans of earlier eras.
Our education debates could benefit from greater humility. We should aspire for greater success in educating immigrants, but nobody has sure answers for how to achieve it. If reform-minded politicians think better schools are simply a matter of turning back the clock, we've got big disappointments ahead.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1237 words

HEADLINE: Law Firms' Pay Soars to Stem Dot-Com Defections

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
In a stark demonstration of the lure and the power of the Internet, some of the nation's top law firms have raised pay for associates by as much as 50 percent in the last two weeks.
The move is the most recent part of a chain reaction that began just before New Year's Day in Silicon Valley, where firms have lost dozens of lawyers to dot-com start-ups, and is now spreading to the white-shoe firms of New York. At least one top New York law firm has matched the California raises, and partners at other firms around the country have held impromptu meetings to discuss salaries. Many are expected to offer big raises in the coming weeks. 
 The pay increases will allow first-year associates to earn as much as $160,000 a year, depending on their year-end bonus. As firms simultaneously adjust the salaries of all other associates, the payroll at a single firm could grow by tens of millions of dollars.
Across the country, more than a thousand lawyers will receive the raises, and that number will multiply if more firms follow suit.
News of the pay increases has ricocheted around law offices thanks to Internet chat boards, like Yahoo's "Greedy Associates," where lawyers have been posting messages about developments at their firms. The online discussions have, in turn, raised the pressure on firms that have not yet offered pay increases, partners said.
Lawyers are now waiting to see whether other New York firms follow the lead of Davis Polk & Wardwell, which told its associates in the last week that it would essentially match the new Silicon Valley salaries, according to lawyers at other firms and a copy of an internal memo posted on the Web. Davis Polk employees did not return phone calls.
Typically, the handful of the most prestigious firms in New York match each other's raises.
Under the new structure, first-year lawyers will make a base salary of $125,000, and with bonuses, often for working long hours, they can earn more than $150,000. Last year, beginning lawyers in the Bay Area earned about $95,000 in base salary, plus bonuses of around $5,000.
At top New York firms during the 1990's, starting base salaries rose from about $80,000 to about $105,000, where they stood until this week. Many lawyers also received bonuses of about $10,000 last year.
With the latest raises, fourth-year associates at many firms will be able to make more than $200,000, up from less than $150,000 last year.
The steep cost of the raises has the potential to cut partners' takes by as much as one-fifth. It will also very likely force increases in the firms' fees, which already start at about $200 an hour. Partners said, however, that they had little choice but to try to stem the Internet brain drain and to keep rival firms from gaining a recruiting edge.
"We want to make it harder for people to leave us for clients," said Tower C. Snow Jr., the chairman of Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison, a San Francisco-based firm where turnover among associates rose to 25 percent last year, from 12 percent in 1998, as lawyers jumped ship for both legal and executive jobs at eBay, E*trade and an array of Web start-ups. Brobeck was among the firms raising its salary structure recently.
The approach, associates say, has its appeal, in large part because much of the pay at Internet companies comes from stock options that may be worthless. "That much guaranteed salary is going to make people think pretty hard" about leaving, said Howard Holderness, a seventh-year associate at Brobeck. "A lot of dot-coms fail."
Still, the draw of the start-ups is fierce, in part because they offer the potential for wealth well beyond what any law firm salary could bring.
"It's been a very difficult situation," said Alan C. Mendelson, a senior partner at Cooley Godward, which has its headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif.
Many other professional service companies are facing the same drain. Booz Allen & Hamilton, McKinsey & Company and other consulting firms have begun taking stock in their clients more frequently and plan to allow employees to invest in the pooled equity, in an effort to mimic the skyrocketing stock prices of Internet companies. Investment banks like Morgan Stanley Dean Witter have raised salaries, in some cases offering restricted stock that workers can redeem only if they stay with the company for at least a few years.
For the law firms, the pay increases also reflect a new balance of geographic power. For decades, New York firms attracted many of the most talented law school graduates and paid them the highest salaries. Firms in other cities largely reacted to salary decisions made by New York firms.
Over the last decade, however, the gap between San Francisco-area salaries and New York salaries has shrunk, and at the most prestigious firms it no longer exists. In fact the current round of raises began at Gunderson Dettmer Stough Villeneuve Franklin & Hachigian, a Menlo Park, Calif., firm, in late December. Other Bay Area firms matched Gunderson last week.
"You now have California setting a trend," said the head partner at another large New York firm, who requested anonymity because he said commenting publicly would increase the chances that his firm would have to match the raises. "This has never happened before."
Perhaps more significant, New York firms are now paying no more than some California firms, where the dress code tends to be more relaxed and associates generally work fewer hours.
Typically, however, young lawyers at firms have less flexible schedules than lawyers at corporate legal departments. With the economy and stock market continuing to boom, and law firms' revenues growing by 10 to 20 percent a year, associates are busier than ever.
That, in addition to the promise of Internet stock options, is causing the increase in turnover. "I wanted to be able to control my schedule," said the general counsel of a dot-com company who recently left a large law firm and who insisted on anonymity. "I didn't want clients to be able to control me."
Lawyers around the country said they expected the decision by Davis Polk -- the fifth-largest firm in the country, according to the American Lawyer magazine's 1999 ranking -- to cause other top New York firms, like Cravath Swaine & Moore and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom -- to match.
Lawyers at Cravath and Skadden declined to comment.
In cities where the cost of living is well below what it is in San Francisco and New York and where there is less technology and finance work, salaries can be considerably lower and firms are less likely to match the raises, lawyers said. But some kind of raise, on top of the usual annual increase that firms doled out at the end of last year, is likely in other major cities, particularly those like Boston, Los Angeles and Washington, with significant technology industries.
"We're definitely reviewing it, and our salaries will definitely change," said Janet Zagorin, the director of practice development at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, a Los Angeles firm with offices in New York, Washington and San Francisco.
One option for firms is to raise salaries selectively. The San Francisco-based Morrison & Foerster, for example, gave raises to associates in its New York and Bay Area offices but not to those in Washington or elsewhere. And Shearman & Sterling, based in New York, increased pay only in its Menlo Park and San Francisco offices.

PUB-DATE: February 2, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 625 words

HEADLINE: For Now, a Real Campaign

 BODY:
Senator John McCain's big victory in New Hampshire's Republican presidential primary and Vice President Al Gore's narrow triumph on the Democratic side send a powerful message. Voters are not ready to anoint, at least for now, the candidates picked by each party's establishment. As a result of this rebuff to the entitlement strategies of Mr. Gore and Gov. George W. Bush, Americans may get to witness one of the more competitive nomination battles in memory.
Mr. Bush sailed into the Granite State backed by practically every leading Republican in the nation, not to mention his own family. But Mr. McCain won the hearts of New Hampshire voters with a gabby, joyful insurgency that emphasized personal character and moderate fiscal policies. As for the Democrats, many experts counted Bill Bradley out only a week ago, but his close showing against Vice President Gore amounts to a license to prolong his challenge despite the animosity of the party's Washington establishment. Because of their money and support around the country, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore still rate as the front-runners for their parties' nominations. But the fight will be tougher than might have seemed possible until recently. The vote could be read as an invitation to the rest of the country to experience a real campaign, complete with weekly debates, town meetings and encounters with voters. 
 The most extraordinary showing was certainly Mr. McCain's. The G.O.P. establishment will see the outcome as the work of independents rather than genuine Republicans. But Mr. McCain's victory, built around his challenge to the party's sterile reliance on tax cuts, special interests and soft money, will force Washington Republicans to take a searching look at Mr. Bush and may compel him to begin personal attacks against Mr. McCain as they move into South Carolina. Mr. McCain needs to keep rolling up victories there and elsewhere to compete on March 7 in the decisive races in California and New York, where it is more important than ever that he be allowed on the ballot. New York Republicans, by the way, should flood the office of Gov. George Pataki with telephone calls and letters demanding that he abandon his authoritarian effort to prevent them from selecting from a full roster of candidates in the state primary.
Both Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley showed impressive toughness and determination. Mr. Gore secured an important victory, but it did not come easily, nor was it large enough to end the Bradley challenge. The former New Jersey senator surged ahead this winter but stumbled with his shaky performance at the Iowa caucuses in January. He engaged in an embarrassingly public soul-searching over whether to attack Mr. Gore for his campaign distortions and fund-raising abuses in 1996. He finally did, but at first that only seemed to send his ratings down. But over the weekend Mr. Bradley's message caught hold, portending an even more contentious Democratic contest in the weeks ahead.
Of course, New Hampshire is a famous incubator of short-lived political rebellions, of dreams that eventually get crushed. But this year's insurgencies have a different root system, having been nurtured in an atmosphere largely free of the anger of years past, when the state suffered from recessions or the hollowing out of its old industries. This year, after the dispiriting scandals of the Clinton administration, the voters were taking a fresh look at leadership and character. They were also thinking about what to do with the budget surpluses and how to shore up the nation's retirement, health care and education systems. On all these issues, New Hampshire voters have had their say and, more important, set the stage for a broader, longer national debate.

HEADLINE: In Austria, Shadows and Worries

 BODY:

To the Editor:
What should we in the United States think of the pressure being exerted by the European Union on Austria to prevent Jorg Haider's Freedom Party from entering a coalition government (front page, Feb. 1)? 
 In 1933 German democracy was destroyed, it will be argued, by allowing the Nazis to join a coalition government, by means of which they created a totalitarian state. But this is a false analogy. Mr. Haider does not have a large social movement outside Parliament that he can mobilize, nor can he exploit a financial crisis.
Austria is a stable democracy. If Mr. Haider entered a coalition government, he would have to modify his extreme views. Keeping him out of power allows him to express radical positions without being accountable to anyone.
 
ELLIOT NEAMAN
San Francisco, Feb. 1, 2000
 
The writer is an associate professor of history at the University of San Francisco.

HEADLINE: The High-Speed Train That Thought It Could, but Can't

BYLINE: By PHIL PATTON 

 BODY:
INSPIRATION for the new logo for Amtrak's Acela train began, strangely, with a turtle.
"A turtle doesn't move very fast," admitted Nick Oakley, one of the designers of the new high-speed train. But during brainstorming sessions, designers kept coming back to the image of a sea turtle making stately and peaceful progress through blue waters as the key to the mood they wanted to suggest. The result was an abstracted fin. 
 The new logo appeared for the first time on a scheduled Amtrak train on Monday when an Acela Regional train pulled out of Boston.
The fully electrified service qualified this New York run as Acela, but the train was made up of refurbished old cars pulled by a venerable locomotive with a top speed of 80 miles per hour.
While Michael Dukakis, Governor Paul Cellucci of Massachusetts and other dignitaries were saluting the departure of the Acela Regional, the critical Acela Express test train -- which can cruise at 150 m.p.h. -- sat idle and forlorn in a cold Amtrak yard in Philadelpia, where it was undergoing repair. High-speed service for the Boston-to-Washington corridor, originally set to begin last fall, has been promoted by a $26 million advertising campaign. But the inauguration was postponed after wheels on prototype trains showed excessive wear. At the end of January, equipment on the test train proved wanting yet again. Amtrak officials have pushed the start of high-speed service back to midsummer.
A reporter visited the first of the 20 new Acela Express trains at the new Ivy Hill maintenance hangar in Washington. Each $20 million Acela Express "train set" -- the cars are meant to stay together -- consists of locomotives at each end, a first class car, four business class cars and a cafe car, for a total of 304 seats.
On first impression, the car interiors do not have the futuristic glamour of the French high-speed TGV or the streamlined romance of the 20th-Century Limited, but rather a practical, comfortable and rugged approximation of an airline interior. There are amenities air travel doesn't provide, however: conference areas and a cafe offering fresh breads and salads, specialty coffees and draft beer. There are six public phones and -- here's a benefit -- cell phones can be used anywhere on the trip.
Each seat is equipped with two music channels and an electrical outlet for plugging in laptops. Seats rotate with the touch of a foot pedal to let neighbors face each other. A more comfortable environment for working en route is an advantage Amtrak hopes will lure business travelers from airlines. When he began the redesign, Mr. Oakley said, "Carrying a laptop and wearing a nice suit and catching Amtrak was not acceptable."
Mr. Oakley and his team debated the virtues of the open overhead racks traditional on trains versus the closed bins of airlines. The bins won.
The new cars offer windows twice as large as those on current trains, allowing passengers to look out even while standing up. The cafe car has chic-looking stools and a leather padded rail for slouchers. And Mr. Oakley was especially focused on the rest rooms. "We explored about 200 different versions," he said.
He tried to avoid making them like the plastic capsules that serve as toilets on airlines, yet they had to conform with the Americans with Disabilities Act. There is a round mirror, light from outside filtering through sandblasted glass, a diaper changing table, and a purple-blue composite sink.
Employees were consulted, too. The people who ran the food service, the designers found, didn't like turning their backs to prepare meals. The new counter is curved.
Engineers asked for traditional instruments instead of digital gauges. Two throttles operate engines and brakes, and a red emergency stop button the size of tea saucer is placed prominently on the dash. The cockpit is heavily reinforced on the safety cage principle used in race car design, but much stronger. Behind the engineers' seats is an emergency area in which they can lie prone in case of collision.
Acela Express (it is pronounced ah-SELL-ah, a made-up cross between acceleration and excellence) is the long awaited American high-speed train. While no match in speed or style for the French TGV or Japanese bullet train, it is still America's best and perhaps last hope for passenger train service that can compete with the airline and automobile for civilized transportation.
Top speed for Acela Express will be 165 miles an hour; the French TGV approaches 200 miles an hour. Amtrak says the Acela Express is aimed at business travelers and that it will cut half an hour off the current three-hour Metroliner trip between Washington and New York, and a full hour and a half off the New York-to-Boston one, which is now nearly five hours. A New York to Washington ticket, now $66 one way on the standard train and $115 on the Metroliner, will be about $135 business class. It now costs $200 for a full-price fare on the Delta Shuttle from New York to Washington.
But Acela Express will never be faster door to door than the shuttle -- even adding in taxi time to the airport. So instead of focusing on reducing travel time, Amtrak is emphasizing quality time. "How you use time is more important than speed with which you get there," said Robin Haueter, a designer who worked with Mr. Oakley and Brent Oppenheimer on the project for the Ideo design firm. "This is a big idea, a fundamental change in the way we all think about business travel."
Barbara Richardson, the executive vice president of Amtrak, who was in charge of the Acela development program, said: "People are tired of being treated like commodities. They view the journey as a space, an element of time that becomes their own."
The new trains are New Age trains, with soothing interiors and soothing aphorisms to sell them. Ads show the train as a place for dreaming and contemplation, "where thoughts and coffee beans brew." One ad is tagged, "Depart from your inhibitions," another "Inner children travel free."
WHAT is really riding on the new trains is Amtrak's very existence. Deficits have plagued Amtrak since it was founded in 1971. Legislation passed in 1997 calls for it to break even by the end of 2002 or prepare a plan for its own liquidation. Amtrak executives count on the new trains to draw 2.5 million additional riders annually and to increase its revenues by $180 million a year.
Acela really had its beginnings in 1995, when Amtrak tested the high-speed Swedish X-2000, with an undercarriage that tilts around curves, and the German ICE (Intercity Express), on American tracks. American tracks are notoriously rough by world standards. European high-speed trains run on tracks whose rails are carefully aligned and welded, and the European models ran here at speeds well below their capabilities. Rebuilding the American track to European standards would be prohibitively expensive.
The contract for the new trains went to a consortium of Alstom, in Paris, and Bombardier, in Montreal, which makes the French TGV. The cars blend mechanical and structural elements from European trains, rejiggered for American tracks.
Amtrak executives, including Ms. Richardson and George Warrington, the president, inspected train interiors in Europe. They were impressed by the Spanish high-speed train. "The inside of the coach felt homier," Ms. Richardson said. "We felt a greater sense of hospitality."
Amtrak sought out the Spanish train's designers, which included Mr. Oakley, who studied at the Royal College of Art in London, along with Mr. Oppenheimer and Mr. Haueter. "The high-speed train was really a piece of the bigger-brand picture," Ms. Richardson said. It would be used to lend a new image to all operations in the Northeast corridor, which carries the majority of Amtrak's traffic. Old train names like Keystone, Empire and even Metroliner will give way to Acela. The new trains will be used on Acela Express routes, while Acela Regional and Acela Commuter will use refurbished cars.
Amtrak surveyed some 24,000 travelers for the redesign, along with Amtrak employees. The designers chose a palette of colors centering on the teal-like blue that the railroad calls Acela blue.
New trains are only part of the $2.6 billion project. New stations are being added at Route 128 in Westwood, Mass., an important Boston commuter hub, and in New London, Conn.; at many other stations, seating and signage will be improved. There are even new uniforms, designed by Stan Herman, who created uniforms for Federal Express.
The "rebranding" campaign carried out by DDB New York began last summer with surreal teaser ads without mention of Amtrak or any image of a train. Clouds, blue tints, and a repeated slogan "Life on Acela" suggested to some viewers ads from a pharmaceutical company, perhaps for an antidepressant. "The ads are not what you would expect from a railroad," Ms. Richardson said. "But people remembered them. They got people buzzing."
Success will depend more on the nuts and bolts than on the buzz. Bombardier-Alstom has expressed confidence that it can fix the wheel problem. It has an incentive: it can be penalized for late delivery up to $13,500 per train per day.
Success will also depend on finances. While Amtrak says it is making economic progress thanks to increased ridership, a report issued last week by the Amtrak Reform Council, appointed by Congress to oversee the railroad, calls its accounting into doubt. An earlier report by the General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative branch, expressed doubt that even Acela could make Amtrak profitable.
Of course, no European high-speed train operates without government subsidy, as Amtrak is being asked to do. Acela's success will depend on whether its stately sea turtle pace can beat the relentless march of Congress's time limit, or whether the Acela's new trains can manage some fancy tilting in Washington.

HEADLINE: A Dwindling Surplus

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Phantom Surplus" (Op-Ed, Jan. 28), by Robert Reischauer: 
 Current and projected budget surpluses have more to do with the strong economic growth and consequent high tax revenues of recent years than with political virtue from the White House or Congress.
However, the surpluses that have been projected by the Congressional Budget Office and others will not happen because they are based on the assumption of a continuation of such growth, which is unlikely. When growth does slow or reverse (even temporarily), standard logic, based on private accounting principles, will require spending to be reduced or taxes to be raised to balance the budget.
But the principles of Keynesian economics, not accounting, should apply to the federal budget: when growth slows, cutting spending or raising taxes will decelerate it even further.
 
ROBERT A. LEVINE
Los Angeles, Jan. 28, 2000
 
The writer was deputy director of the Congressional Budget Office, 1975-79.

HEADLINE: Data Signals Economic Growth Should Continue in Current Year

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A key forecasting gauge rose to a new high in December, signaling that the economy's record expansion should continue well into the year.
The Conference Board said yesterday that its index of leading economic indicators increased four-tenths of a point in December, to a record 108.7, after rising three-tenths of a point, to 108.3, the month before. That was in line with analysts' expectations. 
 Separately in Washington, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that sales of new homes rose 4.5 percent in December, helping to raise the total for the year to a record high.
The strong economic readings came only a few hours before Federal Reserve policy makers, meeting in Washington for a second day, raised short-term interest rates one-quarter of a percentage point and warned of the risks of heightened inflationary pressures in the foreseeable future. The move to cool off the economy was expected.
The index of leading indicators is a barometer of economic activity in the next three to six months.
The latest reading signaled that the nation's economic expansion, would continue, economists said.
The Conference Board, a business-funded research group based in New York, said the index reading for December was the highest in the 40 years the index has been calculated on a comparable basis. The record mark was first passed in November.
Nine of the 10 components that make up the index rose in December. The 10th, which measures the average workweek in manufacturing, was unchanged, it said.
The group said its index of coincident indicators, measuring current activity, increased two-tenths of a point in December, to 126.8, from a revised 126.5 in November. The index of lagging indicators, which tracks past activity, went up half a point, to 109.4, in December from 108.9 percent in November.
The separate home sales report said that Americans purchased new single-family homes at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 900,000 in December, aided by favorable weather. December's 4.5 percent increase, bigger than the 4 percent rise many analysts were forecasting, followed a 6.3 percent decline in November.
For all of 1999, new-home sales rose 2 percent, to a record 904,000, surpassing the previous record of 886,000 in 1998.
Existing-home sales tracked by the National Association of Realtors also set a record in 1999 of 5.2 million.

HEADLINE: First Store Opens at the First Shopping Mall in Harlem

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
As dozens of headset-sporting store workers handed out dark blue mesh tote bags to use in place of shopping carts, a two-level Old Navy store began welcoming customers yesterday, becoming the first retailer in the long-awaited Harlem U.S.A. complex to open its doors.
By June, the glassy six-level structure at 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard -- the first retail and entertainment complex of its kind in the neighborhood -- will be home to seven other tenants: a Chase Manhattan Bank branch, a Disney Store, a nine-screen Magic Johnson Theater multiplex, a Modell's sporting goods store, an HMV record store, a New York Sports Club and a Jeepers video arcade. 
 Less than an hour after the Old Navy store opened, Tawania George had already stuffed three tote bags with T-shirts and other basic clothing for her five children. "I'm having a ball," she said with a big smile. "It's convenient, so I don't have to go downtown. It's hard to travel with little kids. And I'm within walking distance, so I save money on carfare."
The developers of Harlem U.S.A. spent years persuading national retailers like Old Navy, which is owned by the Gap, to venture into their inner-city neighborhood to capture some of the dollars local residents are spending downtown and elsewhere. Consequently, the new retail and entertainment complex is expected to be closely watched by other companies. How well it does is likely to have a large impact on the future of economic development on 125th Street and similar shopping strips.
Many shoppers said they welcomed the new complex because of the jobs it was bringing to a neighborhood where the unemployment rate in December was 9 percent, nearly twice the rate for Manhattan as a whole.
The $66 million shopping center is expected to create 600 jobs, three-quarters of them earmarked for Harlem residents. About 2,000 people applied for the 150 openings at Old Navy, said Sekee Clarke, the general manager of the store, who is himself a Harlem resident.
A number of the people who lined up in the cold yesterday to wait for Old Navy's doors to open were also seeking jobs. Rhoda Payne, a cashier at a Times Square multiplex, said she was disappointed to learn that there were no more openings and surprised not to see any familiar faces among the employees. "I've been living here for 13 years," Ms. Payne said, "and I don't see anybody that I recognize." Many of the employees helping customers or watching out for shoplifters had been brought in for the day from other Old Navy outlets, store officials said.
Built with private and public money, Harlem U.S.A. was developed by Grid Properties Inc. and the Gotham Organization in conjunction with the development arm of the Harlem Commonwealth Council, a local nonprofit organization that began assembling the site in 1973. Originally, the group hoped to develop a hotel there, said Barbara Norris, the president of the Commonwealth Local Development Corporation. The current project has been eight years in the making, Ms. Norris said.
In 1996, the developers received an $11.2 million loan from the New York Empowerment Zone Corporation, which oversees a joint federal, state and city economic development program. That loan was a key element in getting the project off the ground, said Drew Greenwald, the president of Grid Properties.
There is room at Harlem U.S.A. for three to six additional stores, the developers said. Mr. Greenwald said they were negotiating with several smaller retailers, including a local entrepreneur who wants to open a bookstore.
Ms. Norris said she had no doubt that Harlem would embrace the new complex. "These residents want the same quality that every other citizen in this town has," she said, "and they're entitled to it."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Share PricesFinish Mixed in Wake of Fed Rate Increase

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks struggled to a mixed finish yesterday after the Federal Reserve's widely expected interest rate increase did little to calm turbulent financial markets.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 37.85 points, to 11,003.20. The blue-chip index rose as much as 60 points in the moments before the Fed released its decision, then bobbed between positive and negative territory for much of the rest of the session. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.16 point, to 1,409.12, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 21.98 points, to 4,073.96.
Stocks gave up early gains after the Fed said it was raising its target for the federal funds rate -- the interest banks charge one another on overnight loans -- to 5.75 percent from 5.50 percent. Several commercial banks quickly announced that they, too, would increase borrowing costs.
Higher rates can cut into corporate profits by making it more difficult for companies to borrow money to finance growth.
As a result, investors yesterday turned to the companies that are advancing quickly enough to outrun rising rates, said A. Marshall Acuff Jr., equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. For the most part, that meant a lift for technology stocks.
"Investors are crowding into shares of the companies that they believe will continue to grow earnings, despite the Fed's tightening of interest rates," Mr. Acuff said.
Hewlett-Packard rose 4 3/4, to 110 9/16, and I.B.M. advanced 9/16, to 113 1/2, the strongest of the Dow components.
On the Nasdaq, Yahoo jumped 10 5/8, to 328, and Qualcomm gained 6, to 142 1/16. Turnstone Systems, which makes equipment that allows for high-speed Internet connections over telephone wires, soared 50 1/4, to 147 1/4, in its second day of trading after its initial public offering.
"Those are the companies that are driving innovation and improving productivity for the U.S. work force," said Philip S. Dow, director of equity strategy at Dain Rauscher Wessels in Minneapolis. "They're helping this economic expansion continue."
Trading remained highly volatile as investors worried that yesterday's interest rate increase might be the first of several this year. In a statement explaining its decision, the Fed said it remained worried that the rapidly growing economy "could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's record economic expansion."
The Fed imposed three quarter-percentage point increases in 1999 in its bid to keep inflation under control, and has suggested it will continue raising rates until it sees tangible evidence of a slowdown.
"The market knows that the Fed is in a gradual tightening mode," Mr. Acuff said. "As long as that's in place, it will be hard to advance significantly."
Financial services companies like American Express, which fell 4 13/16, to 164 3/16, are especially vulnerable, analysts said. Lending volume typically slides when interest rates are rising.
While interest rate concerns dominated Wall Street, corporate news also drove trading yesterday.
General Motors fell 3 7/8, to 81 3/8, after the company named its president and chief operating officer, G. Richard Wagoner, as chief executive, preparing G.M. for the retirement of the chairman and chief executive, John F. Smith Jr.
Time Warner rose 7 3/4, to 86 1/2, after reporting earnings that exceeded analysts' expectations. The strong report also lifted shares of America Online, which has stumbled since it announced plans to acquire Time Warner last month. AOL rose 4 1/2, to 60 1/4.

HEADLINE: General Motors Chief to Hand Over Reinsto Company's President

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 2

 BODY:
John F. Smith Jr., the chairman and chief executive of General Motors announced today that he would hand his chief executive title and day-to-day responsibility for running the company, the world's largest automaker, to G. Richard Wagoner Jr., 46, the president and chief operating officer, starting in June.
Mr. Smith, 61, will serve as the executive chairman. Harry J. Pearce, 57, who is recovering from leukemia, will stay on as G.M.'s vice chairman and may later be tapped to replace Mr. Smith as chairman, people close to the board's deliberations said. 
 While the titles change, the same triumvirate will lead General Motors. Mr. Wagoner will run the day-to-day business. Mr. Smith will spend more time working on the company's alliances with companies like Fuji and Toyota and with repairing G.M.'s frosty relations with car dealers. Mr. Pearce, who will report to Mr. Smith, will continue to oversee G.M's nonauto businesses plus its efforts on safety, the environment and public policy.
"The three of us make a great team," Mr. Smith said. "We've worked together since 1992 and share a common vision for General Motors." Indeed, Mr. Smith has presided over kaleidoscopic change at General Motors.
Mr. Smith was installed in a board coup in November 1992, when the company teetered near bankruptcy. It lost $2 billion in 1990, $4.5 billion in 1991 and $23.5 billion - more than $20 billion from an accounting change -- the year Mr. Smith was handed the reins.
Mr. Smith, working closely with Mr. Pearce and Mr. Wagoner, turned the red ink to black. Last year, with the economy and auto sales booming, G.M. earned a record $6 billion. G.M. has also improved nearly all aspects of its business, other auto executives and industry experts acknowledge. But many question whether G.M. has done enough to keep up with competitors. G.M.'s market share in the United States dipped to 29.5 percent last year, down from 34.3 percent in 1992.
Robert C. Stempel, the chairman and chief executive whom G.M.'s board ousted in 1992, acknowledged that G.M. has been partly turned around on Mr. Smith's watch. "It is obvious they've got their financial house in order," he said in an interview last month, adding, "To be a good, successful corporation you also have to have that market share."
Wall Street praised the management changes, and said that the drop in G.M.'s stock price today -- it was down $3.875, to $81.375 -- was driven by investors who took profits after G.M. announced Tuesday that it would distribute about half the value of its Hughes Electronics stake.
"It is good to have younger people moving into positions of importance at organizations like that," said Wendy Beale Needham, an auto analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Auto industry veterans echoed that sentiment. "In an organization as traditional and hidebound as General Motors, having a person who doesn't know all the reasons that things can't be done" can be a benefit, said Robert A. Lutz, former president and vice chairman of Chrysler and now the chief executive of the Exide Corporation, the battery maker.
Mr. Pearce has enormous credibility on Wall Street and within the auto industry, and praised the board's move today.
"Had I been an outside director I would've selected Rick Wagoner as C.E.O. of this company," Mr. Pearce said. "His track record speaks for itself -- it is extraordinary."
Mr. Wagoner has been a star at G.M. for more than a decade. Just like many past chief executives, he began his career in G.M.'s powerful treasurer's office in New York. He later became treasurer of G.M.'s Brazil operations, then was moved to the finance jobs in Canada and Europe. He was then sent back to lead the Brazil operations, which he turned around. When Mr. Smith was named chief executive, he tapped Mr. Wagoner as chief financial officer.
"Rick will have responsibility for the strategic, operational leadership of General Motors," Mr. Smith said. "He is in charge."
Still, Mr. Wagoner could end up reporting to Mr. Pearce some day. Mr. Pearce said today that his health was not a concern, noting that his bone marrow transplant was 17 months ago. "The possibility of a relapse is very remote," said Mr. Pearce, who noted that while "I may not look quite right to you yet," he will be weaned from drugs suppressing his immune system by midsummer, when Mr. Wagoner is scheduled to take over. Those drugs cause swelling and redness in his face.
James L.M. Ferrara, director of the Bone Marrow Transplant program at the University of Michigan, said that generally speaking, "the majority of relapses occur within 12 to 18 months after transplants," and that someone like Mr. Pearce is in the recovery phase, but "is not home free."
The changes announced today are not the only shifts in store at the top of G.M. John G. Smale, G.M.'s lead director and leader of the 1992 board coup, announced in November that he would retire from G.M.'s board in May. Mr. Wagoner said today that he had no plans to change course for G.M.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
That30-Year Benchmark? Think 10-Year, Treasury Says

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Since 1977, when the federal government began regularly issuing 30-year bonds, they have been the benchmark of the American bond market. But yesterday the Treasury signaled that those days should soon be over.
In a move that could eventually eliminate the 30-year bond altogether, the Treasury Department announced plans for a reduction in new issuance of the bonds and the buying back of other long-term Treasury debt. 
 The department's under secretary for domestic finance, Gary Gensler, said bond market investors were already starting to regard the 10-year note as the benchmark. "The focus," Mr. Gensler said, "is more and more on the 10-year note than on the 30-year bond."
The changes the Treasury announced were forced by growing federal budget surpluses, which have allowed the government to pay off some of the publicly held government debt, which now stands at about $3.3 trillion. In this quarter, the Treasury expects to reduce the public debt by $17 billion followed by a record payoff of $152 billion in the second quarter.
The shift to the 10-year note as a benchmark had already begun because of its wide use as a pricing point in the corporate and mortgage markets. But the change has accelerated because of the distortion in the performance of the 30-year bond since the Treasury first announced last month that it was going to buy back old Treasury securities. Since then the yield has fallen almost half a percentage point.
"It would not surprise me if the Treasury phases out the 30-year bond over the next several years," said Ward McCarthy, managing director at Stone & McCarthy in Princeton, N.J. "It's trading like it's a collectors' item."
Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said the Treasury itself had hastened the shift from the 30-year bond by announcing the buybacks. The Treasury, he said, "triggered the event that has called into question the reliability" of the 30-year bond.
The Treasury said yesterday that it would reduce the issuance of its 2-year, 5-year and 10-year notes and its 30-year bond. It will also reduce the issuance of its 30-year inflation-indexed bond. Together, the issuance of regular and inflation-indexed 30-year bonds will be less than half the $45 billion total in the fiscal year 1999, which ended on Sept. 30.
Accordingly, Mr. Crandall said that based on what has been issued so far this fiscal year, the $10 billion in new 30-year bonds to be issued next week will be followed by about $5 billion in May. The May figure is significantly less than the $10 billion many analysts expected.
The Treasury also said it would reduce the issuance of one-year bills by cutting the schedule from every four weeks to four times a year. Officials are also considering the elimination of the one-year bill. At the same time, the Treasury will increase the supply of three-month and six-month bills.
The reduction of longer-term debt issuance and the shift to more three- and six-month bills will help lower the overall cost of government borrowing, which is one of the Treasury's main goals.
The Treasury buybacks will start in the next two months. The initial buybacks will be about $1 billion at a time. Mr. Gensler said the buybacks would give the Treasury and investors the experience they need before moving to larger buybacks. Investors are not required to sell their Treasury securities back to the Treasury, so a premium price will have to be offered. The Treasury said it hoped to buy back up to $30 billion in longer-term securities by the end of 2000.
The announcement of the details of buying back long-term debt and the reduction of issuance of new 30-year bonds had a marked effect. The price of the 30-year bond jumped 1 27/32, to 97 29/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.28 percent, from 6.42 percent on Tuesday.
The yield on the 30-year bond is now not much higher than the yield on the one-year Treasury bill, which was at 6.19 percent yesterday. And it is lower than the yield on the Treasury's 2-year note at 6.58 percent, the 5-year note at 6.65 percent, and the 10-year note at 6.57 percent, down from 6.62 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Albright Visits Post-Tudjman Croatia and Hails the New Leadership

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright came here today to praise the government that was recently formed from the democratic opposition.
She also encouraged the two candidates for the presidency and promised that the United States would support the rapid integration of a "new Croatia" into NATO, the European Union and the West. 
 Dr. Albright and her aides expressed hope that the "Croatian example" would affect neighboring Serbia, where Washington wants to see the end of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. Washington also hopes that "Croatia's rapid move into Europe" and Western institutions like NATO's Partnership for Peace will "make the Serbs think hard," a senior American official said.
On her last visit here, in August 1998, Dr. Albright had a bitter meeting with President Franjo Tudjman, whose government resisted full cooperation with the international tribunal on war crimes in the former Yugoslavia and worked to undermine the 1995 Dayton agreement in Bosnia.
But with the death of Mr. Tudjman in December and the electoral victory of a six-party opposition coalition led by Prime Minister Ivica Racan that Washington encouraged, "I think everyone is ready to embrace the new Croatia," Dr. Albright said.
"What a difference a year and a half makes," she added.
She said Washington would increase economic aid, from $12 million to $20 million. She also delivered a letter from President Clinton to Mr. Racan that promised support for Croatian democracy if the new government lived up to its promises to cooperate with the tribunal and abide by the Dayton agreement, including allowing Serbian refugees to return to their homes. Washington would like Croatia to stop spending up to $3 million a day to support a separate Bosnian Croat administration and military, an official said.
Mr. Racan, leader of the reformed Communist Party, now called the Social Democrats, said Croatia would live up to its responsibilities toward Bosnia, Serbia and Europe. "Judge us by our deeds, not by our promises," he said.
Unusually, Dr. Albright arrived in the middle of an election campaign for the presidency, a period that ends on Monday in a runoff between the front-runner, Stipe Mesic, and an ally of Mr. Racan. Drazen Budisa. United States officials said they would be happy if either won, and Dr. Albright had private meetings with each today after she had arrived from Moscow.
