HEADLINE: Victories That Will Be Fleeting

BYLINE: By Garry Wills; Garry Wills is the author, most recently, of "A Necessary Evil: A History of American Distrust of Government."

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
New Hampshire's returns were not only a case of the suppposed winning candidates losing, but of men losing whose whole rationale for being in the race at all was that they are winners. The Republican establishment backed George W. Bush early (and lavishly) because this time out, it preferred winning to principle. What happens, then, when the winner does not win?
Bill Bradley, too, picked up early and sizable donations because he alone, it was felt, could win in the fall. Mr. Gore, according to early punditry, could not defeat Mr. Bush -- he was too wooden, too tainted, too mired in difficulties with his campaign staff. Mr. Bradley had Mr. Gore's views without his disadvantages. 
 Yet, Mr. Bradley not only lost to this loser; in exit polls, those who said they care about winning in the fall went more than three-to-one in favor of Mr. Gore.
Well, Mr. Bradley's spinners say, he didn't really lose because he made a strong comeback, and Mr. Gore just "edged" him (by four points -- some "edge"). A big defeat is defined, for this occasion, as Mr. McCain's 19-point victory over Mr. Bush.
Yet that 15-point difference in the margins of victory hides more than it reveals.
If the ludicrous candidates were removed from the Republican side, almost all their combined vote -- 20 percent -- would have gone to Mr. Bush, giving him 50 percent of the total. The right wing of the party, which splintered its vote among the also-rans, has its doubts about Mr. Bush, but it abominates Mr. McCain.
Despite the pundits' warning that Republicans will now have second thoughts about Mr. Bush, what Mr. McCain's victory will do instead is dispel any hesitancy by the party about Mr. Bush's candidacy. Republicans will now rally urgently to make sure that their party does not nominate a man who threatens the mother's milk of the party -- campaign donations -- and denounces one of the principal sources of that milk, the tobacco companies. Mr. McCain is in for a heady few weeks, delighting reporters and infuriating party regulars. Then reality will set in.
On the Democratic side, Mr. Bradley not only lost his campaign's rationale (that he is a winner) but he did what little "winning" he did by abandoning the rationale for that rationale -- that he was offering a new politics, serenely above politics as usual.
This claim was suspect, even before his last-minute assault on Al Gore as a person.
After all, the lowest blow thrown in this whole campaign, on either side or at any time, was Mr. Bradley's false assertion several weeks ago that Al Gore was the first candidate to bring up Willie Horton. The meanest attack dog on any side has been Mr. Bradley's surrogate, Senator Bob Kerrey.
Mr. Bradley said that he did not want to look at the past when Mr. Gore brought up old votes on farm aid, but he spent his last few days in New Hampshire doing little but looking at his opponent's old votes on abortion, trying to manufacture a difference with Mr. Gore where there is none.
The man who said he was above "ploys" and "tactics," like Mr. Gore's challenge to a series of debates, used a ploy to distract from his imminent loss in New Hampshire by releasing his own version of that challenge just before the polls closed.
Mr. Bradley is running for the Democratic nomination, but he lost the Democratic vote decisively in New Hampshire -- by 19 points, according to exit polls. (The independent vote made up the difference.) He lost every income category to Mr. Gore except those making more than $100,000 a year. That demographic is not the backbone of the Democratic Party. Those who said jobs and the economy were their prime concern preferred Mr. Gore to Mr. Bradley by a whopping four to one.
Mr. Bradley is the "insurgent" of the fashionable fat cats -- who include, of course, his cheerleaders in the press. He is the champion of campaign finance reform who has outspent Mr. Gore, and he can continue to dog Mr. Gore only because his coffers are full of the very money he calls unclean.
That is why John McCain, the apparent big winner in New Hampshire, will soon prove just a momentary nuisance to George Bush, while Bill Bradley, the four-point loser, will be a long-term spoiler for Al Gore. He will be because he can afford to be. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Robert J. Milano, 87, Self-Made Industrialist

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Robert John Milano, a self-made millionaire industrialist who briefly served Mayor Edward I. Koch as deputy mayor for economic development, died Saturday at a hospital in Palm Springs, Fla., where he lived. A former New York resident, he was 87.
In January 1978, a newly minted Mayor Koch introduced him as a Horatio Alger he had recruited to head the office that the mayor said would produce the city's salvation. Ten weeks later, the two men announced their parting at separate news conferences. 
 Both said Mr. Milano had not been dismissed, but the circumstances left little doubt that the mayor had asked for his resignation. Coming but 74 days into the Koch administration, his was the first casualty in the mayor's cabinet.
He certainly did not need the $1-a-year compensation he was to be paid. At the time, he was selling a business he had started from scratch to the Gulf Oil Company for $16 million.
A native of the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood on Manhattan's West Side, Robert Milano was born on June 14, 1912. He attended the High School of Commerce and studied business administration and financial law in evening sessions at City College. In 1930, he went to work as a bookkeeper for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.
After scraping together extra cash by selling insurance and holding a part-time accountant's job, he started his own venture selling chemicals in 1936 at the age of 24. It prospered even through his four-year Army service in World War II and, by 1975, evolved into Kewanee Industries, a conglomerate with sales of about $500 million a year.
By the 70's, his business activities were slowing, and Mr. Milano devoted his energies to a role as the businessman in civic and governmental groups. Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller appointed him in 1971 to the Scott Commission, which the governor created to investigate the city's fiscal policies.
Serving on that panel and on a State Charter Study Commission for New York City gave him enough experience with the workings of the municipal government to enable Mr. Koch to draw on his talent.
He helped expand the New School for Social Research into the present New School University. He joined the New School's board in 1976, served as vice chairman and remained a trustee at his death. In 1995, the university named its Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy for Mr. Milano.
Mr. Milano's survivors include his wife of 61 years, Sidonia Friedsam Milano; their son, Robert S., of Los Angeles; and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Precautionary Rate Hike by the Fed

 BODY:
Perhaps the Federal Reserve acted prematurely yesterday when it raised short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point in order to reduce spending and thereby weaken inflationary pressures. After all, inflation remains subdued. But the Fed has evidence on its side, and the support of many experts. Its decision is reasonable.
The Fed stubbornly refuses to disclose the criteria it uses to decide when to pump more money into the economy to drive interest rates down, or when to draw money out of the economy to drive interest rates up. This lack of clarity is the one knock on Alan Greenspan's otherwise excellent stewardship of the Fed. Many monetary experts believe that the Fed tries to keep inflation at about 2 percent a year. Rates much above 2 percent disrupt the private sector and, because inflation rates can accelerate, could force the Fed eventually to crack down hard, throwing the economy into recession. Rates much below 2 percent flirt with setting off deflation, when prices fall and make it hard for the government to keep production and jobs from falling alongside. 
 So why did Mr. Greenspan decide to crack down yesterday? The inflation rate has been running at almost 3 percent for the last 12 months and even a bit higher for the last six months. Compensation -- wages plus medical and other fringe benefits -- rose by about 3.5 percent at the end of last year. Both wages and prices were rising faster at the end of last year than they were at the beginning, a worrisome trend for the Fed. The Fed also points to a rapid growth of spending that could cause wages and prices to rise even faster.
There was a time when the Fed was afraid to let the unemployment rate fall much below 6 percent lest inflation take off. But under Mr. Greenspan's direction, the Fed mostly sat back as unemployment fell to close to 4 percent. Inflation hardly budged. There would have been nothing wrong if the Fed had decided yesterday to stay put. But Mr. Greenspan judged the risk too high. February marks the 107th consecutive month on Mr. Greenspan's watch that economic output has risen, the longest uninterrupted growth on record. His judgment warrants the benefit of anyone's doubts.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fed Raises Interest Rates And Hints at Further Action
The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point and signaled that further rate increases will probably be needed to keep the persistently strong economy from generating inflation. 
 The move, the fourth rate increase since June, was in line with what economists and investors had expected. Financial markets took the announcement in stride. Page A1.
 
Stocks struggled to a mixed finish. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 37.85 points, to 11,003.20, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.16 point, to 1,409.12. But the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 21.98 points, to 4,073.96. C12.
 
Publicis to Acquire Fallon McElligott
Fallon McElligott, the Minneapolis advertising agency, said it had agreed to be acquired by the Publicis Group unit of Publicis in Paris, the world's 10th largest agency company in revenue and 12th largest in billings. Maurice Levy, the president of Publicis, would not comment on the purchase price, but it has been estimated at $120 million. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C10.
 
F.T.C. Wants to Halt Amoco Merger
The Federal Trade Commission decided to try to block BP Amoco's $30 billion proposed acquisition of Atlantic Richfield in a move designed to stem the trend of huge consolidation in the oil industry. A1.
 
Senate Approves Bankruptcy Bill
The Senate voted decisively to make it harder for people to erase their debts, a measure that would overhaul the nation's bankruptcy law. Major differences still exist between the Senate bill and a rival House version approved last year. But lawmakers from both parties and Clinton administration officials expressed confidence that Congress can produce a compromise bankruptcy bill that Mr. Clinton can sign into law this year. A1.
 
Indonesia Receives a Credit Plan
International donors meeting in Jakarta gave Indonesia's government a powerful show of support by extending up to $4.7 billion in credit to fill a budget hole and keep the country's tenuous economic recovery alive. C4.
 
30-Year Bond to Be Phased Out
The Treasury announced plans for a reduction in new issuance of 30-year bonds and the buying back of other long-term Treasury debt in a move that could lead to the elimination of the 30-year bond altogether. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.28 percent. C12.
 
Economic Indicators Show Gain
The Conference Board said its index of leading economic indicators increased four-tenths of a percent in December, in line with analysts' expectations. Separately, the Commerce Department reported that sales of new homes rose 4.5 percent during December. For all of 1999, new-home sales rose 2 percent, to a record 904,000. C25.
 
Pfizer Said to Win Warner-Lambert
Pfizer has reached an agreement to buy Warner-Lambert for a sweetened price of $87 billion, but the deal must be approved by American Home Products. C2.

A Fired Executive Sues Citigroup
A former senior vice president and chairman of Citicorp's internal technology division has filed a lawsuit accusing the corporation of age discrimination and of inventing reasons to fire him. Citigroup denied the charges. C13.
 
Time Warner Operating Earnings Up
Time Warner, which has agreed to be acquired by America Online, said its fourth-quarter profit from operations rose to 20 cents a basic share from 11 cents a year ago. Revenue rose 9.9 percent, to $7.99 billion. C10.

HEADLINE: Central Bank's Statement On Interest Rate Increases

 BODY:
Following is the text of the statement by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to raise short-term interest rates: 
 The Federal Open Market Committee voted today to raise its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 5 3/4 percent. In a related action, the board of governors approved a 25-basis-point increase in the discount rate, to 5 1/4 percent.
The committee remains concerned that over time increases in demand will continue to exceed the growth in potential supply, even after taking account of the pronounced rise in productivity growth. Such trends could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's record economic expansion.
Against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the committee believes the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future.
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago, St. Louis, Kansas City and San Francisco. The discount rate is the rate charged depository institutions when they borrow short-term adjustment credit from their district Federal Reserve Banks.

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Gives a Nudge To 2 Key Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point today and signaled that further rate increases would probably be needed to keep the persistently strong economy from generating inflation.
The move, the fourth rate increase since June, was in line with what most economists and investors had expected. Financial markets took the announcement in stride. 
 Stocks ended mixed. Bond prices rose, in part because the Treasury Department announced a plan to buy back some of the government's long-term debt as part of an effort to deal with growing budget surpluses. Market Place, Page C1.
The central bank allowed the economy to expand for the last several years at rates well above what conventional wisdom once thought could be sustained without igniting inflation, betting that huge investments in technology would allow companies to absorb cost increases without raising prices.
In the process the Fed discovered that the United States was less susceptible to an upward spiral in wages and prices than almost anyone previously believed, even with unemployment at its current level of 4.1 percent, a 30-year low.
But in raising rates today, the Fed and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, made clear once more that the central bank's growth experiment had its limits. The message today was that the Fed was increasingly reverting to its traditional posture of stamping out any inflationary pressures before they could endanger an expansion that on Tuesday became the longest on record.
In increasing its benchmark Federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks by a quarter- point today, to 5.75 percent, the central bank pushed rates above where they had been in mid-1998, when the Fed cut rates three times to help bring the global financial crisis under control. The Fed also raised its discount rate on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system by a quarter-point today, to 5.25 percent.
"By tightening, the Fed signaled carefully to the markets its intention of keeping inflation from accelerating," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at Bank of America in New York. "It recognizes that stable inflation is the key ingredient to economic expansion."
By raising its official short-term rates, the Fed puts upward pressure on rates paid for everything from credit cards and mortgages to business loans. Banks immediately said today that they would raise their prime lending rates.
Many longer-term rates set directly or indirectly in the bond market -- like those for mortgages and much of the borrowing done by corporations -- have moved higher since the Fed began raising rates last year. But analysts said the impact of long-term bond rates on the economy could be clouded somewhat by the Treasury Department's debt buyback plan.
The Senate took up Mr. Greenspan's nomination to a fourth term today. Both parties said they expected an overwhelming vote in his favor on Thursday, reflecting the broad consensus that he has guided the economy skillfully for more than a dozen years.
In a statement, the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee sent a clear signal that today's increase was not likely to be the last.
"The committee remains concerned that over time increases in demand will continue to exceed the growth in potential supply, even after taking account of the pronounced rise in productivity growth," the statement said, alluding to what Fed officials view as the most basic of economic imbalances.
"Such trends could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's record economic expansion," the committee said.
Economists said the Fed was likely to raise rates by at least another half a percentage point in coming months, hoping to temper demand by making borrowing more expensive and taking some steam out of the stock market. The Fed's next meeting is on March 21.
"One more increase is probably in the bank, taking the funds target to 6 percent," said Chris Varvares, an economist at Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting and forecasting firm in St. Louis. "From then on it depends on a series of factors -- the stock market, the underlying trend of demand and any inflation surprises in either direction that might occur."
The economy grew in last year's fourth quarter by 5.8 percent, well above anyone's estimate of its speed limit. And in a further indication that last year's rate increases had not yet slowed the economy much, the Commerce Department said today that new-home sales rose a strong 4.5 percent in December despite higher mortgage rates.
Still, inflationary pressures are no more than shadowy. By a price measure included in calculation of the gross domestic product, inflation rose at a 2 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, up from 1.1 percent in the prior three-month period. Yet when volatile oil prices are excluded, the Consumer Price Index rose 1.9 percent last year, down from 2.4 percent in 1998.
"The strong economy is not creating inflation," said Gary Thayer, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. "The Fed, as it has been doing, is trying to stay ahead of the problem."
In trying to keep inflation under control, the Fed is trying to reduce demand for goods and services across the economy. There are a variety of channels through which higher interest rates can make that happen, from increasing unemployment to cooling off interest-sensitive sectors like housing.
But analysts say that one of the most important variables in demand is the stock market, which is creating much of the wealth that is allowing consumers to spend freely at auto dealers and malls. If higher rates do not put a ceiling on stock prices, they said, demand is likely to remain too strong for the Fed's tastes.
"If a stock market correction doesn't happen, then consumer spending remains very strong, to the point where a Fed funds target of 6 percent would be insufficient to get the economy down to the speed limit," Mr. Varvares said. "If the stock market were to hold at its recent peak, Fed funds would easily have to go to 7 percent to elicit the slowing the Fed would need to see."
The Fed might also need to push rates up more aggressively if long-term bond rates continue their recent decline.
At the same time, Fed officials are well aware that recessions are often caused by the central bank's raising interest rates a bit too much in the pursuit of price stability, choking off growth. Without firmer evidence that inflation is actually bubbling through the economy, Mr. Greenspan is likely to stick to a cautious, incremental approach to tightening policy.
"Since they're not behind the curve and we don't have an inflation problem outside of energy," Mr. Thayer said, "I don't think there's any urgency."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1186 words

HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES A BILL TO TOUGHEN BANKRUPTCY RULES

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The Senate approved a sweeping overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy laws today, decisively passing a measure that would make it harder for people to seek legal protection from payment of their debts.
But in a move that could complicate final passage of the legislation, it also included in the measure a $1 increase over three years in the minimum wage to $6.15 per hour.
Major differences still exist in the details of the bankruptcy overhaul passed today and a rival House version approved last year. But lawmakers from both parties and Clinton administration officials expressed confidence today that Congress could produce a compromise bankruptcy bill that Mr. Clinton could sign into law this year. 
 Less certain is how Democrats and Republicans will resolve their differences over the minimum wage. Democrats had wanted the $1 increase be phased in over two years.
The Senate vote today passing the Bankruptcy Reform Act came after Democrats summoned Vice President Al Gore from the campaign trail in Manhattan to break a possible tie vote on a contentious abortion rights amendment to the bill. The measure would bar people convicted of crimes against abortion clinics from using bankruptcy protection to avoid paying civil judgments.
Republicans, who had vigorously opposed the amendment, abandoned their opposition once Mr. Gore took his seat as president of the Senate, letting the measure pass handily. Page A20.
Senators later voted 83 to 14 to approve the overarching legislation that was proposed by the nation's largest banks and credit-card companies, but opposed by consumer and civil rights groups. One reason the outcome was so lopsided was that the campaign contributions and lobbying muscle come mainly from the politically powerful financial community, concentrated in New York.
The banking industry has grown increasingly concerned that too many people with money are taking advantage of the bankruptcy laws and skipping out on mountains of debt. "Despite their ability to pay, wealthier filers walk away from an estimated $3 billion per year in debt," said Edward L. Yingling, chief lobbyist for the American Bankers Association.
The measure imposes new income requirements on people seeking a fresh start by using the nation's debt-forgiveness laws and limits a loophole used by the wealthy to shield their homes. And the bill requires credit-card companies to disclose interest rates and fees more prominently on monthly statements.
"It was time for Congress to close the loopholes that let big spenders walk away from debts and update the code to achieve a healthier balance between consumers and creditors," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican who sponsored the bill.
Negotiators from the Senate will now meet with their counterparts from the House to reconcile competing bills. Last year, the House approved, 313 to 108, a bill with even stricter provisions on debtors. The White House said both versions are unacceptable, calling the House version too harsh and inflexible and the tax breaks attached to the minimum-wage provision in the Senate measure unacceptable.
A spokeswoman for Hillary Rodham Clinton, who in her campaign for the Senate in New York has criticized the bankruptcy legislation for being unfair to women and children, declined to comment today on the Senate's action.
Under the Senate bill, the minimum wage would increase to $6.15 from $5.15 over three years, instead of over two years as Democrats want. Senate Democrats also object to $76 billion in tax breaks over 10 years that Republicans say would help small businesses adjust to the rising minimum wage. Democrats had proposed $29 billion package over 10 years. The House bill does not have a minimum-wage provision.
"The amendment in the bill includes a poorly targeted tax package with tax breaks that are skewed disproportionately to upper income people," said a letter signed by all 45 Senate Democrats to the lawmakers who will negotiate the House-Senate compromise.
The thrust of both House and Senate bills is to make it more difficult for people to discharge their debts. Both measures try to make debtors accept more responsibility by making it more difficult to file Chapter 7 bankruptcies, which allows consumers to discharge unsecured debts that remain after assets are liquidated. Lawmakers aim to make Chapter 13, which requires reorganization of debt under a repayment plan, the bankruptcy of choice.
With Americans filing a record 1.4 million bankruptcies in 1998, Senator Jeff Sessions, an Alabama Republican, said the bill "closes loopholes and ends unfairness in provisions that are totally being abused and making a mockery out of legitimate bankruptcy law."
But critics of the measure, like Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today "the industry's cure is worse than the disease." Bankruptcy filings dropped by 112,000 in 1999 from 1998, Mr. Kennedy said, and the bill's provisions make it more difficult for thousands of debtors who file for bankruptcy because of corporate layoffs and downsizing because of mergers.
At issue in several days of floor debate and outside Capitol Hill today, was whether it is the banks or their customers who are responsible for the growth in bankruptcy filings.
The chairman of the Consumer Federation of America, Howard M. Metzenbaum, a former Democratic senator from Ohio, said the Senate bill "will deny many families in financial crisis a fresh start while spurring more reckless and irresponsible lending by credit-card issuers."
House and Senate negotiators have a tough road ahead. There are several crucial differences between the two bills. Both measures impose a new income requirement. The Senate bill generally says that anyone with the ability to make at least $15,000 in payments over five years would not be able to have their debts forgiven. Under the House bill, the threshold is $6,000 over five years.
The Senate bill is more generous than the House in shielding, or creating "safe harbors" for debtors who make less than the median income in their state or regions.
For Chapter 7 bankruptcy filers, the Senate puts a $100,000 cap on housing equity they can exempt from creditors' motions. The House bill has a cap of $250,000, but allows states to opt out, an important distinction for wealthy bankruptcy filers in Texas and Florida.
Finally, the Senate bill provides new consumer protections, like the disclosures on credit cards. The House protection is more limited and more generic.
Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, said of the bill, "The proverbial small type that hides fees and interest costs will be converted to large font so that consumers can make informed purchases, determine the best repayment schedule and manage family expenses."
While adopting the abortion rights amendment, senators rejected several others, including one offered by Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, that would have prohibited gun makers and dealers from using bankruptcy to escape debts incurred in civil lawsuits.

HEADLINE: A 3-Hour Talk With Putin Leaves Albright Encouraged

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 2

 BODY:
After a month of what she called "psychobabble" from people trying to decipher Russia's new leader, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met Vladimir V. Putin today on his turf and said she was taken with his "can-do approach" and his lack of dogma.
"I found him a very well-informed person, a good interlocutor, obviously a Russian patriot who seeks a normal position with the West," she said of Mr. Putin, who also caught her attention by abandoning note cards that his aides had prepared for him. 
 The three-hour meeting, in Mr. Putin's elegantly refurbished white and green office in the Kremlin, was the first lengthy session that a high-ranking Clinton administration official has had with the acting president since he replaced Boris N. Yeltsin, who resigned on New Year's Eve.
While it seemed that Dr. Albright found the contrast between the erratic Mr. Yeltsin and the crisp Mr. Putin refreshing, the meeting, which ran more than double the time expected, did not produce any breakthroughs in the recently troubled relationship between Washington and Moscow.
The war in Chechnya remained an irritant between the two, with Mr. Putin arguing that Russia had to take military action against the "terrorists" in the republic, she said.
"We did not mince words, either of us, on Chechnya," Dr. Albright told reporters. "I said to him what I said publicly -- that he's riding a tiger."
She added, "I do not think we are any closer to a political solution in Chechnya."
Dr. Albright said she proposed that an international team of experts be allowed to visit Chechnya to determine the needs of people who have been displaced by the fighting and stranded with little heat or shelter. "He seemed receptive," she said.
In addition, he did not reject a proposal that foreign journalists be given accreditation to cover the war, she said. "He seemed to take that on board," she said. "We'll see."
On arms control, Dr. Albright said she was encouraged that Mr. Putin seemed open to the Clinton administration's push to modify the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.
In public, Russian officials have been defiant in rejecting any changes to the treaty. Earlier this week, Mr. Putin alluded to Washington's promoting the "destruction" of the treaty, the key arms control agreement of the cold war.
The administration contends that the threat of long range missiles from nations like North Korea raises the need for a limited national missile defense system, which could be deployed only with changes to the treaty.
Today, Dr. Albright said Mr. Putin showed flexibility on the subject. "He seemed to have an understanding of the new threats and how to deal with them," she said.
Elaborating a little on Dr. Albright's account, a senior administration official said that Mr. Putin "did not deny the new threat." Mr. Putin suggested that the United States and Russia should together develop a "common assessment" of the threat while at the same time "maintaining the fundamental principles of the A.B.M. treaty," the official said.
"I'm not saying he agreed with us," the official said. "But his approach was, 'Let's see if we can accomplish something here.' It's encouraging when a Russian leader adopts flexibility on a position."
Mr. Putin told Dr. Albright that the new makeup of the Russian Parliament since the December elections made it more plausible that the second strategic arms reduction treaty would be ratified. Start II, which mandated a reduction in warheads deployed by each side, was signed by the United States and Russia in 1993 but has languished in Parliament since. One test of Mr. Putin's leadership, administration officials have said, will be whether he follows through on his pledge to see that the treaty is ratified.
In a speech last month, Dr. Albright said she believed that Mr. Putin was "one of the leading reformers" in Russia, based on his activities as deputy mayor of St. Petersburg and then in the Yeltsin administration,
Some experts on Russia have disputed this, but Dr. Albright appeared to be confident of her view after the meeting today.
Aides who accompanied her said Mr. Putin had stressed the need for strengthening the legal system so that the economy could function properly. He understood the need for new bankruptcy laws and for closing loopholes in the tax code, they said.
Unlike Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Putin was attentive to details, listened and took notes, said aides of Dr. Albright who attended the meeting. And Dr. Albright said she also found Mr. Putin attentive and patient.
"I've been in lots of meetings where you could just exchange your cards," she said of the note cards that diplomats often rely on and read from during official meetings like the one today. Instead, Mr. Putin made a joke by holding up the stack of cards that had been given to him but he did not need.
But for the secretary, the real assessments were yet to come. "What is important is to judge him by what he does," she said.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Tennis Tries to Take Root in Unlikely Soil

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: CHITUNGWIZA, Zimbabwe, Feb. 2

 BODY:
There were four tennis courts and a wall to hit against, all surrounded by acres upon acres of poverty. On this oasis of athleticism, there were kids with big smiles hitting forehands, and a few of them had bare feet.
"The bare truth of tennis is that it takes money," said Levar Harper-Griffith, though he stood on these sun-baked hardcourts today as something of a counter to that point. 
 He is 18 years old, a black kid from Fort Greene, Brooklyn, whose mother worked two jobs so she could shepherd him to junior tournaments to play against kids of more affluent means.
Somehow, against the odds and his mother's better judgment, her efforts and his talent landed Harper-Griffith here this week, as a practice partner for John McEnroe's United States Davis Cup team as it prepares for the first-round competition against Zimbabwe on Friday.
The host country has approximately 80,000 whites in a population of nearly 13 million, but its three competing players this weekend are white. Wayne and Byron Black, Zimbabwe's pro tour veterans, are national heroes for their surprising share of Davis Cup success. The Black brothers are also a reminder of the imbalance of wealth distribution here that remains from the colonial years before 1980.
Economic power may not require a big forehand, but Paul Chingoka said that a black tennis star in Zimbabwe would, symbolically, be huge.
"This is the pressure I am getting every day, for us to develop a top black player," said Chingoka, the president of Tennis Zimbabwe. "This is going to happen. In all age groups now, the top players are black children. Tennis is still seen as elitist, but there has been pressure to desegregate."
Five years ago, Tennis Zimbabwe embarked on its plan to privately finance the tennis courts here, in one of the country's highest poverty and population density areas, about a 30-minute drive from Harare.
Chingoka said that 400 to 500 children use the facility, free of charge, every week. Coca-Cola helps underwrite the costs for the right to cover much of the facility with its promotional graffiti. Three years ago, the United States government kicked in for one of the courts.
"The U.S. paid for one court -- big deal," huffed McEnroe, ever the ambassador, after a one-hour clinic in which he was the star attraction.
Gently prodded, he soon went on an anticorporate rant that was overheard by a Tennis Zimbabwe official, who rushed over to say that the soft drink company's largess was more than the "thousand Cokes" that McEnroe surmised.
Longtime Nike pitchman that he is, this probably isn't a potential platform for the political future McEnroe keeps talking about. Yet in his wonderfully roundabout way, he was making an excellent point about tennis and the excessive grandstanding that goes on when officials of the sport in any country get going on the subject of introducing the sport to people who don't traditionally play it.
One of the Tennis Zimbabwe coaches said that many of the local juniors live too far from these courts, or any courts, and must travel for hours to play. The Black brothers, conversely, grew up on a farm outside Harare that had four grass courts installed by their father, Don, a former pro.
McEnroe has always wondered how good he would have been had Harry Hopman, the Australian legend, not dropped out of the sky, onto Long Island. Venus and Serena Williams had a most unusual father in Richard. Andre Agassi, for all his hard work to become tennis's irresistible force, was trained by daddy from the age of 3. Another bare tennis truth is that it takes a willing parent or guiding angel to raise a child who may one day compete in the global village.
A native of Grenada, Bernice Griffith used to carry young Levar along with her racket to neighborhood parks to save money on a sitter. She would play for 55 minutes, then hit with her only child for five.
She never cared much for the wealthier and pushier tennis parents she later spent afternoons with. It was never her intention for Levar to become a real player.
"He loved it, though, and it kept him into his studies because those were the rules," she said from her home in Sarasota, Fla.
When her son grew into a world-ranked junior, she hoped tennis would carry him to a Stanford scholarship. He recently turned pro instead. His mother, not wishing to dwell on a sore point, just keeps reminding him to take pictures, to bring something home, when he calls every night to report from Africa.
Tonight, he said he would tell his mother about those kids he'd hit with on a hardcourt that was a long way from home. Brooklyn was never as forbidding as Chitungwiza. Levar Harper-Griffith understood that the odds for those kids were much greater than his own. He said he would wish them an angel, even if it could be for only five minutes an hour.

PUB-DATE: February 4, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 35; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4598 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.
* denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
'THE AMERICAN CENTURY: ART AND CULTURE, PART 2: 1950-2000," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 13). Filling the museum's six floors, this complicated, conflicted exhibition once more demonstrates the difficulty of mounting sweepingly inclusive exhibitions with no discernible point of view. It displays hundreds of works in dozens of mediums expertly placed in contexts that constantly pull one's attention outward, toward the show's flickering edges: landmark events, famous personalities, banned or controversial books, emblematic snippets of film, song and television and even the ephemeral. But these do not disguise a discouragingly conventional core and the predictable, severely truncated story told by the objects on view. The many great works in the show's first half tend to be overly familiar because they are mostly drawn from the museum's collection. Moving toward the present, the works become weaker, the choices of artists arbitrary, the sense of history increasingly confused and the absence of non-American artists more and more glaring. Ultimately one senses not an "American Century" or even half-century but two decades, the 1950's and 60's, during which American art -- seen in isolation -- held its ground. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, 1 to 8 p.m. Admission: $12.50; $10.50 for students and the elderly (Roberta Smith). 

* "BERLIN METROPOLIS: JEWS AND THE NEW CULTURE, 1890-1918," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through April 23). A show that should be a required course in every New Yorker's education: our cosmopolitan tradition, our appetite for novelty and change spring partly from seeds planted a century ago in Berlin. Though it highlights the part played by Jews, the story it tells could be the story of all outsiders who gravitate toward cities in search of meaning. With more than 200 paintings, stage designs, sheet-music covers, gallery catalogs, photographs, sculptures and other objects, it covers the years when modernism took root: in galleries, publishing houses and theaters, in advanced art from France and Italy, in the rich street life of newspapers, cafes and shop windows. Given the revolutionary temper of the art, the presentation is surprisingly understated, and this adds enormously to the show's power. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., Tuesdays until 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students and the elderly (Herbert Muschamp).
* "BODY ART: MARKS OF IDENTITY," American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100 (through May 29). The theme of this smart, entertaining, globe-spanning show is personal adornment of the most intimate kind, including tattooing, piercing and scarification. The packed installation offers just enough bare multicultural flesh to inspire rubbernecking without actually being an adults-only affair. Most interesting is the way art and anthropology are seamlessly brought together. Greek vases and African hairpins, ethnic postcards and Indian miniatures, Victorian corsets, Amazonian nose plugs and contemporary neo-tribal body work from New York share the limelight. It all makes fascinating sense, and a family-style museum gets to looks sexy in the bargain. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 8:45 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and the elderly; $4.50, children (Holland Cotter).
"KOREAN CERAMICS FROM THE MUSEUM OF ORIENTAL CERAMICS, OSAKA," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through June 4). This beautifully serene exhibition, cloistered within the Met's white-on-white Korean arts gallery, presents 48 objects, all considered masterpieces. For starters there are the exquisitely refined 12th-century Koryo dynasty celadons, coveted even by the Chinese. Then comes the marvelously loose, incipiently modern punchong ware from the early Choson dynasty, which brings out a distinctly Korean penchant for roughness, asymmetry and the unexpected. The show closes with the restrained all-white and blue-and-white porcelain made from the late 15th to early 19th centuries, which return to a Chinese aesthetic but remain subtly apart in their assertive shapes, plain surfaces and the slight irregularities: in short, in their perfect imperfectness. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 8:45 p.m. Suggested admission: $10 for adults; $5 for students and the elderly (Smith).
* CILDO MEIRELES, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through March 5). This prominent Brazilian artist is usually labeled a conceptualist, but he might better be called a producer of magic theater. His enveloping installations are like waking dreams, closer to Magritte than Duchamp. In "Volatile" you walk barefoot through ankle-deep talc to behold a single candle illuminating a cavernous room; it is like a religious experience. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $4, students and the elderly (Ken Johnson).
* "MILLENNIAL DREAMS: VISION AND PROPHECY IN AMERICAN FOLK ART," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 65th Street, (212) 595-9533 (through May 14). With all the Y2K furor it's easy to forget that for most Americans not so long ago the turn of the millennium carried profound spiritual weight: it signified the end of time, the culmination of history, when good and evil faced off and the heavenly kingdom arrived on earth. This intelligent and stirring show explores these ideas in works ranging from the Apocalyptic paintings of the Pentecostal preacher William A. Blayney to Sister Gertrude Morgan's visions of an interracial paradise to Edward Hicks's earthly lions-with-lambs "Peaceable Kingdom." At the center of everything is a set of Shaker chairs, each as plain and elegant as a hymn-book tune and suspended together in space like a stairway to heaven. Just perfect. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Cotter).
* "ONLY THE BEST: MASTERPIECES OF THE CALOUSTE GULBENKIAN MUSEUM, LISBON," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Feb. 27). A Turkish-born Armenian oil millionaire who spent most of his adult life in Europe, Gulbenkian (1869-1955) was as eclectic in his aesthetic tastes as he was focused on quality. He bought, he scrutinized, he de-accessioned, ending up with one of the century's greatest collections, 80 of whose 5,000 objects are in this show. Organized in alternating groups of fine and decorative arts, it nearly covers the cultural glove, with mostly outstanding examples. The decorative holdings include Turkish and Islamic ceramics and textiles, jaw-dropping examples of 18th-century French silver and a selection of jewelry by Rene Lalique. Alternating with these are Egyptian, Greek and Roman antiquities; medieval and Renaissance paintings, including a stunning portrait of a young woman by Ghirlandaio; and one great painting each by Rubens, Fragonard, Manet and Degas. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
* "VISIBLE TRACES: RARE BOOKS AND SPECIAL COLLECTIONS FROM THE NATIONAL LIBRARY OF CHINA," Queens Borough Public Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica, (718) 990-8550 (through March 15). One of the freshest exhibitions of Asian art in New York this season is this gathering of 68 manuscripts, books, maps and ink rubbings installed in the Queens Library Gallery. The chronological span is huge, and although the written word prevails, there are visual delights aplenty. Highlights include a seventh-century Buddhist sutra scroll from the Dunhuang caves; a sweetly tinted manual for raising goldfish, and a vivid pictographic text from the Naxi people, an ethnic minority within China. A free daylong scholarly symposium will be held on Feb. 19, at the Queens Flushing Library; reservations are required: (718) 990-8665 (Cotter).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
"CONTEMPORARY BRITISH CERAMICS," James Graham & Sons, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through Feb. 19). Traditionalism prevails in this selection of more than 50 mostly functional pieces by 16 British ceramicists. Against the understated background of earnest technical and formal refinement, Elizabeth Fritsch's geometrically patterned bottle and vase, Geoffrey Swindell's small, podlike vases with delicate pink openings, and Ursula Morely Price's containers, curiously finned like underwater creatures, stand out (Johnson).
MELVIN EDWARDS, CDS, 76 East 79th Street, (212) 772-9555 (through March 31). Compact assemblages of found metal parts, welded together into dense Cubist compositions, continue the "Lynch Fragments" series that Mr. Edwards began in the 1960's. Comprising elements like chains, padlocks, spikes, horse shoes and hammer heads, these works from the 90's are formally implosive, poetic meditations on a long history of racial violence (Johnson).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
MORRIS GRAVES, "Instruments for a New Navigation," Schmidt-Bingham Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 888-1122 (through Feb. 12). These nautical-looking "instruments," spurred by the cosmic implications of space-age exploration, were made by the painter in 1962 but have not been shown until now. Mostly table-top constructions of cast bronze and steel with marble or alabaster bases, they are disks and plaques that frame mirrors, lenses and thin sheets of materials like mica, glass, brass filings and fossilized iron pyrites. A small chromatic forest of them inhabits the gallery. At best these objects are high decoration, a far cry from the delicate mysteries of Mr. Graves's luminous paintings at their best (Grace Glueck).
DAVID HUNTER, "Self-Portraits," Danese, 41 East 57th Street (212) 223-2227 (through Feb. 12). Each of the extremely elegant Neo-Minimalist paintings by this 34-year-old New York artist consists of an off-white, textured square joined to a velvety black vertical band; razor-incised lines crisscross at the center while faint pencil lines, arced and straight, define the perimeter. Whether they work as self-portraits, as the artist intends, is doubtful, but subtly sensuous formal variations invite close, meditative scrutiny (Johnson).
"VACLAV VYTLACIL AND THE ADVENT OF AMERICAN MODERNISM: 1920-1940," David Findlay Jr. Fine Art, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 486-7660 (through Feb. 12). Through teaching and his own painting, Vytlacil (1892-1984), born in New York to Czech immigrant parents, played a role in promoting European modernism in the 1930's and, as a founding member of the American Abstract Artists, pushed actively for the recognition of home-grown American abstraction. Early on his work was inspired by Cezanne through Hans Hofmann; later he was influenced by Matisse and Picasso. The strongest works here are his abstractions of the later 30's and early 40's, biomorphic and geometric forms deftly melded into dynamic compositions. They seem on the verge of Abstract Expressionism, but the development of that movement fell to more muscular talents (Glueck).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
CECILY BROWN, Gagosian Gallery, 136 Wooster Street, (212) 228-2828 (through Feb. 19). Something of a cautionary tale, the third solo show of this highly visible young English painter indicates that her public career has outdistanced her artistic development. On canvases that seem big for bigness's sake, she highlights blizzards of energetic yet vacuous brushwork with hints of bodies and erotic activity. The results are best when taken as Conceptual Art objects, particularly as feminine sendups of Abstract Expressionist angst and posturing. But naughty bits not withstanding, the majority of these paintings are uninteresting from any distance. The artist's earlier work, which featured orgy-crazed bunnies, was merely promising, but it had a raunchy painterly abandon to call its own (Smith).
 GEORGE DEEM, Nancy Hoffman, 429 West Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 966-6676 (through Feb. 16). Since the early 1970's Mr. Deem has been appropriating and more or less cleverly manipulating images from Vermeer and other famous artists. In this small show he offers Vermeer copies in which he has omitted the figures, leaving oddly familiar, empty rooms (Johnson).
* KEITH EDMIER AND RICHARD PHILLIPS, Friedrich Petzel, 26 Wooster Street, (212) 334-9466 (through Feb. 12). Mr. Edmier presents a haunting life-size sculpture of his pregnant mother cast in translucent pink plastic. She wears a pink suit copied from the one worn by Jacqueline Kennedy on the day her husband was assassinated, and it reveals her translucent abdomen, which holds the artist as a young fetus. Mr. Phillips's pencil drawing of a Christlike George Harrison, copied from an old Playboy magazine illustration, brings out the Virgin Mary in Mr. Edmier's sculpture (Johnson).
JAMES FEE, Yancey Richardson, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-1255 (through Feb. 19). Previously known for romantic photographs of the industrial landscape, Mr. Fee here turns to the female nude. In these blurred, solarized, toned, cut-up and otherwise aggressively manipulated pictures, shadowy models run, dance or tumble in outdoor settings. There is a feeling of dreamlike action, but the pictures seem overly caught up in technical processes (Johnson).
CHRIS HIPKISS, Cavin-Morris, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 226-3768 (through Feb. 26). This self-taught English artist's vast, intensely detailed visions of nature under the baleful dominion of industry -- with pretty androgynous warriors clad in sexy outfits appearing here and there -- suggest the drive of a genuinely offbeat imagination struggling to come to grips with powerful psychological tensions. He conceives of his epic, ongoing narrative as a story of war between masculine culture and feminine nature. Whatever they mean, they are fascinating (Johnson).
RAYMOND PETTIBON, David Zwirner, 43 Greene Street, (212) 966-9074 (through Feb. 12). Mr. Pettibon continues to practice his signature formula with nonchalant perfection. To poetic and humorous effect, he loosely copies found images onto paper and neatly adds words from sources like the Bible, Proust or Charles Manson. One piece shows Jesus suffering on the cross with the words, "Truth is I have been in such a state of mind as to read over my lines and hate them" (Johnson).
BEATRICE RIESE, A.I.R., 40 Wooster Street, (212) 966-0799 (through Feb. 12). Ms. Riese began her long and distinguished career as an art student in Paris in the 1930's, and later worked in New York as a textile designer. This retrospective of her intricately patterned grid paintings, beginning with one from 1969, includes oils on canvas, watercolors and most recently rows of angular alphabetic forms finely inked on paper. Throughout, the artist's play with repetition and variation, flickering light and muted colors keeps the eye engaged (Johnson).
JENNY SCOBEL, Locus, 594 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212) 334-6424 (through Feb. 12). Working with graphite and wax on gessoed panels, Ms. Scobel creates mysterious portraits of a certain imaginary, pretty young woman posed in front of old-time animated cartoons. It might be interesting to see her fascination with this character extended beyond portraiture (Johnson).
IONEL TALPAZAN AND EDWARD NAGRODZKI, American Primitive, 594 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212) 966-1530 (through Feb. 12). Obsessed with U.F.O.'s, Mr. Talpazan, a Romanian immigrant who lives in New York, makes powerfully abstracted, vividly colored diagrammatic pictures of flying saucers. More amazingly inventive than obsessive, Nagrodzki (1915-1999) produced amusing, eccentric sculptures like a grinning snake made from hinged-together coconuts (Johnson).
"(UN)RESOLVED," Rosenberg & Kaufman, 115 Wooster Street, (212) 431-4838 (through Feb. 12). The ambiguous title is appropriate for this miscellaneous group exhibition. Among the more interesting works are exquisitely made drawings on music-composition paper by Andrew Topolski, a soberly sensuous rectilinear composition made of red commercial primer paints on a sheet of steel by Merrill Wagner, and an abstract canvas with a curiously raised, netlike grid of green paint by Vadim Katznelson (Johnson).
ADRIANA VAREJAO, Lehmann Maupin, 39 Greene Street, (212) 965-0753 (through Feb. 12). The best piece in this Brazilian artist's second New York show is an illusionistic, three-dimensional painting: what appears to be a rectangular section of European-style blue-and-white tiles has torn and slipped like skin, revealing an underlying stew of bloody entrails. It is funny like a good special effects event in a horror movie, and it is also a visceral metaphor about terror underlying the veneer of colonialist civilization (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
HARRY BERTOIA AND TODD EBERLE, Robert Miller, 524 West 26th Street, (212) 980-5454 (through Feb. 26). "Sounding Sculptures" is by Bertoia (1915-1978), who was best known as a furniture designer for Knoll International but also made hand-welded copper and bronze sculptures that tinkle like chimes and resound like bells when struck. He created an entire orchestra of such instruments and composed music for them that seems perfectly attuned to New Age ears. Mr. Emberle's photos, titled "Wired," are close-ups of historic hardware from the Computer History Museum at NASA's Ames Base in California (Cotter).
 MARTIN CREED, Gavin Brown's Enterprise, 436 West 15th Street, (212) 627-5258 (through Feb. 12). Two years ago this winning British conceptual artist packed the gallery with colored balloons. This time he fills it with darkness and light. His "Work No. 127, The Lights Going On and Off" is just what it says: a row of overhead spots flashing on and off at five-second intervals in an otherwise empty room (Cotter).
JEFF ELROD, Pat Hearn, 530 West 22nd Street, (212) 727-7377 (through Feb. 26). The abstract forms in Mr. Elrod's clean, cool paintings are digitally derived from random doodles executed by mouses and then printed out and transferred to canvas with razor-sharp precision. "Mythic Proportion" looks like a cross between a Clyfford Still peak and an Ellsworth Kelly pod. The super-streamlined "Delete Yourself" consists of a big Dionysian scribble that never quite lets loose (computers never do), set on a monochromatic Matisse-flat field (Cotter).
TIM GARDNER, 303 Gallery, 525 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-1121 (through Feb. 12). This young Canadian artist makes a United States solo debut with dozens of snapshotlike watercolors of teenage boys doing the uncouth, spacey things that some boys do: streaking, surfing, climbing mountains, staring slack-jawed into space. The results, many of them self-portraits, seem complicated until you think of them as updated Winslow Homers, in which virtuosic execution and just-the-facts nostalgia disguise slow-acting uncertainties (Cotter).
MICHELLE GRABNER, Ten in One Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 604-9660 (through Feb. 12). The grids in Ms. Grabner's table-top-size paintings, made up of little dots and strokes of enamel paint, are far removed from classic geometric abstraction. With their soft colors and off-kilter sway, they point to humbler decorative patterns found on baby blankets and dish towels, the raw material of a domestic sublime (Cotter).
 "LUX," Lucas Schoormans, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3159 (through Feb. 19). As its title suggests, this good group show in a new Chelsea gallery is about luminosity. It centers on a utopian Dan Flavin neon sculpture, "Monument for V. Tatlin" (1964), and radiates out from there with work by Alex Katz, Karin Sander, Bing Wright and Liz Rideal (Cotter).
DEBORAH MESA-PELLY, "Safety," Lombard-Freid Fine Arts, 531 West 26th Street, (212) 967-8040 (through Feb. 12). Ms. Mesa-Pelly is one of several young artists creating cryptic, psychologically charged narratives for the camera. Female protagonists appear in dreamlike settings, which Ms. Mesa-Pelly constructs by hand. The romantic, anxious scenarios that result are a mix of Nancy Drew, Emily Bronte and "Roswell," pitting innocence against experience, home against the world (Cotter).
 RICHARD SERRA, "Switch," Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, (212) 228-2828 (through Feb. 26). Big art doesn't get much bigger than this 28-ton, 13-foot-high sculpture multipart by Mr. Serra, installed in Gagosian's new hangarlike gallery. Mr. Serra's work has been called oppressive, but visitors seem to be having fun with this one. It's theater, epic, expensive, flawlessly produced (Cotter).
 
Other Galleries
 
VALENTINA DUBASKY, Cheryl Pelavin, 13 Jay Street, between Hudson and Greenwich Streets, TriBeCa, (212) 925-9424 (through March 4). In semi-abstract landscape paintings with heavily built-up surfaces, Ms. Dubasky, who has been exhibiting regularly in New York for 20 years, layers fanciful plant forms over blurry, patchwork fields. The best, as in the swamplike scene of "Ancient Futures," have an appealing combination of material richness and shimmering light (Johnson).
"FROM THIS WORLD TO THE NEXT," Jewish Approaches to Illness, Death and the Afterlife, Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway at 122nd Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 678-8000 (through April 12). The seminary houses the largest repository of Jewish manuscripts, books and prints in the Western Hemisphere. This stirring, modestly scaled thematic exhibition on death and immortality gives a hint of its resources. Installed on three floors, it includes 18th- and 19th-century prints of funerals, Renaissance manuscripts on the much-debated topic of the afterlife, and memorial books recording individual deaths and the names of vanished communities. The library closes at 3 p.m. on Fridays and is closed on Saturdays. (Cotter).
 
Last Chance
 
CHRIS FINLEY, Jack Tilton, 49 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 941-1775 (through tomorrow). If Chris Finley's painting had a soundtrack, it would be some kind of comical shrieking. Wedding Cubism and Pop, he uses high-keyed sign painter's enamels in moods that range from manic goofiness to hysteria. The feeling of catastrophic hilarity is very much of the moment (Johnson).
DAVID HUMPHREY, McKee, 745 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 688-5951 (through tomorrow). A comic, surrealistic eroticism is grounded by Mr. Humphrey in lushly materialistic painting. Outlined cartoon style or realized as blurry photographic images, male and female figures morph and merge on opalescent fields, yielding dreamily layered, pastoral visions at once graceful and funky (Johnson).
"INSTRUMENT OF CHANGE: JIM SCHOPPERT RETROSPECTIVE 1947-1992," National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3820 (through Sunday). Schoppert (1947-1992) was born in Alaska of American Indian and German descent, and his work bridges European modernism and traditional Northwest Indian art. His European models (Miro, Brancusi) are fairly easy to spot, as are the Indian forms that he drew on. What's moving is the diplomatic way he brought them all together so that they both yield and retain their distinctive identities. The synthesizing process is most successful in several monumental polychrome wall sculptures carved from wood, with deeply cut designs and twilight colors. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Free (Cotter).
* "EASTMAN JOHNSON: PAINTING AMERICA," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Sunday). If he wasn't the most exciting painter, Johnson (1824-1906) was a solid one whose mix of corny stereotype and original observation was heavily influenced by 17th-century Dutch genre painting. His narrative focus encompassed rural and domestic life, women, children and old men, and a group of important African-American subjects. His boldest endeavor before and during the Civil War was painting antislavery scenes, like the powerful "Ride for Liberty: The Fugitive Slaves" (circa 1862). After the war he became noted for his domestic interiors and scenes of rural life. This show is a worthy tribute to an artist who fused home-grown talent with European training to convey a well-varnished vision of 19th-century America. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (first Saturday of each month, 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.) Admission: $4; $2 for students; $1.50 for the elderly (Glueck).
"LA LA," Tricia Collins, 83 Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 226-1861 (through tomorrow). This playful four-artist show offers a quirky mix of representation and abstraction. It includes Michele Basora's paintings of chubby, big-eyed little girls; swirling psychedelic doodles by Layla Lozano; Jason Rosenberg's jewel-like compositions of stripes, rectangles and targets; and best of all Warren Isensee's buoyant, perfectly patterned arrangements of crisply painted pastel-colored ovoids (Johnson).
* JOHN SINGER SARGENT, "Portraits of the Wertheimer Family," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Sunday). A reunion of a dozen Sargent portraits commissioned by the wealthy Jewish art dealer Asher Wertheimer. The ensemble hung in the family's London home, but the bequest of nine of them to the National Portrait Gallery in the 1920's aroused the ire of British worthies, who felt they didn't belong in a museum devoted to exalted Britons. Most of the portraits were eventually consigned to storage at the Tate Gallery. The show's catalog raises interesting issues like the position of Jews in English society and to what degree Sargent stressed his friends' Jewishness, given the slight edge of caricature and stereotype that he conferred on many of his portrait subjects. Most of the paintings give a wonderful account of Sargent's bold brushwork and his talent for finding and projecting his subjects' individuality. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).
ROBERT THIELE, M-13, 72 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 925-3007 (through tomorrow). Mr. Thiele continues to produce small, monochromatic shaped paintings. His boxy rounded rectangles or circles and other eccentric shapes have an appealingly clunky, near-sculptural presence and delicately nuanced surfaces. They look best gathered into groups, however; this exhibition seems underpopulated (Johnson).
B. WURTZ, "Buttons, Part I," Feature, 530 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 675-7772 (through today). Like a cross between Kandinsky and Richard Tuttle, B. Wurtz's painting seems both cosmic and mundane. On loose, raw canvases he has painted circles and straight lines with dry economy and strategically sewn buttons to the fabric. At first these works seem too unfinished and too slight to sustain interest, but they have a cheeky intelligence and a material presence that can grow on you (Johnson).

PUB-DATE: February 4, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 29; Column 6; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1898 words

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Not Easy to Like, but Impossible to Forget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN; "Walker Evans," is at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through May 14.

 BODY:
HIS general note is lyrical understanding of the street, trained observation of it, special feeling for patina, eye for revealing detail, over all of which is thrown a poetry."
That's Walker Evans, writing in 1931 about Atget. Later, lecturing in 1964 about Atget and also about Mathew Brady, another hero, he projected a group of the penny picture postcards he had collected since he was a child. 
 "Can you imagine anything more?" he asked his audience about his anonymous little hand-colored images of small-town main streets and trolley cars. "A conglomeration of hideous things that come together by casting a spell of -- I can't call it beauty, but of a certain kind of silent poetry."
Twice, poetry. That was what Evans was after in his own photographs, a poetry that you couldn't call beauty, not conventional beauty anyway, an art inspired by vernacular subjects and aspiring to the natural dignity of the street. As the Met's excellent new retrospective of him reiterates, to the end of his life (he died in 1975, at 72), Evans had this goal, which in his case became a distinctly American project.
Accounts of him during his last years make him out to be an ironic, oblique conversationalist, funny, insecure, vulnerable, weakened. His best work was years behind him. He had trouble understanding why people were no longer interested in what he was doing, but he had been out of the spotlight for a long time. Some people thought he was already dead when he had his last retrospective in 1971.
The list of people he couldn't abide or about whom he made nasty, unbecoming cracks is well known. About Ralph Steiner, the photographer who generously offered to teach him photography, Evans commented, "He is a bitter little Jew, intelligent, whose limitations are skillfully blurred."
Evans despised Victorian proprieties, which he associated with his parents. He hated all do-gooders and ideologues, whether they were limousine liberals or far-right-wingers, and he especially disliked "artistes."
"Too much exposure to art is not very good for an artist," he told his students. He couldn't stand the idea that he might be linked with somebody like Alfred Stieglitz, who represented what might be called official bohemianism, which to him was as bad as the old academy.
As Douglas Eklund puts it in the catalog for the Metropolitan's show, "In all of those circles Evans the man moved quite comfortably but with a residue of free-floating negativity; the uniquely subdued, dispassionate tone (and some might argue the chilling effect) of his photographs came from this sustained and critical refusal to join."
The Met's survey, organized by Jeff L. Rosenheim, a curator in the museum's photography department, sweeps skillfully through six decades of Evans's career, with 175 vintage photographs and other objects and documents. The stress on vintage photographs means that there's a patina to his early work, now 70 or so years old, which is an interesting counterpoint to the astringency.
The documents and objects come from Evans's archives, which the Met owns. They include "Pictures of the Time," a rarity of sorts: a splenetic, witty scrapbook of clippings from newspapers and magazines that Evans compiled with the writer James Agee. It consisted of what they hated about commercial photography and photojournalism, like celebrity portraits and soft-core bathing-beauty advertisements, but also what they liked, like crime scene photos and ethnographic documents: all straight, unpretentious pictures. You see clearly what Evans became when you look at what he did and didn't admire.
There are also copies of Fortune magazine, where he was a longtime editor, with Evans's photo spreads in them, a slide show of his great color pictures of railroad cars, which he did for Fortune, and postcards and old road signs.
From the beginning, Evans was fascinated by lettered signs, and he emphasized the obvious connection between language and photography: they were two surrogates of reality, words and pictures each being meaningful but incomplete and often misleading by themselves. Signs, like photographs, were to him specifically a form of poetry, and his photographs of isolated words or letters read as a kind of abstract language.
He collected road signs, even pilfered them: he would drive around rural Connecticut with students who would unscrew the signs he liked most when the coast was clear.
This is the first complete retrospective of Evans. The 1971 overview, at the Museum of Modern Art, came before he worked with the Polaroid SX-70, with which he took his last photographs. Those are minor pictures, mostly, but intriguing. A mass-market gadget given to him and a few other prominent photographers by Polaroid to help publicize its product, the SX-70 gave Evans a new lease on life.
It spit out palm-size glossy images in saturated colors. It was for casual snapshot portraits. Evans had trouble wielding bigger cameras by then. Now he could work again, and no doubt he relished working with a tool as mundane and populist as the SX-70. It involved photography at its most basic level: point and shoot. He had always tried to show what was distinguished in what other people overlooked, and now he was making art, or at least trying to, with a tool that sophisticated photographers generally wouldn't take notice of.
He took 2,600 pictures with the new camera, lots of fish-eye close-ups of friends, and especially of young women he was trying to impress, but also tightly cropped abstract vignettes that reprise basic themes from the 1920's and 30's, now in the SX-70's garish colors, which he clearly embraced. The late street-sign pictures are derivative and unremarkable. But one Polaroid recalls his best work: a junked pink Ford in the weeds, the grill a toothy smile. Typical of Evans, the car is a ready-made American beauty.
We see basically what was already clear before this exhibition: that American documentary photography is synonymous with Evans. It is built on his belligerent independence (this was his most truly American trait), his elevation of the everyday, his open eye, his mordant concentration and deliberate organization, his slow, razor-sharp, deadpan gaze.
This was also something particularly American about him: his lean, laconic scrutiny of the world. His pictures are called elegies, but they're elegies devoid of nostalgia. They are difficult to like at first, they're so austere. Gradually one can be moved by them because their construction -- often head on, seemingly uncomplicated, sometimes as if the images are not really even composed -- comes across as plain, eternal truth. Evans photographed disappearing national icons, like old Model T's and gingerbread houses, but no matter what his subject was, his pictures always connoted the world out of time. Not just time stopped, which is the condition imposed by all photographs, but objects held in a kind of supreme suspension.
Disorder is suddenly made to seem like order, the timeworn and commonplace looks extraordinary, and everything briefly snaps into focus. Call it a natural state of grace, which gives inherent dignity to all the ephemeral subjects Evans shot.
You see his elegance of vision in his famous pictures of sharecroppers' and tenant farmers' cabins in Alabama for "Let Us Now Praise Famous Men." These may be even better than his portraits of the Burroughs and Tingle families. The portraits are ingrained in the American psyche basically because Evans, in a photographic style as spare as James Agee's writing was the opposite, denied us what we expected: he short-circuited pity for those people by cutting out the charm and anecdote. We stare level-eyed, and as if without any distance from his subjects, who gaze -- squint really -- at us as if demanding to know who are we to look at them. Lionel Trilling, observing the portrait of Allie Mae Burroughs, put it this way: she "simply refuses to be an object of your 'social consciousness,' " he wrote. "She refuses to be an object at all."
Still, the cabin interiors may be closer to the core of Evans's achievement, because in essence he was always a still-life photographer, even when he was photographing street scenes or people. Still life implies an art of inanimate objects, of objects made into archetypes. Evans constantly implied that the things and people in his pictures had symbolic roles. They never seemed to exist in the here and now, just through Evans's lens.
So the few spare objects that the Burroughs family possessed -- table, towel, jug, bowl, kerosene lamp -- as in a Vermeer, are each given a separate weight, purity and value. Together they nonetheless look isolated and self-contained. No doubt this quality was an expression of Evans's own feeling of separateness.
His history is familiar: born in St. Louis to an advertising executive and a housewife; boarding school in the East; rebellious adolescence; Williams College briefly; literary aspirations; Paris in the mid-1920's, too shy to meet Joyce; makes photographs in the 20's in an abstract, Cubist-inspired mode; documents the South in the 30's for the Resettlement Administration of the Department of Agriculture, then with Agee; "American Photographs" show at the Museum of Modern Art in 1938 establishes his early fame.
It can be useful to read Evans, not just see his pictures. As a writer he was lean and fastidious. The second edition of "Let Us Now Praise Famous Men" has just been republished with his brief memoir of Agee. Evans managed in prose something of what he achieved in his pictures: concision, clarity, no pretense, dry wit. Critics and historians, starting with Lincoln Kirstein in the essay he wrote 62 years ago for "American Photographs," have stressed Evans's literary connections for good reason.
Hemingway's writing showed him the virtues of economy. Cummings showed him how to make fun of stuffy social conventions and vapid consumerism. Eliot showed how to express emotion in a chilly, oblique style, which came naturally to Evans.
The result was a modern visual grammar of forms that, in picture after picture, resists easy absorption. They take time to sink in. The more we look at an Evans photograph, the more his language elaborates itself through essential details: the sliver of light through the shutters of the plantation house in Louisiana; the lovers at Coney Island whose forms echo the column and tower behind them; the light reflected above the man in the subway, who is absorbed in thought, his face in shadow; the menu of the sandwich shop that we read over the shoulder of the cook and his pal; the three men outside the barber shop in Vicksburg, Miss., serendipitously posed.
It is curious that such a prickly man could have made such moving, ultimately optimistic pictures. But maybe that's why they're moving, because sentiment is checked by dispassion. The world is a beautiful place, Evans keeps telling us -- often despite itself.
In one of his best-known photographs, of rain-slicked Main Street in Saratoga Springs, the street's slow arc is picked out, as if in black outlines, by parallel rows of identical parked cars. The geometry of the scene is neatly complicated by a scrim of Dutch elms in silhouette. America is freshly born. Everything is complete. Nothing is hackneyed or maudlin, just straight. Typical Evans.

E29); "Couple at Coney Island, New York" (1928), by Walker Evans, from his retrospective at the Met. (Metropolitan Museum of Art) (pg. E31)
