SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 23; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2146 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 8.
 
Now Playing
 
 * "ALL ABOUT MY MOTHER," starring Cecilia Roth, Marisa Paredes, Antonia San Juan and Penelope Cruz. Directed by Pedro Almodovar (R, 101 minutes; in Spanish with English subtitles). A whole new order of Almodovar extravaganza. The antic fizz and theatrical exaggeration of his earlier work have blossomed into a newly sophisticated style, one that is far more wise and deeply felt. Lovingly dedicated to actresses who have played actresses, this film weaves its own soap opera around "A Streetcar Named Desire" and tells of splendidly resilient women; Mr. Almodovar has aptly described his material as "screwball drama." Rich and entertaining, this story celebrates the power of artifice and impersonation to transcend ordinary truth. The irrepressible Ms. San Juan, a Spanish nightclub performer, plays a transsexual named Agrado and is the film's biggest treat (Janet Maslin). 

"EYE OF THE BEHOLDER," starring Ewan McGregor and Ashley Judd. Directed by Stephan Elliott (R, 105 minutes). Mr. McGregor is a British surveillance expert and Ms. Judd the serial-killing femme fatale he falls in love with (while observing her kill a boyfriend) in this ludicrous psycho-thriller. As Mr. McGregor's character, known only as the Eye, follows the object of his obsession from city to city, the movie tries futilely to capture some of the mystique of "Vertigo." But the film, by the director best known for "The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert," is so garish, disjointed and incoherent that it feels like an extended music video posing as a movie (Stephen Holden).
"FANTASIA/2000," with James Levine and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and introductions by Steve Martin, Bette Midler, Mr. Levine, Itzhak Perlman, James Earl Jones, Angela Lansbury, Quincy Jones and Penn and Teller. Various directors (G, 75 minutes). The millennial version of Disney's 1940 groundbreaking fusion of animation and classical music includes seven new segments and keeps one from the original film (the wonderful "Sorcerer's Apprentice," starring Mickey Mouse). Despite the science-fiction title and the Imax-size screen on which it is shown, "Fantasia/2000" is more backward-looking than futuristic. The two best segments are "Rhapsody in Blue," a witty Manhattan-in-the-Jazz-Age homage to the caricaturist Al Hirschfeld set to the music of Gershwin, and the finale (set to Stravinsky's "Firebird" Suite), in which a cometlike sprite whooshes around the globe explosively creating, destroying and renewing the planet's life forms. Celebrity introductions lend the film the feel of a deluxe corporate promotion. At the Sony Imax Theater, Broadway at 68th Street, (Holden).
"GIRL, INTERRUPTED," starring Winona Ryder and Angelina Jolie. Directed by James Mangold (R, 120 minutes). Except for being several years too old for the role, Winona Ryder, an actress who oozes high-strung intelligence, is ideally cast as Susanna Kaysen, a college-age girl who lands in a Massachusetts mental institution in 1967 after a halfhearted suicide attempt. (The movie is based on Ms. Kaysen's memoir.) The period details are perfect, and Ms. Ryder has the courage to make her character a pain in the neck. But the small, introspective movie is nearly stolen by Ms. Jolie as a charismatic, brutally truth-telling sociopath who becomes Susanna's best friend (Holden).
"THE GREEN MILE," starring Tom Hanks, Michael Clarke Duncan, David Morse, Doug Hutchison, Sam Rockwell and Bonnie Hunt. Written and directed by Frank Darabont (R, 180 minutes). In adapting the death row drama that Stephen King wrote in multiple installments, the director of "The Shawshank Redemption" could have managed more economy and fewer talky bits of business around the cellblock. Still, this lengthy film is vivid and well played. Smooth ensemble acting builds up to the discovery that a gigantic condemned man (Mr. Duncan) is a prisoner with very special abilities, which gives the film its mixture of religious overtones and mild horror. Mr. Hanks, as a wry Southern prison guard, is so unaffectedly good that it's redundant to say so (Maslin).
"HOLY SMOKE," starring Kate Winslet and Harvey Keitel. Directed by Jane Campion (R, 95 minutes). Having roamed so gorgeously through North Africa as a young hippie mother in "Hideous Kinky," Ms. Winslet this time appears in India as Ruth Barron, a headstrong young Australian seeking enlightenment. Eventually Ruth's mother coaxes her home, where a "cult exiter" named P. J. (Mr. Keitel) is waiting to wean Ruth away from her Indian guru. But as the film moves from its early mix of rapture and humor into this more serious, confrontational stage, it runs into trouble. It doesn't help that Ms. Winslet's obvious strength and beauty leave Mr. Keitel's P. J. looking overmatched (Maslin).
* "THE HURRICANE," starring Denzel Washington. Directed by Norman Jewison (R, 120 minutes). The life story of Hurricane Carter, a middleweight contender who spent nearly 20 years in prison for a triple murder he didn't commit, is a big, schmaltzy ballad of a movie redeemed by Mr. Washington's moving, bone-deep portrayal of the boxer from Paterson, N.J. But the movie plays fast and loose with the facts, giving far too much credit to the members of a Canadian commune who took up Mr. Carter's cause and all but eliminating his heroic co-defendant, John Artis, from the story. And the minor characters are either saints or monsters. Yet the story of a man heroically fighting his demons and winning his freedom is still inspiring (Holden).
"ISN'T SHE GREAT," starring Bette Midler, Nathan Lane, Stockard Channing, David Hyde Pierce and John Cleese. Directed by Andrew Bergman (R, 90 minutes). In this bio-pic, Ms. Midler portrays the author Jacqueline Susann, who took the lurid pulp genre to a new, sweaty level. No one is more suited to playing a tease of a diva than Ms. Midler, who can wring more comedy out of operatic self-absorption than anyone else. And Mr. Lane, who plays Irving Mansfield, Susann's husband, promoter and biggest fan, is a spark plug: his voice shows up before he does. Yet in this adaptation of the material, Susann's life is flattened, made campy and cute. Sly hostility seems to be a facet of the screenwriter Paul Rudnick's talent. But Mr. Rudnick and Mr. Bergman have so defanged "Isn't She Great" that it's like watching a sketch from the old "Carol Burnett Show" that has mildewed (Elvis Mitchell).
"THE LIFE AND TIMES OF HANK GREENBERG," directed by Aviva Kempner (not rated, 90 minutes). This unabashed valentine to baseball's Hall of Fame slugger demonstrates how little mankind and some of its sports figures have advanced since the 1930's and 40's and reminds us how the persistence of bigotry stains a nation founded on ideals like religious tolerance. The 30's and 40's were the heyday of Greenberg, a son of Jewish immigrants who came out of the Bronx to star with the Detroit Tigers, threaten Babe Ruth's home run record and become the first man to win most valuable player awards at two positions, first base and left field. In blazing his trail into the Hall of Fame, the tall, handsome Greenberg became a target of anti-Semites. But his stardom, his innate decency, his work ethic and his World War II record made him a beacon of hope to many Jews. Taken as a whole, the documentary is faithful to its title, valuable as history and resonant with meaning for today (Lawrence Van Gelder).
"MAGNOLIA," starring Tom Cruise, Melinda Dillon, Philip Seymour Hoffman, William H. Macy, Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly and Jason Robards. Written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson (R, 180 minutes). In "Magnolia" the colossally talented Mr. Anderson has set up an artfully orchestrated symphony of intersecting L.A. stories, with many of the cast members from his "Boogie Nights" assembled to form a charismatic ensemble. The movie is saved from its own worst ideas by the intimacy of the performances. Its single biggest surprise is Tom Cruise in the role of a strutting, obscenity-spouting cult figure named Frank Mackey (Maslin).
"PLAY IT TO THE BONE," starring Woody Harrelson, Antonio Banderas and Lolita Davidovich. Directed by Ron Shelton (R, 124 minutes). This screwball sports comedy stars Mr. Harrelson (with a shaved head) and Mr. Banderas as fading middleweight boxers and best friends summoned at the last minute to fight each other as the opening act for a Las Vegas heavyweight bout. The formulaic road movie follows them with their pal and mutual ex-girlfriend (Ms. Davidovich) on their wisecracking way from Los Angeles to Las Vegas, where they fight a brutal match. The dialogue has sass, and the filmmaker's jaundiced vision of the professional boxing world is very knowing, but the relationships don't track (Holden).
* "THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY," starring Matt Damon, Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow, Cate Blanchett and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Written and directed by Anthony Minghella (R, 135 minutes). There are diabolically smart surprises wherever you care to look in this glittering thriller. Proving that the brilliance of "The English Patient" was no fluke, Mr. Minghella shapes a hypnotic, sensually charged adaptation of Patricia High smith's fascinatingly reptilian murder story. The traffic-stopping cast includes Mr. Damon as the dangerous chameleon of the title and, in a star-making role, the English actor Jude Law as a rich dilettante who exerts a homoerotic magnetism. Ms. Paltrow plays the odd woman out with the shrewdness of a fine character actress, while Ms. Blanchett makes the delirious most of her role as a needy American post-debutante. As the story's odious playboy-snob, Mr. Hoffman is scene-stealingly wonderful. Gorgeously photographed in Italy by John Seale (Maslin).
* "TITUS," starring Anthony Hopkins, Jessica Lange, Alan Cumming, Harry Lennix and Jonathan Rhys Meyers. Directed by Julie Taymor (R, 160 minutes). Ms. Taymor, the theater director and puppeteer who created transfixing stage pictures in "The Lion King" and "Juan Darien," has turned Shakespeare's goriest tragedy, "Titus Andronicus," into a powerful contemplation of murderous revenge enacted throughout history. Mr. Hopkins is ghoulishly funny and tragic as the title character, whose political stupidity sets in motion a devastating chain reaction of killing, torture and retaliation. Ms. Lange is Tamora, the captured Goth empress who strikes back. Although the movie's British theatrical and American film acting styles don't mesh, Ms. Taymor's vision is realized with a shattering force in time-traveling imagery that blends ancient Rome with Mussolini's Italy and contemporary cyberpunk flash (Holden).
 * "TOPSY-TURVY," starring Allan Corduner and Jim Broadbent. Directed by Mike Leigh (R, 161 minutes). Mr. Leigh's grandly entertaining "Topsy-Turvy" is one of those films that create a mix of erudition, pageantry and delectable acting opportunities, much as "Shakespeare in Love" did last year. Instead of a love-struck young playwright, it presents the curiously matched personalities of the librettist William Schwenk Gilbert and the composer Arthur Sullivan in the midst of a robust, knowing, frequently hilarious look at the musical theater over which they held sway (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
"FREDERICK WISEMAN: AMERICAN FILMMAKER." The police officer's lot and juvenile justice are in the light of the projector this weekend at the Walter Reade Theater, where the Film Society of Lincoln Center, in association with Human Rights Watch International, is offering a complete retrospective of the nonfiction works of Frederick Wiseman. At 1 and 5:30 p.m. today and again at 6:45 p.m. tomorrow, the attraction will be "Law and Order" (1969). This 81-minute documentary surveys the wide range of work the police are asked to perform and its affect on their behavior. A panel discussion on "Law and Order" is to take place at 7:30 p.m. today. At 2:45 and 9 p.m. today and at 4 and 8:30 p.m. tomorrow, the attraction will be "Juvenile Court" (1973). This 144-minute documentary shows the complex variety of cases before the Memphis Juvenile Court, illustrating conflicting issues, the range and limits of choices available to the court, the psychology of offenders and the constitutional and procedural questions involved in administration. The series continues through Feb. 24 at the Walter Reade Theater, at Lincoln Center. Admission: $9; $5 for Film Society members and children; $4.50 for the elderly at weekday matinees. Information and screening times: (212) 875-5600 (Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.
 
Opera
 
"LES CONTES D'HOFFMANN," Metropolitan Opera. One of the Met's more satisfying productions meets the splendid Bryn Terfel, who will take on the Offenbach opera's four deep roles single-handedly. Also with Ruth Ann Swenson and Neil Shicoff. James Levine conducts. Metropolitan Opera House. Tonight at 8. Tickets, $26 to $225. Sold out but returns may be available. (212) 362-6000. (Bernard Holland). 

"LA TRAVIATA," Metropolitan Opera. The tasteless, cluttered, grossly overdone Franco Zeffirelli production of Verdi's "Traviata," which was drubbed by critics when it was introduced last season, is back, unabashed and unchanged, complete with the dancing cows in the Act III party scene. But the young soprano Cristina Gallardo-Domas, who sings Violetta, is worth checking out. Though last month when the production opened she was suffering from a sinus problem, Ms. Gallardo-Domas still brought a vibrant voice, sensitivity and passion to the role. The tenor Roberto Aronica was a rather unsubtle Alfredo. And, good news, the baritone Thomas Hampson takes over the role of Germont for three performances starting Saturday afternoon. Metropolitan Opera House, Tomorrow at 1 p.m. Sold out, but returns may be available. (212) 362-6000 (Anthony Tommasini).
 
Classical Music
 
THE AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA. The performances can be uneven, but the American Symphony Orchestra and its conductor Leon Botstein keep drawing us back with interesting programs. This one, "Polishing the Jewel: The Genius of George Enescu," deals with work of the composer-violinist-teacher and includes four symphonic items. A known but not too often heard 20th-century figure gets a close hearing. Avery Fisher Hall, tonight at 8. Tickets $18 to $45. (212) 875-5030. (Holland).
ARTEMIS QUARTET. This young group, formed in 1989 in Lubeck, Germany, is making its New York debut and thus not yet familiar. But a recording on the Primavera label speaks well for an adventurousness in its programming, with works by Wolf, Zemlinsky, Webern and Berg, as well as for the vitality of its performances. The programming here, slightly more standard, sandwiches Ligeti's Second Quartet between Beethoven (the last quartet, Op. 135, in F) and Mozart (the D minor, K. 421). Tonight at 8, Weill Recital Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $31. Sold out but returns may be available (James R. Oestreich).
CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER. "Musical Evolutions II: Crisis and Creativity (1922-1945)" is the title of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's interesting six-concert series that concludes tonight. Offering six concerts and four lectures, the series examined music composed during that historic period of catastrophic economic collapse, political turmoil, fascism, war and genocide. Paradoxically, these were years of intense creativity and radical innovation in the arts, especially music. The Orion String Quartet will be the guest artists, offering Barber's famous String Quartet No. 1, Copland's "Vitebsk, Study on a Jewish Theme" for piano trio, Antheil's raucously exuberant Violin Sonata No. 2, and selected American songs with the tenor Jerry Hadley. Alice Tully Hall, Tonight at 8. Remaining tickets are $35 and $25. Call: (212) 875-5788, or CenterCharge, (212) 721-6500 (Tommasini).
BARGEMUSIC. The concerts offered on this converted coffee barge on the East River are favorites of connoisseurs for both musical reasons (the programs typically combine familiar works and intriguing novelties) and extramusical ones (the view of lower Manhattan across the river is stunning, and the intimacy of the setting is perfect for chamber music). This week's programs are drawn from the heart of the standard repertory. The centerpiece of the program tonight and tomorrow evening is Schumann's "Dichterliebe," to be sung by the baritone William Sharp, with Gilbert Kalish at the piano. Also included are a group of Spohr songs, to which a violinist (Carmit Zori) is added to the ensemble; and David Leisner, an eloquent guitarist, will perform Bach's Prelude, Fugue and Allegro and -- with Toby Appel, violist, and Julia Lichten, cellist -- Paganini's Terzetto Concertante. For the Sunday concert, Mr. Kalish and Ms. Zori are to perform a Mozart Sonata (K. 378), and will be joined by the cellist Ronald Thomas for the Schumann and Smetana Piano Trios. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083 or (718) 624-4061. Tickets: $23, $20 for the elderly, $15 for students (Allan Kozinn).
EMERSON STRING QUARTET. The eminent American ensemble begins its five-part survey of the Shostakovich String Quartets. Seldom has so much human misery been rendered with such beauty and eloquence in these pieces. An excellent opportunity to hear great repertory in good hands. Alice Tully Hall, Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets $38. Call (212) 875-5050. (Holland).
STEVEN LUBIN. This pianist has provided some fine, provocative performances of both Classical repertory played on the fortepiano and Romantic literature performed on a concert grand. He is using the modern instrument for his recital on Sunday, which includes Bach's Italian Concerto, Beethoven's Sonata in F (Op. 54) and Schubert's Sonata in B flat. Sunday at 2 p.m., Armor Hall, Wave Hill, 675 West 252nd Street, Riverdale, the Bronx. (718) 549-3200, extension 229. Tickets are $15, $12 for the elderly, $10 for members and students (Kozinn).
NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. When Yuri Temirkanov, busy in Baltimore and elsewhere, agreed to give up a week at the Philharmonic to make room for Riccardo Muti, who scored such a success with the orchestra last season, speculation that Mr. Muti was the prime candidate to become the next music director grew hotter. Now that Deborah Borda, then the orchestra's executive director, has decamped for the Los Angeles Philharmonic, all bets seem to be off. So there is little to do but enjoy a program of vintage Muti: Rossini's "Viaggio a Reims" Overture, the divertimento from Stravinsky's "Fairy's Kiss" and Strauss's "Aus Italien." Today at 2 p.m. and tomorrow at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: today, $16 to $64; tomorrow, $18 to $77 (Oestreich).
NEW YORK YOUTH SYMPHONY. The orchestra's excellent conductor Mischa Santora leads them in a concert framed by American classics: Barber's Adagio and Dvorak's "Sorrowful Songs" Symphony and Symphony No. 9. As usual, the young musicians are appropriately given the opportunity to play a piece by a composer of their own generation, in this case John Mackey, whose Percussion Concerto will feature Samuel Z. Solomon. Sunday at 2 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $7 to $40 (Paul Griffiths).
POMERIUM. Alexander Blachly and this most venerable of New York's early-music vocal ensembles consistently present programs that offer both beautiful singing and scholarly enlightenment. This time Mr. Blachly and company are examining works composed for the chapel of Charles V, the Duke of Burgundy, King of Spain and Holy Roman Emperor in honor of the 500th anniversary of his birth. The composers on the program include Josquin, Lassus, Crecquillon Morales and Gombert. Sunday at 4 p.m., Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, Manhattan, (212) 666-9266. Tickets: $20, $15 for students and the elderly (Kozinn).
"RE-ENCOUNTERING RACHMANINOFF." The New Jersey Symphony's three-week festival, with a variety of events behind it, sticks to orchestral concerts for its final weekend. Tzimon Barto plays the Second Piano Concerto, whose popularity has far outlasted that of the song based on it, "Full Moon and Empty Arms." Zdenek Macal, the orchestra's music director, also conducts the less familiar First Symphony. To judge from the performance Mr. Macal elicited in the Second Symphony during the opening weekend, the results could be memorable. Tonight at 8, War Memorial, West Lafayette and Barracks Streets, Trenton; tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m., New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (800) 255-3476. Tickets: $15 to $58 (Oestreich).
ROYAL PHILHARMONIC. One might have hoped that this London orchestra and its young music director, Daniele Gatti, would have visited New York with something more adventurous than a program devoted to the Brahms "Haydn" Variations, the Beethoven Fifth Symphony and a Mozart concerto, but, of course, an orchestra's touring selections tell audiences a great deal about the state of its collective imagination. The one real draw here is the superb pianist Ignat Solzhenitsyn, who is to be the soloist in Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 23. Sunday at 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall. There is a pre-concert lecture at 2 p.m. at the Kaplan Penthouse in the Rose Building, 165 West 65th Street. (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $25 to $47 (Kozinn).
ANDRAS SCHIFF. For one listener, the most enduring memory of the last Bach year, 1985, was this pianist's performance of the six keyboard partitas. Mr. Schiff seemed as much creator as recreator, conjuring not only a distinct mood but also a distinct world of sound for each work. Now, on his way to the partitas next weekend and having already polished off the six English Suites in another Bach year, Mr. Schiff plays the six French Suites. Tickets may have to be begged, borrowed or stolen. (For those who relish a daylong immersion in Bach -- a worthy project for any day -- Lincoln Center offers a symposium, "The World and Music of Johann Sebastian Bach," from 10 to 5, and a prerecital lecture by one of the world's foremost Bach authorities, Christoph Wolff, at 7, in the Kaplan Penthouse, 165 West 65th Street, 10th floor.) Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $38 (Oestreich).
 SPECULUM MUSICAE. This one will be exciting. Some of the city's finest musicians get together to present works by Edgard Varese, who spent most of his adult life here, creating music of beautiful intensity. The program ranges from pieces he wrote in the 1920's for forceful ensembles of wind and percussion to "Deserts," his late masterpiece for orchestra and electronic sounds. Sunday at 5 p.m., Miller Theater, Broadway and 116th Street, (212) 854-7799. Tickets: $15 (Griffiths).
FREDERICA VON STADE, MATTHEW POLENZANI AND CRAIG RUTERNBERG. The George London Foundation offers an interesting recital series at the Morgan Library that pairs established artists of international renown with younger artists who are recent winners of grants from the foundation. On Sunday the renowned mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade will perform with the young tenor Matthew Polenzani, with Craig Rutenberg at the piano. During a pre-concert talk the great mezzo-soprano Rosalind Elias will recall her work with London, who died in 1985. Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street; Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets $40, $30 for members. Sold out, but returns my be available. Ticket information: (212) 685-0008 ext. 347 (Tommasini).

Dance
 
COLORADO BALLET. A company known for its polished dancing and rich repertory offers three contrasting works: Sir Frederick Ashton's "Facade," a satirical ballet of 1931 that is considered one of the 20th century's great choreographic comedies; Stanton Welch's "Of Blessed Memory," a tribute to a mother and her children, and Peter Pucci's "Picture of Sedalia," a look at a turn-of-the-century community. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, Tickets: $30 (Jack Anderson).
FLAMENCO: ANDREA DEL CONTE DANZA ESPANA. Back by popular demand, the Andrea del Conte Danza Espana troupe will present a new program of flamenco dance and song. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; Sunday at 4 p.m. and Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m. and Sundays at 4 p.m. through March 5. Tickets: $20; $18 for students and the elderly; some $5 tickets available for students through the High 5 Tickets program. Thalia Spanish Theater, 41-17 Greenpoint Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens; (718) 729-3880 (Jennifer Dunning).
FLAMENCO EXTRAVAGANZA. The cast may change from performance to performance, depending on which guest artists turn up at this intimate club to sing, dance or play flamenco guitar. HEADLINE: The Fed's Bad Strategy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re your Feb. 3 editorial about the Federal Reserve's short-term interest rate increase: The United States is facing a labor shortage over the next 20 years. Between now and 2020, when the number of people of traditional working age (20 to 64) will increase by 15 percent, the over-65-year-old group will increase 100 percent. The country will need a rapidly growing economy to support this dependent population. 
 Slowing growth is the wrong strategy. The right strategy is to continue the increase in worker productivity, expand immigration of productive workers and, most important, remove the disincentives for workers to stay on the job after age 65.
Future American prosperity will be determined largely by how early or late workers retire. Raising interest rates in response to labor demand is the wrong strategy for the demographic challenges we face in the new century.
 
BETSY MCCAUGHEY ROSS
New York, Feb. 3, 2000
 
The writer, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, was lieutenant governor of New York, 1995-98.

HEADLINE: Frank E. Morris, 75; Once Led Boston Fed

 BODY:
Frank E. Morris, who was president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston from 1968 to 1988, died Monday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 75.
Earlier, Mr. Morris was an economist with the Federal Office of Price Stabilization and the Central Intelligence Agency, an assistant to the secretary of the Treasury in the Kennedy administration and a vice president of Loomis Sayles & Company, an investment firm. 
 After leaving the Federal Reserve, Mr. Morris taught economics and finance for five years at Boston College.
Frank Eugene Morris was born in Detroit on Dec. 30, 1924, graduated from Wayne State University and served in the Air Force during World War II. He earned a master's degree and doctorate in economics at the University of Michigan.
He is survived by his wife, Geraldine; three daughters, Susan Carlson, of Acton, Mass.; Lisa Grobar, of La Crescenta, Calif.; and Betsy Rosen of Wellesley, Mass.; a sister, Dorothy Green, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A Parent's Dream, Circa 2000: Be the NextDenise Savoie

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
THERE was a time when children were told they could hope to be president, but for many Americans the envied footsteps are no longer those of Al Gore or George W. Bush. Now people dream of being like P. Kingston Duffie, Richard N. Tinsley or M. Denise Savoie.
Never heard of them? Two years ago they invested almost $8,500 as they founded Turnstone Systems to design products that help local phone companies provide DSL lines, which allow rapid Internet communications. The company looks as if it may succeed, having so far sold $27 million in products. Last year, it almost broke even. 
 This week Turnstone went public, selling stock to the public at $29 a share, compared with the one-tenth of a cent a share that the founders paid. Investors fell all over themselves to buy the stock, and yesterday Turnstone closed at $132. The shares bought by the three founders, who range in age from 35 to 44, now are worth $1.1 billion. The company, in which about $100 million has been invested -- including the $87 million put up by public investors this week -- has a market capitalization of $4.3 billion.
What makes the Turnstone story so impressive is that it is not all that extraordinary. Seven American companies have gone public this week. Besides Turnstone, they are SkilSoft, a provider of corporate training courses; Sequenom, a biotechnology company; Quantum Effect Devices, a semiconductor company; Telaxis Communications, a wireless equipment company; Centra Software, an Internet company; and Alamosa PCS, a cell phone company.
The seven sport a total market capitalization of $13.4 billion, equal to 16 times the amount of money that equity investors put into them and more than 170 times the $78 million in combined annual revenues.
Those figures reflect the wealth effect in action. The Federal Reserve, which has now raised the federal funds rate four times since last summer, is expected to raise it two or three more times before this year is out. That has put a damper on some old stocks, but it has not damaged the market for companies like these.
An initial public offering that immediately doubled in price used to be an amazing phenomenon. Now it is almost taken for granted that new offerings will soar. Of the seven, all but SkilSoft traded at twice the offering price or better the first day, although Alamosa faded to close with a gain of just 66 percent. But none got much attention.
Those doubles benefit the lucky people who got in on the public offering. Those who got in earlier do much better. All told, insiders -- including founders, employees and the venture capitalists who financed these seven companies -- have put $257 million into their equity investments. Their stakes are now worth $11.4 billion.
That wealth is created not by the success of the companies -- none are now profitable -- but by the enthusiasm and hope of investors. It is a virtuous circle, in which optimistic investors produce higher share prices that justify the optimism and draw in more investors.
All this is possible because many companies have a shot at being winners in an era in which technology is changing the economic landscape. But while some companies may prove to be great successes, there is no way that the economy will produce enough profits to justify all the optimism now being shown. Someday, when enough companies have fallen by the wayside, investors will grow hostile, and even promising ventures will find it hard to raise capital. There are no signs that day is near.

HEADLINE: Senate Ratifies Nomination Of Greenspan to4th Term

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed Alan Greenspan's nomination to a fourth term as chairman of the Federal Reserve today after members of both parties lauded his performance over the last dozen years in nurturing the economy's long expansion.
The vote was 89 to 4. 
 The action gave Mr. Greenspan, who is 73, another four-year term as head of the central bank, a post that makes him one of the most powerful policy makers in an increasingly interconnected global economy. It came a day after Mr. Greenspan raised interest rates by a quarter of a point to slow the fast-growing economy in an effort to head off the possibility of inflation.
President Clinton, whose administration has had a close working relationship with Mr. Greenspan, a Republican, said he was pleased by the Senate's action, especially in light of the Fed chairman's role in allowing the current expansion to become the longest on record this month.
"Chairman Greenspan's wise and steady leadership has inspired confidence here in America and around the world," Mr. Clinton said in a statement. "He has made a truly remarkable contribution in helping lead our nation to the longest economic expansion in history."
Mr. Greenspan was first appointed to the Fed by President Reagan in 1987. He was subsequently reappointed by President Bush, and now twice by Mr. Clinton.
Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said Mr. Greenspan was the only person who could have won such broad bipartisan support.
"And why have three successive administrations appointed Alan Greenspan to be chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve system?" Mr. Gramm asked during Senate debate on the nomination on Wednesday. "Because he is the best central banker we have ever had."
The four votes against Mr. Greenspan came from liberal Democrats who said he was too focused on fighting an inflation threat that was more theoretical than real, and doing so behind a cloak of excessive secrecy at the Fed. They were Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa, Byron Dorgan of North Dakota, Harry Reid of Nevada and Paul Wellstone of Minnesota.
During the debate, Mr. Harkin said that in focusing singlemindedly on the "specter of inflation," the Fed was paying too little attention to its legislated mandate of encouraging full employment.
"Mr. Greenspan and the Federal Reserve Board seemed to think they needed to make a pre-emptive strike on inflation before we see clear signs of inflation out there," Mr. Harkin said. "This view, if aggressively acted upon, would place an absolute cap on our economy's ability to grow. It would destroy much of our potential for growth. That is a tragedy."
The Fed has raised rates four times in quarter-point increments since June, pushing its federal funds target rate to 5.75 percent.
The Fed released today the minutes of its policy-setting meeting on Dec. 21, when it voted unanimously to hold interest rates steady. The minutes showed that Fed officials were concerned about continuing signs of incipient inflationary pressures in December, but that they were primarily focused on guiding the economy smoothly through the Year 2000 computer problems.
The officials said at the meeting that the three rate increases they had approved over the previous six months had had relatively little effect up until that point in slowing the economy. But they agreed that it would be prudent to delay any action on rates, in part because waiting would give the central bank further time "to assess the delayed effects of its earlier tightening actions."
The Fed concluded this week that its prior rate increases had not been enough. In explaining its decision on Wednesday to raise rates again, the Fed said the risks to the economy "are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
2000 Begins With Plenty Of Momentum

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
A surge in factory orders in December gave manufacturers their best year since 1995. That, plus big sales gains at retailers and a surprise dip in unemployment applications all show the economy is starting 2000 with plenty of momentum.
Strong demand for airplanes and electronic equipment helped to push orders to factories up 3.3 percent in December and contributed to making 1999 the strongest year manufacturers had experienced in four years, the Commerce Department said today. 
 Consumers, meanwhile, continued their yearlong buying binge in January, giving major retail chains better-than-expected sales, retailers said in another report.
And, the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits last week fell 5,000, to 274,000, the Labor Department said, indicating that the economy is still growing and that employers are having trouble finding workers.
The Federal Reserve bumped up interest rates on Wednesday by a quarter of a percentage point in an effort to slow the economy to a more sustainable pace so as to not set in motion inflation.
In the last three months of 1999, the economy grew at a 5.8 percent annual rate. It grew 4 percent for the whole year, and economists said the momentum had carried over into the new year.
December's bigger-than-expected 3.3 percent rise in factory orders was the largest monthly increase in seven years. It was led by a 20 percent jump in orders for transportation equipment, including airplanes and cars. A 6 percent increase in orders for electronic and other electrical equipment, the category that includes household appliances and communications equipment, also contributed to the rise.
Many economists expect the unemployment rate -- now at 4.1 percent -- will fall to 4 percent when the January employment report is released Friday.
The less volatile four-week moving average for unemployment-benefits claims fell last week to 282,000. Economists consider claims below 300,000 an indication that employers are having difficulty finding workers to fill job openings.

HEADLINE: For Many, Abortion Is Lost in the Crowd of Issues

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich.

 BODY:
Solidly in the Republican camp, Tom Miller rattled off the issues most important to him: taxes, the economy, health care.
Abortion was nowhere near the top of the list. 
 "Oh, I just put that one aside," said Mr. Miller, a 36-year-old engineer, waving a hand in the air, as if to dismiss a troublesome topic. "The politicians talk a lot about abortion, but it's not something that's going to decide my vote."
For all the passionate debate over abortion among presidential candidates, interviews with more than 50 voters in Michigan, Illinois and Wisconsin found that it was the rare voter who saw the issue as pivotal.
Questions about abortion evoked a welter of complicated feelings that left many people uneasy about even discussing it, preferring instead to focus on tax policy, or the trustworthiness of candidates.
Taylor Manning, a 46-year-old corporate manager in Naperville, Ill., who is the bishop of his Mormon ward, said that while he held "strong personal views about abortion," he preferred that the issue remain outside the political debate. It was a position he said was common among his Republican acquaintances.
"I run with a pretty conservative group of people," Mr. Manning said, "and I don't think they're basing their votes on abortion."
To be sure, a core of deeply committed voters see abortion as the overriding issue in American politics. Patricia Gantz, 59, who lives in Dewitt, Mich., said she wanted to see abortion "outlawed in all cases," and could not fathom casting a ballot for a candidate who supported a woman's right to choose abortion.
But a far greater number of voters, including those on both sides of the abortion debate, said it was just one of many issues to be considered. Moreover, voters expressed a skepticism about the hard-line statements against abortion by some candidates, particularly Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, saying they could be merely an effort to win ardently conservative voters in the Republican primaries.
Finally, a big share of voters said they did not believe it was likely that any president could overturn laws that protect abortion rights.
For that reason, Heinke Hoenck, a retired secretary in Janesville, Wis., said she could vote for Mr. Bush in the fall, even though she disagreed with his opposition to the Roe v. Wade decision by the Supreme Court in 1973 that gave constitutional protection to abortion rights.
"When it came right down to it, there would be an uproar in this country" if abortion were made illegal, Ms. Hoenck said. "It would be very hard for a president to change the law."
Tony Harvey, a 38-year-old engineer in Chicago, expressed a similar view, saying that government would ultimately find it impossible to stop abortion.
"I'm very religious, and I do not believe in abortion," Mr. Harvey said. "But to me, all this talk about abortion is beside the point. If people want to have abortions, they're going to have them."
President Ronald Reagan consistently sided with forces opposed to legal abortion, Mr. Harvey noted, but failed in two terms to make it illegal.
That sentiment was also voiced by strong opponents of abortion, like Herb Dowman, a 37-year-old environmental engineer in Dewitt, Mich. "I'm going to vote for an anti-abortion candidate," he said, "but I don't expect anything to change."
Marilyn Smith, a 41-year-old secretary for an insurance company in Fort Atkinson, Wis., said that while she opposed the late-term procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion, she favored keeping abortions legal in the early term.
Nonetheless, when she talked about the issues that would determine her vote, Ms. Smith mentioned taxes and help for farmers, among other things. Abortion was simply "not that high on the list," she said.
"I want to look at the total package," Ms. Smith said. "One issue is not going to decide my vote. There are too many important things to think about."
Liz Schweitzer, an administrator at St. John's Student Parish in East Lansing, a center for Roman Catholic college students, said abortion did not dominate the political discussion, even among people who tried to adhere to church teachings on government issues.
"Abortion gets a lot of press, but it is just one of the church teachings on life and social justice issues," Ms. Schweitzer said, noting that Catholic leaders, while opposing abortion, also espoused many positions that seemed at odds with Republican politicians, like greater help for immigrants and the poor.
Michigan, which holds a primary on Feb. 22, has demonstrated a penchant for surprise. The state's Democratic voters, for example, have in the past supported George C. Wallace and the Rev. Jesse Jackson in primaries.
The willingness of many voters to support candidates regardless of their views on abortion concerns Marie Jones, a 32-year-old research scientist at Michigan State University.
"It worries me that maybe they could make it illegal," Ms. Jones said, noting that many states had enacted restrictions on abortion, like 24-hour waiting periods and requirements for parental notification.
The same concern was voiced by Laurie Stephens, a 26-year-old factory worker.
"If they say they're going to outlaw abortion, maybe we ought to take it seriously," Ms. Stephens said as she walked down a department-store aisle with her 4-year-old daughter, Kristin. "What if it goes through, and we're back to illegal abortions?"

HEADLINE: And Let the Lawyers Sing: 'Glory to the Salary King'

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The frenzy over law firm salaries reached new heights yesterday and spread for the first time to a law firm based in neither New York nor Silicon Valley.
The nation's largest law firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, sent memos to associates yesterday telling them they would receive raises of about 40 percent. First-year associates will now make $140,000 a year in base salary, about $15,000 more than they will at other firms that announced large raises in the last two weeks. 
 The big increases are the latest sign of the widespread effect that the Internet is having on highly skilled workers in a range of professions. Silicon Valley law firms started the bidding war over the last month and a half to keep their younger lawyers from defecting to dot-com start-ups, and other firms have reacted to keep pace with the salaries of the California firms, many of which have offices on the East Coast.
Thousands of young lawyers, already among the highest paid workers in the country, are getting raises that usually go only to people who receive promotions or who switch jobs. And almost overnight, the nation's largest law firms have added as much as $50 million to their individual payrolls.
"It is a lot of money," said Benjamin F. Stapleton, a partner at Sullivan & Cromwell, which announced raises on Wednesday. The moves by Skadden and Sullivan & Cromwell virtually ensure that every other top firm in New York will offer similarly large pay increases in the coming weeks, lawyers said. Davis Polk & Wardwell, which told its associates last week that their salaries would jump by about 25 percent, was the first New York firm to act.
Skadden's decision will also put pressure on its rivals to hand out large end-of-year bonuses to bring associates' total pay packages to about the same level as those at Skadden. Because Skadden will pay relatively small bonuses, its partners do not consider the raise to be an attempt to top the other firms' salaries, said Robert C. Sheehan, the firm's executive partner.
Boston-based Testa, Hurwitz & Thibeault told its associates yesterday that they, too, would receive raises of as much as 40 percent. Recent law school graduates will now earn $140,000 in a city with real estate costs that are well below those in New York or San Francisco. Sixth-year associates at Testa will make $205,000 this year. Lawyers in Boston typically work many fewer hours than those in New York.
Testa will not offer bonuses of any kind, said Timothy C. Maguire, a partner. All 330 of Testa's lawyers work in Boston, and Mr. Maguire said he expected Testa's rivals, like Hale & Dorr and Ropes & Gray, to offer similar raises soon.
The new salaries indicate just how much law firms have profited from the long economic expansion, the current wave of mergers and initial public offerings, and the growth in litigation over the last decade. In addition to announcing the raises, Testa's memo to associates said it hoped they would curtail the long hours they have recently logged and improve their quality of life.
If that happens, Mr. Maguire said, the firm would have an easier time hiring more talented lawyers and bringing in more clients. "We're turning away an awful lot of work," he added.
The East Coast firms have avoided the strategy of most Silicon Valley firms, which have tied bonuses -- as much as $30,000 for first-year associates -- to the number of hours that a lawyer bills.
The latest round of raises brought glee to associates around the country, many of whom keep each other apprised of the announcements through e-mail and postings on a Yahoo Web site called Greedy Associates. One participant posted a poem yesterday afternoon praising Skadden. Its last lines were: "Arps! The Skadden Angels sing! Glory to the Salary King . . ."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE SCENE -- CAMPAIGN SKETCHBOOK;
Long Day's Journey Into Morning Finds Gore Long on Talk

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Even with Michael S. Dukakis nodding off in the second row, Al Gore kept talking. One of the Secret Service agents standing at the edge of the crowd had his eyes closed, too, and the press corps was literally moaning for mercy -- so loudly, in fact, that many of the real people at the town hall meeting here at Los Angeles City College turned around to look.
But until nearly 1 o'clock this morning -- or 4 a.m. back in New York, where his day had begun -- the vice president stood close to his questioners, looked straight into their eyes and tried to close the sale, finally wrapping up after 3 hours 18 minutes (just a few minutes shy, aides said, of his personal record, 3:24). 
 He had warned them, though, telling the crowd of about 200 straight away that he would stay to answer all questions, until California's presidential primary on March 7 if necessary. Often his answers were so comprehensive that they seemed to begin with the creation of the earth -- the biblical version of which, he happened to mention, he does not believe should be taught in science class.
Though California is not considered a state where retail politics works particularly well, the audience here, mostly undecided Democrats, not only rewarded the candidate's endurance but stayed afterward and asked him to elaborate on a variety of answers.
Several people said later that they particularly appreciated his not always giving the answer that his questioner seemed to want. When a retired evangelist asked the vice president if he was a born-again Christian, he said yes, but went on to say that this did not mean he wanted to be associated with what he called the intolerance of Jerry Falwell. "I'm sorry to be long-winded," Mr. Gore said by way of finishing.
"I am, too," replied the man, who, having had a little fun at Mr. Gore's expense, added that "America needs to get back on its knees."
The vice president made clear that he did not agree with the questioner's support for prayer in schools, and he also defended the welfare overhaul to a man who said many people had been hurt by it.
He did not, however, correct a young man who said, "Many years ago you wrote books about the Internet." Instead, he joked about having stretched the truth on that topic some time back: "You notice he didn't say I invented the Internet; I didn't say that this evening either, did I?"
He may have made a teensy overstatement, though, when he told the crowd that "we had a huge event with 3,000 people at Ohio State University" earlier in the day. Officials at that rally said the room where it had taken place did not hold more than 1,200 people, and, given the area needed for the staging erected for the occasion, they estimated the crowd at 500.
In another answer, about how to keep youths from joining gangs, Mr. Gore said the whole idea that quality time spent with children could make up for a shortage of time with them "is a lie," but then added, "There is some truth to that lie."
In his 10-minute answer to the young man's question about the future of the Internet, Mr. Gore was nothing if not thorough. He began with a description of "stagflation" caused by the oil crisis of 1973. Eventually moving into the present, he said, "Now, instead of big price increases, we have a price decrease for processing information, low unemployment and low inflation because the price of processing information is cut in half every 18 months."
For good measure, he worked in a statement of support for universal preschool and for smaller class sizes before finally wrapping up that same answer about the Internet by admitting, "I've given you a mouthful there."
At times, Mr. Gore seemed to go out of his way to state the obvious. To a woman who told him that she was disabled and that she and her three children had previously been homeless, he said, "I'm glad you have a home."
The audience, though, seemed quite moved by his attentions.
A man who spoke passionately about his work with children, trying to keep them out of gangs, said he was holding down two jobs and volunteering a lot of his time to help others in his community.
"We need support," the man said. "Jesus Christ, we need more people up there helping, and when you become president -- and I hope you're not doubting yourself that you will become president -- hopefully you will remember what we said here at L.A.C.C."
After the marathon, Brian Price, a previously undecided screenwriter in the audience, said: "I saw two things I hadn't seen on television -- a plan and passion. I want somebody who can take on the anti-gun-control morons on the other side, and I saw somebody who looks like they have the pluck to fight."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Citing Currency Weakness, Europeans Raise Key Rate

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Declaring that the weakness of Europe's year-old single currency had created concern about price stability, the European Central Bank raised interest rates today for the second time in three months.
The rise in the benchmark refinancing rate, to 3.25 percent from 3 percent, came the day after the Federal Reserve increased interest rates in the United States and indicated that further rises might be necessary to keep America's strong economy from producing inflation. 
 Economists and investors had expected the European rate increase, though many said they did not see that happening before the spring. The timing led some economists to express fear that Europe's fledgling central bank would be seen as sailing in the wake of the Federal Reserve. But financial markets in Europe appeared, for the moment at least, to welcome the move.
The president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, maintained that the timing of the move after the Federal Reserve action was coincidental.
Share prices reacted favorably, with the benchmark index of the Paris stock exchange closing up 3.41 percent and that in Frankfurt rising 2.54 percent. In Britain, which has not adopted the single currency, the euro, and sets rates independently, stocks gained one-third of a percent.
The euro rose as well, settling in New York late in the day at 98.85 cents, up from 97.57 cents on Wednesday.
Hints of today's increase in the interest rate the European Central Bank charges commercial banks for short-term loans had come on Monday, when Mr. Duisenberg suggested that continued weakness of the euro threatened to generate inflation. At a news conference at the bank's headquarters in Frankfurt today, he repeated that reasoning.
The euro's drop in value compared with the dollar, Mr. Duisenberg said, is a "cause of concern with regard to future price stability." As the euro weakens, the prices Europeans pay for goods they import from the United States or pay for in dollars, like oil, increase. So, the bank chief said, "import prices can be expected to rise further, thereby increasing the risk that upward pressure on consumer price inflation might materialize in the medium term."
An increase in interest rates tends to strengthen a currency by making deposits denominated in that currency more attractive. Even with the euro's improvement in trading today, it has been languishing below $1 for much of the last week.
At the end of January, the European currency was valued almost 12 percent below its average worth during the first quarter of 1999, and it has continued to erode since then.
The central bank, before increasing rates in November, to 3 percent from 2.5 percent, had been primarily concerned with stoking sluggish European economies, which have shown less vigor than the American economy through most of the 1990's.
But in raising rates today, the central bank put its emphasis clearly on avoiding inflation.
Though evidence of inflation in European countries is sketchy, Mr. Duisenberg said that the bank's principal yardstick for growth in the money supply, an inflation barometer, showed an annual increase of 6.1 percent in the last quarter of 1999 -- well above its 1999 target of 4.5 percent. He said long-term bond rates in Europe, another inflation signpost, showed evidence of continued strong increases, reaching the highest level at the end of January since 1997.
Though economic growth has been strong in France and Spain, and in several smaller European countries like Ireland and the Netherlands, it remains fitful in Germany and Italy, which with France form the core of the Continent's economy.
The central bank's move drew mixed reactions from economists. Many said that the rate increase was premature and that the evidence of inflationary danger cited by Mr. Duisenberg was overdrawn. Some accused the central bank of acting primarily to slow or reverse the euro's slide against the dollar and said the move seemed to be a reaction to the Fed's rate increase on Wednesday.
"With their timing, they threw into question their independence," said Ulrich Ramm, chief economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt.
Mr. Ramm said he saw little danger in the move for European growth prospects, since many economists had expected a rate increase within the next six to eight weeks. But he added, "It would be a real embarrassment if the euro fell further."

HEADLINE: Austrians Defend Austria, but Views on Haider Party Range Wide

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Feb. 3

 BODY:
O.K., tell the truth, a young reveler at Jorg Haider's birthday celebration on an Alpine ski slope was prodded recently -- isn't all your Freedom Party's talk about the economic threat posed by immigrants really just a cover story for not liking dark-skinned people?
"No," Martin Pohl answered, fixing his questioner with a straight, if slightly beery gaze. "We Austrians are not like that." 
 "It's not," he added firmly, "as bad here as in America. I have seen 'Mississippi Burning.' "
That, in its way, encapsulates the view of many Austrians in Mr. Haider's camp -- and many who dislike him -- about the threats from the European Union, Israel and the United States to isolate Austria diplomatically if Mr. Haider joins the government. Look to your own houses before dictating to us, they say. Some leaders, they suggest, have mounted the dung heaps of corruption scandals and neo-Nazi incidents in their own countries and suddenly shouted that they have the moral high ground.
To be sure, there are others who feel just the opposite.
"I, as an Austrian, I enjoy this," said Georg Hofmann-Ostenhof, a columnist for Profil magazine. "Why shouldn't the E.U. say we don't want an extremist in your government? It's not good manners to have racists in government. We don't do that."
Interviews in the Alps, where Mr. Haider comes from, and in the streets of liberal Vienna, where hostility to him is strongest, produce a range of musings -- not just about the diplomatic crisis, but also about Mr. Haider's unpredictable personality and Austria's complex self-image as the one-time seat of a vast empire later reduced to a Nazi state and now to an Alpine chalet on Western Europe's frontier.
Mr. Haider often says what some other Austrians feel but dare not say. Sometimes, it is complaints normal to a democracy: The government is full of tired old men who divide the spoils. The economy would be stronger if they dared privatize. Civil servants are lazy and rude.
In Carinthia, as a lawyer who inherited wealth, Mr. Haider is seen as above corruption, pro-business and a leader who made the civil servants smile on time.
Sometimes, what he says is unpleasant but true: Immigrants are responsible for a disproportionate amount of the small crime rate. Some cheat on the generous welfare system.
Sometimes it is wacky: immigrants use state-paid fertility treatment to out-breed Austrians.
And sometimes, it is over the line: The Waffen SS deserves the same respect as any military unit.
Mr. Haider's style has been called "defamation followed by halfhearted excuse," and he used it again last week, calling the Belgian government corrupt protectors of pedophiles and implying that France's president, Jacques Chirac, was a doddering failure. Senior politicians say such language cannot be used in international relations.
Alexander van der Bellen, leader of the Green Party, called him a "persistent offender."
Some Haider backers enjoy his forthrightness; some worry.
"He's a good man, but when he opens his mouth, it's a catastrophe," said Willy Klima, 53, a Vienna cabbie.
Manfred Spahn, 32, a casino floor manager, said: "I admit I did think of voting for Haider as a protest, because he exposed corruption. But I have an aunt who died recently at 93. She lived through two world wars, and she compared Haider to Hitler and said it might be possible to happen again, so she decided to vote for the reds, even though she'd voted black all her life. I listened to what she said."
In Austrian politics, the Social Democrats are known as the reds; black is the color of the conservative People's Party, which has signed an agreement on a coalition government with Mr. Haidar's party.
Michael Chik, 19, who was to join an evening anti-Haider demonstration, is part of the tiny Chinese minority, born here of parents who immigrated to open a restaurant. "I know some people in the Freedom Party, and they are quite racist," he said. "And it's the members who make the party."
He said he had been teased as a child. "They did this," he said, pushing his eyes up into slits. "But it's the Turkish people who get beaten up and face discrimination."
Others who are, by Austrian law, "foreigners," say they do not feel threatened.
"I'm not a supporter, not at all, but Haider's not against anyone like me who's been here 30 years and does his work properly," said Milan Lakobria, 50, an electrician originally from Yugoslavia. "He's against those who don't work."
Mr. Lakobria is still not a citizen, nor are most of his children born here. But they could be if they wanted, he said, "and anyway, it's better here than in my country."
Anna Krailler, 75, a retired cashier walking her small white dog through a middle-income Vienna shopping center, made no secret of her feelings. "Yes, I am for Haider," she said. "It's time that all those foreigners who steal cars were out."
"Over there," she said, pointing to a residential district, "there are blocks with only one or two Austrians. You get no peace, there are so many children running around. In summer, the foreigners take over the parks. And it's not only them. My generation helped rebuild Austria, and I don't get enough pension to live on. I think things will be better under Haider."
Asked about the diplomatic isolation, she said: "Well, the German criticism wasn't so bad. The worst was the Jews. They're afraid. I don't know why -- no Austrian would ever harm a Jew. And their ambassador should just go home. How are we supposed to react? Suddenly everyone's against us, but no one has the right to condemn Austria."
But Elisabeth Sickl, a minor official of Mr. Haider's party in Carinthia who is likely to be the social minister in the new government, denied that xenophobia and racism are characteristic of Haider supporters. "Humanism is my aim," she said. "I feel treated very unjustly. We are no Nazis."
A theme coming up repeatedly was fear of the "jetzt erst recht" backlash. The phrase is literally "now first right," but is translated as "now more than ever," meaning that if you push an Austrian, he will get his back up and do exactly what you wanted him not to do.
"We're afraid of new elections, because Haider will get more votes," said Susanne Fromwald, 31, a social worker who spent the night sleeping on a sidewalk in an all-night demonstration against the proposed government. "People here who don't like people from other countries telling us who to vote for will vote for Haider." She said she preferred European "concern" to isolation, but her companions liked the stronger course.
But Simon Wiesenthal, the Nazi-hunter based in Vienna, opposes isolation, fearing that the tiny country's lifeline -- tourism and trade -- will shut down. He prefers new elections, even knowing that they could strengthen Mr. Haider.
"Nobody can say he's a Nazi," Mr. Wiesenthal said, "but when Jews call me and say, 'We're not against Haider because he never said something against the Jews,' I ask: 'Is that the best you can say about him?' "
But many Austrians, regardless of their political sympathies, said the European Union had gone too far by condemning Austria before Mr. Haider spent a day in office.
"If Haider is a problem -- O.K., I can cry," said Mr. Klima, the ebullient taxi driver. "But every man should have a chance."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Bonds' Rise Sends Traders Into Turmoil

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON and PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Chaos swept through the bond market yesterday as traders and investors tried to make sense of a spectacular and damaging rise in the prices of longer-term Treasury bonds. Rumors of significant losses sustained by banks, brokerage firms and hedge funds said to be on the wrong side of the Treasury market's move roiled the market, reminding many participants of the crisis created by the near collapse of the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund that gripped the market in September 1998.
Tripping over themselves to buy 30-year bonds, investors and traders drove the price of the bonds up an unusual 3 percent early in the morning. The yield on the bond fell from its Wednesday close of 6.28 percent to as low as 5.93 percent before settling at 6.13 percent at the end of the day. The yield on the 10-year note fell from 6.57 percent Wednesday to 6.44 percent yesterday. 
 Market participants were stunned by the action. "The government bond market is trading with an extraordinary amount of stress," said Tom Juterbock, head of government bond trading at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company. "I can't recall a time when this market had this much stress. This is without historical precedent."
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York issued a statement in the early afternoon denying a rumor that a special emergency meeting had been called by the Fed to assess the damage caused by the move in the market. Such a meeting was convened when Long-Term Capital Management was teetering and resulted in a Fed-assisted bailout of the hedge fund.
But bond traders at banks and brokerage firms across Wall Street said yesterday that losses were surely large at many institutions this time around because of the nature of the bets that had been made by these firms in recent weeks. Once again, as was the case with Long-Term Capital Management, the majority of bond market participants are finding themselves all in the same troubling trades.
The root of the recent trouble is the Treasury's plan to reduce its issuance of long-term debt and to buy back a good deal of the debt that is outstanding. Worried about a shortage of Treasury debt to be traded, investors who need to own high-quality long-term government securities -- managers of pension funds and insurance company portfolios who offset their long-term obligations with assets of similar maturities -- surged into the market.
As these investors scrambled to buy long-term Treasuries, traders who had sold those securities short faced mounting losses. Because banks and brokerage firms typically offset the potential risk in their sizable holdings in mortgages or corporate bonds by selling government bonds they do not own, a process known as selling short, the move had punishing effects on firms' positions up and down Wall Street.
Worried about possible trading losses, investors pounded the shares of two Wall Street firms known for their bond trading operations. Goldman Sachs Group's stock fell 6.3 percent, to $85.375, one of its biggest one-day declines since the firm went public in May, while shares in Lehman Brothers Holdings dropped 2.5 percent, to $70.4375.
A spokesman for Lehman Brothers said, "We're not having any problems as a result of the Treasury market moves." A spokeswoman for Goldman Sachs declined to comment.
Although the Treasury announced its buyback plan on Jan. 13, the reality of its effects was not fully recognized by bond traders until recently. As the meaning of the reduction in supply sank in among investors, the rush into the bond market began.
On Wednesday, the Treasury said that it would retire $17 billion of its debt in the first three months of this year. Most of the buybacks are to be focused on debt with maturities of 10 years or more. In addition, the Treasury said its most recent auction of securities would raise $32 billion, almost 14 percent less than the $37 billion analysts had been expecting.
Charles Parkhurst, managing director for government bond trading at Salomon Smith Barney, said that it was troubling that the Treasury had led the market to believe that the 30-year bond was a dinosaur and would be eliminated.
What traders find particularly maddening about the action in the market is that many of the trades that are causing the greatest woes are not especially speculative. In fact, they are fairly ordinary. It is simply that the Treasury's debt reduction plan has turned the market on its head.
Although no bank or brokerage firm came forward with reports of losses, the carnage in the market will most likely push brokerage firms and banks to reassess their heavy reliance on Treasuries to hedge their corporate bond or mortgage holdings. The United States Treasury market is the largest and most liquid in the world, but now that this market will be shrinking, traders will look for new securities to use as hedging vehicles.
In the meantime, these traders are exiting their troubled short positions, which are sizable, buying long-term Treasuries to cover those they had sold short. One trader said a conservative estimate of the Treasuries sold short is twice the securities available for trading, indicating that the pain in the bond market could continue for some time.
A senior executive at a commercial bank said, "This started last Friday afternoon and all the trading floors are shaken." The executive added that because no one knew which firms had been hit the hardest, anxiety levels throughout the market would remain high.
The rally in bonds has exacerbated an unusual occurrence in the market: short-term interest rates are considerably higher than those on long-term securities. That is unusual because investors are traditionally paid more to hold long-term instruments because they are taking on more risk than those investors who buy short-term securities. When short-term yields rise above those of long-term instruments, Wall Street traders say the yield curve is inverted.
"Whenever we have changes in the structure of the yield curve, it has taken about six months for the market to assimilate the changes," said Gemma Wright, senior interest rate strategist at Aubrey G. Lanston, an investment firm in New York. "This is not going to be any different."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Unusual Movement"
Even as the Federal Reserve has raised rates, the yield on the 30-year bond has moved sharply lower in recent days, falling below the yield on the 2-year note. The result is an unusual occurrence, an inverted yield curve, in which investors who take on more risk by owning long-term debt are paid less than those holding short-term instruments.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seizes Russia Tanker Said to Carry Oil From Iraq

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Two American warships enforcing United Nations sanctions against Iraq seized a Russian tanker in the Persian Gulf today after boarding it and discovering evidence that it might be smuggling oil out of southern Iraq, a Pentagon spokesman said.
A lightly armed boarding party from the guided missile cruiser Monterey landed on the tanker by helicopter on Wednesday after repeated attempts to get the tanker to respond to radio queries about its cargo, said the spokesman, Rear Adm. Craig Quigley. 
 "There were no incidents of violence whatsoever," he said. The Americans reviewed the tanker's navigational equipment and documents, including bills of lading. They also took samples of the cargo of gas oil to determine whether the petroleum originated in Iraq. Late today, the analysis of the petroleum -- and the sediment carried in it, which should indicate its source -- had not been completed, officials said.
The Volgoneft-147 tanker, flying a Russian flag, is only the second Russian vessel stopped by the international patrols since 1990, when Iraq was prohibited from selling oil on the open market as punishment for its invasion of Kuwait, Pentagon officials said.
For the last month the United States has warned the Russian government of its monitoring of two Russian tankers that had arrived on the Iraqi coast and appeared to be involved in smuggling oil. The Russian ambassador to the United States was briefed regularly on the issue, and American diplomats in Moscow have discussed it with the government there, said James P. Foley, a State Department spokesman.
"The Russian government has told us that this ship is privately owned and that an investigation on the Russian side is under way," he said.
The number of ships trying to smuggle oil out of Iraq has risen dramatically with the increase in oil prices to $27 a barrel from $11 a year ago, a senior Pentagon official said. But the unusual presence of Russian vessels pushed the United States to involve the Moscow government.
"We tried to get the Russians to police this ship themselves," the Pentagon official said, "but I guess with oil prices so high it's hard to stop these entrepreneurs."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Corporations on Steroids

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Yasir Arafat came to Davos this year, and there were two people he insisted on meeting with: Bill Clinton of the United States of America and Steve Case of America Online.
I never got to ask Mr. Arafat whether he thought Bill C. was more important than Steve C. After all, AOL-Time Warner has a market value exceeding the gross national product of most countries Mr. Arafat deals with. It's no wonder that when you ask White House officials what the President did in Davos, they say he had a few "bilaterals" -- meetings with other heads of state and business. When I asked the spokesperson for one of the giant technology firms what the company's C.E.O. was doing in Davos, the answer was: "He's holding bilaterals" with other heads of state and business. Every day the line between companies and countries blurs a bit more. 
 Get used to it. As the walls around the world disappear, companies can increasingly compete everywhere. And when you can compete everywhere, in many businesses you must compete everywhere. This is making companies bigger than ever, whether it is AOL-Time Warner or Exxon-Mobil or Microsoft. World leaders, investors and the media are naturally dazzled by the sheer size and power that some of these companies are amassing.
But what happens to democracies when companies grow to size extra-extra-large, in order to compete globally, but democratic regulatory institutions -- like the antitrust division of the Justice Department -- remain a size small?
At a press lunch in Davos, Bill Gates was asked how Microsoft could have hired lobbying firms to try to defund the Justice Department's antitrust division when it had a case pending before the antitrust division. Flashing anger, Mr. Gates said this was "an outrageous characterization -- it's untrue . . . The only thing that we ever spoke out on in terms of funding is p.r. funding." The Justice Department, Mr. Gates said, shouldn't be leaking or promoting "negative activities against U.S. companies overseas. I wasn't involved in any of the specifics of that, but to characterize that as defunding . . . is an outrageous thing."
This answer was disturbing on two levels. First, the notion that it was O.K. for Microsoft to engage lobbyists even just to reduce the public relations budget of the Justice Department's antitrust division -- while Microsoft had a case pending before it -- suggests a moral obtuseness that is, well, outrageous.
Second, the antitrust division of the Justice Department has no p.r. budget! It has one spokeswoman assigned to it from Justice's central office of public affairs, and her salary and related p.r. expenses are paid by public affairs, and they amount to roughly $100,000. Yet, according to The Washington Post, Microsoft's lobbyists, and several nonprofit foundations Microsoft brought to its headquarters on an all-expense-paid trip, tried to get the fiscal 2000 budget for the Justice Department's antitrust division slashed by $9 million -- from Justice's request of $114 million (a modest increase so it could hire more lawyers) down to $105 million (so it would have to cut back activities).
Microsoft wasn't trying to reduce the antitrust division's ability to engage in p.r.; Microsoft was trying to reduce its ability to engage in antitrust -- in a year when there had been a 30 percent increase in corporate mergers. As The Post noted, while corporate lobbying over policies is normal, it is rather unusual for a firm "to seek an across-the-board cut in a department's budget, especially in the middle of a major court battle."
Old problem -- dangerous new twist. America's antitrust laws were initially motivated by two concerns, argues the Harvard University political theorist Michael Sandel -- preventing big monopolies from overwhelming consumers and preventing big business from overwhelming democratic government. Those laws first arose when businesses grew beyond the control of state and local institutions, and therefore some federal power was needed to rein them in.
"Now business is growing to global dimensions, but governments are still national -- so government is again struggling to keep pace," observed Mr. Sandel. "In a world without walls, we are going to have to come up with new ways for government to rein in the power of global corporations, and prevent them from buying up democracy. Instead of just being dazzled by these mega-mergers, there should be a nagging voice in us all asking: Is democracy going to be bought up too?"
