HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Vodafone and Mannesmann In $183 Billion Merger Deal
Vodafone AirTouch of Britain is buying Mannesmann of Germany in an all-stock transaction worth $183 billion.
If consummated, the takeover will vastly expand the geographic reach of Vodafone, which already is the world's biggest wireless telephone company, giving it dominance in the European market and a global base of more than 50 million customers. Vodafone already has a major presence in the United States and two dozen countries in Asia and Africa. Page A1. 

Greenspan Nomination Is Confirmed
The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed Alan Greenspan's nomination to a fourth term as chairman of the Federal Reserve after members of both parties lauded his performance over the last dozen years in nurturing the economy's long expansion. The action gave Mr. Greenspan, who is 73, another four-year term as head of the central bank. The vote was 89 to 4. C2.
 
Ford Offers Its Workers Computers
Ford Motor announced that each of its 350,000 employees would be offered a high-speed desktop computer made by Hewlett-Packard, a color printer and unlimited Internet access for $5 a month. A1.
 
Technology Shares Climb Sharply
Technology stocks bounded higher, but blue chips were little changed. The Nasdaq composite index rose 137.02 points, or 3.36 percent, to 4,210.98, its third biggest point gain in history. The Dow Jones industrial average increased 10.24 points, to 11,013.44, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 15.85 points, to 1,424.97. C10.
 
Europe Raises Interest Rates
The European Central Bank raised interest rates for the second time in three months, declaring that the weakness of Europe's year-old single currency had created concern about price stability. C4.
 
E.D.S. Reports Strong Quarter
Electronic Data Systems, still rebounding from two disastrous years, reported fourth-quarter earnings that beat estimates, and it announced a more than fourfold increase in new contracts during the quarter. C8.
 
Kodak and Hewlett Form Venture
Eastman Kodak and Hewlett-Packard announced a joint venture to develop and market retail and consumer photofinishing products using the Internet and Hewlett-Packard's inkjet printer technology. The company is expected to generate $500 million to $1 billion in sales by 2005. Shares of Hewlett-Packard closed at $113.50, up $2.9375. Kodak shares closed at $63.125, up $2.0625. C2.
 
Big Law Firm Joins Salary Frenzy
The frenzy over law firm salaries spread to the nation's largest firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, which told associates that they would receive raises of about 40 percent. First-year associates will now make $140,000 a year in base salary. C8.
 
Factory Orders Surged in December
A surge in factory orders in December gave manufacturers their best year since 1995. That, plus big sales gains at retailers and a surprise dip in unemployment applications all show the economy is starting 2000 with plenty of momentum. C10.
 
Retail sales rose 4.9 percent in January as a brisk economy fueled spending on clothing, home furnishings and appliances. C2.
 
Spice Maker Reaches Settlement
McCormick & Company, the spice maker, agreed to let antitrust enforcers review its sales contracts for 10 years to head off a lawsuit contending that it had illegally charged some grocers more than others. C8.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Tennis Is Part Of Farmer's Charmed Life

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: MANDARA, Zimbabwe

 BODY:
THE grounds are out of a dusty colonial storybook, from another time and a privileged place. This is where Don Black raised a tennis family, where the grass is lush and the fruits are plenty and labor was love.
Here, on 22 acres rife with avocado pear trees and vegetation that sways to a gentle breeze as if it were music, Don Black awakened his sons, Byron and Wayne, and later daughter, Cara, to the first sign of dawn. School days, every day, they would all hit barefoot on grass moistened by dew. 
 In addition to the fruit, Black grew three tennis pros. The boys, no physical specimens, always went along with what the father called "the contract." They became tour veterans, and something of a local Davis Cup dynasty.
"Imagine if I'd had an athlete to work with," Don Black said, half-kidding. "If I had one like Michael Jordan, he could have killed Sampras."
The Black brothers don't have to worry about Pete Sampras this weekend. Only Andre Agassi, whom Wayne will try his luck with today in what the country's president, Robert Mugabe, is calling "the dwarfs against the giants," Zimbabwe hosting the United States, in the first round of the Davis Cup.
Don Black was also a tennis player, once a match point from Wimbledon's fourth round. Then he returned to his native Rhodesia and became a teacher, like his English mother, and a farmer, like his Scottish father, who came to this former British colony in 1913.
What a charmed life the 72-year-old Black has led on this fertile African land, a straight shot from downtown along Enterprise Road. He retired, at 40, from teaching with a full pension. He was too young to fight in World War II and too old, by three weeks, to be drafted by the colonial regime during the revolution that resulted in independent Zimbabwe in 1980.
"So many of my friends were gone to war and I was over there working on the kids' strokes," he said.
"Over there" was the grass court he had just stepped off, after finishing a lesson in an unobtrusive rain. From the veranda, his bare feet resting on the dry stone floor, he pointed to where Roy Emerson had climbed the fence and collapsed a rail now known as "Emmo's Bend." All of his old Aussie friends had visited him here, in fact, and hit on his well-manicured lawns. He and Rod Laver became good friends.
From his hideaway outside Harare, Black tended to his fruit, read books and corresponded anonymously (he forgot to sign his name) with the likes of Bertrand Russell. He constructed four grass courts, one hard court surrounded by banana trees. He married "the girl living two miles down the road." Velia Black wrote letters to her family in England, and they subsequently became a book, "Growing Up in Rhodesia."
The Black kids were raised in a very different place than the ones who beg for money downtown, or even those visited Wednesday by John McEnroe. In Chitungwiza Township, where unemployment is roughly 50 percent, some of the kids also played barefoot, only it was on sun-drenched cement.
While Velia Black has offered scholarships for a few talented children there, it is hard to connect or comprehend such disparate worlds. When he schooled his own children, Don would set up a bucket and the kids would aim for it with the serve. An African gardener whom the family knows only as Madala -- Old Man -- would retrieve the balls.
The gardener, still with the family, was once going blind from cataracts. An Australian eye surgeon teaching in Harare sent a car. Old Man was fearful, Don said, and wouldn't get in. They plied him with brandy, and off he went, returning the next day, eyesight restored.
Don Black opened his historical storybook and even Byron's scrapbook for visitors yesterday. Inside, he played a musical video called "It's the Blacks," composed by a local performer named Fungai Malianga. There is no disputing the Black family's popularity here, but the economy is failing, the government is wheezing and turmoil may be brewing.
While two-thirds of the white population left after 1980, Don Black stayed. He wouldn't even travel to watch his kids play. "How the hell could I leave all this?" he said.
Off in the distance, his wife was teaching tennis to a diplomat's kids. A servant was cleaning the first-floor windows. Old Man was strolling across the avocado fields.
The breeze was calming and intoxicating.
"I'll die here, whatever happens," Don Black said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TITLE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES (TIMES COLUMN)

HEADLINE: EUROPE'S MEGADEAL: THE OVERVIEW;
$183 BILLION DEAL IN EUROPE TO JOIN 2 WIRELESS GIANTS

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: DUSSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Two of the world's leading companies in wireless communications agreed today to combine in a $183 billion takeover deal, the largest ever.
In a stunning end to the kind of hostile takeover attempt once considered unthinkable in Europe, Vodafone AirTouch of Britain negotiated the acquisition of Mannesmann of Germany. The all-stock transaction shattered the previous record for a takeover deal, America Online's $165 billion purchase of Time Warner announced less than three weeks ago. 
 If consummated, the takeover will vastly expand the reach of Vodafone, which already is the world's biggest wireless telephone company, giving it dominance in the European market. Vodafone already has a major presence in the United States, Asia and Africa.
But the Vodafone-Mannesmann deal is perhaps more important as a watershed in European corporate behavior and the export to Europe of bare-knuckled takeover tactics first honed on Wall Street.
Never before has a European company carried off a hostile takeover on such a scale: cross-border, cross-cultural and paid for with shares in a company that was almost unknown outside of Britain 10 years ago.
The exact terms of Vodafone's acquisition of Mannesmann are still subject to approval by the German conglomerate's supervisory board -- the equivalent of a board of directors -- which is expected to ratify the agreement on Friday.
The deal came just four days before the expiration of Vodafone's takeover offer to holders of Mannesmann stock. Mannesmann's management had called the offer unwanted, unfriendly and too low.
Although it was nominally called a "friendly" merger today, Klaus Esser, the chief executive of Mannesmann, capitulated only when it became obvious that a majority of his shareholders were about to sell.
"The shareholders clearly think that this company, Mannesmann, a great company, would be better together with Vodafone AirTouch," Christopher Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, told reporters in Dusseldorf, where Mannesmann is based.
It remained unclear what the combined company would be called. But the deal would bring together two businesses with vastly different backgrounds. Mannesmann, founded more than a century ago as a maker of steel pipe, has evolved into technology-driven leader that specializes in communications. Vodafone, by contrast, was born 18 years ago as Britain's first cellular phone company, and that has been its only business ever since.
Together, Vodafone and Mannesmann would have 42.4 million subscribers. NTT DoCoMo of Japan is a distant No. 2 with 26.7 million, and Telecom Italia No. 3 with 17.8 million, according to estimates by the Lehman Brothers investment bank.
Mr. Esser, who had been voluble in his opposition to Vodafone's takeover designs and had been expected to resign, said he would continue to work for the combined company. He will become a nonexecutive chairman and keep a seat on the board.
Mannesmann shareholders will control 49.5 percent of the combined company and will get 58.96 Vodafone shares for each share of the German company that they own, up from the original 53.7 offered. Based on Vodafone's closing share price Wednesday of 3.855, or $6.21, the day before word of the deal got out, the total value is about $366.14 a share, or $183 billion.
If Vodafone shares hold their value, the agreement will be a bonanza for shareholders in Mannesmann, the most widely owned foreign stock in the United States. The takeover price for Mannesmann shares is more than double what they cost before the takeover battle began.
The arrangement has to be approved by the European Commission, which is expected to issue a preliminary decision on Feb. 17. But the deal is a bitter defeat for Mr. Esser, who had passionately fought to preserve his company's independence, though he insisted tonight that the situation was the best possible outcome.
"It's not a change of opinion," he told reporters.
But a slight discomfort was evident between the two men as they presented their agreement tonight. Despite a show of collegiality, they awkwardly shook hands for just a moment. After a bit of prodding by photographers, they were cajoled into shaking hands again.
Despite Mr. Esser's public nonchalance, the takeover is also a shock to Mannesmann, an old-line industrial and engineering conglomerate that had transformed itself into the biggest provider of wireless communications in Europe.
Mr. Gent also outmaneuvered Mr. Esser on the chessboard of Europe's wireless industry, which is based on a handful of immensely valuable national licenses in each country.
Mannesmann owns networks in Germany, Italy and Britain. Vodafone owns Britain's second largest network and scores of other stakes around Europe and elsewhere.
Mr. Gent's biggest victory came last Sunday, when Vodafone managed to steal one of Mannesmann's longtime allies -- Vivendi, a French media conglomerate. That move derailed Mr. Esser's desperate attempt to negotiate a merger with Vivendi, which would have given him control of a major French network and greatly strengthened his position with shareholders.
But Mr. Gent cut his own deal with Vivendi's chairman, Jean-Marie Messier, by forming a joint venture in Internet services. That deal convinced wavering shareholders that Mr. Esser had lost the upper hand, even with his allies, and shareholders began betting on a takeover.
Executives from both companies began to work in earnest together at the start of the week. The companies reached a basic agreement early this morning. Negotiations continued for most of today until the announcement was made late tonight.
The combined company will control wireless networks in Europe's three biggest markets -- Britain, Germany and Italy -- along with a 45 percent stake in an AirTouch-Bell Atlantic venture and holdings in more than 30 other countries.
Though Europe has had a surge of big hostile takeovers in the last two years, the takeover of Mannesmann makes history on several fronts besides sheer size.
For one, the only successful European takeovers have been between competitors within a single nation.
The battle for Mannesmann is also one of the first real battles for the entire European market, one in which both the combatants recognized that the economic integration of Europe and the adoption of a single currency in 11 countries made it crucial to overcome boundaries.
The battle also is one of the first cases in which national political leaders did not try to interfere to protect an important domestic company.
When three of France's biggest banks plunged into a heated takeover battle last year, the battle was largely sanctioned and guided by the Ministry of Finance, which wanted to consolidate the nation's banks and keep out foreign bidders.
The same was true when TotalFina, the French-Belgian oil company, began a successful hostile takeover of Elf Aquitaine. Likewise, Italian political leaders opposed the proposed merger between Deutsche Telekom and Telecom Italia in favor of a hostile bid by Olivetti of Italy.
In Germany, the reaction was different. Despite the angry talk about the dangers of hostile takeovers, the German government stayed out of the fight.
That reflected a widespread view among German business executives that it was far more dangerous to interfere with a legitimate if hostile takeover attempt and jeopardize the ability of German companies to buy up foreign companies.
As a result, Mr. Esser and Mr. Gent waged their battle almost entirely through direct appeals to shareholders themselves.
The conflict began in January 1999 when Vodafone acquired AirTouch of the United States, a minority partner in all of Mannesmann's communication ventures. But it deepened whenMannesmann invaded Vodafone's home territory by buying the British mobile phone network Orange for $33 billion in October.
Faced with Mannesmann's direct attack in Britain, Mr. Gent decided that Vodafone could not remain a real player unless it took over its partner-turned-rival.
Word of the deal weakened Vodafone's share price. In London trading, shares ended at 368.5 pence, down 17. In Frankfurt, Mannesmann shares added 0.5 euro to 325.50 euros.
Both companies employed armies of investment bankers to advise them. Vodafone's lead adviser was Goldman Sachs, which will earn about $75 million, analysts estimate. Vodafone is also advised by Warburg Dillon Read, which is expected to take home $50 million.
Mannesmann's advisers are Merrill Lynch, J. P. Morgan, Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. It is unclear how much Mannesmann's advisers stand to earn.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: EUROPE'S MEGADEAL: THE IMPACT;
Dusseldorf and Mannesmann

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: DUSSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Had it not been in large part for Mannesmann, this old industrial city might well have suffered a decline similar to that of Gary, Ind., or Birmingham, England.
Yet just as Mannesmann reinvented itself from a producer of seamless steel pipe to a fast-growing telecommunications company, Dusseldorf, a center of the German industrial renaissance of the postwar period, has reinvented itself as a newly prosperous center of high technology and services. Both the city and the company at its heart achieved what countless other cities in Europe and elsewhere only talk about: they moved beyond their history, embraced change and fostered entirely new jobs based on fast-growing advanced technologies. 
 And despite all that, the most important company here is now succumbing to a $183 billion takeover by the British telecommunications giant Vodafone AirTouch, which seems intent on running the company from London.
"It is as if a German company decided to come along and buy General Electric, only to sell off all the parts it didn't want," said Christoph Blume, Dusseldorf's director of economic development.
Yet business executives and political leaders here seem to share an overwhelming view that there is no turning back. To the extent that Dusseldorf and Mannesmann have achieved new prosperity, they have done so by embracing high technology and ignoring national borders so they could tap into foreign trade and capital markets.
City officials publicly criticized Vodafone's bid for Mannesmann, but no one tried to stop it. And in Germany's once-protective financial circles, bankers argue that it would be far more dangerous to block Vodafone than to let shareholders decide for themselves.
The reason is apparent on the streets of this city: it is packed with foreign companies, many of them providing highly paid jobs in technology and management. Dusseldorf has shed 125,000 industrial jobs since the early 1960's. But it has added almost the same number in fields like accounting, management consulting, software development, advertising and telecommunications.
"When I was growing up," said Michael Monks, the leader of the workers' council at Mannesmann's mobile phone subsidiary here, "people called this the executive desk for the Ruhr Valley -- the headquarters for heavy industry."
They don't anymore. A crumbling wharf along the Rhine River, rusting and dormant 10 years ago, has been redeveloped as a "media harbor" and now boasts gleaming buildings packed with new companies and trendy restaurants. Nokia of Finland and Ericsson of Sweden, two of the biggest mobile phone manufacturers, have research and business centers here. The electronics conglomerate Siemens A.G. has a development center for computer chips.
And at least half a dozen telecommunications companies have installed fiber optic networks to provide high-speed data communications through the main business areas. Mannesmann is at the core of this new population; others include MCI Worldcom, Esprit Telecom of Britain and Isis Multimedia of France.
Few companies have become more entwined with the international economy than Mannesmann itself. The company was founded more than a century ago by two brothers who came up with a method for making seamless steel pipe. Later, it branched out into engineering services, auto parts and electronics.
Since obtaining a license to supply mobile phone service throughout Germany in 1989, Mannesmann has evolved into one of Europe's most successful and internationally active competitors. Until now the biggest mobile phone carrier in Germany, with slightly more customers than Deutsche Telekom, it has spent tens of billions acquiring wireless businesses in Italy and Britain.
Such an enormous transformation required foreign partners and foreign capital. Airtouch Communications, formerly the wireless communications arm of the Pacific Telesis Group of San Francisco, provided money and technical expertise from the beginning. Mannesmann also raised billions in international bond markets and attracted scores of foreign stockholders. About 60 percent of Mannesmann's shares are owned by non-Germans, and a large share of that is held by American or British institutional investors.
And Mannesmann is not unusual. Werner Seifert, president of the Frankfurt stock exchange, estimates that two of every five shares traded in the DAX index of leading German stocks are held by foreigners. Far from viewing that as a threat to jobs and stability, Mr. Seifert argues that it makes companies healthier by forcing them to compete in the global markets. And takeovers, he said, are part of that process.
"In the United States, the target companies in corporate takeovers are usually companies in old industries that have not been producing jobs," Mr. Seifert said. "The market was punishing companies that had not been able to create jobs."
The economic unification of Western and Central Europe -- where trade barriers have all but disappeared and 11 countries including Germany have adopted the euro as a common currency -- has added to the pressure for mergers, as well as for openness.
"In the past, you might have dominated your domestic market," said Theodor Baums, a professor of banking and finance at the University of Osnabruck, "but now you are just one of many players and you must build up your position across borders. If you want to have operations abroad, you have to recognize the rights of companies in other countries to come in here."
Mannesmann, in sharp contrast to companies embroiled in takeover battles in France or Italy, was careful never to deviate from that model. In his three-month barnstorming campaign to defeat Vodafone's hostile bid, Mannesmann's chief executive, Klaus Esser, never invoked political defenses and trained all his efforts on persuading Mannesmann shareholders that Vodafone's offer was simply too low. "The final decision belongs to shareholders," he said again and again. And though he might have grimaced at the results, Mr. Esser generally acted in accordance with that belief.
Jorg Pluta, director of the Deutsche Schutsverein fur Wertpapierbesitz, an advocacy group for individual investors, praised Mr. Esser for his openness. "I would give him an A for transparency," he said.
That may come as cold comfort to people here. Several recent surveys have found that the overwhelming majority of Mannesmann individual investors in Germany opposed selling their shares to Vodafone.
Nonetheless, employees at Mannesmann's wireless business say they are not worried about their future. Wireless, which employs 8,000 people in this country, is growing rapidly and is almost certain to need more rather than fewer people.
But many fret that Vodafone will move to sever ties quickly with Mannesmann's older businesses, like steel pipes and auto components. While both companies had planned to spin off the older businesses, Christopher Gent, the chief executive of Vodafone, is widely expected to be harsher than Mr. Esser in closing older factories. "All the evidence thus far suggests that foreign takeovers lead to the disposal of management functions and jobs," said Udo Siepmann, head of the Dusseldorf Chamber of Commerce and Industry.
Others business leaders are somewhat more optimistic. "This city has shown that it can go through a huge transformation," said Hans Georg Crone-Erdmann, head of the Association of Chambers of Commerce for North Rhine-Westphalia. "I have absolutely no worries about the future."

Britain Intensifies Effort To Get I.R.A. to Disarm
Britain moved to suspend the power-sharing government in Northern Ireland by next week, but said it would work to get paramilitary forces to begin disarming before using that authority. A1
 
Rightists in Austria Coalition
Austria's president announced that he would swear in a new government today that includes the anti-immigrant Freedom Party of Jorg Haider, after a day of hesitation that was marked by objections to two Freedom Party members as proposed cabinet ministers. A1 

The European Union, which warned it would shun Austria if the Freedom Party was in the government, prepared to carry out its threat. A10
 
No Progress in Mideast Talks
Israeli and Palestinian leaders ended a summit meeting in the Gaza Strip in frustration, still bogged down over interim issues. A3
 
Russians Hand Over Journalist
Russian authorities exchanged a Radio Liberty correspondent, Andrei M. Babitsky, for two Russian soldiers held by Chechen rebels. Russia detained the correspondent on Jan. 16 as he left a rebel-held section of Grozny. A8
 
Jordan Links Plot to bin Laden
Jordanian security agents said 13 men imprisoned in Amman on charges of plotting terrorist attacks in Jordan had been trained in Afghan camps operated by Osama bin Laden, the Saudi fugitive. A4
 
U.S. Diverts Russian Tanker
Two American warships enforcing United Nations sanctions against Iraq seized and diverted a Russian oil tanker in the Persian Gulf after finding evidence that it might be smuggling oil out of southern Iraq, a Pentagon spokesman said. A4
 
Former Chad Leader Indicted
A court in Senegal indicted the exiled former dictator of Chad, Hissene Habre, on torture charges. It was believed to be the first time a former African head of state was charged with human rights violations by a court of another country. A3
 
Hope for New Year in Vietnam
Vietnam will celebrate Tet, the Lunar New Year, today and the Year of the Dragon's traditional promise of prosperity, after a year of economic hardship. A5

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Before Play Starts, Zimbabwe Gets Lift

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe, Feb. 3

 BODY:
The No. 1 player in Zimbabwe stood shoulder to shoulder with No. 1 in the world here today. At the Davis Cup draw to determine the pairings for Friday's opening matches, Zimbabwe's president, Robert Mugabe, might have been hoping that Andre Agassi's magic is contagious.
With lines for gasoline lengthening, unemployment, inflation and H.I.V. infection rates soaring, and Parliamentary elections coming, the beleaguered president made sure that Agassi was right next to him for the group photo at the statehouse. 
 "If you've read the papers, Zimbabwe is going through a bit of a rough time right now, and I think this is a bit of a breath of fresh air," said Byron Black, who plays the American Chris Woodruff in the second match at the Harare Sports Center. Black's brother, Wayne, will play Agassi in the first match.
There are seven other first-round matchups in the World Group: Australia, the defending champion, at Switzerland; Britain at the Czech Republic; Italy at Spain; Belgium at Russia; Austria at Slovakia; Brazil at France; and the Netherlands at Germany.
Mugabe called the Zimbabwe-United States encounter "the dwarfs against the giants." But Woodruff did not want to hear about it.
"I'd be lying if I told you I didn't feel any pressure," he said. "This is a big deal."
He was home in Knoxville, Tenn., when the United States captain, John McEnroe, called last Friday to inform him that he had been drafted by Uncle Sam. Here he is, at 27, set up as the biggest target in Zimbabwe.
"Andre is playing the best tennis of anyone on the planet right now," Byron Black said. "Obviously, the guy we're aiming to beat is the No. 2 player, Woodruff. Hopefully, the doubles could be the crucial decider."
If that occurs, McEnroe may run out of hairs that have not turned gray. The United States team of Alex O'Brien and Rick Leach has never played together. The Zimbabwe captain, Gavin Sinney, is pairing Wayne Black with Kevin Ullyett for Saturday's doubles, and engaging in some playful warfare with McEnroe.
"America, with the players they've got, should win the Davis Cup every year for the next few years," he said.
Agassi, speaking for the depleted Americans, said, "I think we'll be fortunate to get through this weekend."
One singles victory by Woodruff would pretty much assure a second-round match against England or the Czech Republic in Los Angeles. But Woodruff has no Davis Cup experience other than being a practice partner. His best ranking was 25, three years ago.
He soon hurt his wrist, then tore up his knee just fooling around, kicking field goals with the tour veteran Richey Reneberg at a high school field in Atlanta. He was out for almost a year.
"He's 6-4, good agility, big hitter," said Paul Goldstein, one of the team's practice players. "At the Australian Open, he beat Tim Henman, didn't lose a set for three rounds, lost to Sampras in the quarters. He's playing good ball."
How that translates here, in the nearly mile-high altitude and under extreme Davis Cup conditions, who knows? Byron Black today was promising more noise than even McEnroe might be able to bear. There will be "a lot of drums," Black said, possibly -- by coincidence, of course -- right behind McEnroe.
This is the first time Zimbabwe has ever engaged an American team, a situation that makes Byron Black something of a prophet. A couple of years ago, after Zimbabwe had qualified for the World Group, the tennis federation president, Paul Chinoka, asked him if he and his brother could help bring famous American players like Agassi, Sampras or even the retired McEnroe to Harare to play exhibitions and promote the game.
"I thought, well, this could be a bit expensive," Black said. "I said, 'Maybe you should wait for Davis Cup. We'll get them for free.' "

HEADLINE: Repairing Relations With Russia

BYLINE: By James A. Baker III; James A. Baker III was secretary of state under President George Bush.

 BODY:
In June 1992, Russian President Boris Yeltsin came to Washington to celebrate "partnership and friendship" with the United States. "We have left behind the period when America and Russia looked at each other through gun sights," he told a joint session of Congress.
Nothing better symbolizes the subsequent decline of Russian-American relations than the recent announcement that Russian military strategists had approved use of nuclear weapons "to repel armed aggression" -- which some see as a threatening expansion of Russian nuclear doctrines. 
 The change, however, is less a cause for concern than for regret. Russia is saying it will not rule out using nuclear weapons to defend itself, even from conventional attack, if all other means fail. Militarily, this reflects Russia's weakness, not its strength. The new policy does not mean the United States need fear an offensive Russian nuclear strike. Russia knows the strength, the reach and the effectiveness of the West's strategic nuclear deterrent far too well to take such a risk.
Diplomatically, however, the new policy signals deep distrust, even fear, of the West. On the nuanced scale of diplomatic rhetoric, Russian leaders now reject "partnership and friendship" and embrace "cooperation" -- a step backward.
Russians today believe we exploited the collapse of the Soviet Union to weaken Russia. To a surprising degree, they blame us for their economic troubles. They think we pushed reforms to enrich the few and impoverish the many.
Why, Russians ask themselves, did the United States, after promising that NATO was strictly a defensive alliance, lead it into an offensive war against Russia's ally, Serbia? After the anti-ballistic missile treaty served as one cornerstone of the Russian and American nuclear relationship for 27 years, why does the United States now want to build an antimissile defense system that will destroy the balance? And, by the way, what right does America have to criticize Russia's struggles to keep its federation together in a war no less brutal than the one America fought to preserve its own union?
Americans are equally frustrated -- by misuse of international loans, stories of money laundering, Russian opposition to American foreign policy initiatives in Kosovo and Iraq, Russia's tactics in Chechnya.
So, in this climate, what should the United States do?
First, remember Russia's importance to our own security and prosperity. Russia's weapons of mass destruction pose threats if they fall into the wrong hands. Russia's economy struggles today but has enormous potential. Russia retains influence as a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council. And Russian organized crime infiltrates the West.
Engagement is the only sensible way to encourage a stable, democratic and prosperous Russia. But our expectations must be realistic. Compared with Western models, Russia's economy and democracy are disappointments. Compared with Communism and czarism, however, they reflect major progress.
Some retreat from the euphoria of 1992 was probably inevitable. But it is possible to repair the relationship. Whatever the outcome of elections in both countries this year, the winners should prepare, quickly and deliberately, to make a fresh start to restore good will.
For the United States, that means recognizing that the relationship with Russia is not friend-or-foe, with nothing between. Russia has made great strides in political and press freedom, and almost all elements of Russian society want democracy and capitalism. But our new leaders will also need to recognize that Russia will have its own foreign policy, independent of ours. We should oppose Russia when its policies conflict with our interests and values.
Our involvement with Russia may not immediately produce results. There will be setbacks. Through it all, we must be patient, persistent and a bit modest. Only this approach can stop the drift toward enmity and make possible an ultimate return to friendship.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Gold Tops $300 on Job Data And an Altered Sales Strategy

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The price of gold surged past $300 yesterday, gaining 8 percent after a leading gold producer said it would adjust its sales strategy in anticipation of higher prices.
Gold for delivery in April jumped $23.10, to $313 a troy ounce, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange. It was the biggest gain in four months, the highest price since Oct. 15, and the first time since Nov. 24 that gold had traded for more than $300. 
 The price rose early in the session after the release of new United States unemployment data, and it accelerated after the gold mining company, Placer Dome Inc., released its annual results and said it was changing its sales strategy.
In its announcement, Placer Dome, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, and ranks fifth among global producers, said it would no longer sell borrowed gold, a hedging strategy that is based on expectations of lower prices.
"It looks like mining companies are pulling out of their hedge programs left and right," said Carlos Perez-Santalla, a gold trader at Hudson River Futures in New York. "It's positive for gold."
Prices have risen for three straight sessions, leaving them 7.5 percent higher than a year ago. In London, gold for immediate delivery rose $22.85, to $310.30 an ounce.
"We believe gold prices will move higher," Jay Taylor, chief executive at Placer, said in a statement. He called on other gold companies to "show confidence in gold" and reduce their hedge positions.
Traders who follow the hedging by mining companies for signs of where gold prices are heading said Placer Dome's announcement had increased confidence that prices were heading higher.
Prices rose after the Labor Department said the unemployment rate fell to a 30-year low in January, raising concern for higher salaries and consumer prices. Investors sometimes buy gold as a hedge against inflation.

LENGTH: 1238 words

HEADLINE: In a Valley Pockmarked by Poverty, Developing a Cure for Suburban Blight

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Martin Munoz, his wife and two children live in a home the couple fashioned around a broken-down school bus and a camper trailer. Just across the way, a fighting cock is tethered near another home, which is nothing more than a camper shell on a pickup.
The rag-tag trailer park where the Munoz family has made its home for the last 14 years is a symptom of a gradual but steady decline in living conditions in the northeast San Fernando Valley that has city officials pondering what could be the largest redevelopment project in Los Angeles's history. 
 The problems of the northeast Valley, redevelopment experts say, are part of a relatively new phenomenon that other communities will face in coming decades: suburban blight, or the aging of neighborhoods outside the traditional urban core.
While the roots of the decline -- poverty, a lack of political clout, the departure of the middle class -- may be the same as those found in urban centers, they present new challenges, experts say. Rather than being concentrated in well-defined areas, much of the worst blight in areas like the northeast Valley is tucked away in small pockets.
"The difference is largely a function of land use and scale," said Robert Fazio, a longtime employee of the Los Angeles Community Redevelopment Agency and a coordinator of the San Fernando Valley project. "We don't have the density of New York and Philadelphia, but there still is great economic disparity of income and education levels and employment opportunities."
While blight exists, Mr. Fazio said, "some conditions are so subtle but so pervasive that it's going to be tough to make clearly defined visible improvements."
In all, the redevelopment project would include 6,835 acres and take at least 20 years, with the possibility of being extended another 10 years.
Redevelopment officials, who devised the plan at the City Council's request, are proposing that about $490 million in property taxes be diverted to the area over the next four decades to upgrade land, provide new housing and stimulate business and industry that will generate jobs. Only a broad outline has been sketched.
Early plans single out basic community improvements, like a $100,000 tree-planting initiative, the development of a community-based art plan and improvement of employment, education and transit services.
The proposal is subject to the approval of City Council, which is scheduled to consider it this spring.
The area's decline is rooted in how it grew up, said James P. Allen, a professor of geography at California State University at Northridge and an expert on the ethnic population of Southern California.
The northeast Valley is a sprawling network of older settlements and the remnants of farming communities like Pacoima in the northeast reaches of Los Angeles. It has long been home to new immigrants, particularly Mexicans, who often find it difficult to break the cycle of poverty. Many of those whose skills and incomes improve move on to the more prosperous communities to the west.
Those left behind traditionally had little political clout.
The northeast Valley developed helter-skelter. Residential areas often crouch next to gritty industrial sites. Trailer parks have sprouted beside gravel pits. Small motels that once gave shelter to travelers along Route 99 now house large families in single rooms. While shopping areas are scattered about the northeast Valley, they are heavy on liquor stores and lacking in the kinds of services that families need.
"There are little things that make you see the difference," said Neal S. Dudovitz, executive director of San Fernando Valley Neighborhood Legal Services in the heart of the Pacoima business district. "All the banks have left; there's one bank for about 80,000 people. Until recently, there was no bank machine."
According to reports prepared for the Community Redevelopment Agency, property values in the area declined by 10 percent from 1994 to 1998, compared with less than one-third of 1 percent during that same period in all Los Angeles County. The average household size, a figure used to measure overcrowding, was 3.4 for the area, compared with 2.97 citywide. In some pockets, the average household size was as high as six. Per capital income was $9,266, compared with $16,188 citywide.
The full picture, however, is less visible. Mr. Fazio tells of 10 people living in an old Airstream trailer, paying $100 a month for the right. In old motels, families double up in one-room lodging.
To address housing issues, the plan calls for rehabilitating existing property, selling blighted property and developing new homes. It also proposes neighborhood improvements, like sidewalk installation, paving and new street lights.
Low interest loans are to be offered to encourage business expansion and modernization while long-range strategies for use are developed. In commercial areas, facade fixups are planned, along with general improvements like better lighting, security and parking.
Critics of the project assert that the redevelopment agency has an unimpressive track record in tackling other projects in the city.
"I'm not opposed to revitalization. I'm not opposed to jobs. I'm not opposed to reinvestment or improving people lives. I'm not opposed to redevelopment," said Don Lippman, who does not live in the area but criticizes the agency's work in general. "I'm opposed to the C.R.A because they don't do the job. All they do is take the money."
Redevelopment officials counter by naming more than a half-dozen sites where their efforts have brought improvements -- like Watts, where an agency project brought more housing and a shopping center.
Still, Dick Symonds, who owns a business in the area and recently won a seat on the project's community oversight committee, is apprehensive.
"I'm trying to learn what they are going to do," Mr. Symonds said. "All I've been able to establish so far is what they can do: take your land, make you fix up your land."
Mr. Fazio said no changes would be made without participation and support from the area.
Caron Caines, a legal aid lawyer who has worked on the community advisory panel, said such suspicions about the project were easy to understand. The legal aid office, Ms. Caines said, had opposed some of the practices of the redevelopment agency on the grounds that they had singled out low-income communities "because it's easier to bulldoze them."
"I still think there's a danger of that," she said, adding that she has grown to believe that the agency can play a useful role in redeveloping the area.
"I'm just concerned that it be used as a scalpel and not a hacksaw," Ms. Caines said. "I've worked with them now for years; they're good people that care about the community."
Mr. Munoz, who moved here from Mexico and is now a legal resident of the United States , had not heard about the proposed development.
He did not have an opinion or any expectations, but he did have a rhetorical question: "What can you ask if you live here?"
Still, standing outside his home, an American flag hanging by his door near a small pedal car secured by a chain, he was intrigued by the idea of neighborhood improvements.
"We need more space," said Mr. Munoz, who pays $343 a month rent to stay in the trailer park bordering a recycling center. "A clean yard where the kids can play and not get sick would be good."

HEADLINE: Lee Hills, 93, Knight Ridder Official and Pulitzer Winner

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Lee Hills, who began a journalism career as a teenage reporter covering mining disasters in Utah, continued it as an editor by bringing Pulitzer Prizes and national renown to The Miami Herald and The Detroit Free Press, and finally spread the gospel of quality journalism around the country as chief executive of the Knight Ridder newspaper group, died Thursday in Miami. He was 93.
He earned a law degree by the age of 29 while moving through newspapers in Oklahoma, Indiana, Ohio and Tennessee, and later became well versed in the financial side of the business, but Mr. Hills never strayed far from the newsroom. 
 Even as editor of The Free Press, he could not resist the lure of reporting -- a predilection that won him a Pulitzer Prize in 1955 for coverage of labor negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the automakers. He later revealed that no less a figure than Henry Ford II had been a crucial source.
Five years later, as editor of The Miami Herald, he directed the newspaper's coverage of mob bosses living in the area, a series called "Know Your Neighbor," which won that newspaper its first Pulitzer Prize.
Most of all, according to journalists who knew him, Mr. Hills saw probing, objective journalism as a calling and a public service. Mr. Hills -- an employee and friend of the late John S. Knight, who, with his brother James, owned the Knight newspaper group -- had sought to make the sharp, the curious, the critical and the crusading professionals around him adopt his standards of fairness, objectivity and excellence.
"He knew full well the kind of journalism he had come into, a journalism of faction and interests and parochialism and provincialism, and of a brawling independence as well," said Hodding Carter, speaking of the 1920's and 1930's -- when Mr. Hills covered everything from lynchings to the crime career of Charles (Pretty Boy) Floyd.
"But," Mr. Carter continued, "he believed so strongly in the implications of a free press that he became one of the guys who helped to guide us into the period in which the adoption of standards and the notion of a semi-profession, with real connection to principle, and with the idea that the news came first and public interest came first."
Mr. Carter, who is president of the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, added: "He came up wanting above all else to be a good newspaperman, a good journalist. He became, in effect, the prime minister for Jack Knight as he created a newspaper organization that was solidly successful economically and held to the old values in journalism throughout."
Mr. Hills was born in Egg Creek Township, near Granville, N.D., in 1906. The family moved to Utah after his mother's death in 1911. It was in that state that he took his first job at a newspaper, sweeping floors at The Price News Advocate.
He received his college education at Brigham Young University and the University of Missouri. While working as a reporter and editorial writer at The Oklahoma City Times, which he joined in 1929, he earned a law degree. He later worked for that newspaper's competitor, The Oklahoma News, a Scripps-Howard newspaper, before introducing himself to John Knight in 1942.
According to the obituary in The Detroit Free Press yesterday, Mr. Hills, looking for a new job, asked to meet with Mr. Knight, who, with his brother, owned The Akron Beacon-Journal, The Detroit Free Press and The Miami Herald. Mr. Knight agreed to take him on as a news editor at The Herald. He soon became managing editor.
When the government rationed newsprint at the height of the war, Mr. Hills persuaded Mr. Knight to cut back on advertising to allow full space for war coverage.
Some of the reporting he made room for was his own, as he served briefly as a war correspondent for The Herald, and filed reports from the Far East, the Middle East and Latin America -- an area of the world that fascinated him. At The Herald, he supported extensive coverage of Latin America.
Even as the head of professional groups, he found a way to get back to his reporting roots. In 1962, touring the Soviet Union with 12 editors -- at the time he was president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors -- he got nationwide attention, reporting an interview with the Soviet leader Nikita S. Khrushchev.
As John Knight's chief lieutenant, Mr. Hills served for the better part of three decades -- from 1951 to 1979 -- as executive editor or publisher of both The Herald and The Free Press.
Alvah Chapman, who, like Mr. Hills, served as a chief executive of Knight Ridder, said yesterday: "Lee, of course, was both a business operator and a journalist. He was responsible for the business success as well as the editorial success of The Detroit Free Press. But he was best known for editorial skills and news skills."
Mr. Hills and Mr. Chapman, at Mr. Knight's behest, arranged the 1974 merger of Knight Newspapers Inc. with Ridder Publications Inc., producing a newspaper group that boasted a greater circulation than any of its rivals -- until the rapid growth of USA Today put the Gannett Company into the lead.
Mr. Hills was the first chairman and chief executive of the merged newspaper group. He retired as editorial chairman in 1981.
Mr. Hills was also an active philanthropist in both Detroit and Miami. Mr. Carter credits Mr. Hills with persuading the Knight brothers to set up the Knight Foundation with gifts amounting to more than $400 million. He also served as president of the Inter-American Press Association -- through which he met his third wife, Tina Ramos Hills.
Mr. Hills is survived by his wife and by Ronald Hills of Saratoga, Calif., his son with his first wife, Leona Hass, whom he divorced in 1944. His second wife, Eileen Whitman Hills, whom he married in 1948, died in 1961. He is also survived by two sisters, Louise Elwood, of Seattle, and BeverLee Margolis, of Mercer Island, Wash.; a brother, Stanley Hills, of Mercer Island; two grandsons and three great-grandsons.
Allen H. Neuharth, a colleague of Mr. Hills at The Herald and later, as founder of USA Today, a competitor, said yesterday: "Among journalists, he was a reporter who never stopped being a reporter, even though he went on to be an executive and a publisher. But he retained his reporter's instincts and sensibility, and that motivated everything he did in his newspaper decisions."

HEADLINE: Oman Letting Seized Russian Tanker Dock

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Oman has agreed to accept the Russian tanker seized by two American warships that were enforcing United Nations sanctions against Iraq, a Pentagon official said today.
Oman is letting the Maritime Inspection Force escort the Russian-flagged tanker, which is suspected of smuggling oil out of Iraq, to one of its ports, where officials will await the results of a laboratory analysis of an oil sample to determine its origin, the official said. 
 If the results confirm that the oil is Iraqi, the official said, Oman is most likely to dispose of it and release the ship, which was intercepted on Wednesday.
Russian diplomats boarded the tanker today to ensure the crew's well-being.
The Pentagon also announced that the size of the inspection force was doubled today, from two to four ships, adding that the action was part of a customary rotation. The number of ships that try to smuggle oil out of Iraq has reportedly risen dramatically with the increase in oil prices. In the last year, 700 were boarded and investigated, with 19 being seized.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Tobacco Ally Takes On McCain

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
The National Smokers Alliance, a group subsidized by the tobacco industry, has begun running a 30-second advertisement in South Carolina that sharply attacks Senator John McCain of Arizona for his sponsorship of an antismoking bill to impose fees on tobacco that would have raised the price of a pack of cigarettes by $1.10. South Carolina holds its presidential primary on Feb. 19.
 
PRODUCER -- National Smokers Alliance
 
ON THE SCREEN -- Two black-and-white photographs of Mr. McCain, smiling in one and scowling in the other, materialize as the voice-over labels him a "typical Washington politician." The narrator accuses Mr. McCain of having proposed "the largest consumer tax increase in history" while claiming in his campaign for president that he has "never voted for a tax increase." Headlines appear on the screen from articles by United Press International ("McCain vows tobacco taxes, regulation") and The San Diego Union-Tribune ("Tobacco politics: tax and spend, not smoking, defined McCain's bill"). They are followed by an effect in which the two photographs merge into one, intended to suggest political duplicity. 

SCRIPT -- Narrator: "John McCain, presidential candidate, meet Senator John McCain, typical Washington politician. Candidate McCain states that as senator he has never voted for a tax increase. Yet in 1998, Senator McCain sponsored legislation backed by President Clinton to increase tobacco taxes. Senator McCain's bill would have imposed the largest consumer tax increase in history: $516 billion. Saying one thing and doing another. That's the real John McCain."
 
ACCURACY -- Mr. McCain was in fact chief architect of legislation intended to discourage smoking among young people. In June 1998 the bill died on the Senate floor because backers could not muster the 60 votes they needed on procedural issues. In addition to the fees, the bill would have imposed monetary penalties on cigarette makers if the number of young smokers did not decline to designated levels. Mr. McCain and the White House, which supported the measure, estimated the 25-year cost of the bill at $516 billion. The senator has, indeed, asserted that he has never voted to raise taxes, and some supporters of the bill said the fees did not constitute a tax. Still, a levy imposed on a commodity like cigarettes, sometimes referred to as a "sin tax," is intended less as a means of filling government coffers than as a way of enforcing a social mandate.
 
SCORECARD -- A classic attack advertisement tailored to the perceived economic insecurities of a tobacco state. The advertisement also tries to portray Mr. McCain as an inside-the-Beltway ally of Mr. Clinton, who is not popular in South Carolina Republican politics. The National Smokers Alliance, which is based in Alexandria, Va., and claims a membership of three million, clashed with Mr. McCain over the 1998 bill; the group, financed in part by the Philip Morris Companies and the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, ran advertisements at the time attacking Mr. McCain. He proved somewhat impervious to cries of hypocrisy on tax issues from advertisements sponsored by interest groups in New Hampshire, and whether the approach has more traction when tied to a home-grown industry like tobacco remains to be seen.
 PETER MARKS

HEADLINE: Post and News Considered Shared Tasks, But Declined

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
The New York Post and The Daily News, whose rivalry has generated flashes of rapier tabloid journalism and multimillion-dollar losses, have held exploratory talks on combining their printing and distribution operations to cut costs, but the discussions have gone nowhere, officials of both papers said yesterday.
In interviews, Ken Chandler, publisher and editor in chief of The Post, and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, chairman and co-publisher of The Daily News, confirmed a Wall Street Journal report yesterday that talks had been held, but both suggested the discussions had been dormant for months and might even be dead. 
 "We always listen to new ideas that are put before us," Mr. Chandler said. "Some preliminary meetings were held. But we are proceeding with our business plans with or without outside parties."
Mr. Zuckerman sounded even less sanguine. "There were talks in the most limited sense, but they never went beyond the exploratory stage," he said. "We never got into specific discussions, and they're unlikely to be revived."
Both men were reluctant to discuss the substance of the talks, except to acknowledge that a merging of printing and distribution operations had been among the topics. There were apparently several sessions over a year that ended about six months ago. It was unclear why the talks were suspended.
The discussions took place against the backdrop of New York City's highly competitive market for newspaper readers and advertisers, in which The Post and The News, two of the nation's largest tabloids, have struggled to survive.
Both tabloids are privately held and do not disclose finances. But The Post, owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, is believed by newspaper analysts to lose $9 million to $15 million a year, and The Daily News recently disclosed in court documents that it lost $17.9 million in 1998, despite a cash infusion of $19 million by Mr. Zuckerman.
Relying on the deep pockets of their owners, the tabloids have each invested heavily in new color presses -- a $200 million plant in the Bronx for The Post and a $62 million plant in Jersey City for The News. The News has had problems with its presses, curtailing the number of lucrative color ads it could sell, and lost a lawsuit against Goss Graphic Systems, which supplied the presses.
The News is also caught up in a potentially expensive arbitration dispute with its drivers, and its circulation has declined. In the six months ended last Sept. 30, its circulation dropped by about 20,000, to 701,831 on weekdays and 790,911 on Sundays, while The Post's circulation was up slightly to 438,158 on weekdays, although its Sunday circulation dropped 5.6 percent to 360,945.
In some cities where hard economics have threatened to kill newspapers, the government has sanctioned cost-cutting agreements in which two papers share production, distribution and even business operations while keeping separate newrooms and editorial voices. The Post-Daily News talks apparently never broached such far-reaching cooperation.
Indeed, as the two sides appeared to back away from the contacts yesterday, the old rivalries rose to the surface, and there seemed to be so little common ground that Mr. Chandler and Mr. Zuckerman could not even agree on who had initiated the contacts.
"A friend of Mr. Murdoch called me and said they would like to get together and talk, so we did," Mr. Zuckerman said.
But Mr. Chandler recalled it differently. "The Daily News reached out to us and asked if we would be interested in ways to share some production costs."
And Mr. Zuckerman said: "I think they are losing an immense amount of money. To merge two very complicated processes on an operational level would be difficult."

HEADLINE: President to Ask for Increase In Help for Manufacturers

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
In the budget he will send to Congress on Monday, President Clinton will propose increased spending to help manufacturers who have been hit by competition from abroad and a shortage of skilled workers at home, administration officials said today.
The proposals have the backing both of organized labor and manufacturing groups. They were developed, in part, at the urging of Vice President Al Gore, administration officials said. 
 Although Mr. Gore is backed by most unions, he is at odds with organized labor over his support for free trade and bringing China into the World Trade Organization. Even so, the proposals could help him show that he is sensitive to the upheaval that global competition is creating among manufacturers.
In his budget, for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, Mr. Clinton will propose an increase of $386 million in spending on a variety of programs that could help manufacturers, administration officials said.
Among the proposals is an increase of $215 million, or 26 percent, for the Export-Import Bank of the United States to help promote exports.
The others include $30 million in new matching grants to states for training programs designed to help manufacturing workers keep up with changing technology. Financing for a separate program to give more science and math training to technicians would be increased to $14 million from $4 million.
Mr. Clinton will also propose a substantial expansion of programs that monitor and enforce trade agreements, in particular those that watch for rapid surges in imports from competitors selling their goods below cost or taking advantage of big swings in exchange rates. Industries like steel were hit hard by import surges after the global financial crisis in 1997 and 1998, prompting calls from manufacturers and from Congress for protectionist measures.
Mr. Clinton will also call for expansions of existing programs to help areas that lose factory jobs to foreign competition and for more money for programs to help smaller manufacturers learn to use the Internet to do business.
Dave Smith, the director of public policy for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said the proposals were "all steps in the right direction" but were modest relative to the size of the problems.
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said the White House had clearly recognized two important issues, "the move to e-commerce and the skills shortage in America's work force."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Unemployment Rate Fell To Just 4 Percent in January
The nation's employers created 387,000 new jobs in January, more than in any single month in more than two years. The Labor Department also said that the unemployment rate fell to 4 percent, the lowest level in 30 years. It had been 4.1 percent since October.
The average hourly pay of the nation's nonsupervisory production workers -- about 90 million people in a work force of 130.3 million last month -- rose by 6 cents in January, to $13.50 an hour. That represents an annual rise of just 3.5 percent, down from an annualized increase of 3.7 percent last fall. Page A1. 

Nasdaq Soars to Another Record
The Nasdaq composite index rounded out a strong week with a new high as investors moved money from industrial companies that may be hurt by rising interest rates to technology companies. The Nasdaq composite index gained 33.16 points, to 4,244.14, above its previous record of 4,235.40, set Jan. 21. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 49.64 points, to 10,963.80, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.60 point, to 1,424.37. The yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.26 percent from 6.13 percent on Thursday. C3.
 
Social Security Review Criticized

HEADLINE: Military Rumblings in Indonesia

 BODY:
Indonesia's passage from army-backed dictatorship to freely elected civilian government over the past two years, though accompanied by terrible economic hardships, is one of Asia's great political success stories. But that achievement is now threatened by a tense confrontation between President Abdurrahman Wahid and Indonesia's most powerful military figure, Gen. Wiranto. For democracy to survive in the world's fourth largest country, Mr. Wahid must prevail.
Mr. Wahid's accession to power last fall marked a clear change at the top of the country's political structure. But at lower levels, much power remained in military hands. Mr. Wahid has tried, gingerly, to ease the army out of politics and subject it to civilian authority and justice. 
 The current crisis was triggered when a government human rights commission this week found General Wiranto responsible for much of the killing and destruction carried out by pro-Indonesian militias on East Timor last year. The commission recommended his criminal indictment. President Wahid appropriately asked the general to resign immediately as minister for security affairs. Mr. Wahid also said that General Wiranto would be tried, but promised to pardon the general if he was convicted.
But General Wiranto has refused to resign. Mr. Wahid, who is traveling in Europe, returns to Indonesia on Feb. 13. Meanwhile there are mounting fears that some of General Wiranto's military supporters may be plotting a coup.
Any military move against the elected government would have devastating consequences. Washington has already said that Indonesia would find itself internationally isolated. Foreign investors would withdraw their funds. Most important, Indonesia's people would strongly resist any return to military rule.
President Wahid has warned restive officers that the civilian authorities are now in charge and urged them to be careful. Washington and other democratic governments must do everything in their power to discourage Indonesian military officers from challenging Mr. Wahid's authority. His continued constitutional rule offers Indonesia its best hope for a peaceful and prosperous future.

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Donations Lag in Last Weeks of Appeal

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN

 BODY:
From Wall Street power brokers to young children with small allowances, people across the metropolitan area and beyond have given more than $5 million this year to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which supports seven of the city's oldest and most respected social service organizations.
Since the 1994-95 campaign, donations to the fund have gone up with every year, but despite a booming economy and a new way of donating, via The Times's Web site -- at www.nytimes.com/neediest -- the amount of money raised in this year's campaign may fall below last year's record total. 
 Daily contribution levels have decreased over the past month, now that the holiday season is over. On Thursday, the fund received only $2,385.63, less money than on any previous day in this year's campaign. Between Thanksgiving and New Year's Day, the fund received an average of $84,822.54 each day.
But the problems of the poor do not go away after the last few bars of "Auld Lang Syne" are sung and people put away their party hats.
Helping to buoy this year's totals are the many donors who give year after year, often in memory of a parent or spouse who had given for many years. And there are people like Alyson Sikorski, who this year made her first donation to the fund.
Ms. Sikorski, a structural engineer with Goldstein Associates, a consulting firm, organized a fund-raising effort at her office in Midtown Manhattan. She and 29 of her co-workers gave a total of $300 to the fund. "We're lucky enough to have jobs and to be able to support ourselves and our families," she said.
Whether they spend their days in the office towers that line the Avenue of the Americas or in classrooms on shady suburban streets, donors to the fund have little in common, except compassion for the less fortunate. While reasons for giving vary, many say they donate to the fund because The Times pays the fund's administrative costs, so every dollar received goes to those in need.
A fourth-grade class from Rye, N.Y., gave $388.10 to the fund in January and sent a handwritten letter signed by 15 students in Elizabeth Block's class at the Rye Country Day School: "In Mrs. Block's class we talk about the news a lot. As we talked about it we realized that there are a lot of poor people, and we decided that we should try to help them because we are more fortunate. We chose you because you don't use up the money. You send it to the people who need it."
Some of Mrs. Block's students helped raise money by doing chores at home like setting the dinner table, taking out the garbage or pet-sitting. Others contributed their allowances. Still others gave out of their savings, providing money to those in need, often because of circumstances beyond their control: the death of a family member, sudden medical expenses or the loss of a job.
"Some of the things we hope you'll help with are homeless people who are getting arrested, or people who have little clothes or don't have enough food and drink," the letter said.
The money the class raised is enough to provide warm winter clothes to children born into poverty, or to help buy furniture for a family burned out of their apartment by a fire, or keep a family from being evicted and forced into a shelter.
Each year, some of the largest contributions to the fund come because of a group of dozens of committed young financial analysts, who despite busy schedules work hard to persuade their Wall Street colleagues to give.
Last year, they raised a total of $201,286 for the fund. This week, the group turned over its first installment from this year's drive, $45,228 from employees of Salomon Smith Barney. Money from eight other Wall Street firms participating in the fund-raising effort is expected to be given before the Neediest Cases appeal ends at the end of the month.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
Bush Begins Taking Shots at McCain

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 5

 BODY:
In a new offensive against his surging opponent, Gov. George W. Bush today attacked Senator John McCain for accepting campaign contributions from corporations he helps regulate as head of the Senate Commerce Committee.
Mr. Bush, who suffered a numbing defeat at the hands of Mr. McCain in the New Hampshire primary, also unveiled a new television commercial that included some of the harshest criticism to date of his rival. 
 Accusing Mr. McCain of "Washington double talk," Mr. Bush said his actions as head of the Commerce Committee seemed to clash with his image as the champion of campaign finance reform.
"He's a person who's a committee chairman," Mr. Bush said. "He's used his positions skillfully to forward his campaign."
Mr. Bush also referred to news reports that Mr. McCain intervened with federal regulators on behalf of a company whose plane he used to travel to campaign events. "When you're chairman of the Commerce Committee, one is capable of finding people to fly you on their airplanes and very capable of using that position to raise money," he said.
The new Bush advertisement began running tonight in South Carolina and is the first by Mr. Bush that attacks Mr. McCain by name. It criticizes a 3-week-old McCain commercial in which the senator asserted that "the one big difference" between him and the other candidates was that "I won't take every last dime of the surplus and spend it on tax cuts that mostly benefit the wealthy."
In the Bush commercial, an announcer says, "John McCain's ad about Governor Bush's tax plan isn't true, and McCain knows it." Mr. McCain's economic adviser says he would support Mr. Bush's plan -- $2 trillion to protect Social Security, reduce the debt and a real tax cut. "McCain's plan?" it continues. "A tax cut smaller than Clinton's. And not a penny in tax cuts for 30 million Americans."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: POLITICAL MEMO;
A New Challenge for Bush: Showing He Wants to Win

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 4

 BODY:
In the past, when Gov. George W. Bush pondered his astonishingly charmed political career, he sometimes sought metaphors to describe the feeling of being propelled and kept afloat by forces that were larger than he was, and beyond his control. He once compared himself to a cork in a stream.
It was an acknowledgment that he had managed to become the governor of Texas without too much fuss or any previous experience in office. It also remarked on the dizzying spectacle of watching Republican kingmakers and money men beat a path to his door after his landslide re-election in 1998. 
 Mr. Bush, in other words, has had it pretty easy. So his crushing defeat to Senator John McCain in the New Hampshire primary, after what many Republicans call a halfhearted campaign there, has led many political observers and Republican officials to wonder how much they really know about the level of determination, energy and humility that Mr. Bush can bring to this quest.
Can he reach down into his gut and find the passion, inspiration and invention that a pivotal juncture like this one requires? Can he regroup, retool, hone a message that apparently did not resonate and find a tone that is more commanding, and less merrily lackadaisical, than the one he has used so far?
"Those are very real questions rooted in the nature of how all of this came about," said Bruce Buchanan, a political science professor at the University of Texas here. "The governor did not go out and build this possibility for himself in any kind of dogged, persistent way of Bill Clinton or Richard Nixon, two prototypes of people who decided they wanted to be president at the age of 4."
But the New Hampshire primary cast doubts on whether Mr. Bush -- or, for that matter, his advisers -- were fully prepared to capitalize on that chance. In the days leading up to the contest, Mr. Bush clung to a confidence about the outcome that proved entirely unwarranted, and he followed a schedule that was sometimes curiously undemanding.
He took midday breaks. He played in the snow for television cameras. And he gave the impression of being tired and homesick.
"They mailed in the campaign," marveled a Republican strategist in Washington. "They did an endorsement a day, and they went sledding."
Even one of Mr. Bush's advisers acknowledged: "I think he worked hard in New Hampshire, but I think they were all surprised by how hard he had to work. Until you do this, you don't get it."
Now more than ever, Mr. Bush has to fight. And the signals of whether he is up to the task -- indeed, whether he truly appreciates the need -- are contradictory and inconclusive.
His public manner since he left New Hampshire has been relentlessly upbeat. And even as polls showed that support in South Carolina was flagging, he arrived there with an arsenal of optimistic quips about shaking the snow off his suit, moving past a bump in the road and onto a smooth highway, forsaking an alien land for a patch of terra firma that was clearly "Bush country."
He chalked up New Hampshire as an aberration, and so, too, did some of his senior aides, almost all of whom have been with Mr. Bush for the last five years in Texas and know him as a charismatic, easygoing man who always rides high.
But Mr. Bush said in a private interview in Detroit today that anyone who mistook his jocularity and stubborn optimism for an inability to hunker down and fight was misreading him.
"Make no mistake about it," he said emphatically in the back hallway of a church where he was campaigning. "Not only do I want to win, I'm going to win. I want to win bad enough to win, and I'm going to win. You can mark it down in your book: on this day, I told you, looked you in the eye, and said I'm going to win the nomination, and I believe I'm going to win the presidency."
"You should not be lulled into a false sense about me, about my competitive nature and my desire to lead this country," he said.
There are external signs that Mr. Bush is heeding the lessons of New Hampshire. In the past two days, he has significantly ratcheted up his criticisms of Mr. McCain.
He began to question Mr. McCain's calls for more integrity in government, noting reports in newspapers that the Arizona senator sometimes received favors or campaign contributions from people who appeared before the Senate Commerce Committee, which Mr. McCain chairs.
He challenged Mr. McCain's claims that his proposal for tax cuts did not leave enough surplus money for Social Security, a charge he answered less aggressively in New Hampshire. The Bush campaign began running a television commercial in South Carolina tonight that belittled Mr. McCain's assertion, likened Mr. McCain to President Clinton and other Democrats and labeled Mr. Bush the true conservative.
"On taxes," the ad states, "McCain echoes Washington Democrats, when we need a conservative leader to challenge them."
Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for the Bush campaign, said more was in store. "I think you're going to see the fire in the governor's belly when he comes out on Monday," Mr. Fleischer said. "We are not going to let Senator McCain again engage in the type of misrepresentation of the governor's position he successfully engaged in in New Hampshire."
Mr. Bush also began rounding out the economic thrust of his oratory in New Hampshire with some of the broader themes he articulated all through the first phase of his campaign last year -- like the importance of personal responsibility and trying to diminish the number of children born out of wedlock and encouraging youths to stay off drugs.
But he still seems to be hanging much of his campaign on the promotion of a massive tax cut that polls suggest is not high on many voters' lists of priorities.
And even in the wake of New Hampshire, he continued the parade of endorsements that played directly into Mr. McCain's claim that what was happening in the Republican primary was a coronation, not an election. On Wednesday, in Greenville, S.C., Mr. Bush trotted out former Vice President Dan Quayle. The gesture left some political analysts scratching their heads.
Mr. Bush's friends and advisers say that none of this should be read as complacency. Moreover, it remains to be seen if Mr. Bush can harness and sustain the energy for what is shaping up to be a longer primary fight than anyone originally envisioned.
When Clay Johnson, Mr. Bush's Texas chief of staff and lifelong friend, praised Mr. Bush's discipline in an interview two months ago, the anecdote easily yielded to a different interpretation.
"He had two hard half-days," Mr. Johnson said of Mr. Bush's schedule as governor. He said Mr. Bush began at 8:30 a.m., ended around 5:30 p.m. and had 90 minutes to two hours of "personal time."
"It requires a lot of discipline not to get sucked into a lunch or a meeting or something," he said. "But it's an inviolate part of his routine, and so, be it a light lunch or exercise or whatever it is, he insists on getting that.
"It's very hard to do, as you can imagine. All my friends say it's impossible to exercise. I say, how can the governor carve the time out if you can't?"
