HEADLINE: Austria Coalition Sworn In as Diplomatic Fallout Rises

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Feb. 4

 BODY:
President Thomas Klestil swore in a coalition government today that includes members of the anti-immigration Freedom Party. That prompted the United States to recall its ambassador "for consultations" and European governments to begin downgrading relations in protest.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said contacts with the Austrian government would be limited, adding that there should be no place in a European government for a party that "doesn't distance itself clearly from the atrocities of the Nazi era and the politics of hate." 
 The leader of the Freedom Party, Jorg Haider, has done just that in recent days, calling the Nazi regime barbaric and signing a document that commits the new government to work for an Austria free of xenophobia and anti-Semitism. But his volte-face after past expressions of sympathy for aspects of Hitler's rule has not convinced the West.
At a tense ceremony in the Hofburg Palace, the icy manner and averted gaze of Mr. Klestil conveyed all his personal distaste for the intermittently hate-mongering politics of Mr. Haider's far-rightist party as he took the oaths of office from the 12 cabinet ministers.
Thousands of demonstrators brandishing banners that denounced Mr. Haider as a fascist clashed with the police outside, obliging the ministers from the conservative People's Party and the Freedom Party to use a tunnel to cross under the square that separates the president's office from the chancellery.
The subterranean debut, and the clamor in the habitually sedate streets of the capital, seemed to sum up the looming isolation of the coalition and the abrupt disquiet of a country better known for consensus than conflict.
Israel immediately withdrew its ambassador. Germany and Finland said bilateral ministerial contacts had been frozen, and other European Union countries promised to follow suit, honoring a commitment made on Monday to shun ministerial-level contacts if Mr. Haider's party entered the government.
"We are filled with concern for Europe," Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer of Germany said, echoing the alarm of several European countries whose real fear is not immediate upheaval, but the prospect that the Austrian coalition could break the general consensus that the moderate right in Europe should not ally with the extreme right.
Such alliances in countries like Germany or France would have a shattering effect on the broad thrust of postwar politics, threatening further moves toward European integration. But for now those moves remain a remote possibility.
The new government here is headed by Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel of the center-right People's Party. Mr. Schussel's decision to form a coalition's giving the sanction of high office to the Freedom Party brought three decades of Social Democratic-led government to an end and the wrath of the West down on Austria.
The formation of the government was the first stage in what could be a protracted battle between Austria and its 14 European Union partners, who have in effect committed themselves to undermining the coalition by isolating it.
"The European governments have placed themselves on a very high horse, from which it will not be easy to descend," said a British foreign policy expert, Jonathan Eyal. "Their unstated aim now seems to be to bring the Austria government down. But what if that merely makes Mr. Haider stronger?"
The long-term effect of the European action appears difficult to predict. The Austrian stock market fell 3 percent today, and rumors of canceled investments and a downgrade of the country's credit rating swirled here. It appears just possible that the economy could suffer to a point where the government becomes vulnerable.
Faced by a possibility of real damage to the country, Mr. Klestil made an extraordinary televised appeal today, several hours after swearing in the government. "The People's Party and the Freedom Party have a majority of seats in Parliament," he said, referring to the two parties' 104 seats in the 183-member chamber. "This must be respected in a democracy. Therefore, the intention of the two parties to form a coalition had to be accepted in a democratic state based on the rule of law.
"To the members of the federal government, I appeal to you to act in the spirit of European values and to work with all your strength so that Austria will find the kind of international acceptance and recognition it deserves."
The European Union took the past words of Mr. Haider as a legitimate basis to downgrade diplomatic relations, a step that the United States has not taken. Still, the Clinton administration's displeasure is clear enough. Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said the new government "might be a step back into a very dark past."
The past in question is the Third Reich, enthusiastically embraced by many Austrians in 1938 and occasionally defended by Mr. Haider in references to Hitler's labor policies and his Waffen SS.
Mr. Haider has since tried to take back those remarks and, in a declaration signed this week with Mr. Schussel, committed himself to "understanding for all human beings irrespective of their origin."
But in an interview today with German television, Mr. Haider appeared to cast scorn on the document. "It is an affront for the Austrian public that such matters of course have to be signed time and again," Mr. Haider said. "I have no intention of wandering around the world apologizing for all kinds of things."
Mr. Haider has chosen not to join the government and stay on as governor of the southern province of Carinthia. But there is little doubt that his influence will be strong.
Many Austrians, tired of the Social Democrats and worried by rising immigration, embraced his message, pushing his party's share of the vote from 5 percent in 1983 to 28 in elections in October.
Today, Foreign Minister Benita Ferrero-Waldner, a member of the People's Party, said she would tell the European Union that it had overreacted. "Jorg Haider has made mistakes," Ms. Ferrero-Waldner said. "But he has also distanced himself from his mistakes, and he is not in the government."

HEADLINE: Expansion Provided 387,000 New Jobs In U.S. Last Month

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Far from easing off as the American economic expansion was becoming the longest in history, the nation's employers added more jobs in January than in any other single month in more than two years -- drawing in people who had given up looking for work and easing the struggle of millions of workers to make ends meet.
The January increase of 387,000 new jobs was the biggest jump since September 1997, when employees of United Parcel Service, returning from a strike, swelled the count to 408,000, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The unemployment rate ticked down another notch, to 4 percent, the lowest level in exactly 30 years. It had been 4.1 percent since October. 
 Wall Street saw the January employment numbers as fresh evidence of a rising inflation rate, if not right away, then by early spring -- the concern being that a shortage of workers forces employers to pay higher wages and then to raise prices to cover the added labor costs.
"These latest numbers do not give any evidence of the slowdown in the economy that many of us had been expecting in the new year," said Edward McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. "The next set of inflation numbers may be low, but the forces we are seeing threaten to push inflation higher soon."
Reacting to the employment report, bond traders pushed up interest rates mildly out of concern that strong employment will eventually result in higher inflation unless the economy slows. In yesterday's action, they reversed course after having driven down long-term rates all week. Traders had been in turmoil over the Clinton administration's plan to shrink more quickly than expected the number of long-term bonds used to finance the national debt. That prospect had people rushing to buy the bonds while the supply lasted. The demand drove up prices of those bonds and drove down the interest rates that the Treasury must pay to get people to buy its bonds.
But while Wall Street saw inflation in the employment report, the Clinton administration saw stability and also the danger that rising rates -- pushed up too quickly by bond traders and the Federal Reserve -- could water down the economic boom in an election year. The Fed raised short-term interest rates on Wednesday by one-quarter of a percentage point and warned of "heightened inflation pressures in the near future."
Secretary of Labor Alexis Herman said in an interview yesterday, however, that the labor market, despite the low unemployment rate, was not inflationary.
"We cannot continue to have these quick reactions to the employment numbers; we have to take the long view," she said. "This is a strong economy that is in balance with a significant pool of people available to take on more work."
She argued that a fluke drove up job growth in January. Of the 387,000 jobs created last month, nearly half -- 169,000 -- were a result of an unusual spell of warm weather in mid-January, just when her department was taking its monthly job survey, she said. Construction jobs rose by 116,000 rather than a more normal 18,000 for January, and similar spikes occurred in industries related to construction -- landscape gardening, for example, and the manufacture of plywood and concrete.
Take away the 169,000 and job growth last month was only 218,000, Ms. Herman said. That is still too much for Wall Street economists. The economy can average a maximum of only 150,000 new jobs a month and still avoid an unacceptable rise in the inflation rate, said Chris Varvares, a partner at Macroeconomic Advisers Inc., a forecasting service in St. Louis.
Job growth averaged 234,000 a month last year, an unusually high level for an expansion that became 107 months old this week, the longest in history and one month older than the 1960's expansion.
If all these new jobs are inflationary, the evidence is missing from the Labor Department's wage data. The average hourly pay of the nation's nonsupervisory production workers -- about 90 million people in a work force of 130.3 million last month -- rose by 6 cents in January, to $13.50 an hour. That represents an annual rise of just 3.5 percent, down from an annualized increase of 3.7 percent last fall. Most other labor cost indexes are also rising mildly.
Whatever the inflationary effect of a booming job market, the monthly job reports, including the one in January, suggest that millions of Americans are finding it easier to make ends meet. The percentage of the work force holding two or more jobs, for example, fell to 5.7 percent last month from 6 percent in January of last year -- suggesting that more and more people now earn enough at one job to get by or get enough extra hours from their employer to avoid taking a second job, or both.
Then, too, the number of people stuck in part-time jobs because they cannot get full-time work is shrinking. So is the pool of people who say they would like to work but are not looking because they are discouraged or think they cannot find work or cannot arrange child care or transportation. Since they are not actively looking for work, they are not included in the labor force, even as unemployed.
But these are the people who are being drawn increasingly into jobs. Their numbers have dwindled steadily from 6.7 million in January 1994, when the Bureau of Labor Statistics first started to track them, to 4.7 million in January 1999 and to 4.3 million last month, the bureau reported yesterday.
That leaves a pool of more than 10 million people still to draw from, including the 6 million who are listed as actively looking for work and therefore officially unemployed.
"An economy where jobs are looking for people as well as people looking for jobs is one of the best social programs we have," Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said at a news conference yesterday.
The weather was not the only factor in driving up job creation last month. The Census Bureau added 11,000 people as it geared up for the 2000 census. After months of cutting back, manufacturers have begun to add people, including 13,000 last month. With oil prices rising, the petroleum industry is also adding people. Retailers added 43,000 people, which is unusual so soon after Christmas, although consumer spending continues to be robust.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Sets Record as Shift to Technology Accelerates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index rounded out its best week in history with a record yesterday as investors moved money from industrial companies that may be hurt by rising interest rates to technology companies.
The Nasdaq composite index soared 33.16 points, or 0.79 percent, to 4,244.14, above its previous record of 4,235.40, set Jan. 21. In percentage terms, the technology-dominated index rose 9.1 percent, its best weekly performance in history. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 49.64 points, or 0.45 percent, to 10,963.80, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 0.6 point, to 1,424.37.
"Money continues to shift from the real world to the virtual world," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd. in New York. "Money managers are going to the stocks that they know will perform."
Investors put money into shares of Nasdaq's largest stocks, including Apple Computer, Intel and Cisco Systems.
But smaller, younger companies that are just beginning to capitalize on the technology craze drew attention as well. Firepond, a maker of software that helps companies manage their electronic-commerce businesses, soared in its initial offering of stock.
"It takes a lot of equipment and labor to build the Internet, not just ideas," Mr. Bleier said. "The companies that are figuring out how to improve the Internet are going to do very well."
The broader market proved more vulnerable after the government delivered the latest indication that the economy is growing quickly enough to persuade the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates in its effort to keep inflation at bay.
The Labor Department said yesterday that employers added 387,000 jobs in January, pushing the unemployment rate down to 4 percent, its lowest level since 1970. Still, some economists had expected the jobless rate to tumble below 4 percent, and investors drew some confidence when it did not, traders said.
Average hourly earnings, a key gauge of inflation pressures, rose a slightly higher-than-expected 0.4 percent, to $13.50, in January, the fastest pace since September.
Despite the rise in wages, analysts said investors apparently had faith that the Federal Reserve was in control of inflation. On Wednesday, the Fed increased rates for the fourth time since June, and indicated that more increases might be on the way.
Vodafone AirTouch was an exception to the strength in technology shares, falling after the company sweetened its bid for the German wireless company Mannesmann. Mannesmann shareholders will vote by Feb. 17 on the Vodafone offer, which is valued at $183 billion.
Mattel shares fell on the New York Stock Exchange a day after its chief executive and chairwoman, Jill E. Barad, resigned. The toymaker reported a steep loss for the fourth quarter, disappointing Wall Street analysts for the third time in the last four quarters.
 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
Treasuries Drop
Treasury bond prices were unable to shake off early heavy losses yesterday after surprisingly strong jobs data reawakened inflation fears and fueled profit taking after stellar gains a day earlier.
Dealers said the heavy drop showed a measure of normality had returned to bond markets after a week of huge price gains, particularly in the 30-year Treasury bond, set off by a government plan to buy back $30 billion of its debt and cut issuance.
"After a few days where it seemed the only thing the bond market was focused on was reduced supply and maybe scarcity, the bond market is reacting a little more normally to the flow of economic information," said Richard Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond plunged 1 25/32, to 98 5/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.26 percent from 6.13 percent on Thursday.
The 10-year notes fell 18/32, to 96 9/32 with a yield of 6.53 percent. Five-year notes were off 16/32 at 96 29/32, yielding 6.64 percent. Two-year notes were down 6/32, to 99 17/32 to yield 6.63 percent.

HEADLINE: Panel Recommends Reparations In Long-Ignored Tulsa Race Riot

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla., Feb. 4

 BODY:
Nearly 80 years after this city erupted in what many historians regard as the nation's bloodiest race riot, a state commission today recommended reparations be made to the aged black survivors who watched as people were shot, burned alive or tied to cars and dragged to death.
The preliminary findings of the Tulsa Race Riot Commission are expected to provoke a contentious debate in the Oklahoma Legislature, which convenes on Monday. The Legislature created the commission more than two years ago to investigate a massacre long obscured in history. But the issue of reparations is controversial. Many lawmakers oppose any payments, and recent polls suggest that a majority of residents share that opinion. 
 A final decision on reparations may be many months away, at best, and the commission did not estimate their cost. The Legislature must first decide whether to extend the life of the commission, whose term expires on Monday even though it has not completed a final report. But the commission's 7-to-4 vote in favor of reparations was a firm statement that advocates hope will lend moral weight to helping the riot's survivors.
"The Legislature may not do what we think is the right thing," said Dr. Vivian N. Clark, a commission member. "But the world is looking at them, so whatever they do will reflect on the state of Oklahoma."
The riot occurred in 1921, and while 40 deaths have been documented, the commission's historian, Scott Ellsworth, has said that interviews and records indicate that the actual death toll could be as high as 300 people. In justifying reparations, the commission noted that the attack far surpassed the 1923 massacre in Rosewood, Fla., in which whites destroyed the small town and killed at least six black residents. In 1994, the Florida Legislature provided up to $2 million to compensate survivors. The commission also noted that Congress authorized $1 billion to revitalize south-central Los Angeles after the 1992 riots.
The workings of the Race Riot Commission have sparked a remarkable and often uncomfortable period of introspection in Oklahoma. For decades, the riots were never publicly discussed in Tulsa, nor mentioned in classrooms or textbooks. Many residents had no idea that whites burned the city's once-prosperous black community to the ground.
But the commission has collected thousands of documents, many found in attics or dusty file rooms. More than 1,000 elderly people have called with information, and investigators have found 80 survivors, many of them elderly and infirm. The commission's plans to excavate a section of a city cemetery in search of a mass grave of riot victims was postponed by Tulsa city officials last week because of bad weather and information that suggested they might be looking in the wrong place.
Two commission members, State Senator Robert V. Milacek and State Representative Abe Deutschendorf, voted against the reparations resolution because they did not think the wording should suggest that the state, unlike the city of Tulsa, bore any culpability for the massacre. Mr. Milacek said many lawmakers were likely to oppose reparations for fear that allowing them could establish a precedent for other communities to seek redress for past injustices.
"Where does it end?" asked Mr. Milacek, a Republican who said he had agonized over the issue and considered the riot a blight on the state.
Gov. Frank Keating, a Republican, has endorsed direct reparations to survivors but expressed skepticism about broader payments. In today's meeting, the commission recommended, among other things, direct payments to survivors and descendants of those killed, scholarships for students in the Greenwood district where the riot occurred, the creation of an economic empowerment zone and a monument memorializing the event.
Last November, a subcommittee of the Race Riot Commission recommended that $33 million be paid in reparations, an amount that stunned the public. But today, the commission intentionally did not recommend a dollar amount, deferring that responsibility to lawmakers. But the preliminary report that will be presented next week does mention a figure, $12 million.
State Representative Don Ross, a Democrat who represents the Greenwood neighborhood, said he did not want the Legislature to consider voting on reparations until a final report was drafted. Mr. Ross plans to introduce a bill next week to reauthorize the commission, and he said a final report would better establish the historical record and more firmly determine culpability.
"I can't help but believe that if a compelling document is delivered that the attitude of the Legislature will change," Mr. Ross said.
"There is no statute of limitations on a moral obligation," he added.
Alfred L. Brophy, an Oklahoma City University law professor who researched the issue for the commission, said there was compelling legal and moral justification for reparations, even though the historical record was incomplete. He said preliminary research indicated that city officials not only failed to protect the lives of black residents but also contributed to the riot by deputizing many members of the white mob that attacked Greenwood. He also noted that promises to rebuild Greenwood were never fulfilled.
The commission was created in 1997 by a law written by Mr. Ross, for whom the attack has been a defining crusade. The commission is led by Bob L. Blackburn, the chairman of the state historical society, and includes lawmakers, historians and at least one survivor of the riots.
Mr. Ross learned about the riot when a teacher mentioned it to him as a young boy. He was infuriated and incredulous at the story. In segregated Tulsa, the Greenwood community once had been a thriving black business and residential district. It was home to 15,000 people and 191 businesses.
On the morning of May 30, 1921, a black shoe-shiner named Dick Rowland and a white elevator operator named Sarah Page had an encounter inside an elevator at the Drexel Building on Main Street. Exactly what happened is not known, though the commission suggested that Mr. Rowland may have accidentally brushed against Ms. Page. But a scream was heard, and Mr. Rowland was eventually arrested on a rape charge. He was released when Ms. Page refused to press charges.
But the fuse for the riot had been lighted. A white-owned newspaper, The Tulsa Tribune, published an article with the headline, "To Lynch Negro Tonight." On May 31, an armed white mob arrived at the courthouse to carry out the lynching. They were met by blacks who had arrived to protect Mr. Rowland, and a gunfight claimed several lives.
The fight moved across the railroad tracks into Greenwood after the Tulsa police deputized a large number of whites, many of whom were members of the Ku Klux Klan.
The commission's final report is expected to detail what happened, but this much is known: whites set fire to buildings and homes, ultimately looting and burning more than 1,200 structures. Klansmen reportedly raged through the streets shooting people. Survivors told of corpses stacked onto wagons and trucks.
In the years that followed, the promised rebuilding of Greenwood never happened. Instead, insurance companies refused to pay fire policies, citing special riot exemptions. Whites ultimately took over much of the land. Today, Greenwood is the site of the Oklahoma State University at Tulsa campus, where the commission held its meeting.
In the audience, a few survivors had come for the vote.
Annie Beaird, 86, recalled the sounds of bullets and the sight of black men rushing to defend their neighborhood. Ms. Beaird, who breathed through an oxygen tube and was in a wheelchair, said reparations are appropriate since her family's four-room house was destroyed.
"I think they should give us something," she said. "We lost everything we had."

HEADLINE: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do

BYLINE: By Michael Beschloss; Michael Beschloss's most recent book is "Taking Charge," the first volume of a trilogy on the Johnson White House tapes.

 BODY:

ON MY COUNTRY
 AND THE WORLD
 By Mikhail Gorbachev.
 Translated by George Shriver.
 300 pp. New York:
 Columbia University Press. $29.95. 
 In the best ironic tradition of Russian literature, Boris Yeltsin resigned on the final day of 1999 -- eight years to the day after he had forced Mikhail Gorbachev to pack his bags. As Gorbachev watched his old rival on television, he could be excused if he took pleasure in hearing Yeltsin admit that the transformation of Russia had been a tougher job than he had imagined.
Although written before Yeltsin's departure, Gorbachev's latest book, "On My Country and the World," might just as easily have been titled "I Told You So." The volume aims to browbeat Yeltsin, burnish Gorbachev's reputation and that of the Soviet Union in world history, cadge some honor and influence from Russians (who gave him just a handful of votes when he ran for president in 1996) and cinch for himself the role that he dreams of as a kind of worldly political-economic philosopher and scold.
Gorbachev's chapter titles have the ring of Pravda or Izvestia headlines during the palmy days of the Evil Empire: "Was Socialism Built in the Soviet Union?," "Let's Not Oversimplify! A Balance Sheet of the Soviet Years," "The Coup: A Stab in the Back -- and the Intrigues of Yeltsin." Gorbachev vents his irritation that after being thrown onto the ash heap of history, the Soviet Union is shockingly underappreciated. Attention must be paid to its "astonishingly great" social, cultural and economic achievements.
Although politically the Soviet Union "kept retreating further and further from the original ideals" of the Bolshevik revolution, Gorbachev writes, "the system that was called Socialist gave people (at least the majority of working people) a minimal income necessary for life and confidence in the future, which working people in the West as a rule do not know." Soviet shortcomings, he says, must not be allowed to discredit Socialism: "The Socialist idea is inextinguishable."
Meditating on his career, Gorbachev considers the breakup of the Soviet Union a "tragedy," without which "the world today would be living more peacefully." His "greatest sorrow and misfortune" is "that I did not succeed in preserving the country as a single whole." Calling for a new confederation of three Slavic republics and Kazakhstan, he writes: "The Union could have been preserved. A new Union can be created."
Gorbachev's nostalgia extends even to the Soviet Communist Party. Shirking credit that is deservedly his for compelling old comrades to bow to reform, he insists that it was the party that provided the "initiative" for his political and economic improvisations.
As in earlier books, Gorbachev defends himself against hoary criticism from the Russian right and left, for surrendering the Soviet empire and extending the Afghanistan war for four years. He blames the frustrations of his perestroika program on political foes who "simply began to sabotage change" and the fact that economic progress lagged so far behind political reform. He justifiably claims credit for laying the groundwork for "normal, democratic and peaceful development of our country."
The only real electricity in this book flows out of Gorbachev's indignation at Yeltsin. This is so deeply felt that while recounting for the umpteenth time in print or spoken word the August 1991 hard-line coup against him, Gorbachev goes so far as to deny Yeltsin serious credit for thwarting the putsch when he famously stood atop a tank and demanded Gorbachev's return to authority. Like a long-defeated pol tugging the visitor's sleeve to bloviate once again about how he was robbed at the polls, the author treats us to yet another heated account of Yeltsin's "double game" in late 1991, when he "sacrificed" the Soviet Union "to his passionate desire to accede to the throne in the Kremlin."
For Gorbachev, the significance of Yeltsin's reign is that "the historical achievements of the Soviet period" were eroded: "Everywhere in the 'post-Soviet space' the economy and culture have declined, and a majority of the population has fallen into poverty. . . . Weakened by economic uncertainty and political instability, Russia has lost many of the previous positions it held in the international arena. Fewer and fewer people take Russia's opinion into account."
These days, Gorbachev does not seem to care much more for the United States than he does for Yeltsin. In language whose echo of the Yippie chant in Chicago in 1968 is probably accidental, he rants that "the whole world is watching as Washington attempts to impose on others its model of how to approach major political, economic and social problems." He warns against "the United States' declared intention to assert American leadership over the whole world." Western democracy, he says, is "not well: it is in a crisis. Democratic institutions persist, but the citizenry seem more and more alienated from those institutions." Like a schoolboy firing a spitball, he says that it is the Western countries that need, "if I may say so, a democratization."
Somewhere amid all of this the author splices in what amounts to an advertisement for the Gorbachev Foundation, which, he explains, "works together with others in the world community who are ready to participate in the search for a way to a better future." Throwing modesty out the window, he goes on: "Is a movement toward a new civilization realistic? I think the lessons of history -- above all, the history of the perestroika era, which was, if I may say so, a practical test of humanist approaches to the transformation of society -- allow us to give a positive answer to this question."
He recommends that the United Nations establish a "permanent worldwide brain trust" consisting of "people having no government duties and who are free of any ideological or other preconceptions or prejudices." In case some dimwitted reader of this book fails to grasp just whom Gorbachev has in mind, the 1990 Nobel laureate goes on, "The experience and authority of Nobel prize winners could be utilized in this connection."
Mikhail Gorbachev had a crucial role in one of the great changes of world history -- the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the cold war. As the last leader of the Soviet Union, he demonstrated amazing political courage and desire to do good. His historical reputation, which deserves to be formidable, is unlikely to be diminished by the vanity, political posturing and sheer pettiness displayed in this book.

HEADLINE: Crime

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio 

 BODY:
In Alex McKnight's rugged neck of the woods -- a town called Paradise, right across from Canada, in Michigan's Upper Peninsula -- anything under a foot of snow is just "scattered flurries," and any fistfight that doesn't require skin grafts qualifies as civilized discourse. A former Detroit cop and failed private eye who drew first blood in Steve Hamilton's strong debut mystery, "A Cold Day in Paradise," Alex returns in WINTER OF THE WOLF MOON (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's Minotaur, $23.95) to duke it out with a roughneck team of hockey players whose postgame rituals extend to dealing drugs and beating up Indians. 
 When an Ojibwa woman comes to Alex with a face full of bruises (and a bag full of dope) that she got from one of these guys, he offers her asylum in a cabin that he rents out to snowmobilers. But her subsequent kidnapping sends him back out into the snow for a series of brutal encounters with amateur thugs, professional killers, dumb racists and even a few lawmen who don't respect boundaries. It's a cold, cruel world up here. ("Once you freeze all the way through to your soul," Alex is advised, "you will never feel warm again.") But Hamilton understands the border mentality, and his tensile prose -- with its shifting images of heat and cold, light and dark -- reflects the dramatic, often violent contradictions of people who live on the edge of the world.
Munch Mancini has cleaned up her act since she showed up for work, stoned and drunk, as the offbeat sleuth in Barbara Seranella's down-and-dirty first novel, "No Human Involved." UNWANTED COMPANY (HarperCollins, $24) finds the former biker babe (and odd-job hooker) clean and sober and working as an auto mechanic in Los Angeles. On the side, she also operates a limo service, a one-Cadillac fleet that attracts more hubcap thieves than prom bookings and exposes her to clients like Raleigh Ward, a State Department flunky who panders to the unethical, even criminal whims of his diplomatic charges.
Although the heroine's moral reclamation lowers the stakes, Seranella shrewdly introduces an ex-con named Ellen, a wig-wearing, trash-talking, risk-taking friend from the bad old days, to juice the action. ("Was it just a coincidence that she had come back and craziness had followed?") Untethered by conscience or common sense, flaky Ellen chauffeurs Ward and his current charge, a sadistic bureaucrat (and possible serial killer) attached to Romania's 1984 Olympic gymnastics team, to Tijuana for a little fun and games and murder. The ensuing mayhem would be hilarious if it weren't so creepy and scary -- a combination of emotions that Seranella handles with the same kind of no-sweat skill that Munch applies to her automotive repairs.
In detective stories, as in life, one revisits the past at one's peril. Try telling that to Gerry Boyle's normally clearheaded sleuth, Jack McMorrow, a former reporter for The New York Times who has to learn his lesson the hard way in COVER STORY (Berkley Prime Crime, $22.95). After years of lying low in Maine, Jack returns to New York -- just long enough, he thinks, to pick up some stringer assignments from The Times and have a drink with an old crony. But his pals at the paper treat him like a bumpkin, and his friend, a burned-out homicide cop named Butch Casey, hits him with a weird conspiracy theory involving the mayor's office in the corruption of the criminal justice system. All in all, it's not an ideal homecoming. It gets worse, though, when Butch is arrested for assassinating the mayor in the men's room of the Algonquin Hotel and Jack is hounded by the police and the press as an accomplice.
Boyle's incisive coverage of the public hysteria bristles with contempt. "The block around the Criminal Courts Building looked like Tower Hill on execution day," he observes of Butch's arraignment. But his fugitive hero is so busy hiding out from the mobs that he does a shoddy job of investigating Butch's political grievances. His sharp interview technique suffers badly, and some editor should tip him off that biting his nails and making anxious telephone calls do not constitute live action.
The boys have recovered from "the big war" in Ed Gorman's WAKE UP LITTLE SUSIE (Carroll & Graf, $22.95). The '53 recession is history, there's a bumper crop in the fields and just about everyone in Black River Falls, Iowa, has turned out for the 1957 Edsel Day festivities at Keys Ford-Lincoln. Gorman's sweetly nostalgic mystery, set in a small-town America that surely never was, continues the education of its narrator, a young legal investigator named Sam McCain, who yearns to restore the lost innocence of a nation by stopping time at some "perfect" year like 1952, when he graduated from high school. But for all McCain's rhapsodic invocations of early rock 'n' roll and hayrides under a harvest moon, reality intrudes. The Edsel is a bust. There's a dead body in the trunk of a display model. And someone in his beloved hometown is a killer. Although McCain's persistent navete verges on stupidity, his zeal to cleanse Black River Falls of evil makes him the kind of hero any small town could take to its heart.
As a way of announcing the truth-telling theme of his new crime novel, George P. Pelecanos opens SHAME THE DEVIL (Little, Brown, $24.95) with a stylishly choreographed but extremely raw scene of urban violence -- a 1995 robbery in a Washington pizza parlor that leaves five people dead, including one of the gunmen and a little boy who just happened to get in the way. Even harder to take are the scenes that occur three years later, in the pathetic support group of family survivors who meet each week to share the never-ending pain of loss and, in a cruel but suspenseful plot turn, to protect themselves from the killers, who are back for vengeance. Pelecanos is one of those dangerous writers who aren't afraid to take risks, so there's a merciless reality to his characters and a cold clarity about the way they talk, think and feel. Whatever their flaws, none of the people in this writer's world are ashamed to tell the truth.

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

BYLINE: By Timothy L. O'Brien 

 BODY:

CAPITALISM RUSSIAN-STYLE
 By Thane Gustafson.
 Cambridge University,
 cloth, $54.95; paper, $19.95. 
 For decades, Russia has been a screen on which American paranoia, fears and dreams have been projected: the Red scare, cold war skulduggery, nuclear nightmares and, for the last several years, free-market fantasies. Russia's experiment with capitalism came to an abrupt and ugly halt in the summer of 1998, when its currency cratered and its economy collapsed. Today, amid various corruption scandals and an uncertain political landscape, there is vigorous debate about whether Russia's economy is on the rebound. This argument is not merely academic nor is it the stuff of boring economics texts; the stability of a vibrant, captivating country still chock-full of nuclear weapons depends on its economic recovery. So for anyone interested in an engaging, sweeping tour of the Russian economy in the 1990's and a framework for understanding the complicated financial and political dynamics at work in Russia, Thane Gustafson's "Capitalism Russian-Style" is a superb guide. Gustafson, a professor of government at Georgetown University, tackles his subject with authority and grace, offering bounteous facts and anecdotes that never drag down his narrative or his argument. While clearly taking financiers and public officials in Russia and the West to task for the failed economic policies of the 1990's, Gustafson is optimistic about Russia's future. "Russia today has sunk to a level of weakness not seen since the early 1920's, when the country lay prostrate after a decade of war, revolution and civil war," Gustafson writes. But, he notes, "the tide of change in Russia is not spent; indeed it is still building." Timothy L. O'Brien

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Australia Highlights Aboriginal Tourism

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
MORE than a half-century ago the Australian Unesco Committee for Museums put together a traveling exhibition of the country's Aboriginal culture, which toured the United States and Canada. The accompanying catalog extolled the rich heritage of the Aborigines, the indigenous people who came to Australia more than 30,000 years ago, and it concluded with the hope that the exhibit would "engender a curiosity about Aboriginal life."
That curiosity took a long time to awaken, but a growing recent interest in other cultures is beginning to pay off for Australia's Aborigines. The most recent figures from the Australian Tourist Commission show that in 1997 the 200 tourism businesses operated by Aborigines generated $20 million a year, while the sale of indigenous arts and crafts brought in another $130 million. 
 While small compared with overall tourist revenues in Australia, about $10 billion, it is a start for a people who number only about 400,000, or just over 2 percent of Australia's population of almost 19 million. And it is all the more impressive in that most Aboriginal villages, cultural centers and tour operations are far from big cities and their amenities.
Yet Aboriginal tourism has stirred some resentment against tourists -- particularly for what the Aboriginal people regard as tourists' cultural insensitivity and their failure to respect mores and traditions. Perhaps the best known example is that of the visitors who climb Uluru (formerly Ayers Rock), even though they are asked at the cultural center at the Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park not to do so.
For related reasons, in 1998 the Queensland government issued a code of conduct with suggestions such as these: That visitors learn a few words of the Aboriginal language, and be aware that avoiding eye contact is a sign of respect. But with many more visitors expected this year for the Olympic Summer Games in Sydney, and with almost 5 million projected in 2001 (compared with 4.2 million visitors in 1998), the chance to satisfy that "curiosity about Aboriginal life" is greater than ever -- and so is the likelihood of offending Aborigines.
Therefore the Australian Tourist Commission is drawing up another -- and presumably more detailed -- code of conduct for visitors, to be issued within a few months. It will counsel them to respect Aboriginal sacred sites, ceremonies and traditions. In the United States, some Indian tribes have also adopted codes of conduct for visitors.
The Australian government wants Aboriginal tourism to succeed for several reasons. Some of them were detailed in a speech at the National Press Club in Canberra three months ago by John Morse, managing director of the tourist commission. Describing Aboriginal tourism as a "win, win, win" situation, he said it can help Aborigines achieve economic independence and help the wider Australian population "discover more of this rich and diverse culture." And it can appeal to "people in countries around the world, over 80 percent of whom want to experience culture in some form or another." And, of course, it adds to the national treasury.
In his speech, Mr. Morse mentioned two particularly successful examples of Aboriginal tourism. The Aboriginal Cultural Park in Cairns, created by the Tjapukai people, last year won the Gold Award for Culture, given by the Pacific Asia Travel Association. With five theaters, an art gallery, a museum and a cultural show, the park -- in the city that is a tropical gateway to the Great Barrier Reef -- is already a major tourist attraction. And there is the Sydney Aboriginal Discovery Tour, whose Aboriginal owner, Margaret Muragun Campbell, has arranged tours for some 10,000 visitors not only to the landmark Sydney Opera House and the city's harbor, but also to the outback and Aboriginal communities.
There are many other examples of successful Aboriginal tourism, as well as a popular tourist site partly on Aborigine land -- Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory, 100 miles southeast of Darwin. It is a trove of archaeological treasures that is on Unesco's World Heritage list; its 8,000 square miles include hundreds of plant and bird species and more than 5,000 rock-art sites, most of them consisting of paintings but some with engravings or designs in wax. Yet while Aborigines have lived in Kakadu for at least 25,000 years, it is not technically an Aboriginal park, since the native people leased their half of the land within the park to the government about 20 years ago. In return, they own concessions in the park and participate in its planning, management and conservation.
Other Aboriginal tourism operations include Native Guide Safari Tours in Mossman, Queensland. Founded by Hazel Douglas, it operates a variety of tours including visits to the Daintree rain forest, a World Heritage site, and catamaran cruises off the beaches of Cairns. Harry Nanya Tours in Wentworth, 60 miles from Sydney, also specializes in tours conducted by Aboriginal guides. And in Alice Springs, in the Red Center desert of central Australia, a Southern Arrernte Aboriginal tribal group owns and operates the Aboriginal Art and Cultural Center, which sells art, crafts, books, CD's, tapes and didgeridoos, the haunting Aboriginal wooden wind instruments. Its Web site, aboriginalart.com.au, sells these items, too -- and if a didgeridoo strikes a browser's fancy, the site also offers lessons in how to play it.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Map of Australia showing locations of local cities.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 11; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.;
On the River, 38 Minutes From Midtown

BYLINE: By CHERYL PLATZMAN WEINSTOCK

 BODY:
IN 1896, the grandparents of Nancy Delmerico Vitagliano, a freelance graphics designer, emigrated from Zungoli, a small town in Italy, to the hilly Westchester village of Dobbs Ferry, where Ms. Vitagliano's father was born and lived all his life.
So when she married Donald Vitagliano, a construction inspector at United Water in New Rochelle, N.Y., who lived here, they, too, followed her family's tradition and remained in Dobbs Ferry. 
 "I'm always telling my 10-year-old son, Willie, stories of what it used to be like here," she said. "It was a small town where everybody knew one another and walked downtown on Saturdays to the five-and-dime, ice cream parlor or drugstore for egg creams. It was always very nice and quiet. It's still a great place for a child to grow up. That's why we stayed here -- for Willie."
She added that she and her husband "love the village's wide economic and ethnic demographics."
Charles Baiano, 78, another native of the community, said: "You're 45 minutes from New York City and one hour to any airport. I can walk to almost any place in the village without any problem and we have a beautiful waterfront park on the Hudson."
Mayor Brian Monahan called his village "a small-town commuter haven where people really get to know and care about one another."
The village has always had a strong downtown, said Celeste Meneses, president of the Dobbs Ferry Chamber of Commerce. And with the recent opening of 11 art galleries, she added, "it's even stronger now." Its diversity, she said, is enhanced by the village's variety of ethnic restaurants, ranging from Asian, Italian and Greek to Cajun. For upscale dining, there's the Chart House on the Hudson River, with a Continental menu.
Barbara Dannenbring, a real estate agent with Coldwell Banker Ye Village, said the community's location, variety of housing styles and prices and "small-town authenticity" strengthened sales.
"You can drive down the street and see old barns and the Zion Episcopal Church where Washington Irving first worshiped and take in the romance of the Hudson River," she said. "Though we're a small town and have never had all that much inventory, it's going fast and for more than expected. A home that sold in 1995 for $458,000 resold for $540,000 in 1998 with no work having been done to it."
Village taxes are high -- $115.40 per $1,000 of assessed value -- because there is a lot of tax-exempt land, including the 68-acre, 3,559-student main campus of Mercy College; the 90-acre, 400-student private Masters School and the 150-acre Children's Village, for troubled boys. But that fact has not affected sales, said Mrs. Dannenbring.
Two- to three-bedroom, 1,400 square-foot colonials, Cape Cods and small ranches on .10-acre lots range from $200,000 to $300,000. Colonials, split-levels and small Tudors with three bedrooms and two baths range from $300,000 to $350,000. Larger homes on up to a third of an acre in the village range from $350,000 to $400,000, said Mrs. Dannenbring.
Three- and four-bedroom, 2,000 square-foot homes with Hudson River views are available for $400,000 to $800,000, she said. Buyers can also find large, older homes dating from the turn of the century in this price range.
There are also 266 co-op units in three complexes. A two-bedroom unit ranges in price from $80,000 at the Beacon Hill garden apartment complex, which has a pool, to $139,000 at the mid-rise Draper Lane, said Lisa Omboni, owner of Main Source Realty.
In addition, there are 126 condominium units in four complexes. Two-bedroom units are priced from $147,000 for a simplex with 1,200 square feet of space at Village Green, which has a pool, to $539,000 for 3,000 square feet in a town house at Wit's End, which has master-bedroom suites and fireplaces, said Ms. Omboni.
TWO more complexes are under construction. One is the 24-unit Livingston Ridge overlooking the Hudson, where a two-bedroom ranges from $619,000 to more than $1 million for 2,870 to 3,680 square feet, said Mrs. Dannenbring. The other is the Landing, with 104 town houses being built on 45 acres of land on the Hudson split by Wicker's Creek, where during excavation artifacts of the village's earliest Indian inhabitants were unearthed. The two- to three-bedroom homes, ranging from 1,800 to 2,400 square feet, will be completed next year, and range in price from $400,000 to $700,000.
Many residents oppose the Landing because it blocks river access, said Mayor Monahan. "We're doing everything we can to lessen the impact on the community," he said. "We've approved a conservation easement from the developer to allow residents to walk to the river."
Demand for rentals outstrips supply, said Ms. Ombini. 'As soon as we get the listings they're gone because young singles and married couples are either trying out the area for a year, or couldn't otherwise afford a home here," she said. A two-bedroom apartment ranges from $1,200 in the garden-style Osborne Manor to $1,300 in the 36-family Broadway Arms. Rentals are also available at several of the village's two- and three-family homes, as well as its co-ops and condominiums.
Ellyn Leverone, a travel agent, moved to Dobbs Ferry from the Park Slope section of Brooklyn in 1995 with her husband, Robert, a television producer at CBS Market Watch, and their two children. She said they were looking for not only "a heterogeneous community with more of an outdoor lifestyle, but one with a small school system that I could become actively involved in."
She is now active in the Parent Teacher Student Association and teaches an after-school cooking class.
"The school is the focal point of the community and the community is the focal point of the school," said Dr. Richard Woolley, interim superintendent of the 1,390-student Dobbs Ferry Union Free School District. And, he added, the district -- which has a k-4 elementary school and middle and high schools -- has "a high emphasis on academic achievement."
"For select, high-achieving children in the middle and high school, we offer the International Baccalaureate Program, a very intensive, challenging and high level academic curriculum," said Dr. Woolley. In addition, he said, the district has eight advanced placement courses.
"But we also see to it that no child in this district falls through the cracks," Dr. Woolley said. "We have a specialized program that gives about 15 to 20 children extensive help in handling the curriculum. These youngsters are given extensive study skills and other assistance with their academic work."
Last year, students scored 567 in verbal and 584 in math on the College Boards, compared with state averages of 495 and 504, respectively. Among the 70 graduating seniors last year, all but four went on to higher education.
Ten percent of the students in the district attend private or parochial schools, including two in the village -- the private co-ed Masters School for grades 5 to 12 and Our Lady of Victory Academy, a girls' high school operated by the Sisters of Mercy. Annual tuition at Masters is $15,300 for the middle school and $16,750 for the upper school. The upper school charges an additional $8,000 for boarding. Tuition at the Academy is $4,350.
FOR recreation and nature walks, there is the 70-acre Juhring Estate nature preserve; the 8-acre Gould Park, with ballfields and a pool, and the 3.5-acre Memorial Park, where residents can play basketball, bocce and baseball. The Embassy Community Center, which opened last year, offers programs for all ages.
But the jewel of the village's recreational facilities is the 8.5-acre Waterfront Park on the Hudson, according to Mayor Monahan. "We have one of the most attractive Hudson River waterfronts anywhere," he said. "One of our goals is revitalization and expansion of our waterfront." It was in the waters around the Waterfront Park that the Weckquaesgeek Indians, who lived at the mouth of a stream they called the Wysquaqua (now known as Wicker's Creek), spotted Henry Hudson's Half Moon gliding by in 1609. Hudson's first mate, Robert Juet, entered "very high land" in the ship's log to describe the area's topography. Around 1730, William Dobbs began operating a ferry at Willow's Point in what was known as Wysquaqua to carry passengers and supplies to Sneden's Landing in Rockland County. The village was incorporated as Dobbs Ferry in 1873.
During the Revolution, George Washington established a redoubt on the site that overlooks the Waterfront Park. After the war, Dobbs Ferry began to grow as an agricultural community and sloops transported passengers and goods to New York City.
The arrival of the New York and Hudson River Railroad in Dobbs Ferry in 1849 heralded a new era for the village as businessmen bought up property and built estates.
At the end of the 19th century, immigrants, mostly from Italy and Ireland, came to the village to work on the estates, or in local businesses and factories. Today, the 180,000 square-foot office complex that was once the site of the Hudson River Brewing Company has about 85 tenants, including a bagpipe maker, the Cartoon Bank, an Internet archive of cartoons from The New Yorker, and artists, writers and musicians.
If there's any downside to Dobbs Ferry, said Mr. Monahan, whose family first came to the village in 1880, it's the ongoing traffic problem.
"Dobbs Ferry is an older community that wasn't built on the notion that every family would have three cars," he said.

A MONUMENTAL MISTAKE?: In 1874, an eight-foot granite monument was erected on South Broadway by the Sons of the American Revolution to mark the site of what was believed to be George Washington's headquarters when he planned what became known as the Battle of Yorktown. Robert Stackpole, president of the New York chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution, said that was the belief at the time. When evidence to the contrary was uncovered in 1895, nothing was done to change the inscription because there were no letters of protest, he said. Now, he said, with an interest in promoting tourism the inscription will be revised, perhaps to reflect that Dobbs Ferry was the western redoubt of the Continental Army's encampment.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3244 words

HEADLINE: Ha Jin's Cultural Revolution

BYLINE: By Dwight Garner; Dwight Garner is an editor for The New York Times Book Review.

 BODY:
On a bright fall morning in 1985, xuefei jin walked out of Logan airport in Boston and took his first real gulp of American air. It almost sent him to his knees. "There is a unique American smell that hits you when you arrive here," he says. "It is very sweet, like chemicals or a kind of perfume. It makes you sick for a while." Jin had flown from Beijing, a student visa stuffed into his pocket, to study American literature at Brandeis University. "I know people who came here from Asia and vomited for days. They couldn't even brush their teeth because the water smelled so different."
Xuefei (pronounced shu-FAY) Jin, who writes under the pen name Ha Jin, is a courtly and soft-spoken man who punctuates stories like this one with a quick, apologetic laugh -- a laugh that says, "How silly this must all sound." He employs it often when talking about his early years in America, while recalling, for example, the menial jobs he took to pay the rent -- busing tables at a Friendly's restaurant, cleaning houses, working as a night watchman at a chemical factory -- or remembering why he initially thought all Americans must be rich. ("There were so many squirrels, and no one was trying to eat them.") It's a laugh that pops up everywhere, vanishing only when he talks about his decision, in the days following the Tiananmen Square massacre, in 1989, not to return to his native country. Or when he recalls the difficult months he spent trying to get permission from the Chinese government so that his wife, Lisha Bian, and later his young son, Wen, could join him in America. 
 Jin's laugh is abundantly in evidence on the windy December afternoon he takes me on an impromptu driving tour of Emory University in Atlanta, where he has taught since 1993. It's a bumpy ride in his small Chevrolet; every so often, Jin brakes suddenly, as if he has gotten lost in his own backyard. His driving skills are almost as shaky as his command of spoken English -- his Mandarin accent, with its hard "r" sound, remains strong. "It is very easy to lose your way in Atlanta," he says. "So many street names begin with the word 'peach."' He rolls down the window to look around, and he sucks down another deep lungful of American air. "I am very grateful for fall and winter," he says. "The rest of the year, Atlanta is pollen central."
Jin has more or less adjusted to America's complicated oxygen supply. But watching him grapple with the intricacies of its spoken language -- he often drops his articles, and an excruciatingly exact rendering of the quotation above would be, "Rest of year, Atlanta pollen central" -- is an experience that will startle anyone who first encountered his voice through his fiction. On the page, Jin has the kind of effortless command that most writers can only dream about. His first novel, "Waiting," the story of a Chinese doctor who wants to end his arranged marriage so he can marry a more modern woman, recently won a National Book Award, a mere 11 years after Jin began writing seriously in English. In the 50-year history of the awards, only two other writers who weren't native English speakers have taken home the fiction prize: Isaac Bashevis Singer and Jerzy Kosinski.
"Waiting" begins with the kind of economical but perfectly turned sentence that abounds in Jin's work -- Every summer Lin Kong returned to Goose Village to divorce his wife, Shuyu" -- and it casts a spell that doesn't break once over the course of the book's 308 pages. Set in northern China in the 1980's and based on a true story, the novel is a delicate portrait of a decent but oddly passionless man. It is also about a love triangle in which there's little genuine love to be found.
Like all of Jin's work, "Waiting" has the stripped-down simplicity of a fable. The novel's protagonist, Lin Kong, is an urban doctor who left behind in the countryside the woman his family chose for him to marry -- a loyal wife whose Old World servility and bound feet embarrass him. Because he can't work up the nerve to force her to grant him a divorce, and because adultery is punished severely by the Communist Party, he is forced to wait 18 embittering years before he can be with the clever, educated nurse he thinks he loves. During those years he lives "like a sleepwalker, pulled and pushed by others' opinions." Worse, he comes to realize he may have been waiting for the wrong woman.
"Waiting" is set just after the end of the Cultural Revolution, and Jin forcefully evokes a world in which both petty rules and local gossips could ruin a life in an instant. It's a world he remembers all too well. "In China there was no privacy," the 43-year-old writer says. "Your banker would tell your neighbors how much money you had in your bank account! It was something you didn't even question."
These kinds of memories remain vivid for Jin, which helps explain why none of his fiction is set in America, even though all of it has been written since his arrival here in 1985. (In addition to "Waiting," he has published a novella, two short-story collections and two volumes of poetry.) Unlike almost every other Asian-American novelist who has attracted notice in the United States -- Gish Jen, Amy Tan and Chang-rae Lee, to name but a few -- Jin steers clear of the bumpy politics of assimilation.
The exoticism of his northern Chinese locales separates him from these writers, but so does the almost classical rigor of his storytelling. If the lucidity and focus of "Waiting" puts you in mind of Russian masters like Gogol and Chekhov, that's no accident. Jin reads and rereads these writers, he says, to remind him of what fiction is supposed to be. "You read so many novels these days by young writers and they feel so ephemeral," he says. "They are full of references to TV shows and movies. What's important is to get human feeling onto paper. That's what is timeless, and that's what you get from Tolstoy and from Gogol and from Chekhov."
In a funny way, says the Chinese-American novelist Gish Jen, the timeless quality of Jin's writing may be among the few really new things happening in American fiction right now. "The whole idea of looking to masters instead of overturning something is very Chinese," she says. "On some level, Ha Jin has chosen mastery over genius. It's as if he said, 'I am going to make something like that.' This never happens with American writers. We are too beset with the anxiety of influence. What he's doing is very challenging, and I am interested to see how the American literati pick it up and deal with it."
The glamorous world of the literati is something Jin himself knows little about. He is a small, somewhat awkward man who can appear to be here but not here in America, and that's not just because he gets lost easily or still struggles with spoken English. Jin has almost zero affinity for American popular culture -- he can't remember the last movie he saw, and his TV knowledge is limited to unhip shows like "Walker, Texas Ranger." In many ways, he resembles the brilliant but slightly bumbling foreign academic in one of his own favorite novels, Vladimir Nabokov's "Pnin."
Jin's monkishness becomes apparent the moment you step into his house, a small brick ranch in a drab suburb northeast of Atlanta. The faux-wood-paneled living room is decorated in a style that might best be described as Grad School Provisional. Besides books in English and Chinese, there are a couple of inexpensive vinyl-covered couches, and, most notably, there is a Ping-Pong table that takes up half the room. ("My wife always beats me," Jin says.) Yet he plays only rarely, he confesses. Often he works so late that he ends up sleeping in his office -- in a small bed placed near his computer.
As Xuefei Jin picks at the platters of food that have been spread across the living-room coffee table -- there are oranges, cookies and plastic jugs of Gatorade and apple juice -- he tells me he's not sure what surprises him more: that he has become a writer, or that he has made a life for his family in America. "It wasn't supposed to work out this way," he says. "This is not where I thought I would be."
When Jin arrived at Brandeis in 1985, he not only didn't plan on becoming a writer, he also didn't plan on staying in the United States. "I just wanted to get my Ph.D. so I could get a good teaching job when I went back," he says. To ensure that Jin would indeed return, the Chinese government made him leave his wife and young son behind. "My first years here were very exciting but very lonely," he says. "My wife and I wrote many, many letters."
Jin's scholarship ran out after a year, and he began working odd jobs to cover his living expenses. It was while at one of these jobs, as a night watchman at a chemical factory, that he began doing his first writing in English -- a language that he studied for several years in China, but one that he had not yet come close to mastering. "I was just dabbling," he says of these early experiments. But as he wrote, he sensed a freedom in English that he had never felt in his native language. "I had written a few poems in Chinese, but I wasn't happy with them. The Chinese language is very literary and highbrow and detached from the spoken word. It doesn't have the flexibility that English has. So I slowly began to squeeze the Chinese literary mentality out of my mind."
At the prompting of a professor, Jin took some of his work to the poet Frank Bidart, who was teaching at Brandeis. "It was extraordinary to find something this shaped from someone whose first language was not English," Bidart recalls. "He had this remarkable idiom." One of Jin's poems, "The Dead Soldier's Talk," was so good that Bidart read it over the telephone to Jonathan Galassi, who was then poetry editor of The Paris Review (and now editor in chief of Farrar, Straus & Giroux). Galassi immediately accepted the poem; a few years later, Jin's first book of poetry, "Between Silences," was published by the University of Chicago Press.
Around this time, Jin began experiencing severe stomach problems. The Chinese government grudgingly allowed his wife to come to the States to care for him; the pains soon went away, and in 1989 he prepared to return to China with his wife. But something happened, Jin says, "that changed everything for me." Student protesters had gathered in Tiananmen Square, and Jin and Bian spent several days glued to the television screen in their small Boston apartment. "I was not mentally prepared for what happened," he says of the government's crackdown. "I had always thought that the Chinese Army was there to serve and protect the people." Disillusioned, Jin decided not to return to China and began working to get his son, Wen, out of the country as well. To his astonishment, Chinese authorities allowed Wen to board a flight to the United States a few months later.
Wanting to write fiction as well as poetry, Jin enrolled in a master's program at Boston University, where his work was embraced by teachers like Leslie Epstein. But his accent, which was still terribly thick, made workshop discussions difficult. What's more, Jin's subject matter turned off some classmates. One of his classmates was Jhumpa Lahiri, whose first collection of stories, "Interpreter of Maladies," appeared last year. "He is such a gentle man, but his stories really pushed people's buttons," she says. "There were a lot of brutal rape scenes in them. One was about a man who castrates himself. I remember people being shocked and outraged by some of it."
Epstein remembers those heated discussions well. "Ha Jin is one of the great poets of rape," he says. "One of his best stories, 'Man to Be,' has this terrible, terrific rape scene in which a man recovers his humanity when he looks into the eyes of the woman he is about to rape." One of the most powerful moments in "Waiting," too, is a rape scene. While Lin Kong dithers about divorcing his wife, his girlfriend is brutally raped, and Lin Kong is convinced, perhaps with some justification, that it is his fault. "Indecisiveness," he thinks, "had opened the door to the wolf."
Jin laughs uncomfortably when I tell him that he has been described as a "great poet of rape." "My stories are not gentle stories," he says. "The question for me has always been, How do you write about terrible things without resorting to vulgarity? I think I might push things farther than people expect. But that's how you test yourself as a writer."
Jin has remained in academe, having taught writing at Boston University for a few years before moving to Emory. Settled in Atlanta, Jin began publishing his work. His first story collection, "Ocean of Words," appeared in 1996 and won a PEN/Hemingway prize; a 1997 collection, "Under the Red Flag," won the Flannery O'Connor Award for Short Fiction. As the awards for his work began piling up, Jin says, he began to be asked the same question over and over at readings and book signings: how can someone write English so fluidly, yet speak it so haltingly? "I always give the same response," he says. "On the page, I can spend all the time I need. I can be patient. I can work and work until I think I've almost got it right."
Jin was born in 1956 in the northern Chinese city of Jinzhou, where his father, a military officer, was stationed. At age 7, he was shipped off to boarding school, where he studied for two years, until Mao Zedong ordered all of China's schools closed at the start of the Cultural Revolution.
He returned home to chaos. "Because my grandfather had been a landowner, my mother was criticized very severely," he recalls. "People did terrible things to her. She was once thrown into a trash can." Soldiers burned books owned by Jin's father in a bonfire on the city's streets.
With no school to attend and little else to do, Jin joined the Little Red Guard, where he spent a few years "wearing red armbands, waving flags and singing revolutionary songs" before lying about his age and signing up, at 14, with the People's Liberation Army. At the time, there were rumors that Russia was planning an attack on China, and Jin did not want to die at home in a bomb shelter. "Like everyone else, I wanted to be a hero, a martyr," he says. Jin spent a year shivering on the Russian border, a year that provided the raw material for his first collection, "Ocean of Words," a cycle of stories about Chinese soldiers who await the outbreak of war and struggle, sometimes comically, to cleanse themselves of "bourgeois sentiment."
The Russian attack never came, but something else happened: Jin came upon a worn Chinese translation of "War and Peace." "I was almost illiterate and could barely read it," he says. "But I remember thinking to myself: What a revelation this is. I'm here fighting the Russians, and Tolstoy showed me that the Russians were just like me."
Jin was discharged when he was 19. Because the schools were still closed, he took a job as a telegraph operator in a remote northern city. For once he had ample time to read. Even better, a local radio station began broadcasting an English-language program from 5 to 5:30 a.m. six days a week. He listened avidly and set himself a goal: to read Friedrich Engels's "Condition of the Working Class in England" in its original English. "It was a stupid goal," he says. "I didn't come close."
When China's colleges finally reopened in 1977, Jin was admitted to Heilongjiang University in the northeastern city of Harbin as an English major. He spent four years there, listening to tapes and reciting English phrases until his mouth felt as if it would fall off into his hands. "I hated it," he says. "I simply couldn't say the words. They twisted your tongue, your muscles, too much. We all went to the clinic regularly to get painkillers."
In the early 80's, just as China was beginning to liberalize, Jin enrolled at Shandong University in eastern China, where he got a master's degree in what was becoming a fashionable intellectual topic: American literature. "Like everyone else, I became obsessed with Faulkner, with Roethke, with Bellow," he says. "It was finally O.K. to read these writers."
At Shandong University, Jin met visiting U.S. scholars who encouraged him to study in America. Around this time, Jin also met his future wife, who was teaching mathematics at Shandong. What's more, he stumbled upon the story that would ultimately emerge in "Waiting." While visiting Bian's parents, who were army doctors, he heard the story of another doctor at their hospital who had waited 18 years to get a divorce. "Intuitively, I knew this would make a great story," he says, "but I never thought I would write it. You needed skill to write a story like that. I didn't have it."
When Jin finally did sit down to begin "Waiting," in the early 90's, he still wasn't sure he could bring the story off. "I was terrified because I didn't know if it was any good," he recalls. Fortunately, LuAnn Walther, an editor at Pantheon, found the novel very good indeed. After years of advances and royalties that were rarely more than a few thousand dollars, Pantheon bought "Waiting" at auction for $50,000, and the foreign rights later sold for another $50,000. "I finally felt like I could breathe," Jin says.
It has grown dark outside, and the oranges and cookies are almost gone, when Jin suggests heading out in search of some real food. We pile into his car along with Bian and Wen and drive to a Malaysian restaurant in Chamblee, another suburb. With the recent influx of Asian immigrants, the area has been nicknamed "Chambodia." Along the way we pass strip malls with Korean hair salons and Vietnamese noodle shops, and Jin points out several excellent Chinese bookstores. As much as he appreciates the bookstores, he says, they are a constant reminder that his own books are not available in mainland China. None of his work has been published there. "The American media sometimes portrays me as a dissident, as an exile, although I'm not sure I really am one," he says. News that a Taiwanese publisher will translate "Waiting" has inspired some hope. "I'd like my parents and my brothers and sisters to be able to read my work."
At the restaurant, Jin digs into a whole sauce-covered snapper and discusses his future projects. He is currently polishing a collection of short stories that are set in the same city where "Waiting" takes place and developing a novel that he describes as being about insanity. "It's about a professor in China who has had a stroke but who remains quite articulate," Jin says. "He talks a lot of nonsense but also a lot of truth." Once these books are finished, Jin says, he plans to put China behind him and write his first novel set in the United States. "I have been gathering some ideas," he says.
The idea of writing about America clearly intimidates him, so I'm almost entirely kidding when I ask him if he'll try a frenetic, jumbo-size Atlanta novel along the lines of "A Man in Full." Jin takes the question seriously, however. He has read Tom Wolfe's book, and he praises its abundance of "great detail" while making it clear that it's not his kind of thing.
"I may not understand America very deeply in that way," he says, "but perhaps I can make sense of it from a different angle, from an immigrant's perspective." Jin smiles. "This book will be a great hurdle for me. I will have to write it very slowly."
