SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2690 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Getting to Laos Ahead of the Guidebooks

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE 

 BODY:
THE stranger approached. He wore a tie-dyed shirt and a nylon zippered waist pouch. A gray ponytail; late 50's, I'd say. "So," he opened, "You're going to Laos?"
I pulled my nose out of the Laos Guidebook and disentangled my chopsticks from the pad thai. "Why yes," I replied. 
 In any other city I would've figured this for a lame pickup attempt. But in Bangkok, the main node of the international backpacker's circuit, this was networking.
Mr. Tie-Dye leaned close. "You'll love Laos," he said, then glanced around to make sure no one was listening, "It's much nicer than Thailand." We got down to business. In return for my travel tips on the Philippines, I acquired the name of the travel agent who had booked his discount flight to Vientiane, the lowdown on the ever-changing Laotian visa regulations, and -- the choicest tidbit -- directions to a guest house in Luang Prabang that wasn't in the Lonely Planet yet. We finished the transaction before my noodles cooled.
I'd stopped off in Bangkok late last November to organize my trips onward to Laos and Cambodia. While it's possible to book flights and tours to these countries from the United States, I didn't do it -- partly because I enjoy traveling more when I'm moving spontaneously, but mostly because I knew that arranging my trips would be easier from there, and much cheaper. All the things I needed -- from tickets and visas and mosquito nets and recent first-hand information to a good Thai massage -- were available in a one-stop traveler's shopping mall, the Khao San Road.
At least a hundred travel agencies elbow for space among Khao San Road's quarter-mile-long crunch of budget guest houses, cut-rate noodle joints, Thai massage parlors, bars, and internet cafes. I strolled down one side of the street and up the other, wondering where to begin. Some agencies looked like regular air-conditioned storefront offices. Others looked like this: a metal chair unfolded on the sidewalk, a half-asleep Thai woman, a plastic electric fan perched atop a pile of blank air ticket forms.
Were these the fabled ticket brokers I'd heard about, the agents who could book you from Bangkok to Timbuktu for 50 bucks on airlines so obscure the F.A.A. hadn't issued safety warnings about them yet?
Every traveler has an inner risk-o-meter, and testing the legitimacy of a travel agent who operates from a folding table pushed my needle into the red zone. So I started with the air-conditioned offices, one by one: How much for a round-trip ticket from Bangkok to Vientiane?
The storefront agents offered similar prices (they negotiate in the Thai bhat, and charge extra to use a credit card) -- cheaper, by at least $50, than the prices I'd been quoted back home. Word-of-mouth sold me on the Blue and White agency (Mr. Tie-Dye's tip). It was owned, curiously, by an Israeli who kept up telephone conversations in Hebrew, English and Thai while I waited. The prices were on the low end of what I'd found -- $134 round trip on Lao Aviation, $171 round trip on Thai Airways. They could arrange my visa in two days, for $34 (including the $24 visa fee), saving me two tiresome trips to the Laotian embassy. The only question was which airline. Lao Aviation was cheaper, but the State Department had issued a travel advisory about it. I caved and bought the Thai Airways ticket.)
Thai Airways hands out orchid corsages to all the women as they get off the plane. I stuck mine in my hair and practiced a big smile for the immigration officer. I was preparing myself for Socialist bureaucracy -- Laos is one of the last countries in the world whose official name contains the words "People's Democratic Republic."
Since 1975, after Communist victories in Vietnam and Cambodia, the country has been run by the Pathet Lao, a junta whose closest ally is neighboring Vietnam. Until quite recently, getting a tourist visa into Laos was a complicated and expensive process. But Laos, which once vied with Myanmar as the most restrictive Southeast Asian country for tourism, decided to get tourist-friendly about two years ago, around the time it joined Asean, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. The government slashed visa fees and loosened requirements. Not only that, it proclaimed 1998-99 Visit Laos Year.
As I entered the immigration area at the Vientiane airport, I noticed that the Visit Lao Year banners now read: Visit Lao Year 1999-2000. I also noticed that I'd lost my orchid. No matter. The official behind the desk looked at my American passport, smiled warmly, said, "Sabaidee," ("Greetings"), and I was in.
Countries that have put up barriers to modernity and its Mc-trappings beckon to tourists in search of the unexplored, the "authentic," the road-less-traveled, which is why Laos, at this moment, is the favorite destination of Khao San Road's cognoscenti.
Downtown Vientiane, a city of around 150,000, has no Pizza Huts. It has wide and impressive, if potholed, avenues, imposing, down-at-heels French colonial mansions, most of themoverrun by a tangle of vegetation, and a long, unpaved waterfront promenade along the Mekong River where Laotians and foreigners gather at sunset to drink beer and play cards. Old Asia hands had told me that Vientiane, more than any other city in the region, retained the allure of colonial Indochina. Instinctively I dismissed this as foreigners' romanticism.
But on my first morning in town, I strolled down one of those broad avenues toward the Patuxai, an imposing monument that looked like an Arc de Triomphe redesigned by a Laotian potentate. The light reflected golden off the dust kicked up by cyclists, scooters, and motorcycles -- and few cars other than an occasional sleek Toyota Pajero (the favored wheels of the diplomatic and development agency set). I watched a sidewalk vendor selling fresh baguettes, sliced in two and spread with condensed milk. I watched a monk, in a temple courtyard, hanging out orange laundry. Serenity kicked in. I'd lost my place on the map, and couldn't speak a word of Laotian, yet felt as if I'd just drifted out of a yoga class.
"We've all fallen in love with Laos," said Sarah, an Englishwoman on a year's contract with a Swiss development agency. We sat, at adjacent tables, at the Scandinavian Bakery -- like a bloodhound, I'd ended up my morning stroll in one of Vientiane's two cafes that serve fresh-brewed coffee and croissants. It's an expatriate's watering hole; CNN plays on the TV screen upstairs. Foreign aid is one of the backbones of the Laotian economy, and Vientiane's tourist population is almost invisible next to the hundreds of resident foreigners. Most, like Sarah, are both intoxicated and frustrated by the country. "The people are wonderful," she told me. "But it's a poor country, where nothing ever changes."
I enjoyed their company, and found it useful, because guidebooks to Laos are quickly obsolete. Vientiane, thanks to its French heritage, is a restaurant town, but quality fluctuates. Sarah's friend John steered me to Nizam, which serves excellent South Indian food for around $2. Another foreigner gave me his list of favorite "upscale" restaurants, including an excellent Italian bistro, Stivale. Upscale, in Vientiane, means dinner for $12.
The expats knew everything: from restaurants and shops, to which of the dusty antiques shops selling celadon teapots and silver bracelets on Setthathirat Road were fronts for opium dens. (While Vientiane today is far from wild and woolly, it still retains some illicit corners). I was interested when Sarah mentioned a meditation session, open to foreigners, at one of the Buddhist temples. I thought perhaps I'd try it -- but later, because I had plans.
At the airport I'd met a driver named Pheng who had an air-conditioned car. He spoke a bit of English and negotiated fairly -- I paid him about $4 to drive me into town to look at guest houses. When I decided on the Lani 1 Guest House -- a well-run, clean, tropical-style place of 1960's vintage with air-conditioned rooms (I took a big one with terrace overlooking the adjacent Wat Hai Sok temple for $35) and a friendly, helpful staff, I arranged for him to take me sightseeing the next morning.
Pheng was early, already waiting when I drifted back from breakfast. We set out on a tour of Vientiane's major temples -- there are half a dozen or so, splendidly peaked and gilded, of fairly recent vintage -- the oldest, Wat Si Saket, was built in 1818. I spent the rest of the morning in that state of awe and contemplation that comes from strolling among hundreds of silver and bronze Buddhas and admiring intricately carved wooden panels. When the sun got too hot I asked Pheng to drop me off at the guest house and return at 3:30. I wanted to enjoy Vientiane's most famous landmark, the That Luang, as the long rays of the sun bounced brilliantly off the towers covered in tons of gold leaf. That Luang is a stupa, a reliquary, not a temple; the legend is that it houses some of Buddha's bones.
There's a monastery adjacent to That Luang; shy young boy-novices in orange robes eyed me as I circled the stupa's perimeter. I thought they were staring out of curiosity; in fact they were working up the courage to approach me and practice their English.
Photong was 14. He said he had been studying English for only nine months. Slowly and carefully, he told me his story: his family was poor, from southern Laos. He was studying hard and very good in math; if he did well on exams, he might be sent to study at one of the Buddhist universities in Thailand.
When I mentioned that I might be going to a meditation class at Wat Sok Pa Luang the next day, Photong got excited. He took classes there, with the monks who studied under Abbot Ajaan Saali, the famous master of a technique called Vipassana. He insisted on accompanying me to the class, to show me around his school and the temple.
We arranged to meet the next day, and then Pheng dropped me off downtown, on Fa Ngum, the boulevard that fronts the Mekong River. In the cool of early evening, Laotians and foreigners sat on plastic stools at folding tables in improvised waterfront cafes, drinking Tiger beer, slurping noodles, and playing cards. I strolled along the banks for about half a mile, following the sound of gongs and drums, until I came upon an outdoor stage set up in a dusty lot. There a visiting Chinese opera company in full regalia was moving through its paces, slowly and elegantly. The opera was free, and so I sat down to enjoy the spectacle.
Walking home, about 100 yards from my guest house, I heard the sounds of Italian disco blasting from tinny speakers. Inside a storefront, about 20 Laotians of all ages were spilling out onto the street, waving glasses of beer. I paused to peek inside, and one of the women, laughing, grabbed my wrist and pulled me in; a man handed me a glass spilling over with beer, and a young girl started to dance with me. I went with the flow. But when an ancient, bearded Lao great-grandpa came over with the second tumbler of beer, I beat a polite retreat -- after all, I had a meditation date the next day.
Pheng drove me by the monastery the next afternoon to pick up Photong and we continued to Wat Sok Pa Luang. Pheng took a snooze while Photong led me into what looked like the jungle. The wat, a few miles out of town, is surrounded by thick tropical forest, which gives it a moody, otherworldly feel. We walked along a narrow path that led past wooden huts billowing smoke -- the wat, like Bangkok's Wat Po, is a center for herbal medicine, sauna and massage.
A bell was tinkling, and two nuns in white robes beckoned me and a handful of other Laotians and foreigners into an open-air temple. I spotted Sarah seated crosslegged on a straw mat. Another bell tinkled, and the aged abbot silently walked in, trailing sandalwood incense. I sat, closed my eyes, and drifted off.
Some time later -- I'm not sure how long -- the bell tinkled again. The nuns in white indicated with hand motions that we were to stand up and start walking -- in Vipassana meditation one learns to meditate in motion. And so, shoeless, our group formed a tiny parade on a dusty path that encircled the temple. Following the nuns' example, we took long, careful strides with a dramatic pause in the middle -- a stride I remembered from high school graduation. Around the path we went, and around and around again.
The path to enlightenment is long, and I didn't get there that afternoon. But that was O.K. Because, stepping slowly and carefully in my bare feet in Vientiane, I knew I had found the road less traveled.
 
The bottom line in one of the last of the People's Republics
I spent $46.50 a day on meals, transport and hotels in Vientiane.
 
Air fare
At the Blue and White Travel Center, 108/12-13 Khao San Road, Banglamphu, Bangkok, (66-2) 282-7705, fax (66-2) 281-3792, I booked a round-trip flight on Thai Airways from Bangkok to Vientiane. The fare was $174 including all taxes.
 
Visa
United States citizens require a visa for entry to Laos. Two-week and one-month visas are available. The fees and regulations have been in flux for the last year, as the Lao government adjusts itself to tourism. Visas can be obtained in Bangkok, where the Laotian Embassy usually processes a two-week tourist visa in two business days for $25. The Blue and White Travel Center will do the legwork for a fee of $8.50.
To apply for a visa from the United States, contact the Laotian Embassy, 2222 S Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20008; (202) 332-6416, fax (202) 332-4923. The charge is $35 plus a $15 service fee.
Malaria is a problem in rural areas of Laos. Anyone planning to visit should consult a doctor.
 
Hotels
The Lani 1 Guest House, 281 Set thathirat Road, Post Office Box 58, Vientiane, (856-21) 214919, fax (856-21) 215639, is a lovely hotel with about a dozen rooms in a cool, two-story tropical house, downtown within walking distance of restaurants, shops and the Mekong. The air-conditioned rooms have overhead fans, telephones (but no TV's), and high ceilings. Try to get one of the larger rooms ($30) that open onto a small terrace. The smaller rooms are $25. Book ahead.
I spent my first night at Le Parasol Blanc, 263 Sibounheuang Street, (856-21) 216091, fax (856-21) 222290), a favorite of foreign journalists. It has a swimming pool and an excellent restaurant set in a lush, hanging garden. But the management has changed recently, and my single motel-like air-conditioned room ($28) was dark and not very clean. It is also about a mile from downtown.
 
Restaurants
The in spots of the lively restaurant scene are constantly changing. Ask around over cappuccino at the Scandinavian Bakery, Namphou (Fountain) Circle, 215-199. Continental breakfast at the bakery costs about $2 to $3.
At Le Cote d'Azur, 62-62 Fa Ngum Road, a simple but well-prepared French meal of watercress salad, roast chicken, and a glass of Beaujolais nouveau was $7.
At Lo Stivale, 43 Setthathirat Road, I had a delicious Italian lunch: fresh handmade ravioli, insalata caprese, tiramisu and a glass of san giovese for $12.
Nazim's, Fa Ngum Road, (856-21) 233-480, is always crowded -- it serves very good, very fresh, and very cheap North and South Indian food. Dinner there, with a large Lao beer, came to around $5.
 
Activities
Every Saturday afternoon from 4 to 5, Abbot Ajaan Sali of Wat Sok Pa Luang leads a session of Vipassana meditation. It is free, but a small donation is customary.
Major temples are open to the public. Dress respectfully and be prepared to take your shoes off. Some charge a negligible admission fee.
 
Transportation
Taxis aren't cruising the streets in Vientiane, so if you want a driver you have to find one at the airport as you come in (the ride from the airport to town should cost about $3 to $4), or through your hotel. For sightseeing I paid $10 a day.
Motorcycles with jury-rigged passenger coaches ply the main streets of Vientiane; it's a hot, dusty way to travel but a cheap one -- about 60 cents to anywhere in town. DAISANN McLANE

LENGTH: 830 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00: The Ethicist;
The Talented Mr. Rip-Off

BYLINE: By Randy Cohen 

 BODY:
I'm an assistant to a screenwriter in Los Angeles. Here your boss is your mentor who will guide you to Your Next Big Opportunity. I believe in this system and I depend on it, as it has served me well, but now I'm being held back. Our scripts are valued at over $100,000 a draft, and these days every script is half mine. Meanwhile, I can't afford a new muffler for my car. It would be simple to get a job if I told the studio executives that the pages they were "loving" were mine. But this would mean breaching a business relationship with my boss. May I do it? -- Anonymous, Los Angeles
Let me make sure I understand the system you've come to believe in and depend on: you help your boss get credit for work he didn't do, and in return, he helps you get ahead through influence and connections. Well, you've certainly found the right industry and the right town for you. 
 I admire your faith in those studio executives and their ability to recognize merit, and that they'd of course believe you when you say the really good work in those scripts is yours. But here's another view.
"Almost everyone who contributes anything to a script develops the delusion that it's 'half mine,"' says the screenwriter Lorenzo Semple Jr., whose credits include "Three Days of the Condor" and "The Parallax View," "so I strongly doubt that going to studio execs with this plaint would make it 'simple to get a job.' On the contrary, he'd be labeled a disloyal nut case and be booted out the gate."
But to answer your question more directly: no, you may not violate your agreement with your boss. Fortunately, you have more honorable options.
You can tell your boss what you've told me. If he places the same value on your work that you do, he might be willing to promote you from apprentice dupe to journeyman dupe and share credit and money on your next project. Or, he'll find some other hungry young writer to exploit.
You can quit. Then go home, write a spec script on your own, sign your name to it and sell it on its merits. (You are free to use your contacts to make sure your script lands on the right desk.) Of course, relying on your own ability is a risky strategy, particularly in your business, where nearly everything that's written fails to sell.
You can work for someone better. That is, for a more honest thief, someone more likely to keep his end of a corrupt bargain. I suggest Satan. But it is surprisingly hard even to get an appointment without the right connections. Maybe your boss can hook you up.
By comparing prescription-drug prices, I found I could save $600 a year if I switched pharmacies. I showed my present pharmacist, and he agreed to meet the lowest prices. When I told my daughter that I should help other elderly people by publicizing the savings, she exploded, claiming that I was proposing to undermine the price system, driving a business into bankruptcy. What do you think? -John Maher, Prior Lake, Minn.
I think you are upholding an essential mechanism of the free market: informed customers, aware of their options, choose wisely, and merchants adjust to those economic decisions. Or as my Aunt Bernice, so fond of misquoting John Stuart Mill, summed up the great man's economic theories: "Shop around for the best price." You have not revealed state secrets; spread the word with a full heart.
A physician, I recently prescribed Viagra to a patient. Shortly after, his wife, also my patient, disclosed that they've not been intimate for months. On the one hand, his private affairs are none of my business. On the other, his wife is likely to feel betrayed if she discovers I've given him the means to satisfy his needs. What should I do? -P.M., Ohio
Unless he is doing real physical damage, you must respect the husband's confidence. Few would seek medical care if a physician could take it on herself to violate a patient's privacy. It would be a different matter if you were treating the wife for, say, a venereal disease contracted from the husband; then you'd have to speak up. (As 19th-century doctors often did not. Indeed, they frequently lied to the wife about what they were treating her for.)
As you've discovered, the interests of husband and wife do not always coincide. The best way for you to avoid such conflicts in the future is to see only one member of a family, a practice many psychiatrists observe. As things stand now, without violating anyone's privacy, you can still draw out either of these patients about their marital discontents or suggest counseling.
On the bright side, perhaps the husband is not unfaithful, but has found some other, socially beneficial, use for Viagra. Didn't I read about corn that grows straight and strong, 50 feet high? Isn't there a car that goes a thousand miles on a single tablet?
Do you have ethical queries that you need answered? Send them to ethicist@nytimes.com or The Ethicist, The New York Times Magazine, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Costly Active-Adult Homes Find a Niche in Chester

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
FROM a distance the big new homes rising just off Old Chester-Gladstone Road in Chester Township look like most others rising in and around this wealthy Morris County community. But they are attached homes, side-by-side, designed to look like one of their stately neighbors -- and they are only for active adults age 55 and older.
With an average selling price of $421,000, the 120 houses, each 2,100 to 2,900 square feet in size, that make up the Four Seasons at Chester are considered both large and expensive by market standards. 
 But K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, which is developing the Chester project, and a small group of other developers say there is a demand for active adult communities with large homes.
At present, the average active-adult home is 1,800 square feet in size and costs $170,000, said William E. Becker, a housing consultant in Teaneck specializing in adult communities. Such communities cater to people in their retirement and pre-retirement years and offer a maintenance-free lifestyle with recreation and socializing.
Mr. Becker said the reason for the demand is simple. "People in this age group today have more money," he said referring to them as the "bounty generation." And the strong economy and a robust housing market have made it easier for them to sell their existing homes at an increasing profit, Mr. Becker added.
About 15 active-adult communities, with a total of 6,500 units, are under way in the state and an additional 1,000 to 2,000 units are planned, Mr. Becker said. Just 5 to 10 percent of those units carry price tags of $200,000 or more, he added.
There are other factors stoking the state's active-adult housing market in general and, by extension, the luxury end of it. Among them is the fact that people 55 and over are living more active lives, are working longer and continue to choose to stay close to where their families are and to where they always lived, industry professionals said. Despite an increasing sentiment against growth, some municipalities where development is occurring prefer adult homes to other housing types because they do not have school-age children in the households.
Demographics is another factor, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Urban Policy and Planning at Rutgers University. "Next year the first boomers, who make up 2.8 million of the state's 8.1 million population, turn the double nickel and then we're in for an 18-year surge in the number of people age 55 and over," Dr. Hughes said. "It is the market to go after. But the question is, 'What house type do they want?' "
Developers are betting there will be a sizable wave of buyers who will choose active-adult housing and the lifestyle it offers and that some of them will opt for luxury as well.
The $50 million Chester project, which is expected to be completed in two years, will test the market's upper limits. It is the highest-priced active-adult community Hovnanian has developed in the state since 1994 when it re-entered the retirement market after a 10-year absence. The company has since developed or is developing six other such projects, totaling 2,927 units. Prices average $140,000 in the least expensive complex to $256,000, not including Chester.
The Chester project is a "niche community," and makes sense for several reasons, said Gabe Pasquale, vice president of marketing and sales for Hovnanian's northeast region. One factor, he said, is that it is near Route 206 and in north Jersey, where there are few active-adult communities. The market is affulent couples in Morris, Hunterdon and Warren Counties who are still working and want to remain in the area where they now live.
Such couples, Mr. Pasquale said, are moving from large homes and want a maintenance-free lifestyle, but do not want to compromise on space. He noted that new single-family homes in the area were selling from $700,000 to over $1 million, adding that Chester wanted active-adult housing.
The 120 stucco and stone-clad two-story houses will have three or four bedrooms, with the master bedroom on the first floor in most models, two-car garages and basements. They will be clustered on a 60-acre gently sloping site. It is small compared with sprawling active-adult developments of the past, most of them in Ocean County, where large tracts are still available.
But Mr. Pasquale said the project's size appeals to affulent buyers who also don't mind the lack of a golf course, an amenity in many of the larger communities, because "they usually already belong to a country club." Amenities planned include a clubhouse and a swimming pool; common charges will be $203 a month.
I 'M not going to say there wasn't a little 'hmmmm' before starting a project at this price range," Mr. Pasquale said. But, he said, since construction and sales started in November contracts have been signed for 40 of the homes, priced from $390,000 to $450,000. He said the company, "which has always followed the baby boomers," is planning other upscale active-adult communities, including one in Readington Township with 180 units.
Continental Properties of Woodbridge also thinks there is a market for such projects and will start construction this fall on Cedar Village at Holmdel, with 158 single-family detached homes for active adults. It will rise over the next two and a half years on 60 acres along Laurel Avenue at the intersection of Route 35 in this Monmouth County suburb.
Location is a key factor, said Steven Fisch, a Continental principal. "Holmdel," he added, "is an affulent area where there is a high demand for such housing from an aging baby boomer population, who love the area, still work, and live within a 15-mile radius of this site."
The trend toward smaller-scale communities is driven by the lack of large buildable sites in established areas, like Holmdel, and the perception that mammoth developments are impersonal, he said. Each of the four other active adult projects his company is planning comprise less than 300 units and is in a wealthy community, he added.
The $40 million Cedar Village at Holmdel is part of a large mixed-use project that will offer a 235,000-square-foot retail center as well as 110 assisted-living units and a nursing home. The other components each will be built by separate developers.
Mr. Fisch said the proximity to the other uses will be an advantage because it will offer a village-like setting with easy access to shopping and, "if they want, a transition" from independent to assisted living.
He added that at Cedar Village, which will be a gated community, the homes will be heavily landscaped, with post-and-rail fences between lots to provide privacy. The homes will have 1,500 to 2,500 square feet of space on two floors and such features as two-car garages and basements. There will also be a 5,000-square-foot recreation center. Though prices have not yet been set, Mr. Fisch said he expected them to range from $275,000 to $375,000. Monthly maintenance fees are expected to be $200 to $250.
Toll Brothers of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., a relative newcomer to the adult-housing market, is also planning upscale communities. "The market is ripe and boomers in general have more money to put into their homes," said Wayne S. Patterson, senior vice president at the company, which is known for its high end single-family detached homes.
One project, off Route 9 in Freehold Township, is now planned to have 300 homes with 1,900 to 2,400 square feet of space, with prices expected to start in the $250,000 range. Mr. Patterson said his company also was in discussions with officials in a wealthy north Jersey community, whose name he would not disclose, to build 75 attached single-family homes with 2,400 to 3,000 square feet priced in the mid- to upper-$300,000 range.
"Ultimately, our objective is to position ourselves in this market like we have in the non-age-restricted single-family move-up market," he said.
Dr. Hughes said the success of such projects would determine how many other developers will follow suit and "give us evidence of what boomers want." But, he said, he wonders about the tag age-restricted, given that many of the intended buyers "don't want to be labeled mature."

HEADLINE: 300 Long Islanders, Tied to Connecticut;
The Dwindling Population of Fishers Island Is Isolated by State Borders and Winter's Winds

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

DATELINE: FISHERS ISLAND

 BODY:
WILLIAM BLOETHE pulled his grocery van up to the pier at Silver Eel Cove at 7:30 one January morning to collect his morning delivery, a bundle of newspapers and magazines. With the temperature in the single digits and the wind blowing to make it feel like 30 below, he left the engine running while he went aboard the ferry, but even a few minutes outside was enough to leave his fingers near frozen.
"Fishers Island is a great place to live if you can stand the winters," Mr. Bloethe said, pulling his hands from their gloves and rubbing them briskly. "Every winter you get aggravated and you want to give it up, but nobody wants to move in the middle of winter. Then in April the weather starts to warm up and the people start to come back and things get real busy, and you don't have any time to think about it." 
 In the winter, the Fishers Island movie theater shuts down. So do the coffee shop and the barber. There are three churches (Catholic, Episcopalian, which also closes for the winter, and United Church of Christ) and two gas stations, but no dentist.
In the summer, the island supports two golf courses. In the winter, sportsmen hunt pheasant on one. Residents get to use the other at no charge because there is no staff to collect the greens fees. The two state troopers who are here from May 1 to Thanksgiving leave the island to part-time constables.
Fishers Island is part of Southold town, whose officials worry whether Fishers Island can maintain a large enough year-round population to sustain itself. In the 1960's, more than 600 people lived there year round; there are fewer than 300 today.
"It's a constant concern out here," said Louisa Evans, the Fishers Island representative to the Southold Town Council. "We worry all the time about how we can keep people, and how we might be able to attract more.
"What's optimal? Certainly more people than we have now. In the school it would be nice to have more children in the classroom. If the population gets much older, will there be enough young people for the fire department?"
The school, a "magnet" school with 12 grades, has 75 students, including 19 who commute from Connecticut and one from Rhode Island, who pay tuition.
Also in the winter, the peculiarity of its local government becomes a little more apparent. Southold is 20 miles -- or two ferry trips -- away. The only ferry serving Fishers Island operates out of New London.
As the Southold town supervisor, Jean Cochran, notes, "They even have a Connecticut ZIP code; when it had a New York ZIP code, no one could figure out how to get the mail out there."
But she added, "We have people stationed over there from our fire department. We have our police constables over there. Our highway department serves Fishers Island, and we go over once a year as a town board, in the summertime, and have one of our board meetings there. It's a good connection, and we enjoy going over to visit."
At just seven miles long and never much more than a mile wide, with frigid winds off the Sound whipping the island into a deep freeze from Thanksgiving to Easter, it is hard to figure out why people might want to live here year-round.
"Can you really call this living?" Charles J. Morgan asks as he warms himself with a cup of coffee in Mr. Bloethe's store. He came to the island 50 years ago. "To live here year-round, you have to be a certain type of individual, self-reliant and able to live on your own. You've got to have hobbies. I wouldn't go to the movies if they had it open all year round. I read and I have my photography and I play golf, even in the winter."
But the real islanders, not the 4,000 residents who show up in warm weather, take perverse pride in being able to eke out an existence. They boast openly about how many things shut down, about how they tough it out until the ice is off the rocky shores and the tourists return.
The winter population is also steeped in tradition. They refer to the "new" firehouse, built in 1964, and the "new" schoolhouse, which two generations of islanders have already attended.
A semiretired gardener, Mr. Morgan still looks after two homes on the island, including one where he has tended plants for almost 40 years. If he has enough time, he also tinkers with two old cars, a BMW and a Toyota.
"Everybody here is pretty self-sufficient. We just kind of take winter in stride," Mr. Morgan said. "Some people come up here and the first winter, the first time the boat gets cancelled, they panic. Well, where are you going to go if there's a bad storm, even if the ferry was running? It's not like it's never going to come back."
It's a question of perspective. A visitor may complain that roads are unplowed days after a storm. An islander says it slows down the traffic. In fact, people tend to walk their dogs down the middle of the road, and seem genuinely surprised when they have to move over for traffic. But the islanders are friendly; city dwellers may be surprised to see that drivers wave with all their fingers.
Everyone helps out when he can. When one resident had a flat tire on her way to Bloethe's Market, a passer-by gave her a ride, even though it was out of his way. After she called the service station, Mr. Bloethe offered her the use of the delivery van to get her groceries home. When Mr. Bloethe's Jack Russell terrier saw the keys come out, he started bouncing around, looking for a ride, so she took the dog with her, promising to return him later that day.
"That's the way it is when you know everybody," Mr. Bloethe said.
For a long time, the island did not have a doctor, but it had an arrangement with a New York teaching hospital that rotated internists out to the island every two weeks. "You knew right away who the doctor was when they got off the ferry," Mr. Bloethe said. "It was the only person you didn't know."
There is a resident doctor now, semiretired, but an important safeguard for the islanders.
First settled in 1615, Fishers Island has attracted tourists since the late 19th century. The year-round population has never been large, though, in part because of the winters. Jobs are few: a couple of positions at what is referred to with a smile as the Boroleum factory, a small building that packages an ointment for skin ailments; a few lobstermen, some jobs at the utilities department and on the road crew.
But some famous people have called it home during the summers: Rockefellers and Roosevelts, DuPonts and Firestones. Many still maintain homes there, but the seasonal residents (islanders call them "the families") value their privacy, and the year-rounders respect that. There is a strong economic interest to observe the policy: many islanders work at the seasonal homes.
Paul Rogan, who came to the island in 1931, will tell you that he has been handyman, bartender, groundskeeper and gardener for a succession of famous people, but he will not tell you which ones.
When Mr. Rogan, who is known as Joe, was growing up on the island, the Army still operated Fort H. G. Wright at the western end. The concrete bunkers that once held heavy artillery to fight off a feared invasion force from Germany stand empty; a fence around the 1,800-acre post is rusting.
One house on Hay Harbor, the next bay east, is familiar to visitors: the shingled summer house where Robin Williams and Glenn Close filmed "The World According to Garp." (Mr. Rogan's daughter was an extra in the film.)
Since the military left half a century ago, Mr. Rogan has made his living on the eastern end of the island, where only residents and guests may travel; the roads there are privately owned by the Fishers Island Development Corporation.
He says the lack of Burger Kings or Dunkin Donuts does not bother him. "I like seafood, and I can dig all the clams I want when everyone leaves," Mr. Rogan said. "I don't like to do it in the summertime because it'll show people where my spots are, and they'll go in and clean them right out."
He tries to get over to Connecticut every week or 10 days, and he generally tries to accomplish several errands: shop, see a doctor, do some banking. If you forget to buy aspirin and come down with a headache in the middle of the night, you have only one choice: "You have to call Billy and get him to open the store."
Fishers Island is desolate when the temperature drops, and Marlin Bloethe, who runs the grocery store with her husband, said islanders think of their ferry trips to Connecticut as more than just a jaunt to the mainland.
"It's nice, but sometimes it gets too quiet, and you have to get on the boat and go back to America," she said. "All there is to do is work around the store and walk the dog."
The highest point on the island is just 140 feet above sea level, a promontory where the utilities district has mounted a water tower. No matter where you are on the island, you can see the ocean all around. And no matter which way the wind blows, you can feel it anywhere.
"People out here call Connecticut 'the mainland,' " said Justin Fisher, 20, who moved to the island with his mother last year. "The first time you hear that, it gets to you. It's not like we're in another country. But after 20 years in Connecticut, it was a bit of a culture shock. I mean, one store on the whole island? When I was back home there was a Cumberland Farms down the street, and a McDonald's. You miss things like that. Just to have a mall would be great."
Alison Scroxton, 21, who works in Bloethe's Market, grew up on the island, and said she used to feel the same way.
"My class was a big class, and it was a class of six," she said. "One boy; all the rest were girls. None of us could wait to graduate high school; we all were going to get out. It was boring, nothing to do, nowhere to go.
"Now I love it. The majority of my classmates, when I talk to them, they regret ever having left. They couldn't wait to get off this rock, but when they have a school break, they can't wait to come back."
Winters are still not the busiest times, she said, but the islanders keep busy. "A few of us just started up our aerobics class,." Miss Scroxton said. "We have a girls' softball league. And we go down to the American Legion once in a while and play cards."
Her father, Edward, a 20-year member of the Fishers Island highway crew, is commander and head bartender at the Legion Post, the only wintertime nightspot, open 365 days a year. There is microwave popcorn and toaster pizza, and a barbecue pit if someone wants to grill a cheeseburger in good weather.
"To a degree, it takes an exceptional individual to live out here in the wintertime," Mr. Scroxton said. "You see the steam rising off the salt water like that, and you know the air temperature is going to be cold when you step out the door. So you spend time inside when you have to. I'll sit in my chair and break apart a fishing reel and clean it or repair it. Everybody keeps busy."
"But it also tends to bring out the best in a few people," he continued. "I've thought about leaving before, but I just can't seem to get it out of my system."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 8; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Q. & A.;
Interest on Security, Less a Fee

 BODY:

Q. I have received a formal notice from a bank saying that I received $33.45 in interest on my security deposit. The notice also indicates that $16.13 of that amount was being deducted by the bank as an "agent administration fee." What right does my landlord have to give any part of my interest to others? May I insist that the full amount of the interest be paid to me? . . . Richard Ferris, Manhattan.
 
A. Colleen F. McGuire, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, said that under current law a landlord who has deposited a tenant's security deposit in an interest-bearing account is entitled to receive an "administration fee" of 1 percent of the amount on deposit. That fee, Ms. McGuire said, is typically deducted from the interest earned on the tenant's deposit. And since the interest rate on such accounts to be as low as 2 percent per year, she said, it would not be unusual for the landlord's administration fee to amount to half of the total interest paid on the deposit. 
 Ms. McGuire added that since the landlord is entitled to the administration fee, he is also entitled to assign his right to collect the fee to someone else, such as the bank at which the deposit is held.
 
Succession Rights In a Second Marriage
 
Q. I am the shareholder of an occupied, rent-stabilized co-op apartment. When I purchased the apartment from the prior shareholder, the tenant was an elderly gentleman whose name was the only one on the lease. Prior to his death last year, he married. Under the law, I was required to offer his lease to his widow. She has informed me that in the near future she may marry. If she does legally marry and passes away, am I obligated to offer her lease to her new spouse? . . . Michael L. Altman, Jackson Heights, Queens.
 
A. Felix Nihamin, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that under the Rent Stabilization Law, a husband or wife becomes entitled to succession rights to a spouse's apartment upon the commencement of the marriage.
Accordingly, Mr. Nihamin said, the original tenant's new wife was indeed entitled to succeed to her husband's lease under the same terms and conditions he had as long as the apartment was her principal residence when he died.
Mr. Nihamin added, however, that the same would not apply to the current tenant's potential husband. He explained that while a new husband would be entitled by law to remain in the apartment upon the death of the wife, he would probably have to pay a higher rent.
"The law says that the first succeeding tenant continues to be treated in the same manner as the original tenant," Mr. Nihamin said. "But with the second succeeding tenant -- in this case, the new husband -- the landlord is entitled to treat the succession as a new tenancy and impose a vacancy allowance." In most cases, he said, the current vacancy allowance is 20 percent for a two-year lease and 18 percent for a one-year lease. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: After Much Delay, a Plan for Raymark Site

BYLINE: By ANNE M. AMATO

 BODY:
IT looks like the world's biggest parking lot. Just off Interstate 95 in Stratford, the 34-acre site where thousands of workers once produced brake linings and one of the best women's softball teams played is now paved over and vacant. But after years of delays, a massive cleanup of hazardous waste and several lawsuits, the area is about to become a mall.
The site where the Raymark plant was once located was sold to three retailers, Shaw's Supermarkets, Wal-Mart Stores and Home Depot, last month for $24 million. The first store is expected to open next year. 
 "It's been a long time coming, but well worth the wait," said Diane Toolan, the director of Community and Economic Development for Stratford. "The land will become the gateway to our town."
Raymark, formerly known as Raybestos, manufactured brake linings from 1919 to 1988 at the East Main Street site. At the height of its operations, it employed about 4,000 and made nearly 11 million feet of linings each year. Its woman's softball team, the Raybestos Brakettes, was so good that it toured around the world.
But the asbestos used in making the brake linings contaminated the soil, resulting in a Superfund cleanup by the federal Environmental Protection Agency, which cost the federal government nearly $100 million. Other contaminants, like lead, PCBs and dioxin, were also discovered there.
The cleanup, which involved putting a protective cap over the layers of contamination, was completed in 1997, but the land sat empty due to lawsuits that eventually led to an auction on Jan. 19, ordered by a federal judge at the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Bridgeport handling the bankruptcy of the company.
Details, including how much each company will pay for the land, are still being negotiated, said Keith Morris, community affairs director for Wal-Mart of Bentonville, Ark.
He said Wal-Mart would build a 139,000-square-foot store, which will have the "usual 36 departments of general merchandise." The store will employ about 250 people, with about 70 percent of them full-time. "We should be open by the end of 2001," he said. This will be the 15th Wal-Mart in the state and the second in Fairfield County. A 120,000-square-foot Wal-Mart opened in Shelton a couple of years ago.
"Based on the success of that store, and on Stratford's population and the proximity of the site to I-95, we thought this location would be ideal for another one," Mr. Morris said.
Atlanta-based Home Depot, which has 14 stores in Connecticut, plans to build one of its standard size stores, said John Simley, a company spokesman. He said the store would be 115,000 square feet with a 16,000-square-foot outdoor garden. It will employ 150 to 200 people, a mix of full- and part-timers. "We haven't set a completion date for construction," he said. "That all depends on town permitting approvals. But we would like to move into Stratford as soon as possible. It's a very good location and with two other major retailers, we will be able to feed off each other."
Bernard Rogan, a spokesman for Shaw's, said it was a long time coming, but the end result was worth it. "We couldn't be happier," he said. "This site is very valuable and was much sought after. It couldn't be in a better location."
Once Shaw's builds its 65,000-square-foot supermarket on the site, it will close another store just up the road on Barnum Avenue, near the intersection with Main Street. At 25,000 square feet, that store is Shaw's smallest, employing less than 100 people. The new store, which will include a bakery and pharmacy, will have double that number of workers, Mr. Rogan said.
Shaw's, based in Brockton, Mass., operates 165 supermarkets in New England, 21 of them in Connecticut.
Construction on the new store should take from 8 to 10 months after they get permits. "We would like to move this along quickly, once we get the necessary permits from the town," Mr. Rogan said.
That shouldn't be a problem, according to Gary Lorentson, Stratford's Planning and Zoning administrator, who said the property is already zoned for commercial use.
He said there had been "enough preliminary hearings" on the property to rule out any major glitches.
"As long as the buildings are within zoning regulations, I don't foresee any problems," Mr. Lorentson said.
Congresswoman Rosa DeLauro, a Democrat, called the sale of the Raymark site "great news for the people of Stratford." She said the development of the property would bring in jobs, critical for the "economic viability of our community."
She said she was pleased not only because the land was being put to good use, but also because "Stratford will gain nearly a half million dollars in back taxes" on the site.
"The town has been dragging in economic growth and this will only help us," added State Senator George Gunther, a Republican of Stratford.
James Leach, a developer from Rhode Island, had also seen the potential of the site and once had a purchase agreement on the property. But the bankruptcy auction halted his plans and Mr. Leach was one of several unsuccessful bidders at the auction. "I spotted it one day and realized its potential," Mr. Leach said about the site.
Although he is no longer involved with the property, Mr. Leach said he was happy with the results.
"Those are the companies we brought to the site and had been working with," he said about the retailers.
 Raymark had its beginnings in 1902 in Bridgeport when the A. H. Raymond Company, which made brake linings for cars, was formed. In 1906, a process for making the linings, called Raybestos, was patented. Raybestos also became the name of the company when it moved to the Stratford location in 1919, said Lewis Knapp, Stratford's historian.
He said demand for the brake linings soared when Buick pioneered its 4-wheel drive automobiles. In 1927, the company merged with Manhattan Rubber to become Raybestos-Manhattan.
"There was an upswing during the 1940's, especially due to World War II, when the company supplied brake linings and clutches for the U.S. military," said Mr. Knapp. That upswing continued into the 1950's.
The company did about $83 million worth of sales in 1953, he said.
In the 1950's and 1960's the company diversified and opened factories in Wisconsin and New Jersey where bowling balls were made, he said. About the same time environmental concerns began to surface, especially due to the asbestos used in the manufacture of the brake linings, Mr. Knapp said. This led to lawsuits and a slowdown in business and by 1989, when the company closed its doors for good, there were only 190 employees, he said.
Then, in the spring of 1993, a public health advisory was issued based on the discovery of elevated levels of lead, asbestos and PCB's at the factory site, prompting the Superfund cleanup. That began in September 1995 and was completed two years later, in October 1997.
The cleanup included the demolition of factory buildings that had become an eyesore.
"It's really a shame the way it happened," Mr. Knapp said. "I knew people who worked there, including a general manager and no one knew about the problems with asbestos. Sometimes I think they wanted to portray everyone there as monsters and that's just not the case."
Now that the future of the site has been settled, the town is happy at the outcome.
"I think we are all very eager to move forward with this," said Ms. Toolan. "We have three well-known retail giants ready, willing, and able to move here. This bodes very well for our town."

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

Little Feat
Mention Little Feat to rock aficionados and one need say no more. This is one band that has achieved the affectionate respect of audiences and the music world over two generations, going on a third. 
 Overcoming disbandment in 1979, the group gathered again 10 years later and found a loyal army of fans waiting.
The current members -- Bill Payne, Richie Hayward, Paul Barrere, Sam Clayton, Kenny Gradney, Shaun Murphy and Fred Tackett -- will play the Palace in Stamford on Wednesday at 8 p.m.
Tickets at $25 may be obtained by calling (203) 325-4466. The Palace is at 61 Atlantic Street off Exit 7 of Interstate 95.
 
Vampire Valentine
Two interpretations of Transylvania's sanguineous seducer are on the bill for Saturday's horror movie show at the Memorial Boulevard Auditorium in Bristol. In celebration of Valentine's Day the original 1935 "Mark of the Vampire" with Bela Lugosi as Count Dracula almost loving Elizabeth Allan to death, will be shown in tandem with "Love at First Bite," the tooth-in-cheek remake with George Hamilton and Susan Saint James.
Also on the program: "Transylvania 6-500" with Bugs Bunny, Sylvester and Porky in "Scaredly Cat" and a Flash Gordon episode with Buster Crabbe. Show time is 7:30 p.m. and admission is $5, $1.50 for children 6 through 12. Proceeds will benefit the building fund for the new Witch's Dungeon Movie Museum at 90 Battle Street in Bristol. The number to call for more information is (860) 583-8306.
 
Women's Issues
A series of lectures entitled "Women Speak Out on Health, Humor and Food" begins today at 2 p.m. at the Meriden Public Library, 105 Miller Street, with Regina Barreca, professor of English literature and feminist theory at the University of Connecticut.
Ms. Barreca is the author of "Sweet Revenge: The Wicked Delights of Getting Even," "They Used to Call Me Snow White, But I Drifted," "Perfect Husbands (and other Fairy Tales)" and "The Erotics of Instruction." Publication dates vary from 1992 to 1997 and publishers include University Press of New England, Anchor and Penguin. The books have been translated into Chinese, German, Spanish, Italian, Czech and Korean. In addition to her humorous books she has written seven scholarly works and she is a frequent guest on "Oprah" and "The Today Show." She is a newspaper columnist and a popular speaker at medical and bar association events.
The number to call to register for free limited seating or to obtain more information is (203) 238-2344.
Landlord High Jinks
The Da Capo Opera Company of Redding will present a performace of Sir Arthur Sullivan's "Cox and Box," suitable for family audiences, today at 3 p.m. in the Community Room of the Easton Library on Morehouse Road.
William S. Gilbert, Sir Arthur's customary collaborator, did not participate in this production. The lyrics were written by Francis Burnand, who later became the editor of Punch, the British humor magazine.
The story revolves around Bouncer, an unscrupulous landlord who finds it economically advantageous to rent the same room to Mr. Cox, who works days, and Mr. Box, who works nights, since they will occupy it at different times. Until one of them gets a day off and all heck breaks loose. Admission is free. The number to call for more information or directions is (203) 372-9586.
Cool Portraits
Alex Katz, whose outsized, probing yet cool portraits have intrigued viewers for decades, will give a talk about his work on Wednesday at 6:30 at the Yale University Art Gallery, 1111 Chapel Street.
His portraits and landscapes, seeming so effortlessly meticulous, have been assembled by museums many times and sent on tours of the United States and Europe. Solo exhibitions are currently on display in Italy and Germany, and he is represented in numerous museum and private collections.
Admission is free. The number to call is (203) 432-0600.
 
Gentlemen in Tuxes
Now in their third year, the Connecticut Gay Men's Chorus Singing Valentines are a definite hit. On Saturday and next Sunday, the chorus's office will dispatch small groups of tuxedo-clad gentlemen to serenade the designated beloveds (male or female) on their doorsteps, anywhere within the state of Connecticut. The balladeers bear Valentine gifts of chocolates and bottles of bubbly (alcoholic or non-alcoholic) with two glasses. The price: $75 for everything.
Greater dedication hath no tenor, baritone or basso than to stand in the snow and sing love songs to a total stranger. Senders must place their orders no later than Tuesday by calling (800) 644-CGMC.
 
'Love Letters'
Joanne Woodward and Paul Newman will give a single performance of A. R. Gurney's "Love Letters" next Sunday at 2 p.m. at the Westport Country Playhouse as a benefit for the theater's regeneration.
Ms. Woodward has been a prime mover in rescuing the building from a succession of development plans that would have insured its demolition. Together with a small group of regional theater stalwarts, and with the support of Mr. Newman and virtually the entire town, she is determined to see the playhouse thrive once again.
Tickets range from $150 to $750. For the top ticket the bearer gets to break bread from 11 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. with Ms. Woodward and Mr. Newmanas well as Frank Converse, James Naughton, Christopher Plummer, Jane Powell, Jason Robards, Marlo Thomas and Gene Wilder, among others.
The number to call for reservations or more information is (203) 227-5137. The theater is at 25 Powers Court, near the junction of Route 1 and Route 136.
 
Pristine Keepsakes
Art conservation is not necessarily confined to the hallowed works in museums and high-powered collections. Ordinary folk with a few prints, family documents, old maps picked up at a garage sale, a tear-stained dance program, are just as entitled to keep their paper keepsakes as pristine as possible.
Today at 2:30, at the Pine Street Library in Cornwall, they can learn how to go about it by attending a slide-talk by Lilly Hollander, a Fellow of the American Institution of Conservation. Some problems, they will learn, are best left to a professional, but others can be handled at home, and most importantly, the proper methods of safeguarding such treasures in the first place could be worth substantial dollars in repairs. Admission is $10 and the number to call for more information is (860) 672-6874.
 
Ben and Jerry
How did they do that? And after they did it so successfully, did they or did they not sell out? Jerry Greenfield of the ice cream makers Ben and Jerry -- environmentalists as well as socially reponsible and innovative entrepreneurs -- will tell it like it is (and was) on Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. in the Kelley Theater at Quick Center for the Arts, Fairfield University.
To hear how two boys from Brooklyn and Merrick, Long Island, wound up famous from behind an ice cream counter in Vermont (and for a product sample) call (203) 254-4010 for a $15 ticket, children and those 65 and older $10. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: Opinion;
A Town's Awkward Silence

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY DUMAS; Timothy Dumas is the author of "A Wealth of Evil: The True Story of the Murder of Martha Moxley in America's Richest Community." (Warner Books, 1999)

 BODY:
WHEN the Moxleys of Greenwich could no longer abide living across the street from a young man they suspected of murdering their daughter, they sold their house to an actor named Jon Lee.
Mr. Lee was pleased with his good fortune. The Spanish-style mansion sat stolidly in the middle of the waterfront enclave Belle Haven. Yes, the place needed sprucing up, and some sort of pall seemed to envelop it, but Mr. Lee could not complain: he had paid $290,000 for 24 rooms on two acres, a bargain in 1977. 
 Soon he noticed something odd. When he told friends where he was moving, they would arch their brows and say, "Ooh, the Moxley house," as if it were the Bates Motel.
Eventually, he learned his estate was a kind of unofficial landmark, ground zero of a bizarre local mystery. Since it was seldom discussed openly, Mr. Lee got the story in pieces: On the night of Oct. 30, 1975, as Martha Moxley made her way up the darkened front lawn, someone attacked her with a lady's six iron. With multiple blows, the killer crushed her skull, and then rammed a fragment of broken shaft through her neck. Martha Moxley was only 15 when she died, a girl whose only misfortune, it seems, was being the object of someone's intense desire.
A couple of months into the investigation, police detectives focused on Thomas Skakel, who was 17 and a known as a hothead. He was also a nephew of Ethel and the late Robert F. Kennedy. Over the next quarter century this murder story would take some preposterous turns, but the Skakel family never did break into the clear. On Jan 19, Thomas's younger brother Michael, 15 in October 1975 and 39 now, was arrested and charged with the murder. He is scheduled to be arraigned in Stamford on Tuesday.
In 1977, Mr. Lee, who has acted on Broadway and in movies, was curious about what had transpired on the lawn that was now his, but he was careful about asking too much. For one thing, nobody ever mentioned Martha's name: Mr. Lee likened her presence in Belle Haven to that of 19th-century pregnant girls who would just seem to vanish. For another thing, few found the business of this unsolved murder terribly pressing, though suspects lived in their midst. When the subject did arise, Mr. Lee said, it was in the context of an annoyance to be groused about over cocktails: Did you see they're dragging that up again?
Mr. Lee was puzzled by this attitude. When it came to an issue like goose poop in the parks or keeping outsiders off the town beach, sparks could fly. Indeed, when a dermatologist built a nice house in Greenwich but cut down all his trees and a few of the town's, some residents shouted obscenities at the house and sent anti-Semitic remarks, even death threats, through his phone line. That is worse than the Skakels ever got.
Yet with this murder, he saw little anger and no concerted push for justice. He did not believe his neighbors hoped for Martha's killer to go free, but rather that they naively wished the bad publicity away. It was, in essence, an invasion of privacy, a subject unfit for polite discussion.
How is such an attitude born? Let me start with a few safe opinions. Greenwich is a town of extraordinary beauty; a town that functions smoothly and safely; a town where all economic classes are represented, but where the wealthy are (especially nowadays, as in the 1920's) gaudily conspicuous.
For many residents, Greenwich is not merely a great place to live. It also symbolizes the fulfillment of one's ambitions. Arriving there means arriving in life. Natives like me also harbor a sense of the town's superiority, though I admit there's a fine line between feeling proud and being arrogant. Greenwich brims with good and thoughtful people, but it also has its share of snobs whose image of the town, so bound up in their images of themselves, admits no evil.
And here they do Greenwich a disservice. If you cannot own up to problems, you cannot fix them. When I was a young reporter for a Greenwich weekly newspaper, a drug counselor told me of rampant drug use at Greenwich High School. Of course, I had known about the problem from my days as a student there. But when we published the story, the newspaper got irate calls from the headmaster, and the drug counselor lost his job. Soon after, a couple of courageous students chastised the headmaster for failing to act on the drug problem that everyone knew existed.
This was far from the only time Greenwich was forced to admit to problems that dogged every other town. Racism had long simmered quietly beneath the surface, only to erupt in a series of ugly incidents in the 1990's: a near riot in a town housing project; a real estate agent caught on TV steering a black couple to Stamford and a white couple away from Stamford; and a racial hate message encoded by students in the Greenwich High School yearbook.
Perceptive Greenwich residents welcome a ruckus despite the unpleasantness, realizing that exposure is a means to resolution. But too often, the importance of image has triumphed over reality.
Big news stories out of Greenwich often follow the same trajectory. Like the Moxley murder and racism stories, they begin as subjects too indelicate for open discussion and end up, as though spring-loaded, detonating in the national news media, who always marry the act to the community's stupendous wealth.
It might seem contradictory, the outrage over small issues like geese and trees and the burying of deep, dark ones. But it makes perfect sense if you understand that Greenwich views itself as a suburban sanctuary, the closest thing to Eden in a fickle and ruthless world.
That is why so many residents seem on the one hand to refuse a knowledge of evil, and on the other to vigorously combat direct assaults on its way of life. Greenwich residents are aware that they live in a special place, and, no matter what it takes, they want it to stay that way.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: $1 Billion in Projects for Johns Hopkins in Baltimore

BYLINE: By CHARLES BELFOURE

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
JOHNS HOPKINS is known for its medical center and university, but its impact on its hometown is more concrete. Together the Johns Hopkins University and its medical center, with the help of their own development company, are the biggest builders in Baltimore. Over the next five years they plan to complete or begin work on $1 billion worth of buildings to expand and update their facilities.
This would have pleased its founder, Johns Hopkins, a merchant remembered for his dedication to the economic prosperity of his city. In the fall of 1873 he single-handedly averted a major financial crisis in Baltimore like those that were sweeping New York and other cities. By using his own money and his reputation, Hopkins guaranteed the stability of investments held by local businesses. When he died a few months later he left $7 million, a huge sum in its day, to create a university and a hospital to serve the people of Baltimore. 
 The influence of the university and the Johns Hopkins Health System cannot be overstated. In addition to being Maryland's largest private employers with 37,900 jobs, together they spent a total of $176 million for construction last year, the most of any business or institution in Baltimore.
Both entities will replace outdated academic and medical facilities and build new space for research, creating an estimated 4,500 construction-related jobs by the year 2004. Most of the planned construction is expected to be completed in the next decade.
"Hopkins is considered a top customer of the Baltimore Development Corporation for economic development in the city," said Jay Brodie, president of the quasi-governmental entity that promotes development.
Many feel that Baltimore, a city that has lost a third of its population since 1970, would be in far worst straits if it didn't have Hopkins as an employer and builder.
Hopkins has its own full-service real estate development subsidiary. Called Dome Corporation, its name is inspired by the famous dome of the original Johns Hopkins Hospital completed in 1889 that still stands on its East Baltimore medical center.
Dome Real Estate, a division of the corporation, develops and builds for Hopkins, but mainly for tenants of its research facilities -- private biomedical companies and federally financed laboratories. "We offer a complete range of development expertise," said Lester Conley, president of Dome Real Estate, "including programming, land planning, financing, construction, and property management." Development has been concentrated mainly within Baltimore City.
A for-profit entity, Dome was created in 1984 when Hopkins purchased the Baltimore City Hospital, a money-losing municipal health center. Its first job was to create a master plan for the 130-acre parcel, renamed Johns Hopkins Bayview Campus, which included new research facilities for private industry.
BECAUSE so many private companies want to be identified with Hopkins because of its reputation, they turn to Dome for its expertise in helping to develop their own facilities "while offering institutional sensitivity to their research needs," according to Mr. Conley.
Dome's biggest client at Bayview is the Institutes on Aging and Drug Abuse Addiction, part of the National Institutes of Health. The agency has a total of 276,000 square feet of laboratory and research space at Bayview.
In 1988, Dome built the 100,000-square-foot Triad Technology Center at Bayview, which provides space for biomedical firms, government and academic laboratories. A year later, Dome completed the 25,000-square-foot Alpha Center, a biomedical incubator building that offers inexpensive lab space for startup biotech firms.
When tenants such as the National Institutes of Health need to expand or renovate their facilities, they usually come to Dome for design and construction services. On most of the projects it develops, Dome stays on as property manager.
Dome builds directly for Hopkins at Bayview as well. It constructed the Johns Hopkins Asthma and Allergy Center in 1989 and its Behavioral Biology Research Center in 1991. Dome is currently revising the master plan to increase the total campus development from 3.5 million to 5 million square feet.
Currently Dome's largest project is the $17 million renovation of the former Eastern High School in north central Baltimore. Built in 1936, the 200,000-square-foot Collegiate Gothic building will be used primarily for university administrative and academic functions, but will have space for tenants. "We'll be trying to attract businesses that relate to high technology and sciences, but not necessarily medical," explained Mr. Conley.
The school is on a 26-acre site on East 33rd Street, a major thoroughfare that connects with Homewood, the university's main campus less than a half mile away. It is hoped that the project will stimulate new development along this linkage. The size of the parcel also lends itself to future development of more buildings, Mr. Conley said.
Not all buildings for Hopkins are done by Dome. The facilities for the hospital, the university and the medical school, which is a part of the university, are done by the entities themselves using a traditional method of hiring an architect and putting the project out to bid.
The two newest buildings on the East Baltimore medical campus are prime examples of how this is done. The $125 million, 540,000-square-foot Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Building will house cancer patients as well as facilities for their surgery and treatment, explained Sally MacConnell, vice president of facilities for the Johns Hopkins Health System.
"We got extensive input from nurses, doctors, and families of patients to see how we could design it to be supportive and not look institutional," she added. The Weinberg Building is built next to the original hospital and was designed to harmonize with the building's Queen Anne style.
The $59 million Bunting-Blaustein Research Building, completed last December, houses all cancer research, which had been scattered in five buildings. It emphasizes bench to bedside research, bringing the latest treatment protocols from the laboratory to the patients as quickly as possible, said Ms. MacConnell.
Projects totaling more than $400 million on the East Baltimore medical campus in the next five years will include the 292-bed Women's and Children's Hospital; the 196-bed Critical Care Tower, which has its own heliport; the 300,000-square-foot Broadway Research Building and the 1,500-car Caroline Garage. Negotiations are currently under way to acquire an eight-acre parcel adjacent to the medical campus to construct a parking garage that may include a hotel with retail space and more medical facilities.
THE university is expanding its presence in downtown Baltimore by renovating a 38,000-square-foot building leased from Peter Angelos, owner of the Baltimore Orioles. It will become the School of Professional Studies, whose main offerings will be graduate degrees in business and education. Most of the $6.1 million cost of renovating the building, which is expected to be completed in December, is being borne by Mr. Angelos.
In 1988, Hopkins looked beyond Baltimore to suburban Washington to create a new campus. The university broke ground this past fall for its second building on the 38-acre site in Rockville, Md., in Montgomery County. The 50,000-square-foot building will add needed space for its part-time graduate programs. With course registration projected to increase 30 percent in each of the next five years, three more buildings are being planned.
Homewood, the university's main campus, will continue to grow with $173 million of construction including a new student arts center, a dorm, a recreation center, and a renovation of its original building, Gilman Hall. A new master plan to be completed this spring will probably identify the need for more improvements, said James McGill, senior vice president for administration.
