SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2435 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
New Jersey Fits the Prescription

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
IF you want to run with the big dogs, you have to go where the big dogs are," said Gerald P. Belle, the president of Aventis Pharmaceutical, about the company's decision to shift the operating headquarters of his newly merged company from Kansas City and suburban Philadelphia to Parsippany, N.J.
The pharmaceutical industry is in a phase of consolidation as companies seek to spread the cost of developing new drugs over a broader sales base. Increasingly, it is consolidating in New Jersey. 
 Drug company executives and consultants say there are a variety of reasons, some of them historical, that have led to the industry's concentration in New Jersey. And, as the recent decisions of a number of companies to move into the state or expand their New Jersey operations indicate, many leaders of the industry believe that a location in the state offers the advantageous combination of access to business and technical talent, regulatory agencies and global markets.
Pharmacia A.B. of Sweden and Upjohn Company of Kalamazoo, Mich., initially chose an area near London as an operating base after the two companies merged in 1995. But within a year of the appointment of a former American Home Products executive, Fred Hassan, as chief executive, the company was hunting for headquarters space on the East Coast of the United States.
It landed first in Bridgewater, N.J., and then moved on to nearby Peapack, where it currently has over 1,000 employees in a 550,000-square-foot building once occupied by Beneficial Corporation. If the company completes its merger with Monsanto Company, as expected in the second quarter of this year, a spokesman said, much of Monsanto's pharmaceutical operations will be transferred from St. Louis to New Jersey.
"New Jersey was the jewel we were looking for," Mr. Hassan said after signing a 12-year lease for the Peapack building. "With 15 of the world's largest drug companies dotting the landscape, New Jersey truly was the nation's medicine chest." Mr. Hassan has also called New Jersey "the global center of gravity of the pharmaceutical industry."
Now called Pharmacia & Upjohn, the company will change its name to Pharmacia Corporation once the merger with Monsanto is completed, with the names Upjohn and Monsanto used to designate divisions within the overall company.
And another heavy hitter may be on the way. Two British companies, Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham have announced their intention to merge, a merger that would create the largest drug company in the world.
The companies have already said they plan to place an operating headquarters in the United States, although the corporate headquarters will remain in London. The company has said they plan to build in the general vicinity of New York City and the betting in real estate circles is that it will be somewhere near Princeton.
Aventis will be staying in the state, but plans to move from Parsippany in Morris County to Bridgewater in Somerset County when two buildings, each with 310,000 square feet of space, are built. In the meantime it is renting 340,000 square feet of space as an interim headquarters from SJP Properties, a New Jersey-based developer and property owner that is also building the Bridgewater structures.
Mr. Belle said it was important to have the company's major administrative and research operations in one location to help create a brand image to go with a new name. "We have an opportunity to put a united front on Aventis before the financial community and the world at large," he said.
Some companies that have long been established in the state are expanding to keep up in the race to develop new medicines. Merck & Company has said it is investing $1 billion in its research and development facility in Rahway. Hoffman-LaRoche is building a new factory on its 125-acre tract in the towns of Clifton and Nutley that will be dedicated to its new anti-obesity drug, Xenical. Other companies have major projects under way as well.
The wave of mergers has meant that some properties are coming to market. Since research and development centers are costly and take a long time to build, the properties are attractive to companies who want to enter the United States market or expand their operations here.
"The pharmaceutical industry's capital investment is enormous," said Thomas Glerum, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate brokerage and services company. "Those research and development buildings cost $400 a square foot without equipment," he said. "High-end office buildings do not exceed $220 a square foot."
James J. Garibaldi, chief executive of the Garibaldi Group, a brokerage and services concern in Chatham, said that among the interesting properties coming on the market as a result of mergers is Aventis's research and development complex in Collegeville, Pa.
Aventis, which was formed by the merger of Hoechst and Rhone-Poulenc, is consolidating its research and development at Hoechst's facility in Bridgewater, making Rhone-Poulenc's Collegeville facility surplus.
Another is a 1.7 million-square-foot research campus in Summit that is being offered for sale by Novartis. The company was formed in 1997 by the merger of the pharmaceutical division of Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz Pharmaceutical Corporation, and the combined company has decided to consolidate its research facilities and offices at the former Sandoz headquarters in East Hanover.
That leaves the former Ciba-Geigy property in Summit on the market. "A lot of pharmaceutical companies want to acquire it, but they want it instantly," said Andrew Merin, an executive director of Cushman & Wakefield of New Jersey. But since construction in East Hanover will probably not be completed until 2003 or 2004, he said, instant gratification is not possible, at least for the entire property.
Mr. Merin said he expects the sale to take place this year, but Novartis is expected to lease about 400,000 square feet of space at the Summit site until the East Hanover buildings are completed.
All this activity and investment is producing results, according to a study underwritten by the HealthCare Institute of New Jersey, a trade group for the larger pharmaceutical companies in the state. More than 40 percent of all the new medicines approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 1999 were developed by companies based in New Jersey.
Of the 40 new drugs and biological agents approved by the federal agency last year, 17 were from New Jersey companies. California, home to many new biological-development companies, was second with six approvals, and North Carolina was third with three.
THE industry has an outsized economic impact on the state, according to an economic survey conducted for the institute by the PricewaterhouseCoopers accounting and consulting company. The survey, using 1998 data, found that the industry was responsible for 140,000 direct and indirect jobs in New Jersey and contributed $10.3 billion to the state's economy.
The report noted that the pharmaceutical companies themselves represent 57,629 full-time jobs, with 43,716 more in services, such as overseeing clinical trials, shifted from the companies to outside suppliers. Indirectly supported jobs, such as those in restaurants and other services used by pharmaceutical employees, brought the total to 140,000, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers.
Those drug industry workers certainly have money to spend. Total compensation of workers at pharmaceutical companies, excluding benefits, averaged $80,223 per worker, the study found.
"The compensation level reflects the high proportion of industry employees with advanced scientific and business degrees, as well as the fact that almost one-fourth of the industry's employees work in the sophisticated research and development functions," the report said.
William H. Tremayne, president of the institute, which was formed in 1997 to give the hotly competitive industry a single voice, said the number of jobs makes the drug industry the largest manufacturing industry in the state, with twice as many as the second-ranking category, printing and publishing.
Patrick J. Zenner, the chairman of the institute and president of the American operations of the Swiss-based HoffmanLaRoche, said the industry's need for common voice was the result of the health care debates of the early 1990's. He said the industry was surprised to find that it was unpopular in some quarters.
"We were heavily criticized and realized we needed to do a better job of communications," he said. He said criticism based on the cost of new medicines overlooked the costly and complex nature of inventing new drugs. "It takes from 12 to 14 years between when a discovery" is made and when it comes to market as a drug, he said, "and it costs $500 million to bring a new medicine to the public. We don't think that message went out."
As to why the drug industry is concentrated in New Jersey, he said that in Hoffman-LaRoche's case, it was the result of a drive in the country.
The company, founded in 1896 in Basel, Switzerland, came to the United States in 1905, opening an office in New York City to sell medicines imported from Europe. As the business grew, it became clear that the company would have to begin doing research and manufacturing in this country and that doing so would be difficult in the cramped confines of Manhattan.
According to Mr. Zenner, Nelson Peterson, then the head of the company's United States operations, went for a drive in New Jersey in 1928. At that time, large tracts of land in the northern part of the state were still devoted to farms. Stopping for gas, he decided that a site straddling the Clifton-Nutley border just south of Route 3 would do nicely for a production plant and offices.
(A similar tale is told of why Johnson & Johnson is in New Brunswick. According to a corporate history, one of the brothers for whom the company is named, James, was on a Pennsylvania Railroad train headed for Philadelphia in 1886. As it slowed to cross the Raritan River at New Brunswick, he spotted a "To Let" sign on a four-story brick building in the town. It became the first headquarters of the company.)
Unlike some pharmaceutical companies that put manufacturing, administration and R. & D. in different locations, Hoffman-LaRoche does all three on its main campus. In addition to the building being constructed to make Xenical, Mr. Zenner said some older buildings have been demolished to make way for a new research complex.
Many of the other companies now in New Jersey have their roots in New York or, if foreign based, opened their first offices there. But as they grew, the cheap farmland in New Jersey beckoned because it was still close to the city and its port. At first they stayed close to the city or along the railroad lines, but as the state's highway system developed, they scattered around the northern part of the state.
Later, the easy accessibility to Newark International Airport became an important factor. "Accessibility to an international airport is important because these are global businesses," said Mr. Tremayne. "If you are located in the hinterland, you have to take a domestic flight to get to the international flight."
IN addition to international travel, New Jersey's location about an hour's flight from Washington is important to companies that have to be in regular contact with the Food and Drug Administration during the drawn-out process of seeking approval of new medicines, Mr. Tremayne said.
Many in the pharmaceutical industry observe that the concentration of drug companies in New Jersey has produced a pool of talent in the state that companies moving in can tap. This allows new entrants to hire researchers and executives without the expense of moving them from other parts of the country and allows individuals to move up the ladder without disrupting their families.
Within the pool of pharmaceutical talent, "New Jersey has the largest concentration of scientists in the nation," said Gualberto Medina, the state's director of economic development.
Joseph Palo, a partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers who helped conduct the economic study for the HealthCare Institute, said that "access to talent is no small issue."
"We are talking about Ph.D.'s, M.B.A.'s and masters in public health," Mr. Palo said. "When pharmaceutical companies go shopping for these kind of people, they do so in large numbers."
He said the sites for meetings of professional and scientific societies was an indication of the number of highly educated people living and working in the state. "They are almost always in New Jersey, at places like the Newark Airport Marriott or the Princeton Hyatt," he said.
But the drug companies are often not happy about the prospect of their scientists mingling with those from other companies, out of a concern that research secrets may leak out and the danger that their brightest talents will be recruited by others. As a result they tend to build campus-like research facilities, both to replicate the academic settings where researchers received their training and to keep them on the reservation.
"These companies build self-contained developments with a ton of amenities to keep their scientists at home," said Mr. Merin of Cushman & Wakefield.
Mr. Medina said it became apparent about five years ago that the pharmaceutical industry was going to globalize and that his agency has been wooing companies still based offshore. "When Pharmacia & Upjohn was still in London, we sent a letter to Fred Hassan reminding him about New Jersey," he said.
Mr. Medina predicted that by the time the globalization process was completed, New Jersey would have gained 50,000 additional jobs in the industry, despite the layoffs that will come as a result of combining companies.
But Mr. Belle said state incentives were not the critical factor in the decision to locate Aventis in the state. "Missouri and Pennsylvania were pretty interested, too," he said. "So it is not a question of New Jersey winning the incentive pool. It was no better and no worse than the other states."
In the end, geography may have been destiny. Mr. Palo noted that about 32 percent of the drug industry's dollar sales are in the United States, 28 percent in Europe and 20 percent in Japan, with the rest scattered around the rest of the world. In a global industry, he said, drugs are launched simultaneously in the major markets.
"New Jersey is a pretty good place to be," he said. "It's about halfway between Europe and Japan."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 5; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1267 words

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES;
One Church, Two Visions

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

DATELINE: NORWOOD

 BODY:
In its 14-year history, the ChoDae Presbyterian Church in New Jersey has blossomed into one of the biggest Korean-American congregations in northern New Jersey. Its membership has grown to about 700 people from 50, and many of its three Sunday services in a rented 250-seat Lutheran church in Paramus are filled to overflowing.
After a four-year search for new land, ChoDae has chosen seven wooded acres near the ball fields and swim club of this quiet suburb of 5,700 people in northeastern Bergen County and has drafted plans for a handsome new $5 million church. Besides a 720-seat sanctuary, the building would include 14 classrooms for Sunday school and Bible study and a fellowship hall with two gymnasiums. ChoDae's senior pastor, the Rev. Young-Chin Cho, called the proposed church "our dream and our vision." 
 Yet pursuing the dream has led to a squabble, as so many development issues do in northeast New Jersey, whether the property at issue is being considered for a school, a synagogue or a Home Depot. The Norwood battle is not the only one connected with the rapid growth of Korean-American churches in the state since the mid-1980's, but it is one of the nastiest involving a congregation seeking to build a home of its own. Of the 170 members of the Council of Korean Churches in New Jersey, 140 do not yet have their own buildings.
Norwood's residents seem equally upset with the size of the church and with the town's board of adjustment for approving a zoning variance for the church last August without getting any advice from environmental, traffic or planning experts.
The outcry prompted the board last December to reverse itself and order new hearings on the necessary variance. ChoDae and its lawyer, Allen M. Bell, of Tenafly, responded by filing suit in New Jersey Superior Court, charging that the reversal violated the state's municipal land-use law.
So far, ChoDae has prevailed. Judge Jonathan Harris has blocked any new hearings by the board of adjustment and ordered it to legally justify its attempt to withdraw the variance. A hearing is scheduled for Feb. 16.
Korean-American religious leaders in the state say they believe the ChoDae-Norwood fight -- with foes mounting townwide opposition and a church going to court -- is the most intense in the 15 years since first-generation Korean immigrants began establishing their churches in New Jersey. Although the number of Korean-American churches, most of them Presbyterian, Methodist and Baptist, has grown sharply, most congregations rent space in other churches for Sunday services, weekday Bible studies and fellowship meetings.
About 200 Korean-American congregations exist in the state now, 170 of them belonging to the Council of Korean Churches, said the council president, the Rev. Hee Moon Lee, a Methodist minister whose 70-member congregation rents from an Episcopalian church in Edison.
Most of the 30 congregations in the council that have their own buildings purchased them from churches that had closed, he said. All pastors long for their own building, he said, but most congregations are small and are still raising money to buy land or build a church.
Mr. Lee said opposition from town governments or residents was "not a big problem" facing Korean-American congregations. He said the council planned to stay out of the ChoDae-Norwood dispute.
"Under our concept -- our Korean-Christian concept -- we usually don't participate in political issues," Mr. Lee said. "I don't want to have us participate in their struggle." He said the council's primary function was helping first-generation immigrants, primarily those struggling to learn English, with personal, social and economic problems.
Last November, Norwood's foes formed a townwide nonprofit organization, the Norwood Civic Association, to fight approval of the church. In two months, about 700 of Norwood's 1,850 families have joined the association, said the group's treasurer, Nejhla) Shaw.
Ms. Shaw said the association considered the proposed church too big. She contended it would create traffic congestion near the swim club and the athletic complex during Sunday games. In addition, she argued, dozens of trees in the wooded plot, which includes some wetlands, would be cut down, raising the risk of floods during heavy rains.
"It has nothing to do with Koreans," Ms. Shaw said. "It has nothing to do with a church. It has nothing to do with who has the church. It's the building, the complex. The building is too big. We've never had a building go up that big in town. It really doesn't serve the community or its residents."
The association's president, Joseph Vitale, denied the group was racially motivated. "Our issue is with the size," he said. "We're just looking to conserve the rural texture of the town."
He and Ms. Shaw both said many Norwood residents were surprised when the board of adjustment granted the variance in August..
"How does something this big pass without calling experts?" she asked. "That's what puzzles Norwood residents. No one understands it."
Town officials, including the four-term Mayor, Gus D'Ercole, a Democrat and lifelong resident, declined comment because of ChoDae's lawsuit.
Ms. Shaw and Mr. Vitale discounted notions that the civic association had political aspirations. But their contention that the organization represents about half the families in Norwood suggests it could exercise considerable political power in the future.
Pastors of Norwood's three existing churches -- which are Catholic, Episcopalian and Presbyterian -- all declined to comment on the ChoDae situation.
In recent weeks, the association has circulated fliers around town denouncing the proposed church. The fliers say the building will be 64,000 square feet.
ChoDae officials said that figure was incorrect and the actual size of the structure was 47,000 square feet.
Mr. Cho, the pastor, said critics were also incorrectly portraying the proposed Bible classrooms as a regular school.
"I don't understand why," he said. "The correct information is open to them."
Mr. Cho, a 41-year-old graduate of the New York Theological Seminary, said the classrooms and the gymnasiums would be open to the community when parishioners were not using them.
"The American system teaches us to learn about other cultures and to share with other cultures and harmonize," he said. "We want to open our building to the community, not only to Koreans but to everybody. We are not the enemy. We are your neighbors, too. We want to be a good neighbor."
He said ChoDae was prepared to contribute to Norwood's schools, library, fire department and ambulance squad, as it has in Paramus for years. He also said the congregation planned to continue the practice it started in Paramus of providing $3,000 a year for two scholarships for college students who are volunteers in the local ambulance squad.
Both the mayor of Paramus, Cliff Gennarelli, and the Rev. Thomas Hjembo, pastor of the Mission Church in Paramus, where ChoDae has paid rent for 14 years, praised the congregation in letters to Norwood's officials.
Mayor Gennarelli said ChoDae's departure from Paramus would create "an enormous void in our community."
Pastor Hjembo wrote that ChoDae had been "very generous" and had contributed to a new roof, a new organ and new carpeting at the Mission Church.
"America is a place where all people from other nations are welcome to seek freedom of religion without discrimination," he wrote. "Is Norwood part of America? Be generous and put up with a little traffic on Sunday morning."

PUB-DATE: February 6, 2000

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 8; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1030 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Proposed Bank Merger Prompts Claims of Bias

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
While the longest economic expansion in history trickles down fitfully to city neighborhoods, a coalition of community groups working to rebuild them is recalling a problem that seemed to fade with the 1970's: the old-fashioned practice of redlining.
The accusations have arisen as a statewide consumer advocacy group, group New Jersey Citizen Action, has challenged the proposed merger of two giants, Hudson United Bank and the Dime Savings Bank of New York. 
 Last week, the New Jersey Black Ministers Council joined Citizen Action in calling on the state banking authorities to intervene in the merger on the ground that Hudson has written off minority neighborhoods and low- and moderate-income homebuyers.
Of more than 1,000 loans that Hudson made in New Jersey in 1998, only 9 went to blacks, according to data that Citizen Action compiled from reports to federal regulators. In Essex, Union and Morris Counties, two loans went to black applicants. The group said the bank made no loans to blacks or to low-income applicants in Hudson County, the bank's home base.
The Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, director of the ministers' council, said that "the bank has not made a serious effort to lend to qualified minorities."
While Mr. Jackson said there was "no more blatant example" than Hudson of a lender refusing to work with community leaders, he said the challenge to Hudson's merger "will remind other banks that they have an obligation to be fair in lending."
The ministers' council and Citizen Action also accuse the bank of reneging on a 1997 agreement with Citizen Action in which it pledged to set aside $4 million for investment in Newark, including home mortgages, housing development and loans to small businesses. Of that amount, it has lent $323,000, Citizen Action said.
Hudson officials have declined to respond to the complaints. A spokesman, Richard Edmonds, referred to a brief statement in which the bank said it was "cooperating to the fullest with the regulators in their review process."
The statement also said that in December the two banks pledged that the merged company, to be called Dime United Bancorp, would set aside $2.5 billion for low- and moderate-income borrowers in its new four-state market. The statement said that in annual reviews of its compliance with a 23-year-old anti-redlining law, federal regulators had given Hudson "satisfactory" ratings.
It is the 1977 law, called the Community Reinvestment Act, that gives groups like Citizen Action and the Black Ministers Council a role in policing banks. The law provides that when a bank applies for a merger or expansion, community groups can register a challenge if they believe it has failed to meet local banking needs.
As a result, many banks have negotiated agreements with coalitions of community groups -- in New Jersey, Citizen Action -- to invest in the urban areas where they have branches.
The law was supposed to have written an end to redlining. While several national studies in the last decade have shown that minority applicants were still significantly more likely to be turned down for mortgages than whites with similar incomes, they also found that, particularly after a flurry of enforcement efforts by the Clinton administration, mortgage lending to low-income people had risen significantly.
But more recently, those efforts have flagged, said John Taylor, president of the National Community Reinvestment Coalition, an umbrella group of community-based nonprofits.
"This is the kind of stuff that impacts millions of people, but people don't see it until branches close, and it becomes difficult getting small business loans, and they try to get a mortgage," he said.
Mr. Taylor added: "If I were the mayor of a major city, or a state legislator, I would wake up. What in the hell is in these banks but the assets of the people of New Jersey? It's not like the banks manufactured this money. It's borrowed from the people of New Jersey."
The Dime-Hudson merger was announced in September. The proposal was submitted to federal banking authorities in December and to the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance on Jan. 7. New Jersey Citizen Action has filed challenges with the Federal Reserve and the state banking department, which has until March 7 to review the merger application.
In the meantime, the organization picketed Hudson branches in several cities, including Newark, Woodbridge and Union City. Phyllis Salowe-Kaye, the director of Citizen Action, said it had enlisted the formal support of some elected officials, including the Hudson County Board of Freeholders and the Woodbridge City Council and its mayor, Jim McGreevey.
Ms. Salowe-Kaye said Citizen Action had agreements with 29 banks, including Hudson.
"All banks are not good," she said, "but none are this bad." Since the merger was announced, she said, Hudson has refused to discuss an agreement for the new bank, which will have more than 330 branches. "The attitude has been total arrogance," she said.
Ms. Salowe-Kaye said the 1997 agreement made no reference to race but only to income levels. Still, she said, "it's so jarring" to find that the bank made only two loans to African-Americans in the Newark metropolitan area in 1998.
The federal reports show that Hudson made 133 home loans to whites in the metropolitan area. Among other lenders, First Union Mortgage Corporation made 268 loans to blacks and 1,603 to whites; Summit Bank made 159 loans to blacks and 2,780 to whites; and Fleet Bank made 5 loans to blacks and 87 to whites.
Hudson's detractors allow that the bank did not deny many applications from minority applicants; the problem, they say, is that Hudson has had only a handful of them despite its presence in areas with large black and Latino populations.
"Other banks market their programs," said Wayne Smith, the council president in Irvington, who works with Citizen Action in counseling minority home-buyers. "They're out beating the drums for business. Some are working with local churches, some with nonprofit organizations, community development organizations. They advertise. They'll advertise in church bulletins."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 14; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 751 words

HEADLINE: IN THE GARDEN;
Some Seedlings Really Need a Head Start

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
ALL too often when the garden season begins, there is a dash to the garden center, supermarket or hardware store to buy young plants. The choices may be limited, depending on the retailer, or the stock of a particular favorite may be gone.
Those who plan ahead and grow their own plants from seed don't have these problems. In addition, raising your own annuals and vegetables is deeply satisfying and economical. 
 This ritual should begin soon. Garden planners will have to be clear on what they will want to grow. The catalogs are here, for the most part. So decisions should have been made and the seed packets ordered.
When to plant? The tiniest seeds are the ones that seem to be the most difficult, requiring the longest time to get started. The almost pepperlike seed of snapdragons, petunias and begonias needs a good head start. The end of this month is not too soon. Pansy seed also could benefit from an early start as the plants can be set out to provide an early spring show along with the bulb flowers.
Other seeds for vegetables such as peppers, melons and squash, along with many showy summer flowers can be started in March. Tomato seed does not need to be planted until the end of March as the seedlings grow rapidly. The trick for strong tomato plants is to set the seedlings out when they are young and vigorous. Large tomato plants usually take a week or so to get settled in the garden before they truly amount to anything.
There is no mystique about starting plants from seed. There are many aids to make this task much easier, including one that comes from the Gardener's Supply Company, 128 Intervale Road, Burlington, Vt., 05401.
This company has developed, and patented, a special seed-starting system called the Accelerated Propagation System.
The system, which comes in several sizes, all easy to place in the home, consists of a greenhouse cover to retain heat and moisture, a growing tray, capillary watering mat, pegboard stand for the seedling tray and a water reservoir on the bottom. It will supply enough water for the plants for an entire week, which means you can go on vacation and all will be well until you get back.
To fill these trays the same company also supplies seedling starting soil mix, which is finely milled, plus potting mixes that can be used for later transplanting when the seedlings mature.
More skill is required when planting other seeds for specialty plants and wildflowers.
Many wildflowers take two years or even more before they even appear above ground, and many require a cold period before they will grow. Somehow storing the seed in the refrigerator for a few months has never seemed to work for this learner.
One dear friend who seems to be able to grow seed with the greatest of ease has the best success by leaving her wooden flats of seed outdoors in the rain and snow. Her husband fashioned seed flats for her and tacked a polyethylene screen over the top to keep out rodents and pets, but leaves the seed area open to the snow and rain.
Other gardeners have had great success by placing their seed flats in a cold frame.
One of the great sources for wildflower seed is the New England Wildflower Society in Framingham, Mass. The society's chief propagator, Bill Cullina, provides practical advice on growing wild flowers when he notes that it takes a great deal of patience.
In a recent presentation he made to a national organization of plant propagators, he spoke of a case in point: the wildflower society's great success in growing the much coveted large-flowered Trillium from seed. It takes five years to grow these plants from seed to salable-size plants.
The first year seed is sown in July. Germination takes place the following spring (year 1). At this time the young seedlings are fertilized, and again in May of Year 2. In the spring of year 3, the seedlings are transplanted to individual pots. Mr. Cullina said that this deed is tricky because the rhizomes of the seedlings must be set just under the potting soil surface so that a good root system develops.
In the spring of year 4, the seedlings begin to develop and form three leaflets. By this time they are large enough to be moved to quart-size pots. Then in year 5 , they should be developed well enough to be ready for planting or sale. Maybe by this time a few of the trilliums may even have blooms.
Seed growing can be a broadening facet of gardening. It is one to try boldly and you will be pleased with the results.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Sasha Meret)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1354 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL / Saab 9-5 Aero and 9-3 Viggen;
New Turbo Jets From Air Saab

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
WHEN I bought a new 900 Turbo in 1985, Saab was basking in its image as the purveyor of eccentric Swedish sport sedans for 30-somethings who couldn't afford BMW's and couldn't abide anything as sensible as a Volvo.
Economic realities have since driven Saab up the luxury scale and toward the conventional. Saab shares a lot of parts with Opel, its buttoned-down cousin in General Motors' global family. And it now costs almost as much to own a Saab as a BMW. 
 But the old fire occasionally still shows. Nowhere is it more evident than in the company's flagships, the 9-3 Viggen and the 9-5 Aero. Though very different cars, they share Saab trademarks: an off-the-beaten-path design, remarkable pep and surprising versatility. In short, both the Viggen and the Aero are niche vehicles for affluent drivers who value being different almost as much as they like performance and comfort.
Start with the Viggen, named for the delta-wing jet fighter made by the Saab aerospace company. Introduced in the United States in the 1999 model year, the Viggen can be distinguished from Saab's standard 9-3 midsize car by the front and rear spoilers. Saab says, by the way, that the bad-boy styling is more than a marketing ploy, that it reduces wind resistance by 8 percent.
Complementing the modifications are jazzy 17-inch alloy wheels that show off the disk brakes and low-profile Dunlop tires (with a Z, or high-speed, rating). And the eye-catching package is rounded out with special colors: "lightning blue," silver or black. For 2000, a Viggen sedan and convertible join the coupe.
Inside, the Viggen has terrific front bucket seats in leather with supportive side bolsters, eight-way power adjustments and optional heating elements. The rest of the interior accouterments, more or less what you'd expect on "near luxury" cars these days, are borrowed from the 9-3 SE. These include an excellent sound system, automatic climate control, automatic-dimming rear-view mirror, trip computer and antitheft system with keyless locking. OnStar, General Motors' concierge in the sky, is an $895 option.
The list of safety features common to all 2000 Saabs borders on the obsessive: antilock brakes, front air bags and belt tensioners, side air bags for the front seat, head restraints that cradle the head in a crash, side window defrosters, daytime running lights, audio controls on the steering wheel, headlamp washers and wipers. There's even a night-panel button that shuts off the instrument panel illumination to minimize glare but pops awake on a need-to-know basis -- say, when the engine is revving near the red line or the fuel is low.
Of course, the market is crowded with safe, luxurious, well-made cars, many for less than $38,000. Apart from its innate Saab-ness, the Viggen's main selling point is performance, and here the verdict is mixed.
On the bright side, there's the engine. Everyone knows that Americans like cylinders: six good, eight better. Four-cylinder powerplants seem indelibly associated with vibration, weak acceleration and save-the-planet bumper stickers.
Saab learned this the hard way in the early 1990's, when it was forced to discount deeply to move its big 9000 model, the forerunner to the 9-5. Today you can buy the 9-5 with a 200-horsepower V6. But Saab engineers' hearts are still in four-cylinder engines, and both the Viggen and the Aero get along nicely with 2.3-liter, dual-overhead-cam versions equipped with potent turbochargers that yield 230 horsepower.
Thanks to the monster turbocharger and fancy electronics, this pocket workhorse produces 258 foot-pounds of torque at a modest 2,500 engine revolutions per minute, with no discernible "turbo lag." That means the relatively light Viggen (3,100 pounds) is a rocket ship -- a jet fighter? -- when it counts: passing on a two-lane road or merging with high-speed traffic. Indeed, the turbo's kick in third gear at 60 m.p.h. provided one of the most satisfying driving experiences I can remember.
Car and Driver magazine pushed the Viggen from a stop to 60 miles an hour in 6.5 seconds. And, not that many Americans care these days, the combination of big turbocharger and little engine also produces pretty good mileage figures: 20 m.p.g. in town, 29 on the highway. I averaged 24 while pushing the car hard every chance I got.
In most circumstances, the handling is up to the standard set by the engine. The brakes feel great. And while the suspension is softer and busier than one might expect of a serious road car, it does the job.
So, why am I less than than ecstatic over the Viggen? One might quibble about the vague five-speed shifter and clutch. Or the limited visibility: The high hood and rear deck make parallel parking a challenge. Or the rear seat: Getting in the back isn't easy and the legroom is tight.
My real beef, though, is with the steering. The Viggen usually goes where it's pointed, and the power assist is nicely tempered to allow adequate road feel. But with the pedal to the metal in second or third gear, the Viggen exhibits the classic systems of "torque steer" -- the tendency of high-powered front-drive cars to veer erratically to the left or right under heavy acceleration.
The Saab people try to make a virtue of torque steer, saying that it adds to the excitement of driving the Viggen. Even so, the company has set the engine's computer to take the edge off the torque steer by limiting the power available in first and second gear.
Is the Viggen worth $38,000 and change? For about the same money you could take home the far more polished and only slightly less peppy BMW 328i. But the BMW makes your upward mobility all too obvious; a Viggen will have your friends and neighbors scratching their heads.
With the Aero, there is both less pain and less gain. The steering manners in the version I drove were impeccable, most likely because the Aero weighed 400 pounds more than the Viggen, had wider tires and came with a slightly detuned four-speed automatic transmission. The cabin is huge, with big, ergonomically correct seats up front, a back seat that is adequate for three adults and a trunk that almost looks as though it could hold an old VW Beetle.
But every Saab 9-5 is big and comfy. The real question here is what you get in the Aero for the $2,000 premium over the dressed-for-success 9-5 SE.
Well, there is the trim: The Aero has a ground-effects chin spoiler plus minor modifications to the lower body to offset the extra drag created by that spoiler.
There is also the engine: The 2.3-liter four-cylinder is a bit noisier than the 3-liter V6 in the 9-5 SE, but it manages 30 more horsepower. More important, the torque is a bit higher over a broader range of engine speeds, though the Aero's transmission limits peak torque to 243 foot-pounds.
Then there's the wheel-tire combination. The Aero comes with 17-inch alloy wheels, as opposed to the SE's 16-inchers, and the fatter, lower-profile tires are rated for higher speeds. The suspension has been tuned for surer footing on curves.
All this adds up to a noticeable improvement in an already excellent sport sedan. The low-profile tires felt surprisingly good, with none of the ride harshness usually found in rubber designed for maximum performance. And though the car dives a bit more than expected in heavy braking and leans a bit more than expected in hard turns, the handling is a pleasure.
With the 400-pound weight disadvantage, the Aero is noticeably tamer than the Viggen. But again, the turbo offers punch when you need it. And with the smooth automatic set to "sport" mode, a nudge of the throttle brings forth the turbo boost.
The Aero is too close to a normal car in looks and performance to attract the dyed-in-the-wool Saab crowd drawn to the Viggen. But at a shade above $40,000, it is arguably a better buy. Like the other 9-5's, the Aero is a practical luxury sedan with more interior room than, say, the Mercedes E-Class. But its acceleration, unlike that of the other 9-5's, can make you feel young again.
 
INSIDE TRACK: Small is beautiful, as long as it's turbocharged.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Saab's 9-5 Aero, left, is less rowdy and more polished than its 9-3 Viggen, right.

HEADLINE: COPING;
The Unequal Glow Of Liberty's Lamp

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
GLENDY SAGASTUME, who is 13, will not spend Valentine's Day dreaming of hearts and flowers or the cute boys at her school in Far Rockaway, Queens. Glendy and her mother, refugees from the long nightmare in El Salvador, will mark the day with an asylum hearing in their quest to stay together in this country after years apart.
In 1987, Glendy's mother, Maria Cristina Batres, fled Texistepeque Santa Ana, a tiny rural Salvadoran town, for San Ysidro, Calif., near San Diego and the Mexican border. By bus and by foot, in the darkness of night, she made her way to New York. She worked as a cleaning woman, usually earning less than $200 a week. But it was enough to survive and to help Glendy and her other children left behind in El Salvador. 
 That country's 12-year civil war, which had the Salvadoran military and right-wing death squads battling left-wing guerrillas and their sympathizers, left 75,000 people dead in a nation of five million. The guerrillas destroyed Ms. Batres's family home and killed the father of one of her daughters. The death squads kidnapped and tortured one of her brothers along with the father of four of her seven children. Fearing for her life, Ms. Batres fled. Her sister in El Salvador agreed to take in the children for a while.
Ms. Batres's story emerged during interviews with her and her lawyer, Anne Pilsbury, executive director of Central American Legal Assistance in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The group gives free and low-cost legal help to Central American refugees. Even as the story of the 6-year-old Cuban refugee Elian Gonzalez has dominated the news, Ms. Pilsbury has had to tell some Salvadoran parents who win residency that their children will be deported.
"We had to run," Ms. Batres said, her voice breaking. "We were very poor. We had nothing. I came with the hope of work. I didn't want my children to live in Salvador." Over the years, her other children were able to leave El Salvador. One was born in New York.
In August 1997 Ms. Batres's sister called to tell her that she had sent Glendy to the United States because she had become too ill to care for her. Glendy was arrested by immigration officials at the Mexican border. Her aunt died a month later.
Now Glendy, who has been with her mother while waiting for her case to be heard, may be separated from her again.
On Feb. 14, the Immigration and Naturalization Service will hear Ms. Batres's requests for asylum and for permanent resident status. Ms. Pilsbury said she believed that Ms. Batres had no chance of receiving asylum, which would allow Glendy to stay here, because of the government's position that Salvadorans are economic rather than political refugees. The war in El Salvador ended in 1991; past persecution does not warrant asylum. These days, Cubans are the only foreigners who can receive asylum almost automatically.
The United States, of course, armed and financed the army whose brutality sent thousands of Salvadorans into exile here. But few Salvadorans could obtain the refugee status granted to Cubans, Vietnamese, Kuwaitis and others whose governments had received American support at various times, mostly because of powerful political lobbies or American economic interests.
Maria Cristina Batres's best chance is to obtain permanent resident status through a 1997 immigration act exempting refugees from civil wars in Central America from more stringent deportation rules. Some of her other children may also qualify.
But because Glendy was arrested as an illegal immigrant, unlike her sisters and brothers, she will be forced to go back to El Salvador before she can apply to stay in the United States legally. It can take 3 to 10 years before she will be allowed to return.
Glendy's "removal hearing" is set for May 12. Ms. Pilsbury will ask that she be allowed to stay with her mother, pointing out that Glendy is a minor with no relatives in El Salvador. Yet she knows such requests are routinely denied for Salvadorans.
"I am not afraid," Glendy said last weekend. Her voice was very soft. "I will tell the judge, 'Let me stay here.' "
"I am very sad to be away from my mother," she said. "Who will I go with? Who will take me? I have many more opportunities here."
An eighth grader at Intermediate School 63 in Far Rockaway, Glendy likes baseball, basketball and the Backstreet Boys. Her friends at school do not know her story.
"These are families who got separated by the war, who faced a Hobson's choice of staying and being killed or leaving their children behind," Ms. Pilsbury said. "If people could wrap their minds around how heartbreaking this is, they'd say, 'Oh no.' "
But the climate these days seems mostly anti-immigration, with a few notable exceptions. Some political winds blow refugee children into the embrace of the United States. Other political winds blow them far, far away.

HEADLINE: SENIORITY;
The Labor Shortage: Color It Gray

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK 

 BODY:
BEVERLY GOLDBERG has a warning for corporate America: Change your attitude toward older workers or face the consequences.
Ms. Goldberg, author of "Age Works" (The Free Press, $25), notes that in 10 years vast numbers of the baby-boom generation will begin reaching the traditional retirement age of 65. But, she says, few companies have noticed that there will not be enough younger workers to replace them. By comparison, today's tight labor market could look benign. 
 Even if the economy turned sour, the labor shortage would ease only temporarily, says Ms. Goldberg, who is also a management consultant and vice president of the Century Foundation, a New York public policy research institute formerly known as the Twentieth Century Fund.
"The most problematic possibility is a continued strong economy that collides with the retirement of the baby boomers," she writes. "That scenario would mean an economic catastrophe."
As early as 2005, when some boomers begin retiring early, a sharp increase in the number of workers over 55 will be needed to maintain the percentage of the population that is employed, she says.
A lot of companies will have to scramble to retain or hire older workers or retirees, many of whom are sitting atop fat 401(k) accounts. Money alone may not lure them. An adjustment in corporate attitudes may be necessary.
That is not good news for companies that have engaged in even the most subtle age bias. It is also a problem for big corporations that -- through mergers, downsizings and restructurings -- have sowed anger, fear and disillusionment among their workers, especially their older ones.
In her book, Ms. Goldberg calls the current workplace a "world of anxiety and distrust." Despite a tight labor market, she says, demands for higher wages remain weak, because many workers fear losing their jobs.
"Whenever I talk to older workers in big corporations, the one thing I most often hear is how they just can't wait to retire," Ms. Goldberg said in an interview. "They have had it. Not that they want to quit working, but that they want to do something on their own terms, or work hours that suit them."
ONE company that is heeding such warnings is the McDonald's Corporation. Its image as an employer of teenagers is changing through its efforts to recruit more older workers.
"We're still going to see a mix of ages working in our restaurants,"' said Barry Mehrmann, director of McDonald's Human Resources Design Center in Oak Brook, Ill. "But from a strategy point of view, we are clearly looking at older workers and the things we can do to attract them."
McDonald's is looking specifically to increase the share of older workers in its company-owned restaurants. Right now, about 7 percent, or three workers per restaurant, are 60 or older. The company attracts older workers by offering flexible schedules and, for those on Social Security, help in tracking earnings to avoid losing benefits. It also offers management opportunities.
Older workers are often good role models, Mr. Mehrmann said. "Their retention rate is very high," he explained. "They go through our training program just as fast and just as well as younger workers. They are great employees that stay with us and add stability."
MS. GOLDBERG said more companies needed to follow the McDonald's example.
"Many companies fail to train older workers, because they think they're going to leave," she said. "They really don't consider them a part of the team or essential to the work that's being done. They see them as sort of hanging around, which is a big mistake. It's discouraging to the workers and doesn't get the best out of them."
Just wait a few years, when these companies try to retain or rehire older workers, she added: "These workers are going to say, 'never mind.' They're going to go off and do something else in retirement -- start their own businesses, pursue hobbies or go back to school and get a degree. And that's going to be a disaster for these companies when workers are ever harder to find."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1216 words

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD;
BackHome, Tough Path For an Entrepreneur

BYLINE: By DAVID HECHT 

DATELINE: DAKAR, Senegal

 BODY:
MASSATA THIOUNE left Senegal for New York in 1986 with just $250 in his pocket. He had no Western education and spoke no English. But he knew how to sew clothes; he had been apprenticed to his father, a tailor, from the age of 6. He was also imbued with the credo of the Sufi Islamic brotherhood to which his family belongs: "Pray as if you will die tomorrow, and work as if you will live forever."
By 1988, Mr. Thioune (pronounced choon) had a factory on Seventh Avenue, making office attire with a West African style and sensibility. Two years later, Massata Fashions was taking orders from national retail chains like T. J. Maxx and Marshall's and directly from consumers through a mail order catalog. The company was soon averaging $2 million a year in sales. 
 Then, in 1996, Mr. Thioune took a fateful step: he moved his factory home to Senegal.
"Coming here seemed like such a good idea at the time," said Mr. Thioune, 40, in his Dakar factory, amid dozens of sewing machines that are now idle. Senior Senegalese government officials had approached him with offers of tax breaks and easy financing to buy the building he would need. And he knew that the country, a former French colony where fashion consciousness runs high, had plenty of skilled tailors who would not demand American wages. "I figured, why pay U.S. workers $250 a week, when you can pay Senegalese workers $150 a month for better work?"
But problems appeared quickly. The first was getting timely deliveries from local textile companies. "There was always an excuse," Mr. Thioune said. "One day a machine was broken, and the only person who knew how to fix it had not come in. The next day it was someone's birthday, and nobody had come to work."
Once he had the fabric he needed, his own plant's output was hampered by frequent blackouts, which not only cost him work time but also damaged his sewing machines when the power came and went without warning. By the time spare parts could be obtained, he said, he had missed the deadline for a recurring $260,000 order, a huge chunk of his annual sales. Similar problems over the next two years cut his revenue by more than half and left him with $2.5 million of canceled goods.
"I had to stop taking orders," he said. "For now, I'm just trying to sell off what I've got."
Since President Clinton visited the continent in 1998, administration officials have been describing sub-Saharan Africa as one of the world's big untapped business opportunities. But the region produces few internationally competitive goods other than raw materials, and its share of world trade is tiny and falling.
Several American initiatives are meant to help entrepreneurs like Mr. Thioune get started in the region. The Overseas Private Investment Cooperation, a government-sponsored agency, has set up new loan funds for Africa, including $350 million to improve infrastructure. A bill before Congress would relax quotas and tariffs on clothing made in Africa; different versions were passed by the House and Senate last year and have yet to be reconciled.
Businesses face many obstacles in Africa, from corruption to inflation to poor infrastructure, but there is little agreement about how difficult they are to overcome or which is the most harmful. To Mr. Thioune, the local mind-set is the biggest problem. "Even I forgot how things worked here," he said. "There is still a slave-and-master attitude here that undermines efforts to work together."
 MOST African economies have two aspects: a moribund official one and a more energetic informal one, full of unregistered businesses and ad hoc markets. Informal economic activity tends to organize around ethnic or cultural affiliations rather than corporate entities.
In Senegal, less than 30 percent of the urban population is formally employed, but what is called the "real economy" provides livelihoods for the rest. It operates mainly through the country's networks of Sufi Islamic brotherhoods, to which nearly all Senegalese belong.
Under French rule, the Sufi brotherhoods formed the basis for fishing and agricultural collectives; when drought in the 1970's accelerated migration to the cities, the brotherhoods diversified into cottage industries and trade. Through daras, or prayer groups, brotherhood members pool resources and gain access to small-scale credit. Thousands of members of the most visible brotherhood, the Moruide, sell watches and sunglasses on the streets of New York and other major cities.
Some of the brotherhoods have formalized their business activities, according to Allione Ndoe, a Senegalese business consultant. But he said the enterprises tend to be "hierarchical and labor intensive, which is only good for certain kinds of activities, like farming and petty trade."
"Creating industry requires strategic planning," he said, "and at this stage they're mostly just concerned with the short term."
Mr. Thioune belongs to the Mouride brotherhood, but he said he runs Massata Fashions on American lines. "Many of my workers are from other brotherhoods," he said. "All I care about is that they're honest and hard working."
Some Mourides are critical of Mr. Thioune and his approach. "If a Mouride has difficulties," one leader of the brotherhood said, "he should meet with other Mourides to discuss the problems and they will then help."
But Mr. Thioune sees the brotherhood's role differently. "Mouridism provides the motivation and discipline for prayer and work," he said. "That's it." He said some "opportunistic" members try to get money from him by claiming to be marabouts, or spiritual guides. "They're not real marabouts," he said, "and I never give them anything."
Unlike Mr. Thioune, many West African businesspeople intertwine the spiritual and the secular. Supernatural powers have been attributed to some of the most powerful, like Babani Sissoko, a Malian who built a billion-dollar empire of international hotels, diamond mines and a regional airline, only to see it collapse under heavy debts after he ran into legal trouble in the United States.
The businesses of most of Africa's informal entrepreneurs are more stable than Mr. Sissoko's, but Western investors know little about working with them. And critics of the recent United States initiatives for Africa say that even American-style entrepreneurs like Mr. Thioune are being left out.
The investment agency recently set up a $105 million direct equity fund to invest in African private enterprises in amounts of $4.5 million to $7.5 million, according to Mr. Ndoe, who advises the fund. "But it is projecting American scale on Africa," he said. Except in South Africa, where the fund does not invest, "few African companies are big enough to qualify."
Mr. Thioune says financing is not his problem. "I know plenty of ways to generate capital here," he said. And he has looked far afield for opportunities; lately he has begun importing New York-style pickles, cranberry juice and other American foods for sale to expatriates and Senegal's small middle class, which considers the goods exotic.
"It's a stopgap measure until Massata Fashions gets going again," he said. "I know I can mass-produce clothing here cheaper and better than anywhere in the world. I just have to figure out how."

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Advice and Dissent

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
The chief economic adviser of one candidate is the co-author of an exuberant book claiming that investors ain't seen nothing yet; unfortunately, the exuberance is a bit, well, irrational. The chief adviser of the other is a pessimist, deeply skeptical about the durability of our current prosperity. One candidate proposes huge tax cuts that will break the budget unless the long boom not only continues but accelerates. The other prefers not to count his fiscal chickens before they hatch. Which is which?
George W. Bush, of course, is the tax-slasher. John McCain is his cautious rival. Kevin Hassett is the raging bull. Lawrence Lindsey is the dour bear. Now for the punch line: Mr. Lindsey is advising Mr. Bush; Mr. Hassett is advising Mr. McCain. 
 The story of the Bush economic program is deja vu all over again. Just like Bob Dole's advisers in 1996 (who by and large were the same people), Mr. Bush's economists have allowed the presumed political appeal of tax cuts to override their professional scruples. The other story is less well known. Indeed, like most other people, I have only started paying serious attention to the McCain campaign in the last few days, and I have to admit that discovering that Mr. Hassett, of all people, is his chief economic adviser was a shock.
Who is Kevin Hassett? Until quite recently he had a solid, not at all flashy reputation in fiscal economics, with a career that moved from Columbia University to the Federal Reserve and then to the American Enterprise Institute, an establishment-conservative think tank. There he teamed up with the investment writer James K. Glassman to write a couple of articles in The Wall Street Journal, followed up by a book expanding on those articles entitled "Dow 36,000" -- a catchy title backed up by a thesis that was ingenious, exciting and unfortunately quite silly.
I don't mean that their forecast was wrong. For all I or anyone else knows, the Dow may indeed go to 36,000. But the way the book justifies that forecast involves a series of conceptual confusions about such things as the sources of risk and the difference between dividends and earnings. (To be fair, when I talked to Mr. Hassett, he offered a plausible explanation -- much better than Mr. Glassman's indignant denials that he said what he actually said -- of why the most glaring apparent error in the book might not be too bad an approximation, but the other objections remain.)
How did someone like Mr. Hassett end up writing that kind of book? As I understand it, a casual, back-of-the-envelope calculation led to a huge publisher's advance so quickly that the authors never had a chance to have second thoughts. Yes, Virginia, that is the way the world works.
The more interesting question is, How did Mr. McCain end up designating Mr. Hassett, hardly a household name until that book, as his chief economic adviser? The answer, which comes as something of a relief, is that it apparently had nothing to do with "Dow 36,000." Instead, it was that inevitability thing: all the usual Republican policy suspects believed that if you worked against Mr. Bush, you would never eat a free lunch in Washington again. (And you might find a horse's head in your bed.) So Mr. McCain had to take what he could get. Mr. Hassett was one of the few identifiably Republican fiscal experts who wasn't intimidated. And if we ignore the brief foray into stock-market hype, the senator could have done worse: before Mr. Hassett succumbed to the imperatives of the book trade he was regarded as quietly sensible, and freed from those imperatives he seems likely to revert to type.
But you have to admit that it's a depressing spectacle. The Republican tent is a big one, which probably contains at least as many first-rate economists as its rival. Yet that huge pool of talent has not only been locked up by the Anointed One; it has been forced to genuflect to the legacy of a crank doctrine -- supply-side economics -- that even party loyalists don't believe in. Meanwhile, Mr. Bush's main rival has been forced to assemble a scratch team from the handful of Republican economists who know something about policy yet are sufficiently remote from the corridors of power to be immune to pressure.
Is this any way to run a Grand Old Party?

HEADLINE: Fed's Faulty Logic

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I find it somewhat hypocritical of Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve to use the threat of inflation to justify rate increases when the effect of higher interest rates is itself inflationary ("Federal Reserve Gives a Nudge to 2 Key Rates," front page, Feb. 3). 
 If inflation is defined as higher costs and prices, interest rate increases drive producers' costs higher because most corporations find that interest is their third-largest cost, after the cost of labor and material. For consumers, higher interest rates drive up prices on virtually everything they buy or consume. If that is not inflation, what is?
 
L.R. JEFFREY
Far Hills, N.J., Feb. 3, 2000

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
A View That Needs No Windows

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
LIKE Bill Gates and Michael Dell, Larry Augustin spent his spare time in college toying with computers and wound up starting a company that made him a zillionaire. But unlike them, Mr. Augustin earned a college degree, at Notre Dame, and later a doctorate, at Stanford.
And so he comes across as less the entrepreneur from birth than the nerd's nerd, never happier than when up to his eyes in bits and bytes and the esoterica of hardware and software. He proudly asserts that he was a charter subscriber to Sys Admin, a trade magazine devoted to systems administrators, the unsung heroes who keep computer systems running. "I've been a systems administrator for every operating system created in the last 20 years," he said. 
 Mr. Augustin's company, VA Linux Systems, a maker of computer systems in Sunnyvale, Calif., does not yet have billions of dollars in revenue. But it does have a multibillion-dollar market capitalization, thanks to an initial public offering in December that set records for first-day gains. And the stock provided most of the $1 billion that VA Linux agreed to pay last week for Andover.Net, an owner of Web sites offering technology news.
From a high of $320, VA Linux shares have dropped, closing at $125 on Friday. But at age 37, Mr. Augustin still has a net worth of about $825 million.
VA Linux is a standard-bearer for the Linux operating system and the Open Source movement. Mr. Augustin and other founders of the company, and the movement, contend that by making computer code underlying a program freely available, and readily modified by anyone, a stronger system with fewer crashes results, ending the domination of operating systems owned by one company, especially Microsoft Windows.
Linux is named for Linus Torvalds, a Finnish programmer who wrote a key component, though he has no connection with the company beyond his friendship with Mr. Augustin. In the hands of Mr. Torvalds and Mr. Augustin, Linux has practically become a cult, although one with a sense of humor. Mr. Augustin breaks out in high-pitched bursts of laughter as he describes an esoteric online parody of slashdot.com, a Linux news site ("News for nerds. Stuff that matters.") owned by Andover.Net that doesn't take itself too seriously to begin with.
But go back to the late 80's and early 90's. Mr. Augustin had gone to Stanford after three years at AT&T Bell Laboratories, where he worked on high-speed digital switching. He ultimately wrote his Ph.D. thesis on electronic automated design tools, the software used to create new chips.
He also played scavenger -- collecting, among other things, cast-off disk drives, in the days when 30 megabytes filled a refrigerator-sized box. He used these castoffs to create a giant site, in a Stanford basement, that allowed the rapid exchange of information over the Internet before the days of the World Wide Web.
He also collected early workstations made by Sun Microsystems. His goal was to build a machine at his home that could use Unix, a sophisticated operating system widely found in academia and industry.
In 1993, Mr. Torvald released Linux on the Internet. Using this software, Mr. Augustin said, "I was able to put together my own computer for $2,000, and it was one and a half to two times faster than these old Suns, which cost about $7,000. Other people saw what I had and wanted one, so in November '93, I put up a Web page and said, 'I will sell people these systems.' I got my first check at the end of the month from someone I didn't know. I consider that the start of the business."
A couple of dozen companies have joined the Linux cause, on the premise that there is money to be made selling an operating system anyone can obtain for free. VA Linux is unusual in that it sells complete computer systems that come loaded with Linux (but not Windows).
"We're designing from the ground up for Linux," he declared. "And what we offer to our customers is not just a system. It's full service, a single point of contact, service and support for building their entire infrastructure."
SO far, VA Linux's major customers are all Web start-ups themselves, companies like Akamai Technologies and eToys, and most are less than two years old. But Mr. Augustin, whose buttoned-down shirts, neatly creased khakis and well-trimmed hair may qualify as the height of formality among Linux users, has positioned himself as the person to take the Linux message to corporate America.
"I make the argument that the current model of software development is just economically inefficient," he said. "I think this is the next big revolution in the software industry."
Stoking the revolution means long hours. He described his previous day, which began in New York and ended in Silicon Valley. "Yesterday I got up at 3 a.m. California time, went into a set of meetings, got on an airplane, got back here at 3 in the afternoon and worked in the office until 7 p.m. when my wife started calling."
Balancing work and family can mean taking his wife, Alice Kitsuta Augustin, and daughter, Andrea, to industry gatherings like last week's Linux World in New York. "That's fine because we get together with Linus and the kids can play," he said, alluding to the fact that both men have 3-year-old daughters.
Mr. Augustin tells employees not to think about VA Linux's share price, and he tries to take his own advice. "I didn't start this thing to cash in and get out," he said. "I started this to build a real company."

HEADLINE: Loss of a Landmark

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Sadly, appeals to halt the demolition of the historic Mapes Hotel in Reno, Nev., fell on deaf ears. The famed Art Deco high-rise was dynamited on Jan. 30 (news item, Jan. 31). The Mapes was a uniquely American landmark. Its groundbreaking design became the blueprint for the hundreds of casinos now scattered across the United States. 
 As legalized gambling became more prevalent around the country, Reno hit upon hard times. Instead of resorting to demolition as a quick-fix effort to repackage a struggling gambling town, the city should have developed a plan to adapt the Mapes to address the city's longer-term needs. The reuse of older buildings can help jump-start a town's economic engine. In a city that relies heavily on tourist dollars, a renovated Mapes Hotel would have been a valuable asset.
 
JOHN D. SABINI
New York, Feb. 1, 2000
 
The writer is chairman of the New York City Council subcommittee on landmarks.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Reading the Signals Of a Baffled Bond Market

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
THE Treasury bond market went haywire last week. What exactly does the chaos in this huge and hugely significant market mean to investors?
The turmoil hit traders hardest at the nation's banks, brokerage firms and hedge funds. Many of these players had bet -- accurately -- that the Federal Reserve Board would raise interest rates. Normally, such a move would push up yields on both short-term and long-term securities. 
 Not this time. Even as the Fed voted to raise short-term rates by one-quarter point, yields on long-term Treasuries declined, from 6.48 percent on Monday to 6.26 percent on Friday. Two-year Treasury notes ended the week at 6.61 percent.
It isn't often that short-term rates are a good deal higher than longer-term rates. And when it happens, it traditionally portends an economic slowdown. That is in large part because financial institutions -- which borrow at short-term rates and lend long -- have no incentive to make loans in such an environment. If credit is tight, companies cannot finance their growth and economic output declines.
Almost nobody thinks that last week's bond market action is pointing to a slowdown. Indeed, all the data point to a blazing economy, which is why the Fed feels compelled to raise rates.
Rather, traders say, the bond market is embroiled in a technical move unrelated to economic fundamentals. Lower yields on long-term bonds are a direct result, they say, of the Treasury's plan to both reduce the amount of debt it will issue and to buy back many existing bonds. With the Treasury focusing its aim on securities with 10- to 30-year durations, investors made a mad scramble to buy long-term bonds ahead of a shortage.
This widely held view worries Andrew S. Teufel, research director at Fisher Investments Inc. in Woodside, Calif. While he agrees that the Treasury refinancing plan is having a huge impact on the bond market, he is troubled by the idea that everyone is writing off the interest rate inversion as merely technical. He wonders if the market is indeed trying to send investors a warning -- one that is being ignored.
"It's a sentiment gauge, and our early sense of it is that people are dismissing it," he said. "If everyone is paying attention, it's innocuous. If no one is paying attention to it, it's dangerous. If people are paying attention to it but writing it off as not dangerous, then there is some danger, too."
It is too soon to tell whether the bond market is signaling a slowdown. But the rise in short-term rates is hurting shares in financial institutions, whose borrowing costs are increasing.
Investors don't have to own bank stocks to feel their pain. Shares of financial companies make up 13 percent of the value of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
Even if the rally in long bonds winds up being solely related to the reduced supply of Treasuries, investors should not expect things to go back to normal anytime soon. Interest rate strategists say that when the bond market undergoes a structural change, as it is now, it takes months for investors to adjust fully to the change. The adjustment may not be pretty.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Globalization: If You Can't Beat It, Reshape It

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
WITH security agents toting submachine guns, army helicopters buzzing overhead and protesters breaking windows in yet another McDonald's, Davos man, the elite agent of global capitalism, is under siege.
It's not hard to reach that conclusion after attending this year's session of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where government officials, chief executives and leading economists gathered to schmooze and ponder globalization under heavy guard. The road to the Alpine resort was icy, and the confidence of the power brokers there seemed to be slipping. Since the disastrous global trade talks in Seattle not long ago, many of those who have long favored closer integration between nations are on the defensive. 
 But it's probably a mistake to think that globalization itself is threatened. On the contrary, the unions and environmental groups that assail the World Trade Organization seem on the whole to prefer that nations become more like one another faster -- and in a greater variety of ways. They are not so much trying to block globalization as to hitch a ride.
Thousands of groups are seeking to influence the Davos crowd in the service of causes from protection of sea turtles to elimination of child labor. They do not speak with a single voice. But their pleas no longer fall on deaf ears.
The human rights group Amnesty International, the environmental action organization Greenpeace and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. were all invited to Davos this year, and they pushed similar agendas. Globalization cannot really be resisted, they said, but neither should it be limited to commerce.
"Globalization is happening one way or another and it can't be stopped," said John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., "but it must be made to work for workers." Beyond going slow with new trade agreements to protect union jobs in the developed world, that means compelling poor countries to rewrite their labor laws to conform more closely with those of rich countries -- in effect, globalizing labor standards.
Groups like Greenpeace and the World Wildlife Fund are taking a similar tack. They want the W.T.O. to inject some environmental horse-trading into trade talks -- say, freer imports of third-world textiles in exchange for stricter limits on logging in rain forests.
That some protest groups accept globalization -- albeit on their own terms -- helps explain why President Clinton, whose free-trade credentials are well established, extended an olive branch to those who led the Seattle demonstrations. In Davos, Mr. Clinton embraced the "new forces" that demand a say in how nations relate to one another, effectively offering them a seat at the negotiating table. And he agreed with them that defining globalization merely in trade terms is no longer enough; instead, the world should start talking about the globalization of society.
"We cannot isolate economics as distinct from the environment and labor," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative. "That's a distinction that's artificial."
The idea struck a responsive chord with the executives at Davos. In fact, this year's conference may be remembered as the time businesses and advocacy groups stopped fighting each other and started talking.
Business leaders proposed a flurry of ways they could become more socially conscious. Louis Schweitzer of Renault, for example, suggested restricting political contributions by multinationals, to restore faith that public policy is not beholden to corporate interests.
Monsanto was another company welcoming a "new dialogue" with its adversaries. "Companies need to understand what society's expectations are and be ready to change a strategy if it does not meet this test," said Nick E. Rosa, senior vice president. The company has overhauled the way it uses genetics to modify crops, largely in response to pressure from Greenpeace and other environmental groups, Mr. Rosa said.
The big problem with all this coziness is that poorer countries like Mexico, South Africa, India and China -- the ones that would have to do all the changing and harmonizing to suit rich-country standards -- are balking at this expanded view of globalization.
"Most developing countries have a knee-jerk reaction to this -- they are not ready to discuss it," said Supachai Panitchpakdi, a deputy premier of Thailand, who is due to take over the leadership of the World Trade Organization in 2002. "I'm afraid we won't see much progress on trade right away."
That prediction remains to be tested. The Clinton administration is still hoping to kick-start a new round of global trade talks before its term expires. And if Davos was any indication, globalization in the broadest sense is just getting started.
