SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1721 words

HEADLINE: Gold Rush In Silicon Alley;
Venture Capital Moves East

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
It was the sort of "elevator pitch" that Timothy C. Draper listens to impatiently every day -- a business plan breathlessly delivered.
Four entrepreneurs -- three in their 30's and the obligatory gray-haired chief financial officer -- were rushing last Tuesday to describe a business they hoped would be the next big thing on the Internet. In this case, it was a service called Sticky Networks, which hopes to let people search the Web using pictures rather than words. 
 They knew that Mr. Draper's venture capital firm, Draper Fisher Jurvetson, based in Redwood City, Calif., could help finance their business and, more important, open doors with its prestige.
Mr. Draper peppered them with his usual questions: Where did you go to school? What have you done before? What is the business model? What's to stop anyone else from doing the same thing?
But there was one thing that was quite different from Mr. Draper's routine. This pitch was not in the conference room of his office in Silicon Valley, but in a 39th-floor suite of the New York Palace Hotel, overlooking Rockefeller Center and the heart of New York's corporate life.
Attention New York entrepreneurs: the checkbooks have landed.
When the first people tried to start Internet companies here in the mid-90's, they had to scrounge to raise money. To their chagrin, the big Silicon Valley venture capital firms like Draper largely shunned New York as a backwater with no history of entrepreneurship or technological innovation.
But now with the success of a wide range of Internet and new-media companies in and around New York City, including the stock market darlings DoubleClick and StarMedia Network, there are an abundance of new and newly expanded venture capital funds in New York, with many hundreds of millions of fresh dollars looking for young Internet businesses to invest in -- in hopes of a big payoff when the company eventually goes public or gets acquired.
"The vacuum of venture capital on the East Coast has been filled," said Alexander D. Lynch, a partner at Brobeck Phleger & Harrison, a law firm that represents a number of Internet start-ups. "There is so much money chasing deals from the existing funds and the new funds. This is now a very good market to raise money if you are an entrepreneur."
Of course, some investors have begun to wonder whether there may soon be too much money chasing too few marketable business plans in Silicon Alley -- a label that once denoted the new-media scene in downtown Manhattan but now refers loosely to Internet-related activities throughout the metropolitan area.
What is clear is that some Wall Street powerhouses that used to ignore deals that could not be measured in the billions -- including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the leveraged buyout tycoons -- now deign to put mere millions into digital start-ups. Established New York venture capital firms -- like Venrock Associates, the Rockefeller family's venture investing arm -- are embracing the sort of Internet deals they would have snubbed even a year ago. And the few firms that did invest early in Silicon Alley are growing much larger.
Bear Stearns's Constellation Ventures and Wit Capital's Dawntreader fund, for example, are both said to be in the process of raising new funds of more than $200 million each. And Flatiron Partners, perhaps the most prominent New York Internet fund, is investing money on behalf of Chase Manhattan at an accelerating pace.
Many more people with money and rich friends are for the first time putting together funds to seek their fortunes as venture capitalists. One of these is I-Hatch Ventures, a new fund started by Chip Austin, former head of Bertelsmann's online bookstore; Derek Reisfield, who once ran CBS's Internet unit; and Brad Farkas, a former venture capitalist at Lazard Freres. I-Hatch expects to raise $150 million, an unusually large amount for a first-time fund.
Perhaps most significant, a number of Silicon Valley venture capitalists are expanding into New York. Draper, for example, hired two former Wall Street executives who had been trying to start their own fund -- Dan Schultz and Ross Goldstein -- to open a New York affiliate, Draper Fisher Gotham, which had an elaborate debut party last Wednesday at which Mr. Draper appeared in a Batman costume. It also made its first investment last week: Mimeo.com, a sort of Internet Kinko's that plans to offer express shipment of copied documents; Draper has not yet decided whether to invest in Sticky Networks.
And Adam Dell, who late last year left Crosspoint Venture Partners, a Silicon Valley firm where he was a partner, has started Impact Venture Partners, a $100 million fund in New York devoted to business-to-business Internet investments.
"There is a great opportunity here because there are so many old-line companies that will be reinvented on the Internet and so many great operations people," said Mr. Dell, who is the younger brother of the computer mogul Michael S. Dell. "And on the East Coast there just aren't the sheer number of investment firms that exist on the West Coast."
To be sure, the $760 million in venture capital investments in New York during the first nine months of 1999 was dwarfed by the $8.1 billion invested in Bay Area start-ups during the same period, according to Venture One, a San Francisco market research firm. But New York venture investments were increasing at an annual rate of 205 percent from a year earlier, compared with a 145 percent increase in Silicon Valley.
New York is growing as an Internet center because most of its traditional industries -- finance, retailing, broadcasting, publishing, advertising and the rest -- are becoming more involved than ever in the Internet and the Web.
"The West Coast creates technology and the East Coast creates brands," said Robert H. Lessin, chairman of Wit Capital. "Now that technology is becoming off-the-shelf, companies need media companies as partners to build their brands. And every media company other than Disney is here."
In addition to investing in Internet start-ups, Wit has helped companies trade equity for promotion. Wit, for example, last year helped Iwon.com, a Web site that offers its users chances to win cash prizes, obtain broadcast advertising time on CBS in exchange for CBS's acquiring a stake in the company.
As elsewhere, venture capitalists in New York are now looking to invest much earlier in a company's life cycle than venture investors did in the past. That is because the stock market nowadays is willing to embrace initial public offerings from companies so young they have barely any revenue -- let alone profits. So companies do not need to go back and raise the traditional second or third rounds of financing that venture capitalists previously specialized in.
Few venture funds want to wait that long, given the buoyant market for the stocks of Internet companies, which have made astounding profits for the earliest investors in such companies.
"We have seen fewer opportunities to invest at later stages, so we have refocused our energy on earlier-stage investments," said William E. Ford, a managing partner with General Atlantic Partners, a $2 billion, 20-year-old venture fund in Greenwich, Conn. General Atlantic, for example, invested in Priceline.com before it even opened for business -- something Mr. Ford's firm would never have considered in the pre-Web days.
Meanwhile, the smaller funds are moving to compete with the so-called angel investors -- wealthy individuals who traditionally provided initial grubstakes to companies too young to seek financing from the venture funds, which are run by professional money managers and which pool the resources of many investors.
New venture funds, like I-Hatch, now play the role of an angel investor. "We want to find the guy as he is just looking for the cocktail napkin to write his idea on," Mr. Austin of I-Hatch said.
Like all venture capital firms, I-Hatch hopes to attract companies with its advice and contacts as well as its cash. I-Hatch, in other words, helps do much of the work that the entrepreneurs themselves formerly had to do before daring to ask anyone for money. "We help people refine their fuzzy ideas and get to the next level," Mr. Austin said.
In addition to advice, investors like I-Hatch and Rare Medium -- a Web development firm with a venture capital arm -- are setting up "incubators" where very young companies can receive office space and technical services in return for equity stakes.
Draper's new New York affiliate will not go as far as providing office space, but Mr. Draper says the companies it backs get something even more useful: invitations to the firm's frequent cocktail receptions, where the 200 other companies backed by Draper affiliates in Silicon Valley, Los Angeles and Virginia can flirt with one another and form alliances.
"An Internet company is only as valuable as the deals it has made," Mr. Draper said.
Of course, determining the value of an Internet company can be a puzzle for venture capitalists these days, especially when the company is at the prerevenue or even pre-cocktail-napkin stage. The frenzied competition among venture firms and among the firms and angel investors, is causing some qualms in the investment community.
"We'll see a company with great prospects, but it is overpriced," said Clifford H. Friedman, managing partner of Constellation Ventures. "The angels invested at a $25 million valuation, and we think it's worth only $15 million or $20 million. That's not a comfortable situation and we've lost some deals because of it."
To Fred Wilson of Flatiron Partners -- which was an early player in Silicon Alley, having been formed way back in 1996 -- this surge in investment at ever higher values is a sign that there is in fact too much venture capital in New York.
"The rate of company creation going on is unsustainable," Mr. Wilson said. "I would not be surprised if there were 20 or 30 new Internet companies a day being formed in New York. That's scary.
"People are forming companies for the wrong reasons," he added. "They aren't passionate about their ideas. They just want to be millionaires like all their friends, and there is so much capital in New York that anybody can start a company today."

SECTION: Section C; Page 12; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 826 words

HEADLINE: After Turbulent Week, Treasury Says Bond Market Will Be Orderly With Less Supply

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

DATELINE: RIO GRANDE, P.R., Feb. 6

 BODY:
A top Treasury Department official sought to assure bond investors on Saturday that they will be able to adjust to the government's new policy of reducing the supply of Treasury bonds.
The official, Lewis A. Sachs, assistant secretary of the Treasury for financial markets, also said that Federal Reserve officials "are confident they will be able to conduct monetary policy," as well, in the new environment as in the old. 
 The comments, made at the annual meeting of the Bond Market Association here, came after a week in which the bond market was roiled by news of a sharp decline in the issuance of 30-year Treasury bonds and by the rising prices and plunging long-term yields that resulted.
Many investors, including big Wall Street firms, had been betting that long-term interest rates would rise after the Federal Reserve raised its short-term interest-rate target in an effort to slow economic growth and forestall inflation.
But on Wednesday, the Treasury Department surprised investors with an announcement that the sale of 30-year bonds in May would be "significantly smaller" than current sales. Analysts estimated May sales around $5 billion, about half of what had been expected.
Long-term prices soared and yields, which move in the opposite direction, plummeted as investors, learning of the planned reduction in the quantity of bonds to be issued, scrambled to buy. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.28 percent on Wednesday from 6.42 percent on Tuesday, and Thursday, the rush to buy continued. The price of the 30-year bond jumped almost two full points and the yield fell to 6.13 percent. But on Friday, investors seemed to change sentiment, and as bonds were sold, the yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.23 percent as selling predominated.
A strong January employment report, with nonfarm jobs rising by almost 400,000, contributed to the selloff. But some bond traders here said that the market just had gone too far in one direction. Still, there is talk of big losses among major bond dealers. And the Federal Reserve Bank of New York on Wednesday denied a rumor that it was holding an emergency meeting to deal with financially troubled firms.
Mr. Sachs maintained that bond investors had been given plenty of notice about the Treasury's intention to reduce the issuance of notes and bonds as growing federal budget surpluses allowed the paying off of publicly held government debt, which totaled $2.8 trillion at the end of last year. He said the Treasury expects to pay off $300 billion of the debt in the current fiscal year.
Mr. Sachs, who spoke at a panel here, was asked if the Treasury was committed to issuing long-term bonds, even as the need to borrow dwindled.
"I can't say what we will be doing years from now," he replied. "We don't have plans beyond that at this point." But he said the Treasury would "maintain liquidity in our benchmark issues as long as we can." Maintaining liquidity means ensuring that each new issue of bonds is large enough so that trades of large size will not distort prices.
The Treasury currently plans to have just one auction of new 30-year bonds a year, in February, followed by a smaller sale of the same bond in May to add to its liquidity. Based on current estimates, the Treasury is expected in this fiscal year to issue less than half the $45 billion in 30-year bonds sold last fiscal year, which ended on Sept. 30.
The other matter on the minds of the traders and executives involved in the corporate, municipal, mortgage and government bond markets was what would replace prices and yields in the long-term Treasury market as the benchmark for the other fixed-income markets. It was clear there is a debate over what alternatives might work.
"At some point," Mr. Sachs said, "the debt of other issuers will become larger than ours, but that will not happen overnight." And he added, "While there will be a period of adjustment, we have every confidence the market will adjust and other instruments will replace the role the Treasury plays."
For example, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two agencies that raise money to underwrite home mortgages, are trying to establish their bonds as a benchmark for the rest of the fixed-income market. Linda K. Knight, Fannie Mae's treasurer, said the agency is working to have a range of fixed-income securities from 3-month bills to 30-year bonds that will have the liquidity needed to serve as a benchmark. In fact, many of Fannie Mae's issues are already being used as a base to price corporate issues and also for hedging.
But Gumersindo Oliveros, the director of the treasury finance department at the World Bank, a major issuer of bonds, said, "It's a tall order for agency bonds to become a government surrogate."
He pointed to the interest-rate swaps market, where investors exchange fixed-rate debt for variable-rate debt, as a possible benchmark for the rest of the fixed-income market.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Out of Africa, but Not Out of Character

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe

 BODY:
AUnited States Embassy employee held up a sign during the Davis Cup doubles match here Saturday. It said: "Hi Mom. Send Diesel."
The President's wife, Grace Mugabe, was said to be furious over this highly public and televised reference to the fuel shortage that has rocked Zimbabwe. She proceeded to snub the United States Tennis Association president, Judy Levering, and didn't return for the third and last day. 
 These things happen when countries mix and when crowds come out. It also puts the presence of John McEnroe into a necessary broader perspective. He apparently wasn't the only source of binational irritation here this weekend.
It only seemed that way, every time a call went against the United States and McEnroe rose from his captain's chair.
"Disgraceful," Wayne Black said yesterday after McEnroe's United States team had claimed the first-round competition, defeating Zimbabwe by 3-2 after winning both reverse singles matches. "They've got a great team full of great guys. I think if they don't win the cup, it will be largely due to McEnroe."
It was pointed out to Black that the American players had all marched into the interview room at the Harare Sports Center to proclaim their devotion to the man they had asked the U.S.T.A. to give them. Alex O'Brien called McEnroe "the best coach in the world." Chris Woodruff credited McEnroe for teaching what it takes to compete under rabid road conditions. Andre Agassi reiterated that he had grown tired of the milquetoast mind-set, and that McEnroe, more than anyone, had the passion to galvanize more interest in the States.
"If you lose the feeling, you're just asking for another week on the road in brutal conditions," Agassi said. "I don't need that anymore."
Black conceded that he only had the outsider's view of McEnroe, and there likely was more to the situation than meets the ear.
There always has been. As a young player, McEnroe tormented officials and opponents, but when other players jumped at the opportunity to earn big bucks in South Africa during the apartheid era, he simply said no.
Upon arrival in Harare, he was charming dinner guests and promising sneakers for the barefoot children with whom he had hit tennis balls on hardcourts in the economically ravaged township of Chitungwiza. Then he was infuriating the host Zimbabwe team and sprinkling his news conferences with his special brand of colorful rebuttals.
"Those guys were giving us a hard time and then pretending like I'm being difficult," he said, in summary. "As difficult as I supposedly was, I guarantee that those guys were giving my teammates a tougher time."
When they announced McEnroe as Davis Cup captain, people should have known they weren't getting a public-relations executive. He could feel persecuted in a soup kitchen, and is about as subtle as an Agassi forehand. "Big deal," was his ambassadorial commentary on the fact that the United States government had built one of the four hardcourts in Chitungwiza.
McEnroe has crossed the line of reasonable comportment enough times but on my personal Mac-o-meter, his performance here was barely enough to make people wince, the equivalent of a sign that said: "Send diesel." He argued calls, which in his mind comes with the territory. When Black revealed what had set him off against McEnroe during the doubles, veteran Mac attack chroniclers looked around and said, "That's it?"
"I'm serving 5-6, and there was a shuffling with the balls," Black said. "I thought it was a new ball. So I said, 'Are these new?' He said, 'You should be so lucky.' "
Black said he couldn't believe his eyes during the fourth game of his match with Woodruff yesterday, when McEnroe stood up and yelled just as Woodruff was about to hammer a forehand winner. They played a let. "I would go crazy if my captain did something like that," said Black, missing the point.
McEnroe, who sheepishly apologized, was so excited he couldn't contain himself. "I was jumping out of my pants," he said.
The hypocrites who wait for McEnroe to so much as sneeze to call him a brat usually go skipping off to watch managers kick dirt on umpires or hockey players slap each other around with sticks. More than anything, McEnroe has always seemed like an athlete who got lost as a youngster and wandered into a country club. For 20 years, he has extolled the virtues of the Davis Cup. This being my first competition in another country, I can better understand him. Those of us who came to Harare, the players included, didn't sit in gas lines, or worry about dinner. But this was a refreshing change from the sterility of tournament tennis, of the luxury-suite-driven sports industry in general.
"You have to have the experience to get a lot out of it," Agassi said when asked what Pete Sampras had missed by pulling out.
In the end, Sampras did everyone a favor. It gave Zimbabwe a chance. It gave Woodruff a chance. It gave McEnroe a cause. He and his players left here last night feeling like Duke surviving in the first round of March Madness. They did it without holding up a sign that said: "Send Pete."

HEADLINE: Clinton to Seek Big Increase in Funds to Fight Child Labor Abroad

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
President Clinton plans to ask Congress to more than double the nation's spending on reducing child labor overseas, administration officials said yesterday.
The officials said Mr. Clinton, in the budget he is submitting to Congress today, would ask for $110 million over all toward fighting the use of child labor, up from $45 million budgeted for the current fiscal year. The proposed spending increase would be used primarily to move children out of the workplace and into school. 
 The International Labor Organization estimates that around the world, more than 250 million children age 14 and under are working, in fields that include making apparel, rugs and fireworks, mining, domestic work and prostitution.
Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's national economic adviser, said the proposed spending increase reflected a greater focus on reducing child labor and on softening the harshest effects of globalization. When Mr. Clinton came into office, the United States was spending $3 million annually on trying to reduce child labor.
The planned spending increase comes after developing nations denounced the administration's proposal, made at the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle in December, to create a task force that might recommend trade sanctions against countries that allowed the use of child labor or violations of other basic labor rights.
Officials from third world countries have said that if the United States is serious about wanting to reduce child labor, it should not threaten trade sanctions. Instead, they say, it should work with developing nations to move child workers into schools and to create better-paying jobs for poor parents so they do not feel the need to send their children to work.
"This child labor initiative is very significant, because we are definitely taking the lead in the world community in the money the president is putting up to fight this problem," said Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat who has sponsored numerous bills against child labor.
The administration's plan calls for giving $45 million, up from $30 million this year, to the International Program for the Elimination of Child Labor run by the International Labor Organization. Child labor experts say this program has been successful in reducing child labor in apparel factories in Bangladesh:children represented 3 percent of apparel industry workers in 1999, down from 34 percent three years earlier.
In a new initiative, the administration is proposing $55 million in financing for the United States Department of Labor, working with the Agency for International Development, to promote efforts with countries where child labor is prevalent. Much of this money would be used to build schools, train teachers or transport children to distant schools.
"Lack of educational opportunity is a major contributor to child labor," White House officials said in a background paper.
The administration also plans to double financing for the Customs Service -- to $10 million -- to enforce the ban on imports made with forced or indentured child labor.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 636 words

HEADLINE: The Durable Expansion

 BODY:
Economic expansions do not die of old age. The current expansion, the longest in recorded history, will not end from exhaustion. A nine-year-old expansion is no more likely to end than a two-year-old expansion. Indeed, the term business cycle is a misnomer. Recoveries and recessions do not occur in regular cycles. There are ups and downs but no pattern.
Though unrecognized at the time, the current recovery began in March 1991, long before Bill Clinton defeated President George Bush on the assertion that he did not know how to manage the economy. This expansion, like all those that have come before, will end. No one knows when. But there are clues about how it will end. 
 Prof. John Taylor of Stanford points out that "the start of every recession since World War II has been preceded by a run-up of inflation." Once inflation begins to rise, the Federal Reserve is forced to crack down, raising interest rates to slow spending and bring prices under control. Mr. Taylor pictures the job of the Fed as a constant struggle to keep spending growing at about the same pace as the capacity of the economy to produce new goods and services. The task is difficult because the actions the Fed takes today will not affect inflation for months if not years into the future. That forces the Fed to anticipate the future. When it errs, inflation can take off.
In the late 1960's, spending on the Vietnam War fueled inflationary pressure. OPEC added to the problem by jacking up the price of foreign oil. By the middle of the 1970's, inflation accelerated and the Fed intervened, producing a prolonged recession. Even so, at the end of the decade, inflation and interest rates soared above 10 percent, and the Fed, under Paul Volcker, cracked down hard. The economy fell into the steepest recession since the Great Depression. A similar story -- recovery leading to inflation leading to Fed intervention and recession -- can be told about the downturn in the late 1950's.
The remarkable feature of the current recovery is that, after almost nine years, there is still little whiff of rising inflation. There is no need for the Fed to crack down. Its decision last week to raise interest rates a quarter of a percentage point was more of a pinprick than a body blow to the economy. The Fed has proved over the last 20 years that it recognizes its obligation to control inflation and marshal its tools appropriately. According to Mr. Taylor's calculations, the Fed reacts today to initial bumps in inflation twice as aggressively -- measured by the size of interest-rate hikes -- as it did in the 1960's and 70's.
Yet no one thinks the Fed can keep the economy growing forever. It will make mistakes. It may let spending grow too quickly, and then be forced to clamp down. Or it may keep spending from growing fast enough to keep workers fully employed, as has happened in Japan. Beyond technical mistakes by the Fed, the economy will some day be rocked by events beyond anyone's control. OPEC has tripled oil prices over the past year and could drive them even higher. Another financial crisis could sweep through Asia or Latin America or both. Stock prices may plunge from their lofty perch, as they did one day in 1987 when they fell a frightening 25 percent. But such shocks in recent years have not thrown the economy into recession, in large part because the Fed reacted quickly to keep spending growing at a healthy clip.
The real danger is something unseen and as yet unknown. But some trends are encouraging. Recessions are getting milder. Expansions are getting longer. Indeed, except for a mild recession at the beginning of the 1990's, the American economy has enjoyed uninterrupted growth for almost 18 years. The important point is that these good times have not been solely due to luck.

HEADLINE: Frederick Vanderbilt Field, Wealthy Leftist, Dies at 94

BYLINE: By ENID NEMY 

 BODY:
Frederick Vanderbilt Field, who supported Communist causes in the 1930's, 40's and 50's and was once described as "the Reds' pet blueblood," died Feb. 1 at the Walker Methodist Health Center in Minneapolis. A great-great-grandson of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt and a descendant of several other prestigious American families, he was 94 and had lived in Minneapolis for almost two decades.
Mr. Field first ventured into politics when he offered his services to the Democratic Party after returning to the United States from a year at the London School of Economics. He had previously been interested in socialist ideas, and when he discovered that Democratic Party leaders were not in a great hurry to change society, he drifted further in socialism's direction. 
 He began to proclaim the gospel of socialism at every opportunity and made a number of street-corner speeches, although he later said they were not very good.
He first publicly proclaimed his adherence to the socialist cause in 1928, when he announced that he intended to vote for Norman Thomas, the Socialist Party candidate for president. He was cut off without a penny by Frederick Vanderbilt, his great-uncle, for whom he had been named. Frederick Vanderbilt, who had no children, had earlier said he would leave his fortune, estimated at more than $70 million Depression-era dollars, to his namesake.
Socialism paled within a half-dozen years for Mr. Field, who termed it "a splendid shell of an idea without anything important growing inside it." His disillusionment moved him further to the left.
After his return from London, he also went to work for the Institute of Pacific Relations, a federation of 10 national councils working to solve the problems of the Pacific area. The organization was considered respectable throughout most of the 1930's, but the Soviet Union became increasingly influential after joining in 1931, and when Congressional investigators began searching for Communists after World War II, the institute was represented as an umbrella for subversives. Mr. Field remained with the organization until 1940 and was on its board until 1947.
In the 40's, Mr. Field was an organizer and executive secretary of the American Peace Mobilization, an organization with ties to the Soviet Union that was dedicated to keeping the United States from entering the war. In 1941 the group picketed the White House for more than 1,000 hours. The picketing ended suddenly when Nazi Germany invaded the Soviet Union.
One of Mr. Field's sisters said that until the early 40's he had considered himself as good an American as anyone else. When the United States entered the war, he tried to get a commission in Army intelligence but was turned down as a security risk. That rejection, his sister said, was the final straw.
He became dedicated to Communism, although whether he joined the party was never known. He did acknowledge in 1951 that he had been an unpaid, registered agent for four companies in Communist China.
In a 1951 Life magazine article, Mr. Field tried to explain his political philosophy. "Understanding your own motives is one of the most obscure pursuits in the world," he said. "I'm not terribly interested in introspection but I do have deep convictions."
He said it was possible that if he had had a job to lose, he might have done things differently. But, he added, "I've really had nothing to lose." He picketed and entertained for the Communist Party, but his most important contributions were, as he was not unaware, his prestigious name and his financial generosity.
In 1951, as secretary of the bail fund of the Civil Rights Congress -- an organization designated a Communist front by the attorney general -- he was convicted of contempt of court for refusing to reveal who had put up bond for four Communists who had jumped bail. He was sentenced to 90 days in jail and served two months.
Two years later, Mr. Field moved to Mexico, where he took up archaeology. He remained there until 1982, when he returned to the United States.
Mr. Field was born on April 13, 1905. His father was William Osgood Field, a descendant of Samuel Osgood, the country's first postmaster general, and Cyrus Field, who was responsible for laying the first trans-Atlantic cable. His mother was Lila Vanderbilt Sloane. His parents' 1902 wedding involved a special train that transported family members and friends to the ceremony in Lenox, Mass., and four detectives to guard the car that carried the wedding gifts, estimated to be worth $1 million, back to Manhattan.
Mr. Field, his brother and his two sisters were raised with every luxury. In his autobiography, "From Right to Left," published in 1983, Mr. Field, writing of himself in the third person, said he had grown up "surrounded by servants who did everything for him but sneeze."
After graduating from the Hotchkiss School in 1923, Mr. Field entered Harvard, where he was a member of Hasty Pudding and an editor of The Crimson. He graduated from Harvard in 1927 and went on to the London School of Economics, where he came under the influence of the socialist Harold Laski.
Mr. Field is survived by his fourth wife, the former Nieves Orozco, who had been a favorite model of Diego Rivera and whom he married in Mexico in 1958. Three earlier marriages ended in divorce. He was married to Elizabeth Brown in 1929 and, three years after his 1935 divorce, to Edith Chamberlain Hunter. That marriage ended in 1949, and four months later he married Anita Boyer, whose first husband, Dr. Raymond Boyer, was convicted in Canada as part of a Russian spy plot.
Survivors also include four daughters, Lila Field Jacob of Minneapolis, Nievska Gonzales of Cuernevaca, Mexico, and Princeton, N.J., Federika Field of Mexico City and Xochitl Field of Minneapolis; 12 grandchildren; 16 great-grandchildren; and a sister, Mary Jackson of Milton, Mass.
Mr. Field, considered a maverick most of his life, never bowed to public or political pressure or to ostracism by his peers.
"You can get stinking drunk at the Stork Club every night and still be held in the highest esteem," Life magazine quoted him as saying in 1951, "but if you write or even believe anything different, then you're a traitor to your class."

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
McEnroe and Americans Save Their Best for Last

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The American no one expected to faint almost did, and the one who many believed would shrink stood tall.
More predictably, the United States Davis Cup captain irritated the umpire and infuriated his opponents, but ultimately landed on his feet, instead of his hard head. 
 John McEnroe's maiden Davis Cup team achieved what Arthur Ashe's first team did 19 years ago, when a wild-haired and stormy tempered guy named McEnroe won the fifth match against Mexico's Raul Ramirez in Carlsbad, Calif., and rallied the United States to a first-round victory from a 2-1 deficit. This setting was, well, different and the end-game hero was a 27-year-old journeyman, not a budding legend.
As far as a relieved and subsequently jubilant McEnroe was concerned, Chris Woodruff was himself, Jimmy Connors and Pete Sampras all rolled into one today at the Harare Sports Arena. With a barrage of winners and powerful first serves, he battered Wayne Black to clinch a 3-2 victory over gritty Zimbabwe.
Woodruff's 6-3, 6-7 (2), 6-2, 6-4 mastery of Black came with one rather important member of McEnroe's team back at the hotel, under a doctor's care. In the process of trying to close out Byron Black in straight sets, Andre Agassi was overcome by cramps and nausea. He held on in a third-set tie breaker, vomiting behind the baseline just before and into a basket right after his 6-2, 6-3, 7-6 (4) decision over the elder Black brother.
Agassi repaired to his bed for treatment by George Fareed, a member of the team's medical staff, and watched on television as Woodruff emerged from the cocoon, in which he was so tightly wrapped Friday during a straight-set surrender to Byron Black.
"He has so much heart and character," said McEnroe, grateful that Agassi showed up here at all after winning the Australian Open and being on the road since Dec. 28.
"It was such a great example for these guys," McEnroe said. McEnroe suddenly slipped into his television announcer's skin and, extending his arm toward Woodruff, said, "How about a round of applause for this guy?"
There might have been a temptation to respond with a favorite expression of McEnroe's -- big deal. Wayne Black, in the world of singular achievement, is ranked in the mid-100's. Yet, under these extreme conditions, in a cacophony of noise and a cauldron of heat, the day pretty much began with this economically roiled nation of 13 million believing that the fifth-match victory was all but assured.
Woodruff had looked stiff and even scared against Byron Black. He had little control of his strokes on the fast hardcourt, in the thin nearly mile-high air. The most vociferous local fans from the Mufakose Supporters Club thus had Zimbabwe's national sports anthem -- "Yave Nyoma Yekugocha" (This meat is ready for roasting) ready and rehearsed, in the indigenous Shona tongue.
In the absence of a sanctioned team psychologist, however, Woodruff had received counseling and support from a variety of sources, including McEnroe, his teammates and a couple of Davis Cup veterans from back home.
There was, on Saturday, an e-mail from Jim Courier wishing him luck, and then a telephone chat with Todd Martin, whose viral infection illness -- along with Sampras's injury -- was the reason the 6-foot-4-inch Tennessean found himself in this delicate situation in the first place.
"Did you have any fun Friday?" Martin said.
"I didn't have a bit of fun," Woodruff said.
Martin reminded Woodruff that, contrary to what it felt like on the court, the Wayne Black showdown was going to be only another tennis match against a player he was better than. And when Woodruff took the court today, what he soon began to realize was that the first match, if nothing else, had prepared him for the second. He was comfortable with the environment, familiar with the chanting and the conga drum. He was more than ready for Jojo the clown.
He also quickly demonstrated he had more than enough weaponry, too much power, for the quick, resilient but undersized (at 5-7) Black.
All Woodruff had to do was measure his ground strokes, apply enough topspin to keep them from flying and generate a good percentage of first serves. That he did, dominating the first set and going up an early break in the second, before Black began to run everything down, send it back and wait for the mistake.
Black broke back in the fifth game, won the tie breaker, and broke again for 2-0 in the third set. This was about the time, Woodruff said, he began to feel the humidity, and had trouble taking air into his lungs.
Never has this been a problem for McEnroe, who laced into his player, or as Woodruff put it, "got into my kitchen." Coincidence or not, Woodruff was soon whipping up a souffle of winners that would carry him to a two-sets-to-one lead, up a break in the fourth.
Having gotten back on serve in the third game, Woodruff seized control of the match in the fifth game, breaking again with two heavy forehands. Including the last 2 points of that game, he went on a Sampras-like roll, winning 22 of 25 points and eight straight games.
He noticed that Black was chewing tablets during changeovers. Black later said he was "maybe a step slow," at least. He had lost in straight sets to Agassi Friday, and won the five-set doubles Saturday with Kevin Ullyet. Shumba, his Shona nickname paying tribute to his "heart of a lion," was one tired cat.
Woodruff, who had 73 winners to Black's 23, finished him off with his 15th ace, down the middle. He tossed his racquet so high it crashed against the overhead light structure. McEnroe rushed the court, into his arms. "Eighty four," McEnroe would say when asked when the last felt this good -- the year of his last Grand Slam title.
Unimpressed, Black would later say that McEnroe's match behavior was "disgraceful," and that the umpire, Bruno Rebeuh, should have tossed him for excessive whining.
In the end, the Americans were dancing in Harare and on their way to the second round, against the Czech Republic in April. Agassi, by evening, was feeling better and saying, by phone, that he was "so proud." And all things considered, it didn't turn so badly for Zimbabwe either.
Its next opponent in the relegation round is none other than Old Mother England. As they say here, Yave Nyoma Yekugocha.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); ZIMBABWE (90%); AUSTRALIA (52%);

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Hearing Loss, but Now Not Loss of Opportunity

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
When she was growing up in Honduras, Maria Bustamante never went to school. When she was older, she never held a job. Because she is deaf, those around her thought Ms. Bustamante was incapable of work, and they did not see a need to educate her. She spent most of her time doing housework with her mother.
In 1985, after years of being ignored and pushed aside, Ms. Bustamante decided to go to New York, in her 20's and with a child, in search of dignity and a job. But when she arrived in the city, Ms. Bustamante found only low-level employment at restaurants and cafeterias where she said people still did not treat her with respect. 
 "I didn't know what they were saying," Ms. Bustamante, speaking through a sign-language interpreter, said of her former co-workers at a corporate cafeteria, where she served food and wiped down tables and chairs under a training program, but was never hired. "I tried to stick in there with them, and I tried to do what I thought I had to do."
For more than 10 years, Ms. Bustamante, now 42, was either unemployed or shifting from one lackluster job to another, trying to support herself and her son, Christian, now 21.
"The food, the apartment, the clothes -- it was all a heartache," Ms. Bustamante said. She struggled in a strange land -- made more difficult to understand without a sense of hearing -- to the point of exhaustion. "I left it in God's hands," she said.
But eventually she vowed to plow ahead and search in earnest for a better paying, long-term job. She started seeing a job placement counselor, who put her in touch with the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
She began attending the bureau's vocational readiness group for the deaf, which helps participants navigate the job application process and teaches interviewing techniques and how to communicate with bosses.
She also enrolled in the bureau's vocational training program, which assessed her skills and placed her in training programs, first at Pfizer Pharmaceuticals' employee food services and then at Pibbs Industries in Flushing, Queens.
At about the same time, emboldened by her involvement with the bureau's training programs, she began working to earn her general equivalency diploma, or G.E.D., by taking classes at La Guardia Community College. And one special afternoon last May, after countless hours of study, she became an American citizen.
At Pibbs, a family-owned and operated business that, among other things, makes furniture for beauty salons, Ms. Bustamante has found a steady job for the first time. She helps assemble, package and ship furniture and has a large group of friends at work with whom she can communicate.
"There's Bibi and Christopher," she said. "We get together at lunch for our chitchat. You know, the deaf crew."
About a quarter of the 100 employees at Pibbs are deaf, said Giulio Petruccelli, the company's production manager. "They find an atmosphere that is very amenable to them," he said. Many of the company's job applicants, hearing and deaf alike, arrive from the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service.
Dominic Liantonio, a counselor for the bureau who places people at a number of work sites, said Pibbs employed more deaf people than any other company he has worked with. "What makes this place so compatible with the deaf is that they have camaraderie here," he said. "They don't mind doing a job that might not be 100 percent what they want to do if they have an enjoyable working environment."
"They've had great success here," he added. The deaf, he said, "just really need an opportunity, and Giulio gives them that opportunity."
Now that Ms. Bustamante's life has stabilized, she can concentrate on her quest to learn English and can spend more time with her son in their Astoria apartment. Despite all the hardships she has faced in New York, she said she is glad she came.
"It's a better life here," she said. "There's more opportunity. In Honduras, you didn't have that kind of opportunity."

HEADLINE: IN AMERICA;
Another Glass Ceiling

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The bad news is that 16 percent of the women in this country and 17 percent of the men say they would not vote for a woman for president.
The good news is that those percentages are sharply lower than just eight years ago, when 26 percent of American women and nearly 4 out of every 10 men said they could not pull the lever for a woman running for president. 
 We may be in the 21st century, and life may be improving, but a fair number of us still hold some ancient attitudes.
The presidential race this year is wide open and the most exciting in a long time. But all of the contenders, as usual, are men in suits (or earth-tone sweaters and cowboy boots). Elizabeth Dole spent a minute or two warming up, but she couldn't even rally the wholehearted support of her husband.
A woman in the White House? What if a war were to break out? What if the economy went south? What in the world would she do?
Marie Wilson, the president of the Ms. Foundation for Women and one of the creators of Take Our Daughters to Work Day, has had enough of the bogus fears and the stereotyping and the ignorance. She is on a campaign to raise the consciousness of Americans to the leadership potential in that half of the population that is routinely taken less seriously than men.
She calls her campaign, which has $3 million in financing so far, the White House Project. Her goal is to hasten the day when a woman is elected president, but not just that.
"What we're trying to do is change the climate in America, to make it friendly toward women's leadership," she said. "As long as there are only one or two women who are seen as potential leaders, the focus will be on gender. We want to permanently increase the number of women who run for office in this country. We want to normalize the whole process so that it is not about one woman at a time."
People were calling 1992 the "year of the woman" in politics. But now, nearly a decade later, there are only 9 women among the 100 U.S. senators, 56 women in the 435-member House of Representatives and just 3 women among the 50 governors.
The women who aspire to high public office are often viewed differently than male candidates. A survey commissioned by Deloitte & Touche and released last month found that the public, in general, "puts more stock in a male candidate's ability to tackle tough issues."
Thus, the tougher the job is perceived to be -- and nothing is considered tougher than the presidency -- the less likely it is that a woman will get the nod.
A report that accompanied the Deloitte & Touche survey said:
"The results of the poll show that on the surface Americans express widespread support for women in high political office. However, the public's underlying attitudes toward women reveal persistent stereotypes that serve to undermine women's chances for election to high public office."
Hillary Rodham Clinton, who officially announced her run for the Senate yesterday, was asked by a radio reporter a couple of weeks ago about the venomous reaction she elicits in some quarters. She replied: "I know it's out there and I think some of it is because of the positions that I've taken and maybe a little of it is because I'm a woman taking those positions. And maybe some of it is people don't like my hair style. I don't know what it is."
There was a venomous reaction in some quarters to that answer. And maybe it wasn't particularly politic. But, surely, some of the heat Mrs. Clinton is taking is because she's a woman.
Marie Wilson has been scrupulously nonpartisan in her campaign to promote women for high public office. And she doesn't want voters to vote for women simply because they are women.
What she wants, she says, is to accelerate the improvement in the public's acceptance of women in high office that has been occurring over the past several years, and to radically expand the number of women seeking top leadership positions.
She is sponsoring media campaigns, commissioning surveys, conducting mock elections, doing whatever it takes to spread the word that women are as capable as men of running the government of the United States of America.

HEADLINE: CLINTON, IN BUDGET, SEEKS TO BOLSTER MEDICARE PROGRAM

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton on Monday will submit a $1.84 trillion federal budget for next year and will call for using much of the projected budget surplus over the next decade to strengthen and expand the Medicare system of health insurance for the elderly, administration officials said today.
Mr. Clinton's plan calls for spending on government programs outside of Social Security and Medicare, the third of the total budget that Congress revisits each year, to grow 3.9 percent next year, and at slightly less than the rate of inflation over the next decade. The administration projects that inflation will be about 2.6 percent a year over the period. 
 Assuming such a growth rate in so-called discretionary spending, the administration calculated that the budget surplus outside of Social Security over the next 10 years would total $746 billion, considerably lower than the projections likely to be adopted by Congress.
The White House's approach is certain to set off a partisan, election-year clash over spending levels, tax cuts and how to define the size of the surplus, and with the Republicans in control of both houses of Congress Mr. Clinton's budget stands no chance of being enacted in anything close to its current form.
But because they take the first step in the annual budget process, presidents get a chance to frame the debate, and the administration's emphasis this year is on defining the amount of money available to the parties as they push their agendas.
Mr. Clinton is trying to take a chunk of the surplus off the table by earmarking it for what administration officials said were realistic spending increases over the next 10 years for general government operations including things as diverse as Head Start and new fighter planes. In doing so, he is formally abandoning the spending limits required by the 1997 balanced budget act.
Those limits have been all but ignored by both parties for two years as the government's balance sheet has shifted from deficit into surplus.
The administration plan would allocate much of the surplus to shoring up Medicare's deteriorating finances and to adding prescription drug coverage to the program. Altogether, $432 billion out of the administration's projection of a $746 billion surplus would go to Medicare over the next decade.
The administration would also use the surplus to help give poor children and their families better access to health insurance, to pay for modest tax cuts and for programs like aid to farmers.
The administration is proposing $350 billion in tax cuts over a decade, offset in part by $100 billion in revenues from closing corporate tax loopholes. Republicans are sure to seek far larger tax cuts, as they have done in each of the previous few years.
To make its numbers add up, the administration is also counting on $66 billion in revenues over the next decade from a 25-cents-a-pack cigarette tax and penalties on tobacco companies that do not reduce teenage smoking.
The administration would use all of the surplus generated by Social Security, about $2 trillion over the next decade, for reducing the national debt, with a goal of eliminating the $3.6 trillion in debt held by the public by 2013.
"By starting with a realistic projection of the surplus and making decisions and tradeoffs on priorities, it's possible to accomplish a great deal and remain on the path of fiscal discipline," said Jacob J. Lew, the director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget.
The Republican-led budget committees in the House and Senate are only beginning to put their proposals together. But they are expected to start with far lower spending assumptions than the administration and far bigger surplus estimates, allowing more room for tax cuts.
The Congressional Budget Office projected last month that the non-Social Security surplus over the next decade could be as little as $838 billion using assumptions similar to those adopted by the administration, and as much as $1.9 trillion if spending were cut for the next few years before beginning to grow again. Republican leaders have indicated that they will choose a number in between.
Rehearsing a theme that they are sure to stress on Monday, when Mr. Clinton's budget is formally unveiled and sent to Congress, Republicans criticized the White House plan today as bloated and developed with an eye more toward the election in the fall than toward getting legislation enacted.
"From what we know of this budget, it would appear that the era of big government is back with a vengeance," said Robert G. Stevenson, the spokesman for the Senate Budget Committee.
"It's one thing to invest smartly in needed government programs," Mr. Stevenson continued. "This budget throws open the vault and says let's spend it all."
Terry Holt, the spokesman for the House Budget Committee, said that by building spending increases into the budget each year Mr. Clinton was proposing government by autopilot and that his extensive spending proposals were political in nature.
"It's like a laundry list of promises to groups that Al Gore will need to get elected president," Mr. Holt said.
Republicans said it was bad policy to assume that discretionary spending would increase each year at around the rate of inflation. In setting surplus projections, Republicans generally prefer to assume a spending freeze, saying Congress should decide each year how much money gets spent and which programs deserve to be cut.
Bigger surplus projections like those favored by Republicans would also leave more room for big tax cuts.
Mr. Clinton vetoed a $792 billion, 10-year tax cut that Republicans passed last year, and in the presidential race, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas is pressing for a 10-year tax cut of $1.3 billion or more.
Over the last month Mr. Clinton has unveiled a host of initiatives that will be included in his budget, from an increase in tax credits for the working poor to more money for AIDS research to an expansion of programs to enforce gun laws.
Many of the initiatives are likely to go nowhere on Capitol Hill. But there is some prospect of action this year on a few big issues, including adding prescription drug coverage to Medicare.
Mr. Clinton's plan would cost $168 billion over 10 years, including $98 billion out of the budget surplus and another $70 billion from savings within the existing Medicare system.
While many Republicans also favor adding drug coverage to Medicare, they would prefer a smaller program than Mr. Clinton.

HEADLINE: It's Official: First Lady Is Now Candidate Clinton

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: PURCHASE, N.Y., Feb. 6

 BODY:
With her husband seated as a mere onlooker at the rear of the stage, Hillary Rodham Clinton declared her candidacy for the United States Senate this afternoon, presenting herself as a "new Democrat" who views government as neither the cause of nor the solution to the nation's problems.
In a spectacle of media and politics, all packed into a loud and raucous gymnasium at the State University of New York campus here, Mrs. Clinton formally inaugurated what was as much a rite of family passage as a political one. It was Mrs. Clinton who was the center of attention today; President Clinton, whose term in office ends in just 11 months, did not utter a single public word during the 32 minutes he spent on stage. 
 But he did not have to. Mrs. Clinton adopted the message President Clinton rode to the White House in 1992 -- much the way Vice President Al Gore has during his campaign for president -- as she sought to begin what her aides hope will be a new, and less troubled, phase of her campaign against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City.
"I am a new Democrat," Mrs. Clinton said. "I don't believe that government is the source of all our problems or the solution to them. But I do believe that when people live up to their responsibilities, we ought to live up to ours, to help them build better lives. I believe that's the basic bargain we owe to one another in America today."
With her announcement, a ceremony in American politics that has traditionally offered candidates an unfettered chance to make their case to voters, she went to great pains to present herself as a public figure in her own right, and not just a product of her husband's success. The day, choreographed down to the last camera shot, was filled with reminders of this, from the gauzy 18-minute biographical video that introduced her, to the personal anecdotes sprinkled through her speech, to what was written on the huge banner at her back: just "Hillary."
As a rule, politicians tend to step aside on the days when their rivals formally declare their candidacy. But Mr. Giuliani, who takes some pleasure in defying traditional political rules, was anything but a recluse. He rode the morning talk show circuit today with vigor, presenting the case for his candidacy, and the case against Mrs. Clinton, on five separate news programs. He took great pains to note his long years in public service, and repeatedly referred to his official duties in contrast to what he called the Hollywood-style event unfolding upstate.
"I think ultimately it's bigger than any one issue or any one personality," Mr. Giuliani said of a viable candidacy for the Senate. "It's a sense of trust that people have to have. And I guess what I would say to them is, in my case, they have a record of public service in the state of New York for a very long time."
He shuttled from studio to studio, and at the ABC studio on Times Square, where he appeared on "This Week," he indicated that unlike his opponent, he probably would forgo announcing altogether, because he had, in the past, won the elections where he had never announced.
Asked whether he was superstitious, he replied: "I think so. I have to admit."
Democrats had anxiously looked forward to Mrs. Clinton's speech today, hoping that she would restore their confidence in her candidacy after what they viewed as an unsteady start and also hoping that she would offer a compelling case for New Yorkers to elect someone to the Senate who has not held public office or lived in the state until a month ago.
"Now I know, some people are asking why I'm doing this, here and now," she said. "And that's a fair question. Here's my answer, and why I hope you'll put me to work for you: I may be new to the neighborhood, but I'm not new to your concerns."
In pomp and scale and sheer spectacle, Mrs. Clinton's announcement was, almost certainly, unlike any other staged by a candidate running for public office in New York before. The gym at Purchase College, which is about 10 miles south of Mrs. Clinton's new home in Chappaqua, began filling up with news crews at 7 a.m.; by 1 p.m., there was not a spot to be had on the risers that were set up for photographers and television crews. It was broadcast live on CNN, C-Span, New York 1 and MSNBC.
The event attracted an eclectic mixture of supporters and critics of the first family. Sidney Blumenthal, the White House aide and longtime Clinton adviser, and Ann Lewis, Mr. Clinton's communications director, milled around in a gymnasium that also included John Podhoretz, the conservative commentator and New York Post columnist, and Lucianne Goldberg, the book agent associated with the Linda Tripp tapes.
Most of the state's Democratic members of Congress had been flown from a party retreat in Virginia as a show of support for Mrs. Clinton's entry. Other prominent New York politicians, including Fernado Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, were lined up outside the gym trying to get in.
Mrs. Clinton did not mention Mr. Giuliani's name during her speech. But she made some obvious references to her opponent as she signaled some of the roads of attack that she intended to follow.
"There's one other thing I'll fight against: the politics of revenge and retribution," she said as shouts of "Yes" could be heard in the by-invitation-only crowd. "If you put me to work for you, I'll work to lift people up -- not push them down."
Mrs. Clinton was introduced by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the four-term New York Democrat who is retiring at the end of this term. Mr. Moynihan has been suffering from back difficulties, so his attendance was in doubt until the last minute. Walking with evident difficulty onto the stage, he compared Mrs. Clinton to Eleanor Roosevelt in a brief tribute and introduction.
The biographical video of Mrs. Clinton marked the start of an effort by her campaign to present a fuller, and softer, portrait of the first lady. Mrs. Clinton, in an interview last week, said she believed that a lack of information about her -- or misinformation spread by enemies -- accounted for the reluctance of some voters to rally behind her candidacy.
Titled just "Hillary," the video was created by the television producer Linda Bloodworth-Thomason, who produced a similar video for Mr. Clinton when he ran for president in 1992. The audience attentively watched the sympathetic portrait of Mrs. Clinton as an aggressive advocate for children, a lawyer and, finally, a standard-issue suburban mother, notwithstanding where she has spent the last seven years of her life.
"I make a mean tossed salad and a great omelet," Mrs. Clinton said, in a pink sweater with a single strand of pearls at her neck. (It was reminiscent of Mrs. Clinton's last foray into cooking, when in 1992, during her husband's first presidential campaign, she remarked that instead of having a professional career, she could have stayed home and baked cookies.)
In her announcement speech, Mrs. Clinton presented herself as an advocate for schools and health care, sounding two of the main themes of the campaign. At times, she sounded much like Mr. Clinton had sounded last month as he delivered his final State of the Union speech. She pledged to support tax deductions to help with college tuition, easing the marriage penalty, raising the minimum wage, and expanding the earned income tax credit.
Without mentioning Mr. Giuliani's name, she raised two issues on which they do not share similar views. "I'll be on your side in the fight against school vouchers, which drain taxpayer dollars from our public schools," she said. "I'll be on your side in the fight against any tax cut so big it would take us back to the bad old days of exploding deficits and deep recessions, making it impossible for us to save Social Security and Medicare, fund our educational needs, and pay down our national debt."
She also tried to make light of her own residency, an issue that Mr. Giuliani has referred to frequently, with what even some supporters conceded was a fairly feeble attempt at a New York accent.
As Mrs. Clinton spoke, supporters held almost 600 house parties across the state to watch Mrs. Clinton speak, and to raise money for her campaign. In Albany, 40 Democrats crowded into a three-story home, dropping more than $1,500 into a crystal bowl, eating fruit and cheese.
"She's ticking off issues that are important to me as a mother and a public official," said Nancy Burton, 48, the city comptroller. "Despite the national economic boom, upstate cities are still suffering."
The night before, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Clinton went to a potluck dinner with neighbors. The Clintons arrived at the party in a gray Suburban sport utility vehicle, bearing a chicken and rice casserole. Dressed casually in sweaters and slacks, the couple mingled with about 100 guests.
At his wife's speech, Mr. Clinton was the first to applaud as she finished presenting herself as a "new Democrat," delivering the line of thought that won him the presidency in 1992. And the moment she finished speaking, after the applause began to die down, Mr. Clinton was the first to dive into the crowd, shaking hands for almost 30 minutes.

HEADLINE: MEDIA TALK;
Journal Escalates Battle With British Rival

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
The Wall Street Journal, long an also-ran to The Financial Times in the competition for European consumers of financial news, has begun marketing its way across the Continent to challenge its rival's dominance -- and The Financial Times is responding in kind.
Today, The Journal will unveil its new Continental persona, a newspaper that colors its name blue and abandons the pinstriped look of the American edition in favor of a colorful, Web-influenced design. 
 More important, it will repackage and supplement its coverage of technology and the new economy in a new section called Networking, with specialized columns on subjects like advertising in Europe, and add about 14 reporters, bringing the total to more than 80.
It will also take advantage of its six-month-old alliance with the von Holtzbrinck Group, publisher of the German business daily Handelsblatt, by increasing the number of Handelsblatt articles it translates and publishes and trading news executives with its German partner. In June, Dow Jones & Company, The Journal's parent, took a 22 percent stake in Handelsblatt, while von Holtzbrinck bought 49 percent of The Wall Street Journal Europe.
Richard J. Tofel, vice president for corporate communications at Dow Jones, said the company intended to step up its challenge to The Financial Times, which outsells The Journal 121,000 to 83,000 on the Continent. The Journal is aiming at a 140,000 circulation by 2003.
The Financial Times currently trounces its American rival in its home base of Britain, 200,000 to 67,000.
The Journal's move comes little more than a year after The Financial Times, which is owned by Pearson P.L.C., made an effort to raise its salmon-pink profile in the United States, where its circulation, now 102,000, has nearly tripled in three years.
The Financial Times has Continental designs of its own. Lionel Barber, the paper's news editor and second in command of the newsroom -- said on Friday that the start of The Financial Times's German-language version, for which it has hired 120 journalists, is imminent.
Mr. Barber also said that the newspaper had hired an additional 120 journalists in London and New York to write for its Web site, ft.com. All their coverage can be used in any of the paper's print or online editions.
Mr. Tofel, for his part, said: "They're not a serious threat to us in America. We've won the game in Latin America. There is no game in Britain -- they won. The game is in the continent of Europe. We're going to step up and play the game much more aggressively." FELICITY BARRINGER

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the European edition of The Wall Street Journal misstated its circulation. The Journal sells 16,000 copies in Britain, not 67,000. The total European circulation -- not the total for copies sold in Europe outside of Britain -- is 83,000.

HEADLINE: Jorg Haider's Other Message

BYLINE: By Ian Buruma; Ian Buruma is the author, most recently, of "Anglomania.'

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Jorg Haider, leader of the Austrian Freedom Party, smirks a lot and wears flashy loden suits. He also trawls in the same rank pool of populist fears and resentments -- mainly of foreigners who "swamp" the nation, "steal our jobs," have criminal habits, and so on -- as Jean-Marie Le Pen in France, the Republicans in Germany, unsavory fringes of the Conservative Party in Britain, and Pat Buchanan in the United States.
This makes him a disturbing figure, but it is not enough reason to break off high-level diplomatic relations with Austria now that his Freedom Party has joined the coalition government. 
 The reactions to his political success have been remarkable. Leaders of the European Union countries said they would not only cut off high-level relations but suspend Austria's membership in the union. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has recalled the United States ambassador in Vienna, at least temporarily. Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel referred to the Holocaust when he recalled his ambassador. The foreign minister of Belgium even told his countrymen that it would be immoral to go skiing in the Austrian mountains.
The European Union has a treaty that allows it to suspend a member nation if it should threaten democracy, human rights or the rule of law. There is no evidence that Mr. Haider's Freedom Party has done any such thing. To be sure, his calculated remarks that the Waffen SS contained fine, upstanding folks, or that Hitler had efficient labor policies, or that concentration camps were mere "punishment" camps are nasty. And his habit of apologizing as soon as his utterances run into flak is creepy.
But pan-Germanic nostalgia for the good old days is not widespread enough in Austria to explain why 27 percent of Mr. Haider's fellow citizens voted for his party.
People who dislike foreigners, liberals and city slickers enough to vote for the far right normally make up about 15 percent of the population in any modern Western democracy. In a two-party system like Britain's, this number is absorbed by the Conservative Party. In the United States it has been visible mostly during the primaries. And in France or Germany the extreme right has never been able to form part of any national coalition. Why then the 27 percent in Austria?
Perhaps the fact that Haider is not a rancid old SS veteran, but a smart, sharp operator, who speaks fluent English, accounts for a few more percentage points than he might otherwise have got. But the main reason for Haider's success has less to do with xenophobia or brownshirt nostalgia than a simple flaw in the Austrian political process.
For more than a decade government has been monopolized by a cozy coalition of Social Democrats and Christian Democrats, a coalition based more on pork barrels and jobs for the boys than ideological compatibility. Mr. Haider's Freedom Party, as the only serious opposition, managed to exploit all the discontentment that becomes chronic when political monopolies last too long. Far from seeing Mr. Haider as an enemy of democracy, then, many Austrians see him as the man who might restore it.
Mr. Haider's economic ideas are a mixture of left-wing as well as right-wing populism; he has promised to protect the welfare state but also to lower taxes and privatize industry. So for Austrians who are tired of corporatist policies that cramp private enterprise, the Freedom Party also appears to stand for more liberty. Mr. Haider's anti-European Union rhetoric, defensive of national sovereignty, fits the Thatcherite mold. There is a constituency for such views, which are not inherently anti-democratic. They are shared to some extent by other right-wing parties, in northern Italy, for example. We may not like them, but it would be damaging to democracy to stifle them.
In fact, the European Union's highhandedness only draws attention to its own authoritarian tendencies. Pan-European institutions are filled with unelected men and women who seem to spend too much time with their snouts in a very rich trough. Brussels is a city of pork-barrel operators and backroom schmoozers.
E.U. leaders are aware of the bad image this engenders and talk a great deal these days about the "democratic deficit." The sharp reaction to events in Austria might be regarded as their way to beef up their democratic credentials.
If so, it is the wrong way. For as long as the democratic nation-state persists, people should have the right to choose their own governments, even people whose views many of us find distasteful.
Yes, Hitler was elected, too. But Mr. Haider is not Hitler. If he were to advocate violence, which Hitler had done many times before 1933, that would be the time to step in. To intervene now would be to confirm all the darkest suspicions of Jorg Haider's supporters, namely that foreigners are not to be trusted, especially foreigners who preach democracy but act like panic-stricken authoritarians when they don't like the results.
