SECTION: Section F; Page 3; Column 1; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 1278 words

HEADLINE: Megadrought Appears to Loom in Africa

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
Lately, it has become increasingly clear to scientists that in the 10,000 years since the last ice age ended, the world's climate has often served up droughts far surpassing anything seen in the last 150 years, resulting in some cases in the collapse of entire ancient civilizations.
Now a new study has found that over the last millennium in equatorial East Africa, decades-long droughts far longer and more severe than any in recorded weather history have alternated with periods when rainfall was heavier than today. The droughts dwarfed any experienced by humans in the 20th century, including the American Dust Bowl of the 1930's and the African Sahel drought of the 1970's. 
 In each of the earlier droughts, some of which lasted as long as 80 years, according to oral traditions cited in the study, famine ravaged the land, provoking social and political upheaval and forcing large-scale migrations of people.
Given this pattern of naturally occurring, long-term variability in precipitation, say the scientists who performed the study, there is a "very high probability" that a devastating dry period, possibly lasting decades, will visit tropical Africa again in the next 50 to 100 years. This time, it would affect a human population that has doubled in the last 25 years and is increasing its use of water even faster.
"We have to anticipate that a major catastrophic drought will happen sooner or later, and we must prepare for such an event," said Dr. Dirk Verschuren, a scientist at the University of Minnesota and the University of Ghent, in Belgium, who headed the study. While such a drought would not necessarily be unremitting, he said, it could result in large-scale crop failures lasting 10 to 15 years at a stretch.
The study by Dr. Verschuren and Dr. Kathleen R. Laird and Dr. Brian F. Cumming of Queens University in Kingston, Ontario, appeared in a recent issue of the journal Nature.
Natural long-term variations in precipitation, especially dry periods, have long had a major impact on human societies. Researchers have linked a 300-year drought starting about 4,200 years ago to the collapse of the world's first great empire, that of the Akkadians in Mesopotamia. Drought is also believed responsible for the collapse of several pre-Inca civilizations in South America, and to have been a major contributor to the disappearance of the Mayan civilization in Central America.
Over the last 3,500 years, according to one study, drought has been the rule in what is now California, with some dry periods lasting as much as two centuries; today's California climate, despite occasional dry spells, is a relatively wet exception.
Droughts as severe as that of the 1930's Dust Bowl, according to a recent study by federal scientists, have occurred once or twice a century over the last 300 to 400 years. And even more severe dry periods have in the past periodically converted big stretches of the Great Plains to Sahara-like conditions.
Scientists draw such conclusions on the basis of indirect evidence, since widespread direct measurements of weather and climate have been in use only since the mid-19th century.
In the recent African study, Dr. Verschuren and two associates examined clues contained in sediments in Lake Naivasha, Kenya. Over the centuries, the shallow lake has collected runoff from its immediate surroundings. In the middle of the lake is a deeper depression formed by the rim of an ancient volcano. Sediment in the runoff has been deposited there in such a way that it has been protected from disturbance.
Dr. Verschuren and his colleagues extracted a 20-foot core from the protected sediments. The strata of sediment preserved in the core reached back 1,100 years. The scientists analyzed the core for three types of indicators of wetness and dryness: varying kinds of soils, the pattern of different species of algae (some thrive in low, saltier water, others in high, fresher water), and patterns of different species of tiny insects called midges, which are also sensitive to salinity.
The analysis enabled the researchers to reconstruct the climatic history of the region, and all three indicators told the same story: over the last millenniums, the region has experienced a constant succession of wetter and drier periods. Most recently, there were serious droughts in the 1870's, just before Europeans colonized the region, and in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. Both of these were much longer and more severe than the Dust Bowl and the 1970's Sahel drought, which threatened millions with starvation.
On the other end of the precipitation scale, rainfall was found to have been significantly higher than today in the 17th and early 18th centuries. This coincides with some of the colder periods of what was called, in Europe, the little ice age, a five-century span in which unusual cold afflicted parts of the Northern Hemisphere from time to time. Conversely, one of the major drought periods coincided with a relatively warm time in Europe, which lasted from about A.D. 1000 to 1270.
The practical question raised by the findings, Dr. Verschuren said, is that of how to plan for the eventuality of a future megadrought in Africa, where the survival of the populace depends mostly on rain-fed agriculture.
"These emerging agricultural economies all do their best in trying to feed their populations, but they do so at a major cost of water use," Dr. Verschuren said. "In many cases, there is serious overexploitation of available water resources."
In countries where water availability is chancy and directly dependent on climate, he said, "you're basically setting yourself up for a catastrophe."
One way to prepare for a coming megadrought, he said, would be to switch to drought-resistant crops. Another would be to reduce dependence on irrigation, which requires large quantities of water.
A broader lesson to be drawn from the findings, he said, is that irrespective of any human impact on the world's climate, there is great natural variability in rainfall, and this variability may swamp the effects of any global warming produced by industrial emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide.
The average surface temperature of the globe is rising, and the dominant view among scientists is that it will increase by 2 to 6 degrees Fahrenheit by 2100 if emissions of the greenhouse gases are not reduced. While attention in the global warming debate has focused mostly on temperature, many experts say the warming's effect on precipitation may be more striking.
Even in the absence of any impact by greenhouse gases, precipitation is often of greater concern than temperature. "Human societies suffer much more from declining or irregular water resources than from changes in temperature," Dr. Frank Oldfield, director of the international Past Global Changes project in Bern, Switzerland, wrote in a commentary in Nature.
In general, a warmer atmosphere causes more water to evaporate from the earth's surface. This phenomenon can produce heavier rains, but it can also make droughts worse. Scientists expect both of these to happen in the future, but they are at a loss to predict where and when it will rain less or more.
In any case, Dr. Verschuren said, the effect of global warming on rainfall will probably be small in comparison with the natural variations reported in the new study. Warming in theory could either exacerbate an African drought or alleviate it. "But even if it does alleviate the problem," he said, "it is not going to solve it, because the beneficial effects might be relatively minor compared to the natural variability."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
When a Money Machine Needs a Helping Hand

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Until reports of hundreds of millions of dollars in losses made the headlines, few Americans had ever heard of hedge funds, the invention of Nobel Prize mathematicians that promised to take the risk out of investing in the stock market. To get in on a company formed in 1992 called Long-Term Capital Management, created to bring about that miracle, you had to invest at least $10 million for three years.
For a time, Long-Term Capital, in Greenwich, Conn., was a Wall Street Wunderkind, paying as much as 43 percent in its best year. The rich got richer. But in 1997 the company ran into deep trouble; its investments lost prodigiously until the company was $100 billion in debt and the government and Wall Street, fearing the effects that its collapse would have on economies around the world, joined to save it from its own misjudgments. 
 How this happened is tidily unraveled by "Trillion Dollar Bet," tonight's cautionary tale about the fallibility of experts and the unpredictability of the market.
Turning finance into a science is the holy grail long sought by investors big and small. In the 1970's mathematicians thought they were moving toward that goal with a way to keep one's investment portfolio in perfect balance with a technique they called "dynamic hedging."
For an explanation of how their system worked or was supposed to work, see tonight's "Nova," which spells out somewhat abstruse matters in an admirably lucid way. The upshot of the theoreticians' labors, which brought a Nobel Prize to Myron S. Scholes and Robert C. Merton in 1997, was a way to cancel out all risks by evaluating the price of options, a kind of insurance that permits investors to buy or sell stock at a specific price by a specific date.
Mr. Scholes and Mr. Merton had already joined a bond trader named John W. Meriwether in a new firm, Long-Term Capital Management, that would operate by the rules of their theory. Their reputations quickly brought in $3 billion of investment money to be bet on continuing assessments of the relationship of markets all around the world.
But then, in 1998, came the Asian economic panic, an event that had never been dreamed of in the economists' mathematical models. As one trader says tonight, "The market will test you and do what you don't expect it to do." Stock prices slid and kept sliding; on one day after Russia's economic default in August 1998, Long-Term Capital dropped $500 million and the Federal Reserve organized a $3.6 billion bailout by Wall Street's biggest power brokers.
The simple lesson that the narrator is left with after all the brilliant theorizing of the economists is, "While models can help us manage risk, they can never tell us when to buy or sell." Another lesson is that unless you are a billionaire, nobody is going to bail you out.

HEADLINE: Coolidge's Democratic Disciples

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, former secretary of labor, is professor of social and economic policy at Brandeis University.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE , Mass.

 BODY:
One party claims that the budget surplus will be small and that a central goal should be to eliminate the debt. The other says the surplus will be big and we can do ambitious things with it. You'd be forgiven if you thought that the first party was the Republicans and the second the Democrats. But it is the reverse. The Democrats are marching under the banner of fiscal austerity, and the Republicans are proclaiming this the era of large ambition.
"Here's the facts," said George W. Bush the other day, pointing to the latest estimate from the Congressional Budget Office as showing that the nation could well afford his plan to trim income taxes by $1.3 trillion over 10 years and still have enough money to fund social programs. 
 But President Clinton, in his new budget, released today, claims the surplus that's left over after saving all Social Security receipts is a little more than half that -- $746 billion. The president's estimate is even smaller than the most conservative projection coming out of the Congressional Budget Office, which foresees a 10-year non-Social Security surplus of $838 billion to $1.9 trillion.
The administration's budget also makes retiring the debt the nation's biggest financial priority, aside from saving Social Security. "Let's make America debt-free for the first time since 1835!" the president exulted in his State of the Union Message. His new budget seeks to pay off the entire $3.6 trillion tab by 2013. Granted, the new budget also provides a buffet of attractive policy ideas, few of which will be enacted by this Republican Congress in this election year. Debt elimination trumps all of them.
Meanwhile, Vice President Gore is blasting both Mr. Bush and Bill Bradley for counting on large surpluses -- Mr. Bush to finance a tax cut and Mr. Bradley for spending. Mr. Gore says he'll pursue debt reduction even if the economy slows, "just as a corporation has to cut expenses if revenues fall off," adding that a recession should be viewed as an opportunity to push cuts further "before any other options are considered."
Even House Democratic Leader Dick Gephardt is sounding a bit like Calvin Coolidge these days, saying that "until the money is in the Treasury" Congress shouldn't make new promises and "if and when it materializes" we should use the surplus for Social Security and Medicare. And what of the non-Social Security surplus that Republicans are drooling over? Use that for "paying down the debt and honoring our existing commitments to health and education," he said. But those existing commitments aren't much to write home about.
It would be one thing if the born-again, fiscally austere Democrats were speaking out of strong conviction backed by sound ideas. But the conviction is paper-thin. Eliminating the national debt has not been a plank of any Democratic economic program in living memory, and most Democrats who are now talking gravely about its importance have never uttered the words "eliminate the debt" before.
Besides, eliminating the debt shouldn't be the nation's goal. As long as the debt doesn't rise as a proportion of national product (and by that measure it's been falling now for several years), the important issue isn't how large it is in absolute dollars but what the borrowed money is used for. Borrow to give all our nation's kids good schools and healthy bodies, and that's a smart investment -- no less important to America's future prosperity than any private-sector machinery or real estate made slightly cheaper because interest rates were driven lower by debt repayment.
So why are Democrats sounding like Coolidge Republicans? Despite polls showing dwindling interest in tax cuts, the Democrats remain spooked by the possibility that voters will be attracted to ambitious Republican tax-cutting plans in the fall, and they haven't the confidence to build public support for an equally ambitious program centered on education and health care. When the surpluses first began ballooning, the president dealt a body blow to Republican tax cutters by telling the public the choice was between cutting taxes or saving Social Security. But last year, as the surpluses continued to mount, the Republicans handed the president a $792 billion, 10-year tax cut that wouldn't touch Social Security revenues. The president vetoed that plan, but the die was cast. The White House felt it had no alternative but to play the debt card if the tax cutters were to be stopped in this election year. The rest of the Democratic establishment is falling into line.
The Democrats are wrong on three counts. First, the public isn't nearly as eager for a tax cut as Democrats fear. During the 1990's, incomes soared only at the top rungs of the ladder, so that most tax revenues are now coming from the well-off. Over 30 percent of income tax revenues are now collected from the top 1 percent of earners, 60 percent from the top 10 percent. Every Republican tax-cutting plan gives most of the money back to the people from whence this money came, leaving peanuts for most other Americans -- and the voters know it.
Second, it's plain dangerous to make the elimination of the national debt a core goal of policy. It is dumb on economic grounds ("He should wash his mouth out with soap," Nobel laureate economist Robert Solow was quoted in The Times as saying of Mr. Gore's plan to continue to pay down the debt even when the economy slows). But it also puts the Democrats in a straitjacket when it comes to any future proposal for universal health care or universally good schools.
Which brings us to the third problem for the Democrats. "Eliminate the debt!" is not the sort of cry likely to rally many loyal Democrats to vote next November, or even to ignite many of the passions of independents.
If the Democrats stand for anything, it should be for helping the little guy who's gotten relatively little out of this buoyant economy so far. Not incidentally, little guys include most voting-age Americans. Little guys could get passionate about good health care and good schools. But faced with a choice between tax cuts for the big guys or fiscal austerity, the little guys may well decide stay home.

HEADLINE: Gad Rausing, 77, Swedish Innovator of Beverage Containers

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
A milk carton made Dr. Gad Rausing, who died on Jan. 28 at the age of 77 in Montreux, Switzerland, one of the wealthiest men in the world.
The Swedish-born Dr. Rausing, along with his younger brother, Hans, helped develop their father's idea for a new type of paper carton that extended the shelf life of milk into a global packaging empire, the privately held Tetra Laval Group in Lausanne, Switzerland. 
 The secretive billionaire died after a brief illness, said a company spokesman, Jorgen Haglind, who did not disclose the cause of death.
Gad Rausing's personal fortune -- an estimated net worth of $9 billion, according to Forbes magazine -- grew from the 1952 invention of a tetrahedron-shaped milk carton by his father, Dr. Ruben Rausing.
The Swedish-born Ruben Rausing studied economics at Columbia University and while there took note of the advanced food packaging methods he saw in the United States. Company legend has it that in the 1940's he was watching his wife, Elizabeth, make sausages by tying off the ends, and he wondered if a similar system could be applied to milk.
His attempts, aided by an engineer, Erik Wallenberg, led to a Tetra Pak, a carton made of paper, plastic and aluminum, that eliminated the need for refrigerating milk.
The cartons, now usually shaped more like a small brick and called Tetra Brik, are ubiquitous in Europe. In the United States, the packages are better known simply as the small rectangular juice containers, usually with a built-in plastic straw, that children often take to school.
Dr. Gad Rausing and his brother joined their father's company shortly after the Tetra Pak was invented. Over the next 10 years, they helped the company grow into a conglomerate, selling water purifiers, bank-note dispensers and other products, as well as other types of containers, like Tetra Rex, the gable-topped carton for refrigerated milk that is common in the United States.
In 1965, the family sold every part of the company except for the Tetra Pak. Then, in 1991, the Rausing brothers bought Alfa-Laval, a large packaging group in Sweden, and created Tetra-Laval.
Today, the company, which moved to Switzerland in 1981 to escape Sweden's high inheritance taxes, produces about 85 billion Tetra Paks, Tetra Briks and Tetra Rexes a year, collects about $6.5 billion in sales and has operations in 170 countries.
Gad Rausing was born on May 12, 1922, in Stockholm. At the University of Lund, he earned college degrees in economics and statistics, as well as a doctorate in archaeology.
Dr. Rausing had a lifelong interest in archaeology; his doctoral dissertation was on bows and arrows. He was an expert on prehistoric boats and he financed research and frequent excavations in Sweden, where he was a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Letters, History and Antiquities. He also supported a variety of institutions, among them a chair at Oxford for Icelandic studies.
His wealth made him a target for terrorists and blackmailers, too. In 1969, he received death threats and ransom demands by carrier pigeon. Later, Middle Eastern terrorists in Copenhagen were found guilty of plotting to kidnap his son, Jorn, and hold him for a $25 million ransom.
Besides his son Jorn and his brother Hans, who both live in London, Dr. Rausing is survived by his wife, Birgit; another son, Finn Rausing, of Stockholm; and a daughter, Kirsten Rausing, of England. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Fed Says Consumer Debt Rose in December

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Consumer debt surged in December for the second consecutive month, fueled by holiday spending and capping a year that had the fastest pace of borrowing since 1996, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Consumer credit rose $11.2 billion in December, to $1.4 trillion, after a November gain of $15.8 billion, which was the largest in four years. Borrowing for all of 1999 grew 7.6 percent. That followed a 5.4 percent increase in 1998 and is the largest annual rise since debt climbed 7.9 percent three years earlier. 
 Consumers have supplied the momentum for an economic expansion that became the country's longest this month.
Americans are "bent on spending the windfall" from economic growth, said Vincent Boberski, senior economist at Dain Rauscher in Minneapolis. Consumption should start to fall this year, he said, but "underlying demand continues to be extremely strong."
Analysts had expected consumer borrowing to rise $8.3 billion.
Consumer borrowing rose at an annual rate of 9.7 percent in December compared with a 13.8 percent annual pace during November, according to the Fed.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Demand for Technology Shares Drives Nasdaq to Record

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index cruised to a record yesterday, as demand for technology and biotechnology stocks remained strong.
But the strength in technology masked another lackluster session for most stocks. 
 "Technology and biotechnology are good and everything else is blah," said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald. "The broader market is responding to interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. There will be more of that."
Led by Cisco Systems and Intel, the Nasdaq composite index closed at 4,321.77, up 77.63 points, or 1.8 percent. It was the sixth consecutive advance for the index and the first time it has closed above 4,300.
Weakness in blue-chip companies like General Electric and Alcoa, however, pulled down the Dow Jones industrial average.
The Dow dropped 58.01 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,905.79. Nine of its 30 components gained in price, while the remaining 21 fell. Strong gains in Hewlett-Packard and Intel prevented the Dow from sustaining what would have been a loss of well over 100 points.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was little changed, falling 0.13 point, to 1,424.24. But strength in technology and biotechnology shares helped to bolster the Russell 2000 index of small company stocks.
The Russell, which so far this year has done much better than either the Dow or the S.& P. 500, gained 6.87, or 1.3 percent, to 532.39.
More than 918 million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Nasdaq stock market was 1.6 billion shares.
The continued strength in demand for technology stocks is surprising some analysts, who point to sky-high valuations throughout the sector as well as a long -- and growing -- list of stocks that are trading at bargain-basement levels.
For the moment, at least, it is not an argument that many investors seem to want to hear, or heed.
John Manley, an equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, just returned from visiting clients in Italy.
"The Italians want to be in this market, and they want to own technology," he said. "That is true throughout Europe."
Much the same seems to be true in the American heartland.
"I am having a hard time getting anyone to listen to anything but technology," said Philip S. Dow, a managing director in equity research at Dain Rauscher Wessels in Minneapolis. "Our clients want to be in the right stocks, and they want to be in the ones that are moving."
Cisco Systems, which is expected to issue its quarterly earnings report after the market closes today, certainly qualifies as a mover.
The stock gained 4 1/16 yesterday, closing at 125 3/16. From the close of business on Jan. 28, the stock has risen by more than 20 percent.
Among Dow stocks, General Electric shed 1/16, to 141 11/16. Alcoa fell 2 3/8, to 68 1/8. And Boeing dropped 2 3/16, to 41 13/16.
Those losses were mitigated by big gains in Hewlett-Packard, which jumped 10 3/8, to 128 3/8, and in Intel, which gained 3 3/16, to 107 15/16.
It was a very good day for biotechnology shares, which continued their torrid rise.
Among biotech companies, Amgen gained 4 9/16, to 69 3/16. Genentech jumped 6 1/2, to 150 1/2. And Human Genome rose 26 15/16, to 142 1/16.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Fall Again, With New Issues Coming

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as the Treasury and Vodafone AirTouch led sales of at least $38 billion of debt this week and on expectations for further Federal Reserve interest rate increases.
The government will sell $32 billion of 5-year, 10-year and 30-year securities at its quarterly auctions beginning today. 
 The sales come after selling yesterday and Friday erased much of the biggest two-day rally in almost 13 years.
The rally occurred as the Treasury's debt buyback prompted traders to reverse losing bets that bonds would fall.
The price of the 30-year Treasury fell 2 9/32, to 97 6/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.34 percent from 6.26 percent on Friday.
Thirty-year yields have dropped more than four-tenths of a percentage point since Jan. 20, buoyed by the Treasury's planned debt buyback and reduced government auctions.
Investors had a chance to add to their holdings of corporate debt at a $5.25 billion sale of 5- , 10- and 30-year debt by Vodafone.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 647 words

HEADLINE: Last-Lap Budget

 BODY:
The $1.8 trillion budget proposed by President Clinton yesterday was for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, when he will have only a few months left at the White House. But Mr. Clinton's fiscal priorities could long outlive his tenure. The president called once again for using projected surpluses to shore up Social Security and Medicare, rather than to grant big tax cuts. He would also spend additional money for education and other domestic needs. Republicans in Congress may rewrite the numbers but are unlikely to reorder his priorities in this election year. In part that is because Senator John McCain's challenge to party orthodoxy in his presidential campaign has thrown Republicans on Capitol Hill into disarray.
Coming after his triumphalist State of the Union Message, Mr. Clinton's valedictory Budget Message spent as much time looking backward as forward. The president credited the longest recorded economic boom in American history to the tough decisions he made in 1993 to restrain spending and increase taxes, and in 1997 to accept budget cuts, especially in Medicare, demanded by Congressional Republicans. His Budget Message was a kind of victory lap for policies reviled by many Republicans and in truth not always welcomed by his fellow Democrats. Indeed, Senator Bill Bradley's presidential campaign appeals to those Democrats tired of Mr. Clinton's embrace of spending restraint. 
 The budget was also significant for injecting a dose of reality into budget calculations. Mr. Clinton wisely called for scrapping the unrealistic spending caps enacted by Congress two and a half years ago, which would destroy domestic spending programs if they were ever adhered to. Congress has all but ignored these caps in the last two years, sometimes by employing gimmicks like labeling regular programs as "emergencies" and therefore outside the caps. The much-quoted projection that there will be more than $2 trillion in budget surpluses in the next decade is predicated on these cuts taking place, which is extremely unlikely. It makes more sense to assume that domestic spending will stay pretty much at current levels, growing at something like the rate of inflation, as Mr. Clinton has proposed.
Only last month the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office projected that, if spending remains at these more realistic levels, the 10-year surplus outside the Social Security system will be only $838 billion. Yesterday the president projected a surplus of $746 billion, roughly in the same ballpark.
Either way, that is not enough money to pay for the large tax cut proposed by Gov. George W. Bush in his presidential campaign. The budget numbers suggest instead that Senator McCain is on sounder ground in favoring more limited tax cuts. Congressional Republicans should not be reluctant to go along with these realistic numbers, even if they undercut the presidential candidate most of them seem to favor.
With the presidential race heating up, Democrats and Republicans in Congress are once again divided over whether it is more advantageous to try for budget compromises or to draw lines in the sand and hope to reap the benefits of confrontation. If they choose to compromise, they could make some progress in bolstering Medicare with money for prescription drugs for the elderly, and they could increase spending for education and children, as the White House wants. A small tax cut acceptable to all sides could become part of this mix.
In their hearts, many voters would prefer results rather than confrontation to provide more fodder for campaign commercials. Mr. Clinton's budget does ratchet domestic spending up, but in a modest way that should be acceptable in Congress. Republicans in Congress should be rethinking their demand for big tax cuts, especially now that the issue is not working even in the Republican presidential race. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Austrians Consider the Cost Of Extremism in the Cabinet

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Austrian economists and policy makers fear that the protests and sanctions against the new government could dampen investment in this country and raise capital costs for companies already doing business here.
But the greater concern seems to be Austria's exclusion from European Union deliberations at a time when the 15-nation group is discussing policies crucial to the country's economic future, including the admission of several formerly Communist East European countries that are Austrian neighbors. 
 The consensus here seems to be that the downgrading of relations by the European Union, and the recall of ambassadors by Israel and the United States, because of the inclusion of ministers from the anti-immigrant Freedom Party of Jorg Haider will not have immediate and serious economic consequences. But that could change if Austria's isolation deepens.
For his part, Mr. Haider sought today to play down the impact of his party's inclusion in the government. "We will have a stable situation in a few weeks," he said in an interview on the "Today" program on NBC.
Financial effects of Austria's political isolation were felt last week, when the country's stock indexes dropped around 10 percent on average. Stocks declined 1.3 percent more today to the lowest level in a year. "No one loves a stock exchange in a country with political problems like this," Ronald Kern, a fund manager here with Constantia Privatbank, told Bloomberg News. "The fears are that the last international investors will leave the market and not return for three to six months."
Only the Dow Jones transportation average and the Brussels stock exchange index have performed worse this year, dropping 13.6 percent and 13 percent respectively.
Austria's financial climate was not helped any last Wednesday, after the Dutch bank ABN Amro announced it was suspending a deal to underwrite asset-backed securities for the Austrian province of Carinthia, where Mr. Haider is governor, because of reports that the securities would be used to finance a children's aid program excluding immigrant families.
One of Austria's most vulnerable industries is tourism, and shares in companies dependent on tourism, like Austrian Airlines and Flughafen Wien A.G. the Vienna airport operator, have been dragged down.
Last week, school authorities in Belgium scrapped ski trips to Austrian resorts and a Belgian tourism trade fair canceled an invitation to a northern Austrian resort, Scharding. The Belgian foreign minister, Louis Michel, said skiing in Austria this winter would be "immoral." How many people may heed such admonitions is unclear.
Sabine Koppl, spokeswoman for the Austrian National Tourism Board, acknowledged "scattered cancellations" by tour groups, but said it was too early to fully judge the reaction. Austrian tourism has been booming. In 1999, revenue reached a record $14.2 billion, after $13.8 billion the year before. "We live from tourism as never before," Ms. Koppl said.
Although it may be premature to gauge foreign investors' reaction to Austria's political shift, there have been some signs. Rene Siegl, managing director of the Austrian Business Agency, a government office that seeks to attract direct foreign investment, said the new government was "no catastrophe," yet he conceded there was "quite some demand for explanations" from prospective investors in Japan, Taiwan and the United States. In 1999, the agency helped secure 118 foreign investment deals totaling $271 million, he said.
Bernhard Felderer, the director of the economic research institute IHS, said further stock market weakness would penalize Austrian companies by increasing the cost of capital, forcing them to in effect pay a premium for investment. And the success of the new government depends in part on attracting capital to help privatize much of the country's nationalized industry, including the remaining 75 percent it holds in Telekom Austria A.G.
For the moment, Austria hardly seems in economic crisis. Helmut Kramer, the director of WIFO, another economic research group, said growth this year could reach 3 percent, after 2.2 percent in 1999. But he cautioned that extended exclusion from European Union deliberations could damage Austrian interests, preventing the government from influencing future policy, notably toward European enlargement eastward. Austria borders on Hungary and the Czech Republic, which with Poland are the first three candidates for admission to the European Union.
But labor costs in those countries are roughly one-tenth the level here, Mr. Kramer said, and Austria has been urging its European partners away from an immediate opening of East European labor markets to prevent a flood of cheap labor.
Thus, the sanctions resulting from Mr. Haider's electoral success could hamper Austria in obtaining measures to prevent the increased immigration he opposes. "In representing our interests to the European Union," Mr. Kramer said, "we are severely handicapped."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
After Seattle, Trade Group Scales Back Its Agenda

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization, seeking to move beyond its highly publicized failure in Seattle to start a new round of global trade negotiations, has agreed instead to begin negotiations limited to opening markets in agriculture and services.
In the two months since the collapse of the Seattle meeting, the organization's 135 member countries have been groping for ways to resurrect the effort to convene negotiations aimed at dismantling barriers to global commerce. But the members had been unable to agree on a broad agenda. 
 Bowing to these realities, at least for now, the trade organization formally set out today a blueprint for proceeding with a narrower agenda that would attempt to revamp trade rules for farm goods and services. Countries agreed during the 1993-94 trade negotiations in Uruguay that efforts to widen trade in at least these two areas would begin this year.
"The W.T.O. is back in business," said Mike Moore, the organization's director general, expressing relief that it had broken an impasse. Members had been meeting steadily since early January to lay the groundwork for the meeting today, the first formal session of the organization's governing body, called the General Council.
Delegates have set a framework for negotiations, which will be handled within existing W.T.O. committees. This means negotiations on trade in farm goods will probably start in late March, and services, which include insurance and banking, in late February.
Figures compiled by the trade organization show that agriculture and services account for 65 percent of global output and 80 percent of the world's jobs. Agriculture alone employs half the world's work force, according to recent World Bank statistics.
No deadlines were set, however, for concluding the talks, which means they could drag on for months or even years. Agriculture, in particular, is a difficult issue because countries like France and Japan are firmly opposed to the Australian and American view that farm goods should receive no special treatment that protects domestic producers.
Also still under negotiation is a request by developing nations for extensions of deadlines to honor agreements made in the Uruguay round of talks, particularly in the area of intellectual property rights. This request has become a major source of contention between industrialized and developing countries, and contributed to the collapse of the Seattle meeting.
Developing countries are seeking solutions to help meet their obligations to respect intellectual property rights and upgrade customs valuation methods and investment policies.
In January, the biggest trading powers indicated willingness to extend the Dec. 31, 1999, deadline on an individual country basis.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: The Battle of the Decades;
Reaganomics vs. Clintonomics Is a Central Issue in 2000

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
By the reckoning of the National Bureau of Economic Research, the independent group that has the final say on these matters, the current economic expansion -- as of this month the longest on record -- dates from March 1991.
That was nearly two years before Bill Clinton took office as president. But since his two terms in the White House have largely overlapped the extended run of prosperity, Mr. Clinton and his team have not been shy about claiming their share of credit. They point in particular to the administration's record in balancing the budget, thereby keeping long-term interest rates down, stimulating business investment in efficiency-enhancing technology and creating jobs. 
 While deficit spending gave the economy a temporary and ultimately costly lift in the 1980's, Mr. Clinton said in an interview last week, the economy only went on a sustainable long-term growth path after he pushed a deficit-reduction package through Congress over Republican opposition in 1993.
"When we actually passed it, people could see we were serious, and I think it was just like breaking through a dam," Mr. Clinton said.
But by the reckoning of most Republicans, the current expansion is nothing more than an extension of a growth surge that began early in the Reagan administration. With the exception of a short, shallow recession in late 1990 and early 1991 that coincided with the Persian Gulf war, the economy has grown steadily since November 1982, driven by Reagan-era tax cuts and deregulation, they say.
To the degree that the country's improved fiscal position has helped, they say, it was only pressure from Republicans that forced Mr. Clinton to abandon big spending programs and support aggressive efforts to eliminate the deficit.
"For Bill Clinton to be taking credit for this economic boom we're experiencing is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader.
Lawrence Kudlow, who was an economist in the Reagan administration, said the reductions in marginal income tax rates in the early 1980's and steps to free a variety of industries from price controls and other regulation "opened the door to a tremendous entrepreneurial burst, which has gained momentum and continues."
This current stretch of good times, however framed, clearly has many factors behind it. There have been dizzying advances in computing power and breakthroughs in new technologies. Investors have proved eager to finance even risky new ideas. The nation's work force, strengthened by a huge wave of capital spending, has become much more productive. The Federal Reserve has conducted monetary policy with skill and flexibility. The United States has benefited to some extent from the problems that have plagued much of the rest of the world.
But this is an election year, making it hard to avoid putting the economy and the longevity of this expansion in a political context.
Representing the Clinton boom is Vice President Al Gore, whose economic platform calls for a combination of fiscal conservatism and incremental government activism that is all but identical to the program pursued by Mr. Clinton.
Representing the forces of Reaganism is Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who is running on a big tax cut intended not just to bolster economic growth but to keep politicians in Washington from frittering away the federal budget surplus on what Republicans see as costly and wasteful government programs.
Given the challenge that both front- runners face from within their own parties, especially on fiscal policy, neither camp can be assured of carrying its message into November. On the Democratic side, former Senator Bill Bradley is unapologetically calling for big spending programs to deal with big problems like child poverty and access to health care. Among the Republicans, Senator John McCain of Arizona is making a case that dealing with long-run problems like the solvency of Social Security is more important than tax cuts.
Nonetheless, to a remarkable degree, the economic policy debate this year comes down to the question of the 1980's versus the 1990's -- tax cuts and an emphasis on reducing the size and influence of federal government versus a belief that spending more on priorities like health, education and the environment can coexist with strengthening the national balance sheet.
Economists, never mind politicians, will no doubt argue the merits of both sides for decades. The importance of Washington in shaping the economy has faded in recent years. Still, some credit no doubt goes to both sides, as well as to other players, even some with otherwise poor economic records, like President Jimmy Carter.
Two things happened in the Carter administration that helped shape what came later, said William Niskanen, who was an economist in the Reagan administration and is now chairman of the Cato Institute, a conservative research group.
One was the beginning of a wave of deregulation, starting with the airline industry, that broke a long spell in which the government had steadily taken a more active role in the economy. Over the next decade it spread rapidly through industries including trucking, bus lines, energy and financial services.
The other, Mr. Niskanen said, was President Carter's decision, in 1979, to appoint Paul A. Volcker to lead the Federal Reserve. Although Mr. Carter turned on Mr. Volcker in the early 1980's, Mr. Volcker went on to defeat the high inflation that was crippling the economy, setting the stage for the era of price stability now being managed by Mr. Volcker's successor, Alan Greenspan.
At the same time there was a growing clamor for tax cuts among Republicans in Congress, led by Representative Jack Kemp of Buffalo and Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware.
"The basics were in place for what later became called Reaganomics," Mr. Niskanen said. "Tax rate reductions, deregulation, tight money."
The biggest change after Ronald Reagan's election was the passage in 1981 of the Kemp-Roth tax bill, which sharply lowered marginal income tax rates, cutting the top rate from 70 percent, to 50 percent.
"The Kemp-Roth tax cut became the rallying cry of the Reagan forces, and it's what turned the country around," Mr. Roth said. "It turned the country from a period of pessimism to confidence in the future, and it freed up money that allowed entrepreneurs to take greater risks. That was the opening shot of the period of prosperity."
But the big tax cuts, combined with a big increase in military spending and an unwillingness on the part of Congress to cut domestic spending, sent the budget deficit and the national debt climbing to previously unheard-of levels.
There were many other developments in the 1980's that had a positive influence on the economy, including a drift in both parties toward supporting free trade and a revolution on Wall Street, which came up with new and sophisticated ways to raise money for entrepreneurs and big corporations.
But in the view of many Democrats, the economy that Mr. Clinton inherited in 1993 was little more than a shell, its strength hollowed out by the strain that rapidly growing deficits were creating. While the economy was growing, it was weak, and another recession did not seem out of the question.
President George Bush and Democrats in Congress had agreed on a deficit-reduction package in 1990, but the deficits had continued to increase. Mr. Clinton originally backed a traditional Keynesian stimulus package of new spending to give the economy a boost, but then went all out to bring down interest rates by persuading Wall Street that he was serious about debt reduction.
"We may have gotten out of the recession of the late 70's and early 80's with this massive deficit spending, but to build it structurally into the economy was a big burden," Mr. Clinton said in the interview last week. "We decided we would break it structurally."
Helped by a steadily improving economy, the deficits have melted away since 1993, replaced lately by huge surpluses that could well continue for many years. The national debt is falling, freeing capital for investment in private industry. Democrats credit the 1993 deficit reduction plan, augmented by the 1997 bipartisan balanced budget act, further moves to tear down trade barriers and the updating of legislation governing key industries like telecommunications and financial services.
"All these things, even before they were actually felt, helped to create a mindset of confidence, which it seems to me is critical for keeping the recovery going this long," Mr. Clinton said. Democrats also point out that nearly all Republicans in Congress opposed the 1993 deficit- reduction plan because it raised rates for upper-income taxpayers. Many Republican leaders openly predicted it would ruin the economy.
Should Governor Bush win the White House in the fall and push through a Reagan-sized tax cut, the president added, the country could ultimately be faced again with painful choices: cutting spending, dipping into the Social Security surplus or returning to budget deficits.
"The likeliest thing would be a slow return to the deficit," Mr. Clinton said, "which I think in the world we're living in would be a bad error."

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE GOALS;
One Step at a Time, Clinton Seeks More Help for Poor and Elderly

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The budget unveiled today by President Clinton shows his extraordinary persistence as an architect of domestic policy. In health care and other social programs, he is pursuing many of the same goals as in 1993, though often by different means.
Mr. Clinton is still trying to increase health insurance coverage, still trying to expand eligibility for food stamps, still trying to increase the earned-income tax credit, one of the nation's biggest anti-poverty programs. 
 "They don't call him the comeback kid for nothing," said Edward M. Cooney, a special assistant to the secretary of agriculture, noting how Mr. Clinton has pressed on despite setbacks and detours.
In 1993, his first year in office, Mr. Clinton proposed a big expansion of the food stamp program, and Congress approved much of his proposal. The 1996 welfare law cut food stamp spending, especially benefits for legal immigrants. Mr. Clinton won restoration of some of the cuts for legal immigrants in 1998, and today he asked Congress to restore more.
Mr. Clinton has been even more tenacious on health policy. No longer does he try to guarantee health insurance for all by redesigning the health care system from top to bottom. Rather, he proposes more modest steps to insure a dozen different groups, including workers between jobs, people ages 55 to 64, uninsured parents of children eligible for Medicaid, legal immigrants and low-income women with breast cancer.
In his new budget request, Mr. Clinton offers bigger versions of health care proposals that failed in the last few years, and he asks Congress to spend more money on them, in the hope that the proposals will prove more popular if they are more generous. Mr. Clinton would use anticipated budget surpluses to finance many of his ambitious plans.
Mr. Clinton described his approach in his State of the Union Message last month. "The lesson of our history, and the lesson of the last seven years," he said, "is that great goals are reached step by step, always building on our progress, always gaining ground."
In 1997, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that his original proposal for universal health insurance coverage would not work. But he said: "Maybe we can do it in another way. That's what we've tried to do, a step at a time until eventually we finish this."
Stuart M. Butler, a vice president of the conservative Heritage Foundation, said Mr. Clinton had persuaded Congress to accept major changes in health and domestic policy by pursuing an incremental approach.
"I wouldn't say it's more palatable," Mr. Butler said, "but it's harder to resist. It's directed at very tangible aspects of people's lives. The president can say he's just solving people's problems, not expanding the role of government."
Today, for the third year in a row, Mr. Clinton proposed to let people ages 55 to 64 buy coverage through Medicare. Stung by criticism that the premiums would be too high, Mr. Clinton now proposes tax credits to let people offset 25 percent of the cost. He would, in effect, offer a tax break to encourage people to participate in a government program.
Mr. Clinton also sweetened his proposal to offer prescription drug coverage to all Medicare beneficiaries.
Congress last year balked at the proposal, under which the government would pay half of a beneficiary's drug expenses, with a maximum federal payment of $2,500 a year. Today Mr. Clinton enlarged his proposal, adding coverage for the costs of beneficiaries with very high drug expenses. He gave no details of how he would design or finance such "catastrophic coverage."
Similarly, Mr. Clinton last year proposed a $1,000 tax credit to assist people caring for relatives with chronic illnesses or disabilities. The idea was well received in Congress, but never became law. Today Mr. Clinton proposed to triple the amount of the credit.
The president also returned to one of his favorite programs, the earned-income tax credit, which offers assistance to poor working families. In 1993, Mr. Clinton proposed an expansion of the credit costing $28 billion over five years; Congress approved $20 billion, providing help to 15 million low-income families.
Today Mr. Clinton proposed a further expansion of the tax credit, which would provide relief to 6.8 million families at a cost of $2 billion a year.
From his earliest days in office, Mr. Clinton has been trying to expand Head Start, the development program for preschoolers, with a goal of serving one million youngsters. When he took office in 1993, Head Start was providing health, education and social services to 713,900 children at a cost of $2.8 billion a year. This year 877,000 children participate, and the program has a budget of $5.3 billion.
In his budget request today, Mr. Clinton sought $6.3 billion, for a total enrollment of 950,000 children.
Mr. Clinton has been equally persistent in trying to immunize children against measles, mumps, polio and other diseases.
In 1993, he and Hillary Rodham Clinton said they wanted the federal government to buy up all childhood vaccine and distribute it at no charge to all children. They settled for a program guaranteeing free vaccine for millions of children who were poor or uninsured. But the program went awry when the administration insisted on storing large quantities of vaccine in a federal warehouse.
In 1994, the White House scrapped plans for the warehouse, scaled back the government's role and sought more money to help drug companies distribute vaccine to state health departments and clinics.
Isabelle Claxton, a spokeswoman for Merck & Company, which makes several pediatric vaccines, said: "The lesson is that the marketplace can work. Once you got past the politics, it became clear that the price of individual vaccines was not the main barrier. The Clinton administration reached out to states and worked with them to do a better job of educating physicians and parents to immunize children on time."

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1018 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE STRATEGIST;
McCain Aide's Conservatism Runs Deep

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 7

 BODY:
Senator John McCain has recently been accused by Republican opponents of being a shadow liberal, but no one has ever leveled such a charge against his South Carolina political consultant and the architect of his Southern campaign, Richard M. Quinn.
Where Mr. McCain has policy positions from across the political spectrum, Mr. Quinn is one of the proudest and most vocal conservatives in the South, editing one of the region's most right-wing magazines, Southern Partisan Quarterly Review. Where Mr. McCain has alternately criticized and sympathized with arguments for displaying the Confederate battle flag, Mr. Quinn has helped lead the fight to keep the flag flying over the South Carolina Capitol. 
 Mr. Quinn's political consulting firm, Richard Quinn Associates, has worked for such candidates as Ronald Reagan, Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina and Pat Robertson. At the moment, however, the company is best known for its work supporting the display of the flag in the face of an economic boycott by the N.A.A.C.P. Several state legislators say the company has conducted private polls that show the flag is widely popular in Republican areas, which have persuaded many lawmakers to keep it flying.
One of Mr. Quinn's longtime associates at the magazine, Christopher M. Sullivan, is also the co-chairman of the South Carolina Heritage Coalition, which organized a large pro-flag rally on the statehouse steps last month. Mr. Sullivan's coalition recently began running television advertisements urging voters and legislators to stand up to liberals who are trying to remove the flag. Mr. Quinn's son, Rick Quinn, is majority leader of the South Carolina House of Representatives, where he has been in the forefront of the effort to keep the flag flying.
"Richard Quinn is a key person in the pro-flag movement in South Carolina," said Dwight James, executive director of the South Carolina chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "He and his son have disseminated a great deal of misinformation to keep that flag flying."
Mr. Quinn, in fact, is such a polarizing figure around South Carolina that he has stayed in the background to avoid obscuring his client with a long-running Southern debate. He said today that he would not discuss his position on the flag or as editor-in-chief of the Southern Partisan, which he has led since 1984. In a statement, he disavowed some of the more inflammatory articles it has published.
"I am not the working day-to-day editor of Southern Partisan," he said. "My title as editor in chief is purely honorary. Frankly, I do not personally read the articles before they are printed, and I certainly disagree with many of the opinions expressed by others on the pages of the magazine."
The McCain campaign also issued a statement, saying that Mr. Quinn was a "highly respected South Carolina campaign consultant" who had worked for a variety of Republicans, including some now supporting Mr. McCain's chief rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
A look at some of the articles in Southern Partisan shows why it has become the nation's leading journal of the so-called neo-confederacy movement, publishing scholarly treatises, political interviews and commentary that glorify the Southern traditions underlying the secession movement.
In issue after issue, writers in Southern Partisan vilify Abraham Lincoln and other Union leaders, and venerate the rebel soldiers who fought to secede from the United States. The quarterly regularly takes the position that the Civil War was fought not over slavery, but over the preservation of a Southern way of life that to this day is worth preserving.
The magazine rarely writes about slavery, but when it does, its positions are usually not those of mainstream historians. A review of a book on the slave trade in a 1998 issue, for example, includes this passage: "Mainstream black leaders perpetuate the myth that vicious white slave traders dragged Africans from their idyllic homeland to serve as chattel for arrogant white Americans. Readers of this magazine know otherwise." The review goes on to say that white slave traders were often less brutal than the African warlords who traded their subjects for livestock and herbs.
The magazine also weighs in on more contemporary topics. One issue last year criticized The Miami Herald for publishing a special section devoted to news about gays. "Who knows, maybe Miami will someday be an exclusively gay city," the article said.
Many of the articles, however, are more high-minded historical reviews in the tradition of the Southern agrarian movement, which glorified the South's slow-paced traditions of farms and small towns.
"It goes back to Jefferson's ideal of the yeoman farmer," said Dr. Blease Graham, an authority on Southern history and politics at the University of South Carolina. "They venerate the idea of a lost way of life, the intrusion of the fast-food chains and industrialization on the sense of place in the South. Of course, the grand old days for Southern aristocrats were grim days for African-American slaves, and there's no way that can be reconciled."
Dr. Graham, who knows Mr. Quinn, says the consultant does not hold racist ideas.
"He is actually a thoughtful intellectual with a square head on his shoulders," said Dr. Graham, dean of the university's College of Criminal Justice. "But he has that states'-rights, pro-Southern point of view that some people find disagreeable."
Mr. Quinn, who often finds himself working for candidates opposed by the state's Republican establishment, has rarely been accused of any kind of personal racism. But several black politicians around the state have said that his association with Mr. McCain could diminish the chances that blacks will support Mr. McCain if they vote in the Republican primary on Feb. 19, which is open to all voters.
"If people realize who McCain is associating with, it could hurt him," said state Representative Todd Rutherford, a Democrat from Columbia. "He's lining himself up with positions that offend people."

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Turns Focus to Plans to Ease Upstate Economic Troubles

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: CHEEKTOWAGA, N.Y., Feb. 7

 BODY:
With her official declaration for the United States Senate behind her, Hillary Rodham Clinton flew into a region of New York today that is likely to be a prime battleground in the race this fall, turning her attention to what has long been a dominant concern among voters here: the region's long-suffering economy.
With President Clinton back in Washington, the first lady moved to settle into life as just another candidate running for public office. She gave the first of what aides said would be five speeches between today and Friday, this one offering measures to spur economic growth here, including about $550 million worth of tax incentives and grants to encourage Internet development. She granted three one-on-one interviews with reporters, a notable break with her more cloistered first seven months of traveling the state. She visited a part of New York where Democratic candidates for office always campaign. 
 But she was also trailed by a presidential-size press corps and Secret Service brigade that served as a reminder of just how complicated it is going to be for Mrs. Clinton to be just another candidate running for public office. The most routine of political rituals -- the official airport greeting by local politicians -- turned into a shoulder-to-shoulder commotion as local Democratic officeholders competed for space with television crews from Washington and Secret Service agents trying to maintain security as they waited for Mrs. Clinton's Air Force jet to emerge from the low clouds.
Mrs. Clinton walked into the terminal and climbed onto a marble ledge, where she declared her affinity for this part of New York. "I did grow up on the Great Lakes," she said, referring to Chicago. "I have spent time in western New York. I listened in western New York."
In her policy speech, delivered at a job training center here, Mrs. Clinton laid out what will be one of the major themes of her campaign against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, noting the economic decline of upstate New York and advocating -- in sometimes dry fashion -- a package of programs intended to help the nation, in general, and the region in particular. Her aides said her total program would cost $550 million a year.
Among other things, she called for creation of tax-exempt bonds that would be issued by the federal government to finance creation of lines for high-speed Internet access. She also endorsed grants to pay for creation of broad-band networks in urban and poor rural areas, again to provide the high-speed Internet access that she asserted was key to the upstate economic revival.
"If upstate New York State were an independent state, it would consistently rank in the bottom-fifth of job growth," she said.
Mrs. Clinton's emphasis on measures to, in effect, transform the economy here -- from its traditional if now faltering manufacturing base to one geared to the Internet -- came in addition to a more typical prescription for the region's problems. Like other candidates for statewide office, notably Charles E. Schumer, who was elected to the Senate in 1998, Mrs. Clinton said she would push efforts under way in Washington to deregulate utilities as a way to try to reduce electric costs.
And like other candidates running for Senate, Mrs. Clinton complained that New York taxpayers were sending more money to Washington than they were getting back. She said the historical justification for this, that New York was more prosperous than the rest of he nation, was no longer so.
"Today, New York has the largest gap between the rich and the poor of any state in the United States," she said. "Therefore, it is time for our friends in the rest of the country to return the favor, to change the way business is done in Washington, to give New York its fair share."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the Democrat Mrs. Clinton is running to replace, has issued an annual report keeping track of that disparity. To date, though, no New York senator has had much luck in changing that formula.
In one of the three interviews she did today, with The Associated Press, Mrs. Clinton said she would all but set a litmus test for how she would vote on judges for federal courts. "I can't imagine that I would vote to confirm" someone who opposes abortion rights, she said.
 
Political Attack for a Song
Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign says it was intended to serve just as an innocuous bit of background music. But a 27-year-old Billy Joel song played before she announced her candidacy for the United States Senate on Sunday inspired an extended attack yesterday from her opponent, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
A Billy Joel greatest hits album played for the audience at the campaign event in Purchase, N.Y., included Mr. Joel's 1973 song "Captain Jack," which tells the tale of a frustrated young man who spends a Saturday night listening to music, smoking marijuana and masturbating. "Captain Jack will get you high tonight and take you to your special island," Mr. Joel sings.
Howard Wolfson, a spokesman for Mrs. Clinton's campaign, said the first lady and her campaign staff did not pick the song, which he agreed should not have been played. He said a sound technician chose the song. But Mr. Giuliani said there was no acceptable excuse for the slip-up.
"Everything was written out, everything was planned, and the whole purpose of it was to reinvent Mrs. Clinton," the mayor said of the opening event of Mrs. Clinton's campaign. "And the message that got out, and they say by mistake -- and sometimes, if you read Freud, that can be the most powerful message -- the message that got out by mistake is 'Let's say yes to drugs.' "
Mr. Wolfson said the mayor should be focusing on the issues raised in Mrs. Clinton's speech, like the need for accessible health care and better education.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON'S BUDGET STRESSES SURPLUS AND HAVING IT ALL

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
President Clinton today sent Congress a budget built on the idea that the burgeoning surplus will allow the nation to have it all, from increased spending to tax cuts and big reductions in the national debt.
The president's budget, his eighth and last, calls for additional spending on issues that have long been central to his agenda, including health care, education and the environment as well as increases for the military. 
 At the same time, it stresses fiscal responsibility and maps a path to eliminate the portion of the national debt held by the public over the next 13 years. And it tries to define the size of the surplus in a way that builds Mr. Clinton's priorities into the budget mix for the next decade and leaves Republicans relatively little room to pursue sweeping tax cuts.
Republicans today declared the budget a nonstarter, although they agreed there was a chance that some provisions, like adding prescription drug coverage to Medicare, could be enacted this year.
There is no argument between the parties that projected surpluses, assuming they materialize, present the nation with tremendous opportunities, including a chance to pay down the debt and ensure Social Security's long-term solvency.
But today's exchanges illustrated the continuing deadlock over how to apportion the surplus. Republicans have generally emphasized tax cuts; Democrats have usually called for maintaining or increasing spending, and each has labeled the other's approach a threat to debt repayment and to Social Security.
Mr. Clinton's blueprint is unlikely to break that impasse, and the debate this year is raging not just on Capitol Hill but on the campaign trail, where there are stark divisions within and between the parties.
The budget calls for spending in 2001 of nearly $1.84 trillion, including an increase of 3.9 percent in spending on the third of the budget that covers basic government operations like the military, national parks, education and law enforcement.
That increase, and proposed growth in this discretionary spending of about 2.5 percent a year for the rest of the decade, would, at least by the White House's accounting, cover the costs of initiatives laid out by Mr. Clinton over the past few months. The proposals range from an expansion of scientific research to new training for pre-school teachers.
"It is a balanced budget with a balanced approach to our national priorities," Mr. Cliton said. "It maintains our fiscal discipline, pays down the debt, extends the life of Social Security and Medicare, and invests in our families and our future."
It is also an election year platform, full of programs that Vice President Al Gore, Hillary Rodham Clinton and other Democratic candidates can use to defend themselves, attack their opponents and illustrate their stands on issues.
The programs include aid for hard-pressed farmers and manufacturers, initiatives to enforce gun laws and to fight wage discrimination against women, additional spending on AIDS and biomedical research, and expansions of efforts to reduce child poverty and make health care more accessible and affordable.
"What you have in this budget is an opportunity for politicians to just go out and tell every single group who has any kind of an interest at all, 'Oh, we're taking care of you,' " said Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee. "That's not leadership. It's all things for all people."
In addition to bipartisan support for adding prescription drug coverage to Medicare, there is general agreement on using the portion of the surplus generated by Social Security, estimated by the administration at $2.2 trillion over the next decade, to reduce the portion of the debt, now $3.6 trillion, held by investors in the form of Treasury bonds.
But Republicans derided the administration's overall proposal as a tax-and-spend manifesto that they would discard as they drafted their own tax and spending bills.
"The president's budget is a paradox," said Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois.
"How can we pay down the debt with a budget that substantially expands the size and scope of the federal government?" Mr. Hastert said. "How can we address the issue of tax fairness, when his budget does not substantially ease the marriage tax penalty? How can the era of big government be over when his budget would create close to $350 billion in new government programs?"
The first battle will be over the size of the surplus.
Surplus projections vary based on assumptions about spending, economic growth and other factors. The Congressional Budget Office laid out three estimates last month of the non-Social Security surplus, ranging from $838 billion to $1.9 trillion.
Mr. Clinton's budget said the surplus outside of Social Security would be $746 billion over 10 years, with most of it being generated after 2005.
In its calculations, the White House assumed that discretionary spending over 10 years would grow at slightly less than the rate of inflation. To assume any less growth in spending over that period would be unrealistic and would risk a nasty fiscal surprise down the road, White House officials said. They noted that even Republican-led Congresses have routinely increased spending at a pace above the inflation rate. "Where we start this year has everything to do with where we end up," said Jacob J. Lew, the director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget. "If you start with realistic, honest numbers and make the tough decisions within that framework, we can get to paying off the debt by 2013."
Republicans in Congress have not yet settled on a surplus estimate, but they made clear today that whatever number they did use would assume substantially less spending than Mr. Clinton's budget and would therefore be considerably larger than the administration's surplus projection.
They said the surplus should not be committed to spending increases, that many programs can be trimmed and that the surplus should be calculated to maximize the amount available for tax cuts.
Should Mr. Clinton's surplus figure be adopted, it would severely limit the ability of Republicans to pursue their tax-cutting agenda, and it would make the tax cut being offered by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas in his run for the Republican presidential nomination look excessive. Mr. Bush's plan is estimated to cost at least $1.3 trillion over 10 years.
Republicans were largely silent today on one of the major changes contained in the Clinton budget: its abandonment of the strict spending limits set by the 1997 bipartisan balanced budget act. The caps would have required deep spending cuts in each of the next two years, and although the two parties have found ways around them, killing them completely would once have been politically treacherous for Republicans and Democrats alike.
With deficits but a memory and surpluses piling up, neither party seems inclined to make an issue of the spending caps, and Congress seems likely to change the legislation this year. Administration officials said efforts to keep spending growth below the inflation rate and use the Social Security surplus for debt reduction, should serve as the standard for fiscal discipline.
Mr. Clinton's budget puts a heavy emphasis on shoring up and expanding Medicare, the system of health insurance for the elderly. It would designate $299 billion out of the 10-year surplus projection of $746 billion to go to extending the system's solvency from 2015 under current projections to 2025.
It would also create a $168 billion program over a decade to help retirees pay for prescription drugs, which have become a burden for many older people. Mr. Clinton also designated another $35 billion over a decade to help beneficiaries who face drug bills stemming from a catastrophic illness.
Under pressure from Republicans, Mr. Clinton called for $350 billion in tax cuts, mostly for low-income and middle-income people. But he would offset a portion of the reductions by closing what officials said were $96 billion of corporate tax loopholes -- a step that Republicans and many industry groups said was unfair.
Mr. Clinton's tax proposals include $45 billion over 10 years to reduce the marriage penalty. Republicans in Congress are pressing for marriage penalty relief this year and are pushing for a much bigger package. The House will take up a marriage penalty bill this week worth $182 billion in tax reductions over 10 years.
Many of the initiatives have Mr. Gore's stamp on them. They include a plan to provide more money to towns and cities that lose manufacturing jobs to foreign competition, the proposal to create catastrophic drug coverage within Medicare and a plan to create a national licensing system for handgun owners.
Mr. Bush said Mr. Clinton's proposal "makes my point that surpluses will be spent if we don't have a leader who's willing to cut taxes." Mr. Bush's rival for the Republican nomination, Senator John McCain of Arizona, who has criticized Mr. Bush's tax plan as too big, said he welcomed Mr. Clinton's emphasis on debt reduction and Social Security, but added that he was "concerned about all the new spending programs that he is proposing here."
