HEADLINE: Croatia Elects a Moderate To Follow the Tudjman Era

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Tuesday, Feb. 8

 BODY:
A jocular former leader of the old Yugoslavia was elected on Monday as president, succeeding Franjo Tudjman, who died in December.
The winner, Stipe Mesic, 65, last leader of the collective presidency before Yugoslavia disintegrated in 1991, earned the trust of Croats for his easy manner, his apparent disregard for pretension and his critical attitude toward Croatian nationalism, in sharp contrast to Mr. Tudjman. 
 A happy Mr. Mesic told a cheering crowd at his campaign headquarters that he would concentrate on taking Croatia into the European Union and NATO "as quickly as possible."
His opponent, Drazen Budisa, 51, a former dissident, conceded defeat shortly after the polls closed and early results showed Mr. Mesic with a large lead.
"I think the moment has come for me to congratulate Mr. Mesic on his victory and to wish him a lot of success in carrying out the presidential duties," Mr. Budisa said.
With 99 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Mesic had 56.2 percent to Mr. Budisa's 43.8, the State Electoral Commission announced early today. The turnout was 61.5 percent of the 4.2 million voters.
In the first round of the election, on Jan. 24, Mr. Mesic received 41.6 percent of the vote in a nine-party field, and Mr. Budisa had 28.
Both men are pro-Western and relatively liberal, favoring membership in the European Union and NATO, and both are part of the six-party opposition coalition that won parliamentary elections a month ago, defeating Mr. Tudjman's once-dominant Croatian Democratic Union.
American and European officials had said that they would be pleased if either man won, especially after the strained and contentious relationship they had with Mr. Tudjman.
The election both ends and starts an extraordinary period of change here, a period that Washington hopes will be a model for neighboring Serbia, run by President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.
Beginning with Mr. Tudjman's lingering illness and death last year, the Croatian Democratic Union that he founded and that led the state since independence from Yugoslavia in 1991 has been swept out of all the major government institutions by democratic means.
With a serious democratic alternative presented by a largely united six-party opposition coalition, Croats voted in big numbers to turn their backs on their fiercely nationalist past, its tenor and repressions founded in the Yugoslav civil wars.
With Mr. Tudjman's party tainted with charges of corruption and the economy deeply troubled by unemployment and unpaid wages and pensions, the opposition won a large victory in parliamentary elections on Jan. 3.
Prime Minister Ivica Racan took office on Jan. 27 and has already moved to soften nationalist policies, free up the media, support democratic and human rights, and promote economic discipline and sacrifice.
In the first round of presidential voting, even the relatively moderate candidate of the Croatian Democratic Union, Mate Granic, finished in a poor third place, failing to qualify for the runoff.
The party, known by its initials of H.D.Z., is wounded and is likely to split. In an interview last week, Mr. Racan said he feared that the rapid collapse of Mr. Tudjman's party was risky, because that would weaken the opposition that all governments need.
"In a way, the H.D.Z. is falling apart too soon for the democratic life of the country," Mr. Racan said.
He said he wanted his main coalition partner, Mr. Budisa, to win, and described Mr. Mesic's appeal as "populism with a smiling face." But Mr. Racan said that both men were democrats and that he could work well with either.
The real turning point was the opposition's victory in the parliamentary vote. Both Mr. Mesic and Mr. Budisa have promised to work to cut back the powers of the imperial presidency that Mr. Tudjman built for himself and to make Croatia a parliamentary democracy.
Still, both men want the president to retain the position of commander in chief and to have an important, if still vague, role in foreign policy and national security. Part of the campaign debate focused on whether Mr. Budisa or Mr. Mesic were harboring secret ambitions or agendas and which one might work more easily with Mr. Racan.
Mr. Mesic is less nationalist than Mr. Budisa, and he has explicitly warned Bosnian Croats that they have to learn to live in Bosnia and not look to Zagreb for financial and military support. By doing so, Mr. Mesic ensured the opposition of H.D.Z. voters, who are especially strong in Bosnia, where ethnic Croats can vote in elections here. Mr. Mesic and Mr. Racan want to stop that, too.
Mr. Mesic's aides were particularly concerned about the possibility of widespread vote fraud in Bosnia organized by the H.D.Z. and its Bosnian allies. But voting went smoothly there, officials said, especially after the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe had criticized fraud in the first round and had asked the Croatian state electoral commission to replace its observers.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Bush and McCain Vie on Truth

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:

The airwaves are getting uglier in South Carolina. On Friday, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas introduced a sharply worded 30-second spot that attacks his principal opponent, Senator John McCain of Arizona, for what Mr. Bush says were distorted statements about his tax-cut plan in an earlier advertisement by the McCain campaign.
Yesterday, in response, Mr. McCain began broadcasting a 30-second commercial that attacks Mr. Bush for having attacked Mr. McCain. Its tag line contains the toughest language of any advertisement by any major candidate so far this year: "Do we really want another politician in the White House America can't trust?"

ON THE SCREEN Photos of the events described.
VOICEOVER "This is George Bush's ad promising America he'd run a positive campaign. This is George Bush shaking hands with John McCain, promising not to run a negative campaign. This is George Bush's new negative ad attacking John McCain and distorting his position. Do we really want another politician in the White House America can't trust?"
 
ACCURACY What started this video set-to was a McCain advertisement, titled "Every Dime," that ran in New Hampshire and later in South Carolina. In it, Mr. McCain says that "the one big difference between me and the others" is that "I won't take every last dime of the surplus and spend it on tax cuts that mostly benefit the wealthy."
The Bush and McCain campaigns have offered dueling tax-cut proposals. Mr. Bush's plan is for $483 billion in cuts over five years; Mr. McCain's amounts to less than half that. Mr. McCain has criticized Mr. Bush's plan as not reserving, as he says his does, money to protect Social Security. Mr. Bush's spot, however, never explains what is not truthful about Mr. McCain's original commercial. And his assertion that Mr. McCain's economic adviser, Vin Weber, actually supports Mr. Bush's tax-cut proposal has been condemned by Mr. Weber as the act of "a desperate campaign."
Mr. McCain's new commercial cites Mr. Bush's promising to run a positive campaign. This falls into the "eye of the beholder" category. Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain did shake hands and repeatedly vow not to attack each other. Each side is now portraying the other as the deal-breaker.
 
SCORECARD An object lesson in how sunshine gives way to darkness quickly in a presidential campaign. The peevish tone in Mr. Bush's commercial is a decided departure from the glossy, statesmanlike sheen of his previous spots, a reflection of his announced desire to refocus his strategy in the aftermath of his poor New Hampshire showing. A subtly key phrase in Mr. Bush's advertisement is "and McCain knows it." It is a shorthand suggestion that Mr. McCain is not the reform-minded idealist he tries to project.
The bottom line in both spots is the suggestion that "going negative" in a campaign is not simply a tactic, it is a moral flaw. Mr. McCain's reply spot raises the ante, throwing the increasingly frequently used insult of the 2000 campaign -- My opponent is just like President Clinton -- back in Mr. Bush's face. And its concluding thought about untrustworthiness seems to send this race to the realm of personal attack. PETER MARKS

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: PENTAGON SPENDING;
Chief Themes of Military Budget: Modernizing and Troop Welfare

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The $291.1 billion Pentagon budget proposed by the Clinton administration today not only reflects peacetime concerns about improving the lives of those who serve but also looks ahead to the challenges of a national antimissile defense and quick-and-dirty regional combat.
The budget, for the fiscal year that will begin on Oct. 1, calls for a 3.7 percent increase in military pay on top of last year's increase, which brought the troops their first raise after inflation since the end of the cold war. 
 New in the budget proposal is an increase in the housing allowances paid to all service members who live off base. The Defense Department would increase those allowances by $3 billion over the next five years, meaning that at the end of that period, personnel living off base would no longer have any out-of-pocket housing expenses. The Pentagon would also push ahead programs to improve on-base housing.
While the budget would add $369 million next year to the Pentagon's medical care program, top officials of the department have yet to agree on a plan providing health care coverage to retirees. Gen. Henry H. Shelton, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has failed to persuade Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen to approve a new $3-billion-a-year program to cover retirees' health care costs, even though both men consider such coverage an obligation of the military.
"All of the options we've looked at are quite expensive," Mr. Cohen said in presenting the budget today.
The military's Kosovo campaign, which brought $2 billion in emergency costs, revealed shortcomings in the services' war-fighting abilities and helped shape the new budget, with its accent on modern weaponry.
In particular, this budget finds the Army, which had serious difficulties deploying its Apache helicopters to Albania, unveiling dramatic changes for the sake of modernization. To make its forces more mobile, the Army has cut by half the financing for its fledgling Crusader artillery system until officials are convinced that it can be built light enough for quick deployment.
In addition, the Army has scrapped plans to build two new vehicles, the Wolverine and the Grizzley, which among other uses would have cleared minefields and knocked down bridges. Instead, the service will spend $14.5 billion to create new weaponry, particularly a mobile, lightweight armored vehicle that could be used for combat in small-scale conflicts as well as major wars.
The Navy has also reordered its budget, to spend more than $3 billion on development of a new destroyer powered by electric motor, a ship that Secretary of the Navy Richard Danzig has said will become a model for the future fleet.
As for the Air Force, it had expected approval of all its plans to build new fighter jets, given the successful air campaign in Kosovo. Instead, Congress last year scaled back production of the F-22 fighter for the current fiscal year, in protest of the plane's escalating costs. Now the Air Force proposes to put the F-22 back on schedule by spending $4 billion on the program next year, with plans to buy as many as 36 planes a year by 2004.
In all, the amount sought to develop various new weapons systems for the military as a whole is $60 billion. The budget also calls for $1.9 billion to be spent on a national antimissile defense system should President Clinton decide to build one, to protect the nation from limited nuclear attack.
The two leading Republican presidential candidates, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Senator John McCain of Arizona, have both argued that military spending is too low. But for the current fiscal year, spending rose by $17 billion, a figure that amounted to the end of the so-called peace dividend, which had brought nearly 10 years of shrinking armed forces and military budgets. The budget proposed today is $13.5 billion more than the current year's.
All those figures are in requested budget authority. The administration's estimate of actual Pentagon outlays in the next fiscal year is $279 billion. When committed contract costs for long-term procurement programs are added, however, the figure rises to the $291.1 billion in the budget proposal that Secretary Cohen presented today.

HEADLINE: Pitching Democrats' Cause, Rangel Advances His Own

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
There is a jingle to Representative Charles B. Rangel's step now, a little like the ka-ching of a cash register swallowing up dollar bills.
"They throw it at me," Mr. Rangel said, only half-kidding, about the money he is collecting to win back control of the House for the Democrats. 
 The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, which is in charge of raising money and spending it strategically to win this year's crucial House races, is awash in money. In a remarkable turnaround, the group had $19.8 million as of Dec. 31, more than double the amount of cash in the bank that its Republican counterpart in the House had. And, in a year of staggering war chests, it has socked away more money than any other party committee, Republican or Democrat.
Few Democratic members have helped raise more cash this year than Mr. Rangel, the 15-term congressman from Harlem with the gravelly voice, wry sense of humor and a bygone aversion to campaign fund-raising. And few members stand to benefit as directly from a Democratic victory as Mr. Rangel, who is now the senior member of the New York Congressional delegation and would become chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which shapes tax, Social Security and Medicare policy.
In a field cluttered with money-raising schemes, Mr. Rangel, 69, has tapped into a novel fund-raising combination. He has by turns reached out to old money -- from traditional Democratic sources in the business world -- and new money, much of it from a burgeoning group of wealthy African-Americans.
"It's new money," Erik Smith, a spokesman for the Democratic House campaign committee, said about the $2.5 million that Mr. Rangel raised last year. "There is a term called 'hitting a new vein.' And that's what he's been doing."
The House Republican fund-raising arm brought in more money than the Democrats last year -- $51 million to the Democrats' $33.4 million -- but spent all but $8.3 million, leaving the Democrats with a significant advantage as the election year began. Democratic leaders said some of the donations came from donors who traditionally give only to Republicans, perhaps hedging their bets on the possibility that Democrats could regain control of the House in November.
Mr. Rangel's pitch is straightforward, more blunt than suave. And it inevitably focuses on his possible ascendancy to the tax-writing committee's chairmanship.
"What Charlie is selling is one of the most powerful positions in the Congress, if not the government," said Robert Johnson, the chairman of Black Entertainment Television Holdings, who is a contributor.
In his pitches to African-American business leaders, who historically have not focused their giving on House races, Mr. Rangel asks them to picture a House where black lawmakers would hold unprecedented sway: himself at the helm of the Ways and Means Committee, Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan as chairman of the Judiciary Committee and 19 other black members in control of various subcommittees.
Chief executives, who relish a tax cut of any size and usually donate more money to Republicans, are often reeled in when Mr. Rangel asks a hypothetical question: What if? And it has been effective. More Republicans are sending money the Democrats' way.
In just the last few months, Mr. Rangel said he had sat down with a few unnamed, rich corporate heads in luxurious private clubs, simply because they wanted to get to know him better.
"With the black community, he relies on a combination of pride and power," Mr. Johnson said. "And in the white community, he says, 'Don't you want to hedge your bet on who will be chairman?' People are putting safe money in his hands and pride money in his hands."
Mr. Rangel is so popular in his district -- New York's 15th, which includes all of Harlem and some of the Upper West Side -- that he has seldom had to raise money for his own elections and none of the current $19.8 million is for himself. He is also involved in a get-out-the-vote plan hatched by Bill Lynch, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, that proved successful in the 1998 elections. He travels to swing districts where black voters can make a difference and asks them to turn out on Election Day, in much the same way the Christian right does with its supporters.
But his cross-country fund-raising trips have served another purpose: to build a national reputation for a man who is headed into his 30th year in Congress. While Mr. Rangel has been a household name in New York, his name does not always ring a bell elsewhere. He is a liberal and a partisan Democrat, and is rightly perceived that way, but he also is letting people see a third side: that of the pragmatist, with a rapier wit, who can juggle the concerns of the poor with the interests of the rich.
"A lot of people didn't know him in the business community," said Representative Martin Frost, a Texas Democrat and former campaign committee chairman. "They have certain preconceptions about a congressman from Harlem, but when they meet him and talk to him, they are blown away."
Some in the business world, however, are not as keen about Mr. Rangel's becoming the Ways and Means chairman, and they are actively working for Republicans to prevent it. They offer the same pitch to their constituents that Mr. Rangel does to his: Imagine this congressman as chairman.
"It would be an unmitigated disaster," said Brian Reardon, who handles federal public policy for the National Federation of Independent Business. "He doesn't support small business and he never met a tax he didn't like."
Mr. Rangel says nobody ever complains to him. But why would they, he adds. He shrugs it off by pointing to the political friends he has among New York's banking, Wall Street and real estate moguls.
"I think my chairmanship would shatter the vestiges of racism overnight," Mr. Rangel said. "There are people that absolutely become colorblind when they got a problem."
"They have no idea how much I want to preserve the economy and make it grow," Mr. Rangel added. "What good is civil rights during a depression? What good is a decent education if you have no jobs? Why would you fight against drug addiction if you were not providing hope on the other hand?"
Sanford I. Weill, the chairman and co-chief executive of Citigroup, says Mr. Rangel does not give business concerns short shrift.
"When you have an issue, he's somebody you can talk to," Mr. Weill said. "And if what you're saying makes sense, he's supportive."
Charles Bernard Rangel was born on June 11, 1930, to a Harlem factory seamstress and a father he barely knew. A high school dropout, he eventually joined the Army and fought in the Korean War, where he rescued 40 men from behind enemy lines. He was decorated with the Purple Heart and the Bronze Star.
In 1995, when the Democrats lost control of the House, Mr. Rangel, who was once considered the least ideological black member, proclaimed a new era for himself as an "oratorical bomb-thrower." He was angry at the Democratic leadership and angry at President Clinton. And he bemoaned the turn the nation was taking with welfare.
Mr. Rangel still says he is fiery, but much of that is simply his role as an agent provocateur in the minority. He enjoys needling the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, whom he sometimes compares to Dreyfus, Inspector Clouseau's sputtering, foiled-again superior. He also once likened Mr. Archer to Hitler, something the chairman did not forget.
"I guess you would call it strong humor," said Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., a conservative Florida Republican on the committee who is friendly with Mr. Rangel. "Some may call it ruthless humor."
Mr. Rangel staunchly defended Mr. Clinton in the impeachment proceedings, saying Republicans were more guilty of high crimes and misdemeanors than the president when they failed to support Mr. Clinton's decision to bomb Iraqi military sites in December 1998.
Mr. Rangel's colleagues on the Ways and Means Committee say Mr. Archer has made his mark in the last few years, helping to keep his party unified in committee and reaching out to more conservative Democrats. Despite his run-ins with Mr. Archer, Mr. Rangel sometimes works closely with other Republicans, including Mr. Shaw.
In a recent speech before the National Federation of Retailers in New York City, Mr. Rangel struck a chord that is seldom heard on Capitol Hill.
"The truth of the matter is, if you're talking about Medicare and you're talking about Social Security and a real large tax bill, the Democrats cannot have this and neither can the Republicans unless we work together," he said. "This is not a spirit of bipartisanship. This is a spirit of common sense."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: NEW YORK;
A Rested Gore Goes After Hard-Hat and High-Hat Votes

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE with DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
After a two-day respite from the campaign trail, Vice President Al Gore stepped up his New York campaign in earnest yesterday, paying homage to the labor unions he is counting on to mobilize for him in the March 7 primary and spending the evening courting arts patrons at Lincoln Center.
On stage at Avery Fisher Hall last night, Mr. Gore narrated Aaron Copland's 1942 classic, "Lincoln Portrait," accompanied by the American Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Leon Botstein. 
 The platform would be the envy of any politician, with the chance to read Lincoln's immortal words, including the Gettysburg Address, with rolling timpani and rising horns.
"Fellow citizens, we cannot escape history," Mr. Gore read in an inadvertent reminder of President Clinton's travails that sent a ripple through the audience, "We in this Congress and this administration will be remembered in spite of ourselves."
Mr. Gore spoke for about eight minutes, applauded the conductor and gave a slight bow to the orchestra, drawing a standing ovation.
His performance at the concert, a benefit for seven charities in New York, followed a day of supplications to organized labor and a renewed attack on Bill Bradley, his rival for the Democratic presidential nomination.
In recognition of Mr. Bradley's popularity here from his days as a star basketball player and a senator from New Jersey, Mr. Gore took on his proposals, particularly on health care, education and the budget surplus, saying they would be bad for New York.
New York is seen as Mr. Bradley's best hope for a breakthrough after his losses to the vice president in Iowa and New Hampshire, and Mr. Gore made it clear yesterday that he was not going to give Mr. Bradley an inch of breathing room. His line of attack was tailor-made for hard-core Democrats in New York, playing on party loyalty and the economic success of the Clinton administration.
"I want to describe to you one of the big differences between myself and my opponent in the Democratic primary," Mr. Gore told about 1,000 people in Lower Manhattan at the headquarters of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
"I don't believe that you can run for the Democratic nomination by running down the progress and achievements of the Democratic Party over the past seven years," he said, "because in fact our policies have been good for this country."
Asked later if he would campaign in New York with President Clinton, Mr. Gore said, "I've got to win this race on my own, and I'm campaigning on my own vision."
Asked if he would campaign with Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is running for the Senate in New York, Mr. Gore said: "It's a matter of scheduling, not just me, but also her. I hope so. But that's yet to be worked out."
While Mr. Gore was courting New York Democrats, Mr. Bradley appeared in Tampa, Fla., and took aim at the Republican governor, Jeb Bush, who signed an executive order last year ending affirmation action in the state. Mr. Bradley has long been a staunch defender of affirmative action, as has Mr. Gore. But by choosing to attack Mr. Bush, the brother of the Republican presidential candidate George W. Bush, he gave notice that he was prepared to take on any elected official or presidential candidate or relative of a presidential candidate in his uphill fight for the nomination.
"I think that he has demonstrated a lack of vision and leadership by repealing affirmative action in the state of Florida," Mr. Bradley said of Jeb Bush at a raucously supportive town hall meeting here.
Mr. Bradley's brief appearance in Florida, whose primary is March 14, was the second in two days focusing on race relations. On Sunday, he visited a large black church in Queens, and on Tuesday he will appear in South Carolina to criticize the Confederate battle flag's presence over the State Capitol.
In his appearance before the labor group, Mr. Gore attacked Mr. Bradley for having retired from the Senate in 1996 instead of fighting against what Mr. Gore called the Gingrich Congress. "When he retired from the Senate during President Clinton's first term, Senator Bradley spoke about what he called a budget stalemate and a process that was, in his words, paralyzed, a continual deadlock," Mr. Gore said. "And so he decided to leave. But he was wrong. We broke that deadlock."
He added: "If Senator Bradley could not foresee the progress that we made when we decided to stay and fight against the Gingrich Republicans, what else does he not see now? How can he be counted on to see what is right for working families today?"
Mr. Gore's remarks seemed to turn the tables on a question Mr. Bradley has been asking about Mr. Gore, whom he has accused of waging a campaign of distortions and falsehoods. If Mr. Gore cannot tell the truth as a candidate, Mr. Bradley has been asking audiences, how can the nation expect him to tell the truth as president? And now Mr. Gore is asking about Mr. Bradley: If he did not fight the good fight a few years ago, how can the nation expect him to fight as president?
Mr. Gore also said that Mr. Bradley's health-care proposal would "eliminate Medicaid for more than three million New Yorkers who depend on it, people with disabilities, people with AIDS, the elderly, in nursing homes," substituting vouchers or subsidies of $150 a month. "See if you can find a health-care plan in New York for $150 a month that pays your prescription drug benefits as Medicaid does, that pays the kind of benefits that Medicaid pays," he said.
Union members account for 30 percent to 40 percent of the Democratic primary vote in New York, much higher than they figured in Iowa and New Hampshire, and they drew most of Mr. Gore's attention yesterday. He began with an appearance via satellite at the United Food and Commercial Workers meeting in Naples, Fla., then met at his hotel with about 65 labor leaders from across New York State.
He later went to a construction site at 63rd Street and West End Avenue, shaking hands with carpenters and masons.

HEADLINE: Internet Company Plans a Queens Center With 450 Jobs

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Queens gained a new share of the high-tech job expansion under way in New York City as Psinet, an Internet service provider, announced yesterday that it would open a $250 million sales and service center in Long Island City that would create 450 new jobs.
"We could have put it anywhere, including the desert," said Psinet's founder and chairman, William L. Schrader, who made the announcement alongside Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Borough President Claire Shulman. "But the best place in the world is right here." 
 Psinet, of Herndon, Va., provides corporate customers with high-speed access to the Internet. It is also a "Web hosting center" where clients as diverse as the Franklin Mint and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration can base their large and heavily used Internet sites. Its Web site is www.psinet.com/.
The 300,000-square-foot complex, slated to open by the summer of 2001 at an undisclosed location in Long Island City, will also be the hub for a new trans-Atlantic link providing direct, high-speed connections between New York, London and Paris, company officials said.
The city is offering Psinet the equivalent of $60 million worth of incentives over the next 15 years, including a $1,000-a-year corporate income-tax credit for each new employee and a partial exemption on real-estate taxes on its building, city officials said.
Citywide, employment in so-called new media firms has jumped from about 55,000 in 1997 to more than 100,000 today, with about 3,000 new media firms operating this year, said Michael G. Carey, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation.
"This is really connecting up Queens and other parts of New York City with Silicon Alley," he said, using the nickname for Manhattan's concentration of Internet-related firms.
Mr. Giuliani took the opportunity to again praise the record job growth in the city last year, a frequent theme in his bid for the United States Senate. The mayor suggested yesterday that the Psinet announcement showed that the city's employment surge was continuing.
"Not only are these a lot of new jobs, they are high-paying jobs, good jobs and the kind of jobs that really spur on the rest of the economy," the mayor said, noting that the 2.7 percent increase in jobs in New York City last year exceeded the national average of 2.3 percent in the rest of the United States. Psinet executives said entry-level technicians would be paid $60,000, while sales executives could receive salaries and commissions up to $333,000, based on the estimate of the market.
Psinet, a NASDAQ-traded firm that employs more than 3,500 people in 26 countries, opened its first New York City Web-hosting site in October on Whitehall Street in Lower Manhattan, intending to offer service to the many Internet-related and financial firms doing business in the city. Some crucial details about the new plant are still being worked out, including a final lease. Psinet executives say they expect that the Internet economy will continue to grow.
"It's fantastic news for your new digital entrepreneurs, who will now have easy access to one of the most advanced Web-hosting facilities in the world," Mr. Schrader said.
Mrs. Shulman joked that she did not exactly understand what Psinet does, but that the benefits it would bring to her constituents were clear. "I understand the kind of salaries these people will earn," she said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ralph Lauren and NBC Form A Joint Multimedia Venture
NBC and its Internet affiliates will join Polo Ralph Lauren in a new media company that will promote the designer's products online and on the air. The deal, a coup for Mr. Lauren, will further blur the line between content and commerce at traditional media companies. 
 The first and foremost task of the joint venture will be to develop Polo.com, which is being billed as an upscale lifestyle destination site. Eventually, the company, RL Media, might develop magazines or even TV programming for NBC. Advertising. Page C13.
 
G.M. Promotes a Cadillac Executive
John F. Smith, charged three years ago with fixing the Cadillac division at General Motors, was named general manager of the parent company's service and parts operations. The unit, which sells G.M. and AC-Delco parts and accessories worldwide and markets the Goodwrench service brand name, has 12,000 employees. Mr. Smith, 49, presided over a redesign of the Cadillac line, but most of the new cars will not appear in showrooms for another two years. C12.
 
Yahoo Site Suffers a Service Failure
Yahoo blamed an attack by computer hackers for a service failure on its Web site, in what amounted to a rare interruption to one of the most popular Internet portals. C11.
 
Nasdaq Tops 4,300 for First Time
The Nasdaq composite index cruised to a record, as demand for technology and biotechnology stocks remained strong. But the strength in technology masked another lackluster session for most stocks. The Nasdaq closed at 4,321.77, up 77.63 points, or 1.8 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 58.01 points, to 10,905.79. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was little changed, falling 0.13 point, to 1,424.24. C16.
 
Consumer Borrowing Surges in U.S.
Consumer debt surged in December for the second consecutive month, fueled by holiday spending and capping a year that had the fastest pace of borrowing since 1996, Federal Reserve figures showed. C2.
 
Austria Fears Fallout From Sanctions
Austrian policy makers fear that the protests and sanctions against the new government could dampen investment in their country and raise capital costs for companies already doing business there. But the consensus seems to be that the downgrading of relations by the European Union, and the recall of ambassadors by Israel and the United States, because of the inclusion of ministers from the anti-immigrant Freedom Party of Jorg Haider, will not have immediate and serious economic consequences. C4.
 
Chevron and Phillips Form Venture
Phillips Petroleum and Chevron have agreed to a joint venture of their chemical businesses, creating a company with assets of more than $6 billion. C14.
 
PBS Appoints a New President
The Public Broadcasting Service announced the appointment of Pat Mitchell, a longtime news producer and executive for Turner Broadcasting, as its president. Ms. Mitchell, the president of CNN Productions, the documentary arm of the cable network, will be responsible for navigating PBS through an increasingly difficult landscape, marked by competition from cable channels and continued pressure to raise funds from both the federal government and corporations. A18.
 
W.T.O. Agrees to Limited Talks
The World Trade Organization, seeking to move beyond its highly publicized failure in Seattle to start a new round of global trade negotiations, has agreed instead to begin negotiations limited to opening markets in agriculture and services. C4.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Giuliani Courts Upstate Voters

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:

This is a new 30-second commercial that the Giuliani campaign began broadcasting throughout upstate New York on Thursday.
 
PRODUCER -- The Victory Group, Inc.
 
ON THE SCREEN -- The advertisement opens with vistas of gold and orange fall foliage in New York State, a lone kayaker paddling on the Erie Canal, a farmer driving a tractor through a field. Then there is a succession of images of people at work: a man cleaning the propeller of a small airplane, a welder in protective suit wielding a propane torch, a doctor and nurses walking along a hospital hallway. The scene shifts to a clip of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in an office followed by a brief black and white image of him at an outdoor news conference. There are scenes of workers in New York City, including two men in hard hats at a skyscraper construction site, and finally the commercial returns to upstate images. There are seven versions of the commercial, and each ends with a shot of a geographical landmark in the region the version is aimed at.
 
THE SCRIPT -- Mr. Giuliani: "The foundation of our freedom depends on steady, good-paying jobs because jobs keep our neighborhoods strong and our families together. But when jobs aren't there and our children have to move away, it can be devastating. That's why we pulled together and got moving, by creating 360,000 new jobs, convincing major employers not to move and by cutting billions in unfair taxes."
 
ACCURACY -- The commercial conveys what Mr. Giuliani considers to be a hallmark achievement of his tenure: the creation of hundreds of thousands of new jobs in New York City. Critics of the mayor would argue that he should not be given credit for economic happenstance. The truth is that the Giuliani administration and the City Council deserve credit for fiscal policies, including substantial tax cuts. While Mr. Giuliani has provided hundreds of millions of dollars in tax abatements and other incentives to keep businesses from leaving New York, some of that has been criticized as corporate welfare.
 
SCORECARD -- The advertisement effectively taps into what may be the most important issue to voters in upstate New York, the still sluggish economy that has not improved as much as other areas have. Mr. Giuliani says pointedly, "When jobs aren't there and our families have to move away, it can be devastating." One opinion poll after another has shown that people throughout upstate New York are extremely frustrated because their children must look elsewhere for good jobs. Still, by pointing out how much better New York City has fared than the rest of the state, the commercial risks reigniting the resentment of the city. Also notable is the racial diversity of people portrayed in the commercial, which was lacking in some earlier Giuliani spots. DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

HEADLINE: IDEAS INTO ACTION;
Regarding Customers as Business Collaborators

BYLINE: By FRED ANDREWS; This column about management issues appears every other week. Fred Andrews's e-mail address is frandrew@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
C.K. PRAHALAD believes a Copernican revolution is putting the consumer at the active center of the business universe. That is his vision of the Internet economy, and he isn't by himself.
Why listen to Professor Prahalad? A decade ago, he and a colleague, Gary Hamel, opened up new pathways in business thinking with a relatively simple but powerful idea. In their book "Competing for the Future" (Harvard Business School Press), they said that a business should think of itself not as boxes on an organization chart but as a collection of skills, or competences, that cut across internal boundaries. Break down those boxes, they said. 
 Most critical was that a company truly understand its "core competences" -- the skills and technology unique to it, the strengths that paid the rent and positioned the company to attack new markets. These were "the soul of the company."
That concept found a permanent place in the business vocabulary. Today, it is hard to find an enterprise of any sort that has not put considerable energy into figuring out its core competences, separating what is fundamental from what is not.
Now the Internet economy has forced a rethinking of what to look for and where to look for it, just as the astronomer Copernicus challenged the orthodoxies of 16th-century European science.
Look outward, not inward, Professor Prahalad urges. See yourself as others see you. A vital source of strength, maybe the most vital, lies in the untapped power of your customers to exploit the Internet. The flood of product information to them, the ease with which they can sort through it and the potential they have for uniting with other Internet users all combine to shift the balance of market power decisively toward the consumer, he maintains.
"We are saying that consumers are going to drive the firm," Professor Prahalad, who teaches at the University of Michigan Business School, said by telephone last week. Consumers are already doing that, he said, at Internet companies, which started up without the baggage of traditional ways of doing business.
Of course, businesses have always tried to figure out their customers. But the Internet world allows customers to take initiative, to talk back, assert preferences and flow quickly to the most responsive sellers. The new task for business is discovering how to channel that power. To succeed, Professor Prahalad said, companies will have to figure out how to experience their products as consumers experience them. They will have to understand what the customer encounters at every step, from beginning the search for a product to buying it, using it and finally disposing of it.
The professor explains how this can be done in a Harvard Business Review article, "Co-opting Customer Competence," which was written with a University of Michigan colleague, Venkatram Ramaswamy.
In their view, the product is "no more than an artifact around which customers have experiences." If so, that puts the customer firmly in the driver's seat. The company makes the product, but it cannot dictate the customer's experience.
The Internet makes it possible to reach customers in new ways, however, and management can use this tool to offer an engaging experience. Ideally that experience should offer enough choices to allow a customer to shape his own path. The goal is to draw on customers' talents, shape their expectations and encourage communities to form around the product. A company can absorb the customers' knowledge of the product and their suggestions for making it better. The customers become product developers. These efforts can be mammoth. More than 650,000 Microsoft customers tested a trial version of Windows 2000, for example.
Professors Prahalad and Ramaswamy suggest a four-part blueprint. Encourage an active dialogue (as Amazon has done with its book recommendations and reviews). Mobilize customer communities (much as customers of Cisco Systems commonly solve one another's problems). Manage customer diversity (for example, by gearing a product to various skill levels). As much as possible, personalize the customer's experience (like learning software that adapts itself to a child's ability).
With the right sites, companies can do a lot to hold onto customers. Scholars who track consumers' buying from site to site have generally found that they do not dart about seeking the lowest price. People seem to learn a site and settle in. Indeed, that tendency points up an apparent paradox: Though consumers hold the best cards, smart management, with superior offerings, can draw them into playing those cards its way.
"There are people who believe that consumers have all the power in the new economy," said Eric J. Johnson, a professor of marketing at the Columbia Business School, "that because competition is only a click away, they'll patrol for prices, or even better, have search robots patrol." That does not seem to be happening. In fact, he found that most customers who bought a book in a given month went to only one site.
"The rules change," Professor Johnson said of the Internet economy. "The results are pretty much the same."
Like it or not, consumers already collaborate with Internet companies every time they fill out an Internet form. "A basic premise of Web business is getting the customer to do the work in the form of data entry," said Thomas R. Eisenmann, who teaches e-commerce at the Harvard Business School. An airline customer can write himself an e-ticket on the Web and then check in with a machine at the airport, assuring the device that he packed his own bag.
For Web companies, the customer is already the center of the universe. At innumerable sites, the customers provide the product. At iVillage, Professor Eisenmann said, "They learned pretty quickly that the reason their audience was coming was to read and react to what other folks had to say." At other sites, the product is consumers stating their preferences in goods and services.
Professor Eisenmann agrees that the Web can powerfully amplify consumer experiences. The customers' reviews that affect business are "turbocharged" on the Web, he said. "People are in touch with one another through their computers, on e-mail and so forth, so if they had a good experience or a bad experience or an exciting experience, word is going to travel much faster. You tell more people and you tell them more quickly. It's the same phenomenon, word of mouth, but it's charged up."

LENGTH: 1631 words

HEADLINE: Sudden Explosion of Game Shows Threatens the Old TV Staples;
Costly Sitcoms and Dramas Scramble for Space and Survival

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Quite suddenly, the television landscape has turned positively Darwinian for comedies and dramas.
With the No. 1 show in the nation, "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire," on the ABC network three nights a week, with CBS planning a five-night-a-week reality show this summer and NBC and Fox rapidly programming game shows, the far more expensive sitcoms and dramas that have served as the staple of network television are struggling to find shelf space and, in some cases, to survive. 
 "It's a disaster: it's going to diminish the level of employment in Hollywood," said Peter Benedek, a partner at the United Talent Agency, which represents numerous television writers and directors. "There are new shows that won't get picked up and writers and directors who won't get hired on all four networks. It's simple arithmetic. The game shows and reality shows will occupy real estate previously rented to fictional entertainment programs."
Top television executives and even some highly successful producers are more optimistic, insisting that the new nonfiction shows are not only extremely lucrative for the networks but are also drawing huge audiences and lifting the ratings (notably on ABC) for comedies and dramas. For instance, "Malcolm in the Middle" on Fox is drawing a large audience.
But executives acknowledge that the face of television is changing and that it is getting harder to keep some sitcoms on the air because of the intense competition.
At ABC, at least three shows were recently canceled: "Oh Grow Up," about roommates in Brooklyn; David E. Kelley's "Snoops," about high-tech private eyes; and "It's Like, You Know," about New Yorkers living in Los Angeles. ABC executives acknowledged that while those shows had slumped in the ratings, their departures were accelerated because of limited time slots at the network.
"It's probably a fair argument to say we didn't have a level of patience with some of these shows that we might have had in years past," said Lloyd Braun, co-chairman of the ABC Entertainment Group. "We had to make some difficult decisions perhaps earlier than we would have in the past."
Mr. Braun is hardly alone among top network executives who acknowledge that television -- perhaps temporarily, perhaps fundamentally -- may be facing significant shifts because of the numerous quiz shows now on the air and shows planned in the next few months involving real people in bizarre and gimmicky situations. At the same time, the continuing popularity of news magazine programs like "Dateline NBC" and "20-20" on ABC have also limited the hours for sitcoms and dramas.
"There's no question," said Sandy Grushow, chairman of the Fox Television Entertainment Group. "There seems to be less of an appetite for the more traditional genres, hour-scripted dramas and half-hour comedies. It's simple mathematics. It's going to put people out of work."
"There'll always be a need for scripted comedy and scripted drama," he added. "Nobody's turning their back on these genres. The bar is just higher."
Cost is a central issue in television's new dynamic.
Not only is "Millionaire" enormously popular -- it has an average audience of 28.5 million viewers and has single-handedly revived ABC -- but it is also relatively inexpensive. A typical episode of "Millionaire" costs an estimated $750,000 (unless, of course, a contestant wins $1 million). By contrast, an hourlong drama like "The Practice" or "N.Y.P.D. Blue," both on ABC, costs at least $1.2 million per episode.
At NBC, a quiz show like "Twenty-One" costs an estimated $600,000 for each episode. By contrast, successful hourlong dramas like "Providence" cost $1.5 million. And franchises like "Frasier" and "Friends" cost over $3 million an episode.
Of course, the economic downside of the game shows and reality programs is that unlike dramas and sitcoms, they cannot be repeated or sold for syndication.
At CBS a new five-night-a-week hour half-hour reality show, "Big Brother," is to begin this July. The voyeuristic show, based on a hugely successful Dutch import, centers on a group of people thrown together into a house and monitored continuously by cameras. The show costs about $200,000 an episode. By contrast, a half-hour sitcom like NBC's "Will and Grace" or CBS's "King of Queens" costs at least $600,000 an episode. In addition to "Big Brother," CBS has scheduled another summer reality show, "Survivor," which is about 16 people stranded on a jungle island near Borneo.
Les Moonves, president of CBS Television, said both reality shows, if successful, could glide into the fall schedule and reduce the number of comedies and dramas. "If 'Survivor' or 'Big Brother' becomes very successful, we will look to get them into our regular schedule if it's the best economic thing for us to do," Mr. Moonves said. "That could, potentially, take away from traditional shows."
Writers are worried that the flood of game and reality shows are usurping them. Tim O'Donnell, a board member of the Writers Guild and a sitcom writer ("Clueless," "Growing Pains") said that writers who once worried about the numerous news shows were now depressed about the reality shows.
"I used to say that the five scariest words for television writers was, 'And now, here's Stone Phillips,' " he said. "Now it's been replaced by, 'Is that your final answer?' There's no question that game shows are eating up a lot of valuable real estate that used to be occupied by half-hour comedies."
Judd Apatow, a top comedy writer who is executive producer of NBC's "Freaks and Geeks," said a new show of his, "Happy Together," about an oddball, was rejected by NBC, which did not even order a pilot episode. "You would have thought that coming off a critically acclaimed show like 'Freaks and Geeks' that this would have been a no-brainer," he said. "We'd at least get to shoot a pilot. With the quiz shows it just makes you wonder how much time will be available for writers now. Just look at ABC: they're not going to need much next year because of 'Millionaire.' "
Like Mr. Apatow, Ian Biederman, a writer and producer on Fox's "Party of Five," said he was uneasy about the impact of the reality shows. "There's no question that in the short term, job opportG1ies will be diminished," he said. "There's a kind of tongue-in-cheek fatalism about these new shows. In the long run I'm optimistic that the one-hour drama and good sophisticated storytelling won't ever go away."
Bob Broder, one of television's most respected agents, said bluntly: "There will be a downturn in the number of writers employed for the 2000 and 2001 seasons. There will be fewer filmed entertainment series. It is a trend that will also pass."
The actress Mary Tyler Moore, who was also once a formidable producer, told the talk show host Rosie O'Donnell last week: "It scares me, you know, what is going to happen to television production, wherein you have a property that is creative and involves actors. It's going to be all game shows from now on, if we don't watch ourselves very carefully.'
Of course, traditional comedies and dramas are not limited to network television anymore. HBO, TNT, Showtime, Lifetime and other cable networks have already stepped into the breach and are sometimes offering riskier dramas than the networks as well as successful series like "The Sopranos" and "Sex and the City." Accordingly, cable networks may benefit from the networks' hunger for the game and reality shows.
Although some writers and agents are plainly nervous about the network obsession with game shows and reality shows, several top producers and writers suggest that the success of shows like "Millionaire" can be viewed as positive for comedies and dramas. The impact of the quiz show has rippled across the network, boosting the ratings of shows that follow it like "Dharma and Greg" and "Sports Night."
"It's fair and appropriate for networks to look for ideas that not only generate huge ratings but also are cost-effective," said Tom Werner, one of television's most successful producers ("The Cosby Show," "Roseanne") with his partners, Marcy Carsey and Caryn Mandebach.
"I'm aware that there's less shelf space for script ideas, whether half-hour or hour. But that's the reality. We have to work within that reality. It's a wake-up call for people like us. It forces us to ask how can we bring the audience in equal numbers to entertainment programming."
Dick Wolf, producer of series like "Law and Order," said that cycles come and go in television and that sitcoms and dramas remain staples, no matter how limited. "Everything is cyclical," he said. "Sixteen years ago comedy was dead, and along came Cosby. Game shows were dead, and now they're No. 1. But the reality is that episodic series television has been a mainstay for 50 years, and will remain so."
"Quality will out," he said. "It's been that way for 50 years."
But other writers, executives and talent agents said they were not so sure about the ultimate impact of the new look in network television. They noted, for example, that network television was distinguished by its traditional hourlong dramas and sitcoms and that each network had its own personality. That distinctiveness could disappear with the advent of game shows and reality programs that were previously more common on syndicated television.
"Will people think about the networks now in a different way?" asked Jon Feltheimer, former president of the Columbia Tristar Television Group. "If you start giving up network time slots to reality shows and game stuff that you see on cable, that you see in syndication, you're starting to erode the very things that have distinguished network television: dramas and comedies. One channel looks like any other."

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 135 words

HEADLINE: Harmful Cuba Embargo

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You are correct in pointing out that the Cuban trade embargo denies American companies access to a potentially lucrative market (editorial, Feb. 2). But more important, it denies access to medicines and medical supplies to the people who need it most, the Cubans. Our work with partner organizations in Cuba confirms that the embargo has worsened the health problems of pregnant women, including inadequate nutrition and low birth weight in their children. 
 Lifting the restrictions on the sale of food and medicine should be the first step toward ending the trade embargo. There is no justification for "incremental changes" where humanitarian needs are concerned.
 
VALORA WASHINGTON
Executive Director, Unitarian
Universalist Service Committee
Cambridge, Mass., Feb. 7, 2000 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 98 words

HEADLINE: Mending Russian Fences

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Repairing Relations With Russia" (Op-Ed, Feb. 5), James A. Baker III says: "Russians today believe we exploited the collapse of the Soviet Union to weaken Russia. To a surprising degree, they blame us for their economic troubles." 
 If it is deemed important to mend fences with Russia, we might consider dedicating a modest memorial to the Russian people, say, near Arlington National Cemetery, in recognition of their bearing the brunt of defeating Hitler's armies and turning the tide in World War II.
 
MARVIN GREGORY
Renton, Wash., Feb. 5, 2000 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter
